HEADLINE: COMPANY BRIEFS

 BODY:
* ASK Computer Systems Inc., Mountain View, Calif., extended until next Friday its offer for common shares of Ingres Corp. ASK said it had received more than 4.3 million, or about 38 percent, of Ingres's shares so far.
* Automatic Data Processing Inc., Roseland, N.J., said its board had authorized the buyback of an additional five million common shares after almost completing the buyback of five million shares since January. The company has more than 69.6 million shares outstanding. 
* CCAir Inc., Charlotte, N.C., which is under contract with USAir Group Inc., said it would cut 25 percent of its 670 employees and reduce the number of aircraft it leases effective Nov. 1.
* Comdial Corp., Charlottesville, Va., a maker of telephone sets and telephone systems, and Eagle Telephonics Inc., Hauppauge, L.I., a maker of telephone systems, said Eagle would be merged into a subsidiary of Comdial in a stock swap.
* Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, a designer of computer systems, said it would sell its VTC Bipolar Semiconductor operation to a VTC management team. Terms were not disclosed.
* FMR Corp., Boston, a mutual funds holding company, said it had cut its stake in Tambrands Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a consumer products company, to 9.91 percent, or 2.1 million of its outstanding common shares.
* Genentech Inc., San Francisco, a pharmaceuticals and research company, said it would build a new $75 million research center.
* Georgia-Pacific Corp., Atlanta, a paper products company, said it had sold its G-P Inveresk Corp. unit to a management group for about $61 million and would record a $40 million pretax loss on the sale in the first quarter.
* Great Lakes Chemical Corp., West Lafayette, Ind., a producer of bromine and brominated chemicals, said it would acquire all of the stock of Bio-Lab Inc., a supplier of products for swimming pools and spas, from Lonza Inc. Terms were not disclosed.
* Lockheed Corp., Calabasas, Calif. has received a $339.5 million Defense Department contract for work on the Trident missile program, the Navy said.
* Newbridge Communications Inc., an operator of book clubs, said it had completed the acquisition of Reader's Garden Inc., an operator of book clubs. Terms were not disclosed.

HEADLINE: Your Money Some Tax Breaks On Falling Stocks

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
For many investors, it may be time to trim the sails. Since stocks and bonds have taken a pounding in recent weeks, many portfolios have losers. While the sentiment may be to hold on, what can be salvaged represents a tax loss.
Of course, as astute investors know, trading should be based on economics, not on taxes. So is a tax loss really a reason to sell? Or doesn't it make sense to hold on to a security that still has sound fundamentals? 
Certainly cases can be made to hold or even buy particular issues. But professionals contend that from a market perspective, as well as a tax perspective, substantial selling makes sense with the Dow Jones industrial average down about 600 points since flirting with 3,000 in July.
''It's silly to pay taxes when you're holding losses,'' said Martin Jaffe, senior vice president and chief operating officer of Wood, Struthers & Winthrop, the investment management unit of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''We see great volatility over the near term and there will be opportunities to buy great companies at low prices.''
''We're in the early stage of a recession; make no doubt about it,'' said Kurt Brouwer, president of Brouwer & Janachowski Inc., a San Francisco investment advisory firm. ''Typically, the market gets beaten pretty badly in the early stages.''
Under the tax laws, there is no limit to the amount of capital losses that can offset capital gains, but only $3,000 of net capital losses can be taken against ordinary income; any excess must be carried forward to future years.
Thus, a taxpayer earning $75,000 a year whose portfolio had $20,000 in losses and $30,000 in gains could see his income reduced to $72,000 for tax purposes by selling the losers and taking gains of $17,000. If he sat on the losses, in the hope those issues would bounce back, but took $15,000 in gains, his adjusted gross income would rise to $90,000.
Tim Kochis, who is in charge of executive financial consulting for Deloitte & Touche, noted that some taxpayers are reluctant to sell winners now because they hope President Bush will prevail in his call for more favorable tax treatment on capital gains, and if they are lucky enough to have only winners, that may be an incentive to wait.
''If there are losses larger than $3,000, take the bird in hand,'' he said. That is, sell the losers and use the opportunity to take whatever offsetting gains can be taken tax-free this year.
''Given the current uncertainty about what Congress will finally do, there may not be more favorable treatment,'' Mr. Kochis added. He predicts that there is no chance of a lower capital gains rate passing this year and less than a 50 percent chance in 1991. He even sees the possibility of ''some deterioration in the treatment of capital losses, which would argue for taking them this year.''
Mr. Jaffe pointed out for those who really like a security, despite a loss posiiton, ''a lot of stocks are fungible.'' A stockholder could sell one bank stock with a loss and buy shares of a similar bank, or sell Ford and buy G.M.
''Scour fixed-income portfolios,'' he added. ''A lot are down. Do what is known as a bond swap.''
The two issues must be different to meet wash-sale rule. If a substantially identical issue is purchased within 30 days, a taxpayer cannot take a capital loss on the sale. This rule does not apply to capital gains, making it possible to sell winners and buy them back at any time to get a higher cost basis, thus limiting future capital gains taxes.
Mr. Jaffe had two caveats, however. One is to avoid excessive trading because transaction costs ''will eat up profits.'' The other is, ''We would not be stock buyers right now.''
''People who are living on their portfolios should look hard,'' he added, because many dividends look vulnerable. He cited bank stocks in particular.
''It's crazy for them to pay 8 or 9 percent,'' he said, given their loan problems. His firm's asset allocation at present is 45 percent in equities and 55 percent in Treasury issues. ''There is no reason to buy corporates,'' he said. ''The difference in yield is not enough to take the risk.''
Mr. Brouwer said, ''We think there is a possibility of another 10 to 15 percent slide in this market.'' People should not wait until the last moment to take tax losses, he added, or their losses are likely to be bigger than they are now.
By the first or second quarter of next year he expects to see opportunities for long-term profits by buying both stocks and bonds that are likely to be ''ridiculously oversold.''
''For someone who is not invested in stocks, we think it's worth dipping your toes in,'' he said, stressing the word dipping, while keeping a strong cash position. ''You can buy at a 20 percent discount'' from the end of last year, he noted, suggesting the Pennsylvania Mutual Funds, T. Rowe Price International and International Discovery funds.

HEADLINE: Kodak Told It Must Pay $909 Million

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
In the largest award ever in a patent-infringement case, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Eastman Kodak Company must pay the Polaroid Corporation $909.4 million for infringing Polaroid's patents for instant photography.
Despite the size of the judgment, the decision represents something of a victory for Kodak, since it is well below the $12 billion sought by Polaroid and the $1.5 to $2 billion that some financial analysts had expected.
''This is very positive for Kodak,'' said Eugene Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. ''It isolates the major element of risk. It is a manageable number and allows management to plan for the future without wondering if they will have to deal with a multibillion-dollar award.'' 
 
Instant Photo Patents
Kodak was found guilty of infringing seven of Polaroid's instant photography patents after a trial in 1985. The decision forced Kodak out of instant photography the following year, but left open the question of how much economic damage Polaroid had suffered.
Polaroid indicated that it might appeal the award.
The award, by Judge A. David Mazzone of Federal District Court in Boston, easily exceeded the $205 million that Smith International was ordered to pay Baker Hughes Inc. in 1986 in an oilfield equipment case. The two companies actually settled for $95 million. The largest actual payment in such a case was the $125 million paid by three baking companies to Procter & Gamble in 1989 for infringing soft-cookie formulas.
Polaroid contended that it lost profits of $4 billion as a result of Kodak's entry into the instant photography business in 1976. Kodak willfully stole its technology, Polaroid argued, and asked that the damages be trebled to $12 billion.
 
Copying Was Denied
Kodak, which denied deliberately copying Polaroid's technology. contended that interest in instant photography flagged after its cameras were introduced and that Polaroid's losses were no more than $150 million. Kodak said that with interest, the award should have been less than $200 million.
''This will be a disappointment to Polaroid,'' said David Nelson, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ''The decision means that the judge accepted the most significant part of Kodak's case.''
In his decision, Judge Mazzone ruled that actual damages to Polaroid totaled $454.2 million. The final figure includes interest payments of $455.3 million, to compensate Polaroid for the delay from the time when the losses were suffered and the original judgment was made.
In a statement, Kodak's chairman, Kay R. Whitmore, said the award ''will have no material financial impact on the company and will be paid from earnings.'' He said the award was ''substantially more that the amount to which Polaroid is entitled,'' but added that the decision ''established that our infringement was not intentional and not due to any willful act on the part of Kodak.''
In a statement, I. MacAllister Booth, the president and chief executive of Polaroid, said, ''Considering the significance of the injury to the company and its shareholders, we will review the decision and all relevant factors to determine what steps the company will take.'' Awaiting 'Final Resolution'
Mr. Booth said the company was also considering how to carve up the final amount it is paid. He said the company ''will not announce how we plan to apply the proceeds, when received, until there is final resolution of this litigation.''
Judge Mazzone's decision came after the close of the stock market yesterday, and some analysts predicted that Polaroid's shares would fall when trading resumes on Monday and that Kodak's are likely to rise. ''This will take $4 or $5 out of Polaroid, but it will probably add $2 to $2.50 to Kodak,'' said B. Alex Henderson, an analyst with Prudential-Bache.
Both companies are widely held. Kodak, which has annual sales of $18 billion, has about 172,000 stockholders and Polaroid, which is much smaller with sales of about $1.9 billion, has about 21,000. Polaroid has said it will give at least one-fourth of any award between $750 million and $1.2 billion directly to shareholders.
Polaroid's approximately 11,000 employees also stand to gain. Under their profit-sharing plan they would receive about 10 percent of the award for profits lost because of the Kodak infringement. The award brings closer to an end a battle that began in April 1976, when Kodak introduced a line of instant cameras. Polaroid filed suit six days later, charging that Kodak infringed 10 patents, most involving technology in Polaroid's SX-70 system, which had been introduced in 1972.
 
Market Peaked in 1978
At the time, instant photography was a rapidly expanding market and the technology promised lucrative financial rewards. But the market peaked in 1978 as the growth of one-hour film processing shops and advances in 35-millimeter cameras dimmed the allure of rapidly developing photographs.
Polaroid pressed the litigation nonetheless, and in 1985 Judge Rya Zobel ruled that Kodak had infringed seven of the patents cited by Polaroid.
In addition to the award to Polaroid, Kodak faced a class-action lawsuit by people who had bought its instant cameras before 1986, when Judge Zobel ordered it to stop production of cameras and instant film. Kodak settled the suit in 1988 by establishing a $150 million fund to compensate owners of the orphaned cameras, including cash payments of $50 to $70, depending on the cost of the model purchased.

HEADLINE: Outlook Rather Glum Among Executives

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 12

 BODY:
The top executives of several dozen of America's largest corporations, gathered here for the twice-yearly meeting of the Business Council, are nervous to gloomy about the economy and appalled by the discord in Washington over how to cut the Federal budget deficit.
A few executives, casting aside quibbling about whether statistics proved a recession had started, said they had little doubt that the economy was already declining.
''I don't know the definition - if it's two quarters or whatever you want to have it - but it feels like one,'' said John F. Welch Jr., chairman and chief executive of the General Electric Company. He said his company's sales of long-lasting consumer goods like washers and dryers, were particularly being hurt. 
Some others here went so far as to predict that a recession would be longer and deeper than most economists have said.
The Business Council is made up of 100 chief executives of the top American industrial and commercial companies. In a report issued here, senior economists from 19 corporations predicted slow economic growth through the middle of next year and a significant chance of a recession.
But at a news conference late Thursday afternoon and in interviews today, executives agreed that some industries have not been hit by the slowdown and may not be soon. Mr. Welch and Edmund T. Pratt Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Pfizer Inc., said sales of medical equipment and other health-care products and services were strong. A positive view also came from George M. C. Fisher, the president and chief executive of Motorola Inc., which produces communications equipment and semiconductors. ''From my vantage point, in our business, I don't see that we're in a recession,'' he said.
Many executives expressed dismay at the inability of Congress and President Bush to enact a Federal budget for the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1. ''It's hard to talk about this without getting mad,'' said David Kearns, chairman of the Xerox Corporation. ''It is a fiasco.''
Kenneth H. Olsen, the president and chief executive of the Digital Equipment Corporation, said that after a decade of wrangling over the deficit, he was pessimistic about the chances for a solution. ''It's going to get worse,'' he said.
 
Budget and Middle East
The consensus seemed to be that a significant decrease in the budget deficit and a resolution of tensions in the Middle East were needed to aid the economy. William W. Boeschenstein, the chairman and chief executive until two weeks ago of Owens-Corning Fiberglas Inc. in Toledo, Ohio, said a budget agreement was needed to allow the Federal Reserve to drive down interest rates, making it easier for companies to borrow.
Several executives, including James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman and chief executive of the American Express Company, called for such a looser monetary policy, but without linking it explicitly to a budget agreement. ''The Fed, we believe, will in fact be able to and should bring down the cost of money,'' he said. ''Inflation is not the No. 1 problem out there.''
The corporate economists' report forecast that economic growth would average less than 1 percent from the middle of 1990 through the middle of 1991 before accelerating to 2.5 percent in the second half of the year.
The United States Chamber of Commerce and Merrill Lynch have said a recession has already begun, but the council's economists said in their report that inventories remained low and that strong growth in exports should support the economy.
The corporate economists prepared their forecast last month, and mentioned in their report that an informal poll taken at a meeting on Oct. 2 found that the majority had subsequently lowered its growth expectations further. Business Council members like Lewis T. Preston, the former chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company, contended that a recession had already begun, adding, ''I'm afraid that it's going to be a little longer and a little deeper'' than the council's economists anticipate.
Several executives were concerned that a loss of confidence by the public might make matters worse. ''Please don't say I have a long face; I didn't have a long face,'' said John S. Reed, the chairman and chief executive of Citicorp. Although pessimistic, he did smile occasionally, and expressed optimism that the economy would improve if the budget stalemate and the Persian Gulf crisis were resolved.
Willard C. Butcher, the chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said the bank's credit card division was already ''seeing a modest increase across the country in delinquencies.''
Chief executives and their economists agreed that oil prices probably would not remain at $40 a barrel. Extra production from Saudi Arabia and other countries, combined with the reduced demand that accompanies higher prices, has made up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti production, said Allen E. Murray, the chairman, president and chief executive of the Mobil Corporation.
''We have absolutely ridiculous crude prices at this stage,'' as a result of heavy buying on war fears, he said. ''I believe crude prices will come down and come down hard.''

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up Sharp 1.6%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
A record surge in gasoline prices helped push the nation's Producer Price Index up by a sharp 1.6 percent in September, the Labor Department said today.
Coming on top of a 1.3 percent jump in August, producer prices had their biggest two-month rise since 1980.
Gasoline prices jumped 20.6 percent, the biggest rise in a statistical series dating back to 1947.
The overall increase in prices last month, although only slightly higher than expected, combined with a Commerce Department report on September retail sales to compound an already serious policy problem at the Federal Reserve. The central bank seeks an opportunity to cut interest rates in an effort to help ward off or soften a recession but it fears to do so at a time of sharply rising inflation. 
 
Scant Increase for Sales
Retail sales climbed 1.1 percent, but if automobiles and gasoline are excluded, the gain is a scant two-tenths of 1 percent. This means that the sales volume of non-automotive goods actually fell when price rises are factored out. [Page 37.] Car sales held up fairly well in August and September but many specialists said this mostly reflected financial incentives and other end-of-model-year promotional activity.
The fact that the bulk of the acceleration in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods came from a jump in oil prices that could be short-lived if the situation in the Persian Gulf calms is only partly reassuring, analysts said. Also only superficially encouraging is the fact that, excluding energy, the index rose only two-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Higher Prices Take Hold
Analysts took little comfort from these situations because higher oil prices are already becoming embedded in the economy.
Next Thursday's report on the Consumer Price Index, for example, will be used to set cost-of-living adjustments for tens of millions of people receiving Social Security and other Federal benefits. With the effects of a second month of extra-high oil prices included, the adjustment is expected now to be somewhat more than 5 percent, up from 4.7 percent, for 1990.
The higher oil prices, which have nearly doubled since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, have also become a factor that is substantially eroding the purchasing power of American consumers, leaving them with less money for other things.
''Consumers aren't going to be spending very much during the next three to five months,'' said Edward Guay, an economist for the Cigna Corporation, the Connecticut-based insurer. He added that while the economy probably eked out a gain in the third quarter, a downturn of some kind was now in the works. The Commerce Department will not report its first estimate of this summer's gross national product until Oct. 30.
The Federal Reserve is currently understood to be divided between those who want to give the economy a hefty stimulus when a suitable deficit-reduction budget deal is assured and more cautious members agonizing not only about the high inflation but also about both a weak dollar that could make future inflation worse and high overseas interest rates.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, responded to today's price data by saying that ''inflation going up is never good news'' and he made only the mildest plea for easier money. ''We still are concerned about growth and about preventing a recession,'' he said. ''We think the Fed has recognized all these factors and is on the right course.'' 11.7 Percent Annual Rate September's 1.6 percent jump in the index for finished goods, which covers prices received by domestic producers for goods moving to the ultimate user, raised the third-quarter annual rate to 11.7 percent.
Overall energy prices, which rose 9.5 percent in August, jumped another 13.8 percent in September, the biggest one-month increase since the Government began such a tabulation in 1974. Fuel oil soared 21.3 percent.
But food prices restrained the price index's rise. Consumer foods fell nine-tenths of 1 percent, slightly more than their August increase, as prices fell for beef and veal, eggs, fresh vegetables, shortening and pasta, and declines accelerated for dairy products and pork.
New-car prices rose 3.4 percent, but seasonal adjustment factors accounted for most of this. The actual increase was only two-tenths of 1 percent.
With food and energy excluded, prices for finished goods rose six-tenths of 1 percent, double the August increase and causing some analysts to fret about a possible sustained increase in this so-called core rate.
But Michael L. Penzer, a senior economist at the Bank of America, predicted that, long term, the core inflation rate would continue to decline. For the latest 12 months, prices have still risen only 3.7 percent, compared with 4.3 percent a year ago, because of a soft manufacturing sector. Over all, ''the economy is getting steadily weaker,'' Mr. Penzer said.
Surging oil prices also dominated the indexes for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production, which climbed by 1.8 percent and 4.6 percent, respectively. Excluding energy, intermediate materials rose four-tenths of 1 percent and crude goods fell 1.3 percent.
Among the widely watched components of the intermediate goods index, prices rose faster than in August for such nondurable manufacturing items as paint materials, paper, nitrogenates and resins, many of which are oil products.

HEADLINE: Taxi Commission Investigates Medallion Pricing and Loans

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission and three other city agencies are investigating complaints that taxi-medallion brokers and lenders are selling the medallions at prices far above the prevailing market rate to unsuspecting buyers.
The commission also said that some lenders and brokers were buying interests in medallions and then selling those interests to others without paying the transfer tax, which is 5 percent of the sales price, and without notifying the commission or the Department of Finance, as they are required by law. The commission said documents filed with the city were often falsified to avoid the tax. 
The commission also is concerned about ''conditional sales'' of medallions, many of them to immigrants who have no credit or financial sophistication or who cannot afford a down payment for a traditional bank loan.
In these sales, the buyers take out installment-type loans with the sellers but without building up equity in the loan. If they miss a payment they can lose everything they paid. If the loan can be refinanced, it may be offered at higher interest rates.
The sellers argue that these arrangements are legal and help people who would otherwise not be able to get started in the taxi industry. But the commission is trying to make buyers aware that they may be paying much more than they should.
 
Medallions Sold at Auctions
In one case cited by the commission, a buyer paid $138,000 for a medallion in August, while the market price was about $125,000.
Under procedures established by law, when a medallion is lost because of a loan default, the lender can try to sell the repossessed medallion at a public auction to recoup the unpaid amount of the loan. Brokers acting as middlemen between buyers and sellers bid on behalf of a client.
The investigation found that some people who agreed to buy medallions through private financing with brokers lost tens of thousands of dollars and their right to the medallion because they defaulted on the loans.
Lenord Desir, 52, of Richmond Hill, Queens, said that he lost more than $100,000 over eight years when he took part in such an agreement to buy a medallion. Mr. Desir said he was unable to make payments on the medallion loan because of a heart condition that prevented him from driving a taxi. ''It's not fair after all the money I paid into the medallion to be left with absolutely nothing,'' he said.
Jack S. Lusk, the commission's chairman, said that while the agency had documented only a handful of such cases, he believed the overpricing of medallions and sales-tax evasion are widespread, and he has proposed new regulations to curb them.
The proposed rules would essentially require medallion transactions, financing agreements, and private auctions to be supervised by the commission. Medallion buyers would also be required to take a commission-sponsored seminar on proper buying procedures. The city Departments of Investigation, Finance and Consumer Affairs are also involved in the investigation.

HEADLINE: Budget Fight: Stakes High; Numbers Clash

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
On the very same day last week that Mayor David N. Dinkins announced that he was considering 15,000 layoffs to close $1.7 billion in budget gaps over two years, Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman painted a much grimmer picture of the city's fiscal health.
The potential budget deficits, she said, could be twice as large - $3.3 billion - and the city's troubles were far worse.
These dire but conflicting pronouncements from the city's top two fiscal officers helped create a sense that the city was spinning toward its worst fiscal crunch in a decade - a sense that spilled from City Hall to the financial markets.
The differences represent more than a political or bureaucratic skirmish. Numbers like these will be used to determine how many city workers will be laid off, how deeply services will be cut and how high taxes will rise in the months ahead. 
 
Vastly Different Assessments
Behind the clashing numbers are vastly different assessments by the Mayor and the Comptroller over how bad the New York City economy will get and how skilled the administration will be at holding down the cost of labor contracts soon to be settled.
While the administration has pledged to hold the line on labor settlements - so that they cost taxpayers no more than a 1.5 percent increase already included in the budget - the Comptroller's analysis assumes that settlements will cost taxpayers hundred of millions of dollars more over the two years.
And while the Dinkins administration is expecting some weakening in the economy, Ms. Holtzman is presenting one of the most gloomy economic forecasts seen so far, predicting a loss of nearly 100,000 private sector jobs next year. That, in turn, she said, would cause a decline of $730 million in income and sales tax collections over two years.
Philip R. Michael, the New York City Budget Director. said he did not think Ms. Holtzman's ''numbers link to the reality as we now know it.''
''They can speculate about a labor settlement; we can say this is not going to be the cost of the labor settlement,'' Mr. Michael said, ''We are looking at actual collections; they are making judgments.''
Asked about the differences, Ms. Holtzman said, ''We are all predicting the future, and no one has a monopoly on wisdom when you are predicting the future.''
 
Produced in a Hurry
Ms. Holtzman defended her estimates but acknowledged that the report was rushed out last week because of increasing concern over fiscal developments. It was released before her staff had a chance to analyze or include some taxes, on business and real-estate transactions, that the administration said would decline by $450 million over the two-year period.
''If we are right about the income tax and they are right about the business taxes, it could be even worse,'' she said.
After several days of dueling numbers, Mayor Dinkins and Ms. Holtzman met at the end of last week and agreed to have their staffs work together to sort out their differences. Yet some differences remain, officials said.
Behind the abrupt surfacing of fiscal worries are months of warnings of deficits by outside observers.
In June the city approved a $28 billion budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which began on July 1. At the same time, the administration produced a financial plan showing a $30 billion budget for the following year, including a $970 million gap to be closed mainly with productivity improvements and uncertain state aid.
 
'Structural Imbalance' Seen
At the time, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan warned that the 1991 budget could end up with a $500 million deficit, while the deficit the following year could reach $1.9 billion. The State Financial Control Board, which monitors city finances, also warned of a $1.9 billion deficit in 1992.
''The city has reached a critical point at which it must redress the structural imbalance between the programs it wants to provide and what it can afford,'' the board's report said.
While those lengthy detailed reports received little attention, Ms. Holtzman's 17-page study, issued during a week of fiscal uncertainty, captured the public's attention.
To get it out so quickly, her staff said, they took details on the labor settlement and cost figures for Mr. Dinkins's police hiring plan from the newspapers, making an occasional mistake along the way.
''It was not news,'' Alair Townsend, a former city budget director said of the Comptroller's report. ''But timing was everything, in a week when everybody's worst-case scenario with respect to a settlement for at least one labor union came true.''
 
Revenue Differences
A major difference between Mr. Dinkins and Ms. Holtzman came in estimates of tax revenues. While the Comptroller predicted sharp declines in income and sales taxes, the administration predicted that collections of those taxes would be unchanged, despite the worsening economy.
Mr. Michael said that the city's forecast assumed a stagnant economy with no growth in the labor force. Even if the number of jobs declined, he said, his experts predicted that this decline would likely be offset by higher wages.
But the Comptroller's staff predicted a far greater decline in the number of jobs. It noted that nearly 8,000 private-sector jobs were lost each month in June, July and August, and assumed that a similar job loss next year would cost the city nearly 100,000 jobs. One city budget official said that this represented all the jobs the city had gained since 1974.
''It is safe to say our economist is on the pessimistic side,'' one Comptroller aide said. But he noted that with the worsening national economic picture and ''no good news in any economic sector,'' it might turn out to be right.
Under Ms. Holtzman's forecast, the city will face up to a $738 million budget gap in the 1991 fiscal year, which began last July, and up to $2.6 billion the following year.
Her report predicts reductions in income and sales taxes, increases of more than $200 million each year in overtime costs and unanticipated labor costs of $83 million this year, and $534 million next.
But the administration tentatively concluded it had a gap of just about $290 million - $150 million in reduced revenue and $140 in increased expenses, Mr. Michael said.
Next year's gap was put at about $1.4 billion, including the previously announced gap of $970 million, $300 or so in reduced revenue and the rest in increased expenses. He said the administration predicted $35 million in unbudgeted overtime costs this year and no such overtime costs next year.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Soviet Economy Saved by Dentist! (Hey, He Tries)

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The worst of this city's slums and the stagnating Soviet Union have a lot in common. At least that is the view of an uncommon New Yorker dedicated to reviving both.
Dr. Jeffrey A. Sachs today leaves to confer with apparatchiks of the Soviet Union, the Russian republic and the city of Moscow on ways to finance Moscow's first AIDS hospital. His goal is to bring municipal bonds to a pay-as-you-go country, enabling it to spread costs over many years. 
Dr. Sachs epitomizes the improbable. He is a lucky, plucky intellectual gunslinger who has gone far in many directions by a logic only he comprehends.
Now 38 years old, he came to know the Russians by knocking on the Kremlin door to promote a heavy metal rock concert. He is a dentist who never filled a tooth. He served in the highest levels of New York State government. With Andrew M. Cuomo, he founded HELP, the much praised public-private housing initiative. He has become a high-priced business consultant. He coaches a Little League team in Brooklyn's tattered East New York.
And he shares a common experience with many of the dozen or so people participating in his Soviet mission: They helped extricate New York from its last fiscal crisis. The problem is much the same: unless exceedingly clever solutions are found, bonds denominated in rubles are more repellent than New York bonds in 1975.
This is Dr. Sachs' ninth trip to Moscow in a little more than a year, all at his own expense - $75,000 so far. He insists he isn't doing it for money, but admits it might build contacts. His proclaimed goal is to help others, particularly America's needy.
He reasons that neither superpower has enough to spend on social programs because each spends too much on war. ''If we can stabilize them and make them successful, there's going to be more money for things here,'' Dr. Sachs said.
So his group is meeting with Russians to devise ways to finance a grain storage center, several stock exchanges and perhaps a condominium complex. The tendentious meetings sometimes seem a flashback to the fiscal crisis.
''It's the same meeting over and over again - there's always someone loud and obnoxious'' he said. ''It's just a matter of scale.''
Dr. Sachs was personally involved in the earlier money mess as senior health adviser to Gov. Hugh L. Carey. At the age of 28, a dozen agencies with 75,000 employees reported through him.
Dentistry never stood a chance, compared to the attraction of policy and politics. Even at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, where he studied things toothy, his first love was student government and his best friend the university president. After several Washington jobs, he went on to serve as the Governor's personal representative at Love Canal, and to preside over the emptying of the state's nefarious homes for the retarded. His dream is to sit in a President's Cabinet.
The other day, Dr. Sachs relaxed on a bench in the sun-filled courtyard of HELP's homeless residence in East New York. Children chased each other madly, dashed about on tricycles and scurried over colorful playground equipment. Mothers scrambled to keep up.
Dr. Sachs' comments reflected deep personal involvement. He told about a family with whom he became friendly here before they graduated to their own apartment in Harlem. The ceiling promptly fell on the woman and she was beaten by her boyfriend. Then her son stole money from drug dealers.
''My older son is dead,'' she told Dr. Sachs when he visited. ''They're going to kill him.''
Dr. Sachs felt she was probably right, and for once was inarticulate. Words are his playthings. He talked about economists being as initially imposing but ultimately as ephemeral as the Wizard of Oz; of possibly repaying ruble bonds in dollars, of chaos theory, of personally briefing K.G.B. officials.
He said his experience with HELP is relevant to the Soviet Union. It works because homeless people see residents leaving transitional housing for permanent. The Soviets, by contrast, are turning their world upside down on blind faith.
He said that they may be as disappointed by the ballyhooed free market as many people in the South Bronx. Small projects, combining private and public financing, are his prescription. ''There's no such thing as big,'' he said.
Indeed, one of his pet projects is of decidedly human scale. Dr. Sachs, always a bachelor, thinks it might be nice to get married.
''You pay a price for this kind of stuff,'' he said. ''I spent so much time with the social problems of the world that I probably didn't spend enough with the social problems of Jeffrey.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Democratic Plan to Tax Wealthy Has Democratic Hurdle in Senate

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Despite broad support among Democratic lawmakers for a House deficit plan that would raise taxes for the wealthy, Democratic Senate leaders are committed to blocking it when it reaches the Senate.
Lawmakers say Senators George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, were forced to make such a commitment, against their personal and partisan preferences, because it was the only way to enlist the Republican votes that were needed to get a budget bill out of the Senate Finance Committee.
Early this morning the committee approved a bipartisan budget plan that would more than double the Federal gasoline tax, cut Medicare benefits deeply and not touch the tax rate paid by the wealthy. Two Democratic committee members, Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Max Baucus of Montana, refused to back the budget bill supported by Mr. Bentsen.
The latest developments set up a showdown next week in the yearlong struggle over the biggest deficit-reduction measure ever. The outcome could have enormous consequences for the economy and the Congressional elections on Nov. 6 and will affect the taxes or benefits of every American. 
On one side will be the House of Representatives, whose Democratic majority will be solidly behind the plan to make the wealthy bear most of the cost of deficit reduction. On the other will be President Bush, who favors the Senate Finance Committee plan. In the middle are Democratic senators, who are deeply divided over which way to turn.
 
Two Plans Differ Greatly
The positions taken by Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Bentsen will probably be one aspect of the showdown. Senate procedures make it almost impossible to pass legislation that the leaders oppose. That does not mean such a measure would not be approved by a Senate-House conference committee. But a bill like the one favored by rank-and-file Democrats that would tax the rich more heavily would almost certainly be vetoed by President Bush.
The Senate Finance Committee bill is in sharp contrast to a plan offered last week by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. His proposal has galvanized Democrats like no other legislation in years.
The Rostenkowski plan, expected to coast through the House next week by a wide margin, would raise the income tax rates for people earning more than $200,000 a year by an average of nearly $11,000, would leave the gasoline tax at 9 cents a gallon, and would raise Medicare premiums and deductibles only slightly.
House Democrats across the board - conservatives from the rural South and liberals from the inner cities, those from white-collar suburbs and those from factory towns - rallied around the proposal. And by the weekend, the plan was gaining strength among Senate Democrats, who were just learning the details.
''I can't understand how any Democrat can vote against it,'' said Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Budget Committee.
From the Democrats' perspective, it turns a difficult budget debate next week into an easily understood question: Should deficit reduction require much higher gasoline taxes and much lower Medicare benefits, or should it force the very wealthy to pay higher income taxes?
It is not hard to divine where voters stand. A New York Times/CBS News Poll this week found that 86 percent of adults were willing to raise the taxes of people making more than $100,000 to reduce the budget deficit. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points. A Times/CBS Poll in August found that a sizable majority of Americans believed that the rich had benefited most from Government policies of the last decade and that they had done so at the expense of everyone else.
 
G.O.P. on the Defensive
Republicans argue that a budget forcing the very wealthy to pay higher taxes would be disastrous for an economy on the cusp of a recession, inhibiting investment and restricting growth. But this week's developments put them on the defensive. When Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, was asked about the Rostenkowski plan on Friday, he said it was ''just another tax-and-spend effort to raise taxes by every way imaginable.''
When a reporter observed that Mr. Rostenkowski would not raise more taxes than the Bush Administration wants but merely raise them mainly from the rich rather than from all segments of society, Mr. Fitzwater simply repeated the mantra. ''It's the same Democratic approach we've seen for years and years of trying to increase spending and increase taxes to cover it,'' he said.
Representative Raymond J. McGrath, a Republican from Nassau County, is one of many Republican lawmakers who is uncomfortable about the votes next week. ''It is a genius of a political plan,'' Mr. McGrath said. ''I told my guys, 'You're going to have a hard time voting against it.' ''
For days this week, Mr. Bentsen tried to put together a tax and spending package favorable to most Democrats. #2 Key Democrats Oppose Plan But there are only 11 Democrats on the 20-member Finance Committee, and two of them, Senators Bradley and Baucus, made it clear that they would oppose a plan that would tax the rich more heavily than others.
Senator Bradley was a principal author of the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986, which lowered tax rates and abolished most deductions and other tax breaks, and he does not want to see the principles of that law changed. Senator Baucus, who is up for re-election next month, has said his career would be in jeopardy if he voted for any measure that raised taxes.
That meant that the entire budget package would have died in the committee unless some Republicans voted for it, and the Republicans made the commitments by Senator Mitchell and Senator Bentsen the price of their support.
Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, and Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, made a similar pledge to oppose any changes in the bill. But that was an easy promise for them to make, since they basically favor the package.
But for Senator Mitchell, who has been the most outspoken Democrat in the Senate about the need for higher taxes on the wealthy, it was an agonizing decision.
In an interview broadcast today on the Cable News Network program ''Newsmaker Saturday,'' Mr. Mitchell said: ''I favor an increase in rates. The top rate should be 33 percent or 35 percent. But the President is opposed, and we can't pass it without his signature.''
He was not asked about the deal he made to get Republican votes, and he was not available for a separate interview.
 
Choices Trouble Bentsen
Senator Bentsen was also said to be anguished. ''I've seen him look wistfully at the paper on the Rostenkowski plan several times in the last few days,'' a spokesman said today, ''but he didn't have the votes to get it out of committee.''
The measure approved by the Finance Committee today is the core of an overall budget that is supposed to reduce the deficit by $40 billion this year and $500 billion over five years. It would neither raise tax rates nor change the capital gains tax rate. These are among the main elements of the panel's budget bill:
* An increase in the gasoline tax from the current 9 cents a gallon to 18.5 cents by 1992.
* An increase of more than $20 a month by 1996 in the premium paid by the elderly, currently $28.60, for insurance covering doctors' bills under Medicare and a doubling of the annual deductible to $150.
* An increase to $89,000 from $53,000 in the amount of wages subject to the 1.45 percent payroll tax for Medicare.
* A 10 percent luxury tax on cars costing more than $30,000, boats costing more than $100,000, private planes costing more than $250,000 and furs and jewelry costing more than $5,000.
* Tax breaks totaling $3.5 billion over five years to encourage oil and gas production. They would not become effective unless the price of oil, now more than $40 a barrel, falls below $34.
* A limit on itemized deductions under which taxpayers would have their deductions reduced by 5 percent of the amount of their annual income over $100,000.
The House is most likely to pass the Rostenkowski plan on Tuesday or Wednesday. The Senate will then take up the bill approved by the Finance Committee and is expected to pass it after rejecting an amendment including the main parts of the Rostenkowski plan.
The two bills will then go to a conference committee, and representatives of the White House will surely take part. The conference will be much like the budget negotiations last month in which the sides were at loggerheads.
The issue for the Democrats will be how far they can push the President toward higher taxes on the rich. The issue for the President will be how to hold on to what he wants and still get a measure that can be adopted by the Senate and the House.

HEADLINE: A Little Lonelier Than in 70's, New York Faces Fiscal Crisis

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Fifteen years after its costly and humiliating brush with bankruptcy, New York City is edging into fiscal straits that seem painfully familiar.
For all the talk of budget gaps, spending cuts, tax increases and layoffs, the city's financial monitors and independent economists say its current fiscal problems are not so severe as those of the mid-1970's when the city, banished from the credit markets, could no longer sell notes and bonds.
But as Mayor David N. Dinkins struggles to stabilize the budget and at the same time combat rising crime and a host of other social ills, he seems likely to find himself more on his own than Mayor Abraham D. Beame was a decade and a half ago.
 
Past Benefactors' Problems
New York State and a reluctant Federal Government, the city's main benefactors then, cannot be counted on to help now, since both have their own fiscal problems. Potentially more worrisome, perhaps, New York City must also contend with weakening local and national economies that may prove a major hindrance to a recovery. 
Late last week, the Dinkins administration said it would cut $2.3 billion from the city's nearly $16 billion capital budget, but the savings in operating funds will average only about $100 million a year over the next 10 years. Mr. Dinkins has also imposed a partial hiring freeze and a moratorium on most raises and is considering laying off 15,000 municipal workers.
But given the size of the budget gaps, the tentative 5.5 percent raise that his administration recently negotiated with the teachers and his plan to hire thousands of additional police officers at a cost of nearly $2 billion over four years, the Mayor has been criticized for failing to put forth a comprehensive plan to resolve the budget problems.
The fiscal crisis of the 1970's was a result both of an economic slide with no precedent in New York City history and of the city's response, which was to borrow more and more money to cover its day-to-day expenses.
But in the summer of 1975, New York's credit was cut off, and it was threatened by a nearly $2 billion deficit and, far worse, a cumulative short-term debt of more than $5 billion, which the city is still paying off.
The crisis was resolved with help from Albany and Washington, the creation of agencies to monitor the city's finances and borrow money on its behalf and the paring of the municipal payroll.
 
'Long, Hard Pull'
Because the crisis occurred just before the start of the most powerful local economic boom since World War II, the city's recovery was also propelled by a largely unexpected surge of tax revenues when it most needed them.
This time, New York's fiscal distress comes early in a downturn that could persist for years. And even when the economy picks up, New York is not expected to return to the soaring growth rates of the 1980's anytime soon.
''It's going to be a long, hard pull,'' said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses.
For three of the last five years, municipal spending has outstripped revenues, causing New York City to dip into savings. Future budget deficits are now estimated at from $1 billion to $2 billion a year or even more.
Then again, today's budgets are almost three times the size of the budgets in the mid-70's. And this time, New York does not have to cope with repaying a huge short-term debt and still has access to the credit markets, though it has been put under a ''credit watch'' by Standard & Poor's Corporation, the bond-rating agency.
New York City now confronts a challenge that seems more managerial than the financial challenge of the 1970's: How can it maintain or even augment services for a population that in some ways has become increasingly dependent on them in an era of slowly growing revenues and uncertain aid?
''The last time, it was a credit problem and a liquidity problem,'' said Harrison J. Goldin, City Comptroller from 1974 to 1989. ''This time, it's a budgetary problem and a social problem.''
 
Series of Rules and Procedures
Even so, a legacy of the 1975 crisis was the adoption of rules and procedures intended to insure that it would not be repeated, and experts say they have worked.
Three state agencies - the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the Financial Control Board and the Office of the State Deputy Comptroller for the City of New York - keep watch over the city.
Fifteen years ago, the city did not know how many employees it had or how much money it owed or was owed.
Mr. Goldin recalled finding billions of dollars worth of negotiable bonds that were deposits from contractors shoved into shoeboxes in a closet at a city office.
New York City's accounting procedures are now so rigorous that its books are regarded as models for other localities. The city also must update its budget quarterly and issue financial plans that cover four years, making it harder for officials to hide from the fiscal implications of a souring economy.
''The thing about 1975 was the avoidance of the economic problems and the assumption that they would go away,'' said Dick Netzer, a professor of economics at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University. ''This is clearly not happening today.''
There were historic reasons for that complacency. As Professor Netzer notes in a new book, ''Urban Politics, New York Style,'' published by M. E. Sharpe Inc., the city's economy had matched or outperformed the nation's for more than a half-century.
But by 1969 New York had begun a long, cruel swoon that left it with about 600,000 fewer jobs by 1977.
During this time, though, the prevailing view of the experts was that the city would soon bounce back, as it always had. Rather than cut spending, the city increased it, and it paid its workers higher wages. As revenues sagged, it borrowed money and simply rolled over the notes when they came due. The debt snowballed.
 
Jobs and Inflation
A severe national recession and tighter credit brought a sudden end to this practice in 1975, leaving the city with a huge debt and no way to repay it or, for that matter, meet its payroll. To resolve the crisis, New York State created the Municipal Assistance Corporation, an agency to borrow money for the city. The Federal Government provided and guaranteed city loans. The state assumed costs for higher education and the courts; the city work force was slashed.
But two events outside the control of the city's fiscal saviors and savants also contributed: a surge in new jobs that began in 1977, and a spurt of double-digit inflation that, with labor costs under control, augmented the stream of unexpected revenue.
New York City's economy, badly shaken by the stock market's collapse three years ago and the subsequent contraction in Wall Street employment, is now moving in the opposite direction. In the first half of 1990 the city lost 8,000 jobs in private industry. Retail sales are down. The rise in oil prices and anticipated tax increases by all levels of government will cut spending power, and the weakening national economy will compound the local problems.
Still, economists do not believe that the 1990's will be so painful as the 70's. While the city has nearly 200,000 fewer jobs than it did in 1969, it has shifted to a service-based economy with more higher-paying positions.
 
Hope and a Warning
''New York has strength in the industries and sectors that are in the forefront of national and international economic growth,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
But in many ways the New York City of 1990 is worse off than it was in 1975.
In a report last week, Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said the city's economic downturn might be reversed by mid-1991, a prediction more optimistic than other economists'. Even so, Ms. Scanlon noted in an interview that the city's dismal mood could be self-destructive.
''If gloom becomes very pervasive, it will become reinforcing,'' she said. ''That is the part that reminds me more about 1975 than the numbers.''

HEADLINE: Economy and Mideast Standoff Bring a Drop in Bush's Standing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
Support for President Bush's commitment of American troops in the Persian Gulf has begun to erode in recent days as Americans grow frustrated with the standoff in the desert and increasingly worried about the sagging economy at home, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.
The poll of 960 adults, conducted by telephone last week, found economic fears at their highest in a decade and Mr. Bush's overall job rating the worst of his Presidency, although it remains at a level that some recent Presidents would have coveted.
There was a dramatic defection from Mr. Bush among the nation's older citizens, those 65 years old and over, whose general economic fears have been deepened by talk from Washington of increases in taxes and Medicare premiums.
Over all, 60 percent of those surveyed said they approved of the way Mr. Bush is handling his job, down from 76 percent in a New York Times/ CBS News Poll soon after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August. Thirty percent expressed overall disapproval, up from 15 percent in August and the highest level of disapproval toward Mr. Bush so far in his Presidency. 
 
A Strong Undercurrent
Support for his handling of the Kuwait situation declined to 57 percent from the 75 percent who expressed approval soon after the invasion.
From the beginning of the gulf confrontation, analysts of public opinion noted a strong undercurrent among Americans against commitment of military power. But until now, this did not seem to undermine the overwhelming support for Mr. Bush's specific actions as Americans rallied around the President.
But in the last three weeks there has been a significant shift. In late September, 75 percent of the public told a survey conducted for Americans Talk Security, a bipartisan research group, that the United States had done the right thing by sending troops to the gulf. In the latest Times/CBS News survey, 61 percent said the United States had done the right thing. Those who said the United States should have stayed out rose to 32 percent from 20 percent.
Figures in the latest Times/CBS News survey should generally be accurate, according to statistical theory, to within three percentage points, plus or minus, of what would have been found if all adults in the country had been sought out for a survey. The margin of sampling error of the Americans Talk Security survey was also plus or minus three percentage points.
Foreign policy and the performance of the economy are generally the two key measures by which Americans judge their Presidents. Seven out of 10 Americans think the economy is getting worse, the largest number to hold such a negative view since April 1980, seven months before President Jimmy Carter lost his bid for re-election.
In the latest poll, 52 percent expressed disapproval of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy and 58 percent disapproved of his handling of the budget deficit. Analysts in both parties suggested that rising economic fears are dragging down overall support for Mr. Bush, as well as support for his most important foriegn policy commitment.
''If people start disapproving on one thing they will tend to generalize that opinion to other things,'' said Fred Steeper, a partner in Market Strategies, a Republican polling concern.
 
Budget Was Dominating News
The Times/CBS News survey was conducted Monday through Wednesday during a period when the Persian Gulf, for the first time since the Iraqi invasion, was not dominanting the news and Mr. Bush's policy in the gulf was facing little direct criticism. What was dominating the news was the great confusion and conflicting statements from Mr. Bush about exactly where he stood on taxes and the proposals Congress was wrestling with to lower the deficit.
By a majority of 54 percent to 37 percent, Americans said Mr. Bush should have shown stronger leadership in trying to settle the budget crisis.
''Obviously, the budget situation, and the news surrounding it, has not inured to the President's benefit,'' said Charles Black, who is a senior political adviser to the White House as well as chief spokesman for the Republican National Committee. ''Nevertheless, that's still a pretty high job approval rating, not far from levels he's enjoyed in the last two years, except during the first few weeks of the Persian Gulf, when he got up to levels no one could sustain for long.''
The cost of the nation's committment in the gulf was cited by several respondents who said they had shifted from approval to disapproval. ''I didn't know it was going to cost a million dollars a day,'' Jesse White, an assembly line worker for B. F. Goodrich in Tuscaloosa, Ala., said in a follow-up interview after the poll.
Those who disapprove of Mr. Bush's handling of the invasion of Kuwait split evenly between those who said they believe the United States should take stronger military action at this time and those who did not.
''If they're going to do something, I think they should get it done,'' said Tillie Daniels, 61, a Democrat from Willow Springs, Mo. ''I don't think they should prolong it and let it go on and on and on.''
Americans are becoming more pessimistic and more cynical, or realistic, about the gulf confrontation. The percent who say they believe the crisis will be resolved without fighting has fallen to 47 percent from 53 percent since August and those who believe the United States is there mainly to protect oil supplies has increased to 55 percent from 44 percent since September.
 
Most Support Commitment
While many recent reports from the gulf have emphasized the deaths of American military personnel in air crashes, 6 out of 10 surveyed said the American troop commitment is worth the cost, roughly the same proportion as supported sending them. While support for sending troops has declined, the public position on a naval blockade, a safer form of military engagement in the minds of many people, remains unchanged from a September survey by CBS News, with 6 in 10 supporting it and 3 in 10 opposed.
With 23 days until Election Day, the survey captured a considerable mood for change among Americans. A plurality favor turning the Republicans out of the White House and the Democrats out of Congress.
Mr. Bush began his Presidency with approval of about 60 percent of the public, and with most of the rest waiting to make up their minds rather than expressing disapproval.
Over the course of the next year Mr. Bush won most of the undecideds to his side. But now he is losing many of them. Approval of the job he is doing declined among every major group, from men and Democrats to Republicans and those making more than $50,000 a year. But in no case were the declines as great as among those most economically vulnerable, including those making under $15,000 annualy and, most dramaticly of all, those Americans 65 and older.
Those 65 and over, an age group which votes more heavily than any other, are now evenly divided between the 41 percent who express approval of Mr. Bush's handling of his job and the 41 percent who express disapproval. That is a sharp shift from the 70 percent of older Americans who expressed approval and the 17 percent who expressed disapproval in August.
 
'More and More Disgusted'
This dramatic shift means that 1 out of every 4 americans 65 or over, the only group of Americans with personal memories of the Depression, shifted from approval to disapproval of Mr. Bush's handling of the Presidency.
''I'm getting more and more disgusted with him,'' said Lois Kemp, 65, a lifelong Republican from Thousand Palms, Calif., said in a follow-up interview to the survey. ''I didn't think Dukakis would do a thing and I'm still glad I voted for Bush. But I'm disgusted with the budget and Medicare. He's letting his buddies off scot-free, and we poor people on Medicare are going to have to pay.''
Mr. Bush's support eroded among other age groups as well, but not nearly so dramatically. The youngest adults remain the most supportive of the President. Approval among those 18 to 29 slipped to 70 percent from 79 percent in August.
This was another example of the growing sense in American politics of a generational scism between young and old. Indeed, one young respondent to the survey, Vinny M. Boland, 31, a sign maker from Miramar, Fla., cited elder citizens as one of the ''big interests'' that he said dominate Congress.
Mr. Bush's approval remains strong by the standards of recent Presidents. Gerald Ford and Mr. Carter both fell below 60 percent approval not long after taking office - Mr. Ford within weeks and Mr. Carter within months -and never recovered.
At this point in his Presidency, Ronald Reagan had approval ratings in the low to mid-40's as the nation struggled through a recession. Mr. Black, the Republican spokesman, suggested that a budget deal would help reverse the current decline in the economy and thus shore up Mr. Bush's political weaknesses by 1992.
But others suggested that Mr. Bush lacked Mr. Reagan's resilency and core of support. ''I just loved Ronald Reagan,'' said Mabel Holton, 62, a Democrat from Philadelphia. ''Maybe it's because he was so handsome and was in the movies. It's a personality thing. Anyone who looks at Bush on television knows there's nothing warm about the man, nothing to instill confidence.''
More substantively, said Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster, Mr. Bush will have a harder time blaming the economic downturn on Democrats the way Mr. Reagan was able to blame the recession and inflation of the early 1980's on Mr. Carter.
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 8-10 with 960 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that only residences would be called.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for people 65 years of age or older it is plus or minus eight percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Church Leaders Declare A 'Holy War' on Drugs

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Churches have been havens in New York's poorer neighborhoods from the drug war raging on its ever-more violent streets. This weekend, 200 pastors and lay members of the United Methodist Church spent the weekend discussing how they can do even more.
National church leaders brought plans for a ''holy war'' against drugs modeled on programs developed by congregations shocked by the soaring violence in Washington. When a turf shoot-out left two young men seeking safety dead on the steps of a congregation that had locked its doors during service, church members there decided that they needed to go out to the streets to combat the causes of the drug plague. 
''We must mount a holy war against drugs and reclaim our streets,'' said Bishop Felton E. May of Harrisonburg, Pa., who is on a special assignment to develop the church's response to the drug crisis on a national level.
While some at the meeting, at St. Mark's United Methodist Church on Edgecombe Avenue in Harlem, wondered how well their churches could meet such a challenge, all seemed to agree that it had to be attempted, and that their churches should take the lead.
 
Drafting Strategies
''People are really worried because it's dangerous out there,'' said the Rev. John Collins, pastor of the Tremont United Methodist Church in the South Bronx. He said that the churches from the eight districts represented at the conference have been asked to draft their own strategies, which will be presented at a meeting in January.
It is time the church gets in the forefront of the war on drugs, said the Rev. Lee Quinlan, pastor of the First United Methodist Church of Hollis, Queens. She said that addicts were shooting drugs across from her church last Sunday and that the churches in the neighborhood plan to take the anti-drug message to the streets.
''In Westchester County, all parents are afraid their children are either involved in drugs or will get involved,'' the Rev. Gail Paul, pastor of the Purdys United Methodist Church, said. She said she would use some of the ideas from the conference in her counseling work with prisoners in three correctional institutions in the area.
Vanna Griffin, the wife of the pastor of the Naugatuck United Methodist Church, near Waterbury, Conn., said that even in a small town, the drug problem was very serious. ''You don't always see it in the fine middle class that pays taxes and mows lawns, but they're all touched by it.''
Bishop May's emphasis is on drug education and treatment and the need ''to strike at the root causes of the drug problem,'' namely: spiritual malaise, racism and economic injustice.
The Saving Stations program is focused on community outreach, which includes drug education, youth rehabilitation, health programs, safe houses for abused women and children, housing, food and clothing for addicts and their families, and evangelism.
''It's a 24-hour-a-day commitment by our churches,'' said the Rev. Bernard Keels, pastor of the A. P. Shaw Church in Washington, who talked about Saving Stations to the assembly and in workshops. It was at Shaw Church, located in the southeast part of the capital, known as ''the killing zone'' that the idea of Saving Stations was born, under a retired pastor, the Rev. Everett Stephenson.
Pooling resources to confront the drug crisis, the Shaw church and 13 other churches in the Washington area have signed a covenant making the drug crisis the top priority on each church's agenda. Shaw and several covenant churches have also set up ''tent ministries'' to offer drug counseling and medical referrals to people afraid to come inside churches.
''We need to put our energies more into people than institutions,'' said the Rev. Ruthenia H. Finley, pastor of St. Mark's United Methodist Church. She approved of the community involvement in the Washington program but said: ''I don't know if we have the stick-to-itiveness power in New York, I don't know if we could sustain 24-hour-a-day commitment.''

HEADLINE: Dinkins Aide Denies Image of 'Confusion'

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration has a firm grip on New York City's fiscal and labor problems, despite the impression of ''some confusion,'' an aide to the Mayor told municipal union officers yesterday.
''I can assure you the administration is very much on top of the situation,'' said Frank T. New, the director of legislative affairs for Mayor David N. Dinkins. 
Mr. New acknowledged that a series of seemingly contradictory events a week ago ''created some confusion among all of us.'' On Oct. 1, the Mayor announced a 5.5 percent raise for teachers, and the next day he proposed hiring thousands more police officers. But by the end of the week, the city was projecting new budget gaps, imposing a hiring freeze and considering laying off 15,000 workers.
Mr. New spoke yesterday to a meeting of officers of Local 375 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, representing about 7,000 technical workers, including engineers, chemists and planners.
''Obviously the city is facing a financial crisis,'' Mr. New said. But he said layoffs would be imposed only as ''a last resort'' and were ''by no means certain at this point.''
Louis G. Albano, president of the union local, expressed skepticism about the extent of the city's financial problems. ''Our economists agree with the city's economists that the situation is tight, but they do not agree it is a bad as the city says,'' he said.
