HEADLINE: A Savings and Loan Bailout, and Bush's Son Jeb

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
After Jeb Bush, a son of the President, and a partner bought a Miami office building using money an associate had borrowed from a local savings and loan, the Federal Government wound up repaying most of the loan.
The savings institution became insolvent, and the Government paid more than $4 million to make good the loan as part of the bailout of the savings industry. Mr. Bush and his partner negotiated a settlement with regulators in which they repaid $505,000 and retained control of the building. While they still have a $7 million mortgage to pay on that property, the settlement with the Government lifted from their backs a $4.565 million second mortgage.
There is no evidence that Mr. Bush or his partner improperly influenced the settlement process. Mr. Bush, in an interview, said he was a ''victim of circumstance'' and had no involvement in the settlement talks.
Mr. Bush invited a reporter to come to Miami to review the partnership's records. ''We have nothing to fear or hide about the transaction,'' he said. 
 
Making Good on Bad Loans
While the complex loan arrangement does not involve allegations of criminal behavior, it stands as an illustration of the poor lending practices of savings institutions that led the industry into desperate straits. The deal also illustrates how the Government has had to absorb a large portion of the thousands of bad loans that were made by savings institutions that failed in 1988. The rescue of these institutions will cost $70 billion.
The Government's repayment of the loan used by Mr. Bush and his partner was part of the bailout program approved by Congress, in which the Government guaranteed buyers of ailing institutions that it would make good on bad loans that had been made by those institutions. Had the Government not made such guarantees, it would have had trouble finding buyers for the institutions and would have had to pay off the depositors.
The loan was made by Broward Federal Savings and Loan in Sunrise, Fla., which became insolvent in 1988 because of what regulators said were poor lending practices on commercial loans in the mid-1980's. The cost of cleaning up Broward Federal has been estimated at $285 million.
 
Arrangement Is Defended
Federal officials defended the Government's previously undisclosed agreement with Mr. Bush and his associates, saying it was the best settlement available because of the weakened commercial real estate market in Miami and because the loan was secured by a risky second mortgage. They said no preferential treatment had been accorded the President's 37-year-old son and his partner.
When the office building was reappraised to reflect the decline in commercial real estate in the Miami area, Federal regulators concluded that it made sense to let the owners keep the building because its value was less than its first mortgage.
Evaluating the settlement is difficult, because crucial papers, including property appraisals, are not public documents. And a lawsuit about the complex loan arrangement, which might have resolved or at least provided a public discussion of various critical issues, was settled out of court.
 
History of a Deal
Debt Plan Causes Misunderstanding
 In a series of interviews in their Miami office, Mr. Bush and his partner, Armando Codina, said the lengthy legal and regulatory process had cost them money, including Federal income taxes they are paying on the forgiven debt.
The two men attributed their problems to the failure of an associate, J. Edward Houston, to join them as an investor, as they had hoped. Instead Mr. Houston's company, the owner of another savings and loan, agreed to lend Mr. Bush and Mr. Codina the $4.565 million and borrowed the money from Broward Federal.
''The intention was to be an equity investment; instead he took a second mortgage and then at the last moment he borrowed the money from another institution,'' Mr. Bush said.
Jeb Bush's dealings in Miami are not related to those of his brother Neil, who was a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver. Neil Bush, who is 35, defended himself last month in Denver on civil charges by the Government that he acted improperly in his role as a director of Silverado, which failed in 1988 after making questionable loans, including some to Neil Bush's business associates.
 
An Active Republican
Jeb Bush has been prominent in Florida Republican politics and is state chairman of the re-election campaign of Gov. Bob Martinez. But his involvement in the complicated loan arrangement has gone unnoticed.
Mr. Bush's name is mentioned in the three volumes of records of a 1987 lawsuit filed by Broward Federal against the recipients of the loan proceeds, including a partnership owned by Mr. Bush and Mr. Codina.
According to the lawsuit, the loan transaction goes back to 1983, when Mr. Codina, a developer, obtained an option to buy a building at 1390 Brickell Avenue, the center of Miami's downtown financial district. Mr. Codina later assigned the option to a partnership, 1390 Brickell, of which he owned 80 percent and Mr. Bush the rest.
Mr. Bush is involved in the real estate business with Mr. Codina through a series of partnerships and corporations, under the umbrella of the Codina Bush Group. The Brickell Avenue building is managed by one of Mr. Bush's real estate companies.
 
Link to Savings Institution
Also in 1983, the J. E. Houston Financial Group, a company headed by Mr. Houston, a former Fort Lauderdale banker, acquired a small savings and loan, South Florida Savings. Mr. Houston became the president of the institution, rapidly expanded it and eventually moved its headquarters to a floor of plush offices at the five-story building at 1390 Brickell Avenue.
Mr. Bush, Mr. Codina and Mr. Houston's company were originally going to acquire the building together, the Bush-Codina partnership argued in court. Mr. Codina said all the parties expected to build a much bigger building on the land.
But one lawyer involved in the transaction said the planned investment by the Houston group had never been approved by Federal regulators, who would have had to approve any real estate transactions involving an insured savings and loan and an affiliated entity, like the Houston company.
 
Acquiring an Option
Instead of making the cash investment, Mr. Houston's company lent the Bush-Codina partnership $4.565 million and obtained a second mortgage on the building and an option to acquire half the partnership. Mr. Houston took that second mortgage, but not the option, and assigned it to Broward Federal as collateral for its loan. By retaining the option, Mr. Houston's company had the right to be consulted before the building could be disposed of.
''We didn't intend to get involved with a savings and loan,'' Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Houston never exercised his option to buy half the partnership and has a different view of the transaction, seeing it as a deal that turned sour for all parties. In an interview, he said, ''It was not my understanding that I was to convert into equity.'' He added, ''Both sides were unsatisfied, which is a sign of an arm's-length deal.''
 
The Money Flow
$11.5 Million Debt On $9 Million Sale
 The deal closed on Feb. 1, 1985, and the proceeds of the Broward Federal loan passed through Mr. Houston's company to the partnership, records show. That same day the 1390 Brickell partnership purchased the office building for $9 million, according to public records.
As part of the acquisition, the partnership secured a first mortgage of $7 million from an insurance company. That and the $4.565 million loan provided $11.565 million. In addition to the $9 million sale price, the money was used for improvements costing $1.7 million and the establishment of reserve accounts of $1.16 million, Mr. Codina said.
 
His Role in Partnership
IntrAmerica Investments, a company controlled by Mr. Codina, is the general partner of the 1390 Brickell partnership. Court records show that Mr. Bush signed various documents in 1985 and 1986 as president of IntrAmerica. Mr. Bush said he had been active in getting the building leased but had not been involved in the subsequent litigation or settlement negotiations.
Broward Federal began the litigation in 1987, two days after regulators placed South Florida Savings, Mr. Houston's institution, into receivership. Contending that its loan to Mr. Houston's corporation was in default, Broward Federal sued the corporation and Mr. Houston, who had personally guaranteed the loan, and the Bush-Codina partnership, whose note Mr. Houston had pledged to Broward as collateral for its loan.
Seeking to protect the collateral it held on the defaulted loan, Broward Federal asked the court to declare it the owner of the partnership's second mortgage note. That note had been pledged to Broward along with the income from the building and a reserve account as collateral for the Houston note.
 
Disputing Who Should Pay
For two years, claims and counterclaims flew over who should pay back the $4.565 million. The 1390 Brickell partnership argued that Mr. Houston or his company should pay. Mr. Houston argued that Broward Federal, having attached the partnership's note, should seek repayment from the partnership.
The lawsuit was twice set for trial, but the case was settled out of court under the auspices of Federal regulators, who were authorized to step in because of a Dec. 31, 1988, agreement under which Broward Federal's assets and liabilities were sold, under Government supervision, to California Federal Bank, a Los Angeles savings and loan.
 
The Negotiations
$7 Million Mortgage Derails One Accord
 The agreement, like most of the other 1988 savings and loan deals, called for the Government to guarantee any loss experienced by the California institution in taking over Broward's affairs. In addition, the Government was obligated to pay the acquiring institution's costs in managing the loans and any litigation to resolve them.
In a settlement agreement dated March 10, 1989, California Federal and the 1390 Brickell partnership agreed that the partnership would relinquish ownership of the building and that Mr. Codina would turn over his option on a nearby property. It also required the Bush-Codina partnership to pay at least $745,000, mostly the balance in an interest reserve account set up as part of the loan.
This settlement was rejected by the Government because it ''didn't make sense economically'' since whoever owned the building was liable for the $7 million first mortgage, said Dan Griffin, an official of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation who supervised the negotiations.
 
Revising an Appraisal
Mr. Griffin said the office building had originally been appraised at $9.5 million but that appraisals in the first half of 1989 reduced the appraised value to no more than $6.5 million. Thus, the regulators concluded that it would be better to let the owners keep the property rather than have the Government take over a $6.5 million building that carried $7 million in mortgage debt.
The new apprasials were ordered because regulators felt the first appraisal was outdated given the changes in Miami's real estate market. The F.D.I.C. declined to release the appraisals or the names of the companies that did them.
Mr. Griffin of the F.D.I.C. said the settlement delays ''had nothing to do with Jeb Bush'' but were ''because of the size of the write-off and the disparity of the appraisals.'' 10 Cents on the Dollar Charles A. Fulton, a senior lawyer at the F.D.I.C. who was involved in the negotiations, said a search by lawyers had concluded there was little legal or financial leverage to recover anything beyond 10 cents on the dollar, in part because the search found that Mr. Houston had few recoverable assets.
Mr. Griffin said the recovery rate of 10 cents on the dollar was about average for second mortgages like the one made by Broward Federal.
After the settlement was rejected by Federal regulators in June, the Codina-Bush partnership tried to settle its debt, starting with an offer of about $325,000. That was rejected, Mr. Fulton and Mr. Griffin said.
 
The Settlement
Leftover Money Is Used for Payment
 About the same time, the reserve account, then the focus of the negotiations and the ultimate source of most of what the Government recovered, was used by Mr. Bush and Mr. Codina to pay more than $200,000 in delinquent real estate taxes, Mr. Griffin and Mr. Codina said. That step was approved by California Federal Bank, but Federal regulators, who were supposed to oversee such transactions, did not learn about it until after it had taken place, Mr. Fulton said.
The final settlement of $505,000 paid by the Bush-Codina partnership consisted of the $437,000 remainining in the interest reserve accountand the balance in a small escrow account, $68,000, according to records and the F.D.I.C. officials.
The final agreement was put together in the summer and fall of 1989, drafted in December, and entered into the court file earlier this year. During this time, legal authority for approving the settlement shifted from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to the F.D.I.C., as a result of President Bush's signing the savings and loan rescue legislation on Aug. 9, 1989.
 
The Issue of Taxpayers' Money
Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Codina expressed surprise that the settlement of the loan could be interpreted as the use of taxpayers' money to make good a loan whose proceeds went for their building. Asked if they were aware that the funds for the repayment of the Broward Federal loan came from the taxpayers, both men said no.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Codina said they had incurred additional costs as a result of the transaction, the largest being a $1.316 million tax liability this year when they declared the forgiven debt as income to the Internal Revenue Service.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Accord Expected Soon on Farm Bill With $13 Billion in Savings

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The House and Senate conference committee that is writing a new farm bill is close to agreeing to significant changes in the Government's commodity price support program that would save more than $13 billion over the next five years.
Committee staff members are working out the details of a broad accord reached Friday night by the conferees and expect to have the bill ready for a committee vote on Monday, a staff member said today.
The changes in commodity programs were necessary to meet the requirements of the Congressional budget resolution aimed at reducing the Federal deficit. The resolution called for the conferees to reduce farm program spending by more than 25 percent over the next five fiscal years. Without the changes, the committee had estimated that the price support program would cost the Government $54 billion to $56 billion from the fiscal years 1991 through 1995. 
Since the program was established in the early 1930's, the core of American farm policy has been a contract between farmers and the Government that sets production by controlling the amount of land under cultivation. $7.8 Bill in Price Supports In exchange for setting aside a specific number of acres to lay idle each year, typically 5 to 15 percent of their tillable land, farmers who sign up for the program gain a payment for every bushel of grain, bale of cotton or pound of rice they produce. Government payments to farmers in the program totaled $7.8 billion in the last fiscal year, having reached a record $25.8 billion in 1986.
On Friday, the House conferees proposed saving $5.8 billion by 1995 by sharply reducing the amount of land on which farmers could grow crops eligible for Government payments. The House also proposed saving $2.9 billion by changing the formula for calculating the level of Government payments. Instead of basing payments on a 5-month average of market prices, the House said farmers' payments should be based on a 12-month average.
 
A $1 Billion Sales Tax
These changes in rules would reduce Government payments to hundreds of thousands of individual grain, rice and cotton farmers by thousands of dollars each. In addition, the House proposal calls for producers of milk, sugar, tobacco, peanuts, honey and wool to pay the Government 1 percent of the sale price of their products at the time they are marketed, a plan intended to raise $1 billion a year.
Some members of the House delegation to the conference said their proposal could be a first step toward eliminating the Government's farm programs, an outcome sought by President Bush and other Presidents.
''At some point a farmer is going to ask whether it costs him more to be part of the farm programs than to be out of them,'' said Representative Glenn English, Democrat of Oklahoma, a member of the House delegation. ''If we get to the point where half or less than half of farmers participate, I think there is a question of whether the farm program becomes nothing more than simple welfare. It can't be justified on that ground.''
In recent years more than 90 percent of the producers of the 14 commodities receiving Government price supports participated in the program.
'From the Pockets of Farmers'
Leaders of farm groups said Friday that their members would be hurt by the proposal. ''They're taking money from the pockets of farmers,'' said Michael Dunn, a vice president for the National Farmers Union, which represents 250,000 farm families. ''It's unfair that farmers are being asked to bear so much of the burden of the Federal budget deficit.''
The House and Senate conferees took up the proposal to cut spending on the price support programs after failing to come to agreement on the last two environmental provisions of the new farm legislation. The first of the disputed provisions would bar the export of pesticides that are unlawful to use in the United States. The second would require farmers to keep detailed records of the pesticides they use and to make them available to medical specialists and farm workers.
Both provisions are strongly supported by Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, who is the chairman of the conference. But Republican Senate conferees and many House conferees of both parties oppose the measures. It remains uncertain whether these provisions will be in the final bill.
 
Deficit Forcing Hard Decisions
It is clear from the proposals to cut spending on the price support program that the budget deficit is doing more to force change than years of political fighting on Capitol Hill. The House conferees say their proposal for sharply reducing the acreage eligible for the program gives farmers more flexibility to choose their crops, something Democrats and Republicans, scientists and economists, Presidents and Agriculture secretaries have been talking about since the 1970's.
The House proposal could eliminate 30 to 45 percent of a farmer's land from eligibility in the price support program by 1995. According to the proposal, a farmer in the program could use about 60 percent of his tillable land to grow crops that would receive Government price supports. Fifteen percent of his land would be idle and he could grow what he wanted on the rest, but the only money he would receive from the crops on this land would come from their sale. This year a bushel of wheat sold for more than $1 less than the price paid by the Government.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Staff members on the Senate Budget Committee meeting on Capitol Hill yesterday as budget negotiations continued. From the left were, John Wagster, Kathy Deignan, Bill Hoagland and Bill Dauster. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: Washington Talk;
House Republicans Try, As Always, to Matter

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The House Republicans' defection from the White House put them at the center of budget politics last week. This week, they were back on familiar turf: shoved to the sidelines, spurned by the White House and shut out by the Democrats.
They try accommodation. They try confrontation. But in a chamber where Democrats outnumber them 258 to 176, the Republicans never manage to lift themselves from a permanent minority status that is essentially irrelevant to making policy. 
Most House Republicans do not even know what it is like to be consequential. Many were not even born in 1954, when their party last controlled the chamber, in the first Administration of Dwight D. Eisenhower.
Frustrated House Republicans have from time to time set out to be noticed. But even one of their political successes, at the start of the Reagan Administration, took Democrats to engineer. A group of Southern conservative Democrats, known as the ''boll weevils,'' broke with their party in 1981 and helped push Ronald Reagan's first budget through the House.
A year later, a group of mostly Northeastern and Middle Western Republicans, known as ''gypsy moths,'' joined Democrats opposed the Reagan economic program.
But mostly, House Republicans have been known for taking the lead of Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader, and seeking to work with the majority.
Enter Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who in 1988 seized on Republican restlessness and led a war of words against Speaker Jim Wright that ended in Mr. Wright's resignation amid charges of ethics violations and Mr. Gingrich's election to Republican whip, the No. 2 minority House post.
But the assertiveness has only heightened the House minority's second-fiddle role. While House Democrats were meeting over the budget the other day in what Representative Charles Wilson, a Texas Democrat, described as a partisan ''love-in -like a revival meeting,'' Republicans were dickering over their own budget strategy in what Representative Chuck Douglas, a New Hampshire Republican, described as ''three hours of spleen-venting.''
House Republicans remain divided over whether the budget alternative they are drafting should include any tax increases. Nor are they ready to agree with Mr. Bush that a deep cut in the capital gains tax now seems out of the question.
''The Republicans have got to bury their animosities,'' said Representative Ralph Regula of Ohio. ''I don't see we have a choice. We were sent here to govern, not to throw bombs at each other.''
But the only thing Republicans in the House seem to share these days is hostility at Republicans in the White House for what the lawmakers say is their high-handed tactics in dealing with them - or rather, not dealing with them.
They will not stand for a budget that was drafted by Democrats, they insist. At the same time, they concede that their only recourse, helping sustain a Presidential veto of an unacceptable budget, is hardly one that will move the process forward.
Not everyone discounts the power of thwarting the legislative process.
''They cannot necessarily enact their own legislation, but they certainly can be obstructionist,'' said John Buckley, a political consultant who has worked extensively with House Republicans. ''They are defined in the negative just like a President who only rules by veto is defined in the negative. But they can use that very effectively.''
Maybe so. For a week or two. Pursuing a ''burn down the House'' strategy of discrediting Congress in the hope that voters will throw out incumbents and elect more Republicans, Mr. Gingrich led the break of House Republicans against the budget plan announced in the Rose Garden two Sundays ago.
But this week, the House Republicans and the man they rallied around found that they were being dismissed as loud-mouthed mischief makers, whose rejection of the Democratic-sponsored budget doesn't even matter.
''Mr. Gingrich made a very big mistake in terms of judgment of what's good for the country and for the party,'' said Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee and a supporter of the initial budget compromise. ''He made two many damn television appearances expressing his opinion.''

PUB-DATE: October 14, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 22, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1360 words

HEADLINE: Virginia Governor Baffles Democrats With Crusade for 'New Mainstream'

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND

 BODY:
With the fervor of an evangelist and with his eyes seemingly on a larger prize, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder has embarked on a nationwide crusade for the political moderation that helped him become the first black ever elected chief executive of an American state.
Hardly a week passes that he does not venture out of Virginia, sometimes two and three times, to spread the gospel of his ''new mainstream'' values. He bluntly lectures fellow Democrats, especially those in Washington, that the party will never recapture the White House unless it veers back to ''fiscal responsibility,'' and he calls for cuts in Federal spending and holding the line on new taxes.
Most recently he has attacked - and infuriated - Democrats who support tax increases as a way to help balance the Federal budget, accusing them of misjudging the political potency of moderation.
 
Nudging Party to the Right
In effect, Mr. Wilder is making a concerted effort to nudge the Democratic Party to the right, to move it to the center where elections are usually won. It is an unusual political move for a black Democrat, but it is one that worked for Mr. Wilder at the state level in the gubernatorial election last year, when he put together a multiracial coalition of Democrats and independents, and it is one he is certain would work nationally. 
It is also a move that has propelled Mr. Wilder high into the ranks of possible Vice Presidential contenders. He seems to enjoy the view from there.
''National issues affect Virginia,'' he said in a recent interview in his Richmond office. ''Many Virginians are among the great American 'new mainstream' that is becoming more and more fed up with the way this country is being governed. I intend to address that issue.''
The other day, as part of his crusade for the ''new mainstream,'' the Governor gave a speech in Washington. Then he sent a letter to Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in which he asserted that Democratic leaders were so out of touch with the nation's ''vast majority'' that they risked getting an ''early start'' on writing their memoirs.
''For the record,'' he added, ''I don't plan on writing my memoirs anytime soon.''
 
'It's Hard to Understand'
The spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, Ginny Terzano, said the party's national leaders were puzzled by Mr. Wilder's criticism. ''It's hard to understand,'' she added, ''why he feels obligated to attack fellow Democrats when our goal has been clear from the start - no tax break for the wealthy and a fair shake for working people.''
But if some national Democratic leaders seem puzzled by Mr. Wilder's attack, others find merit in his approach. They note that in his 25 years in politics, he has often lashed out at fellow Democrats to make a point.
''Doug doesn't always do what I like but his mainstream message serves a real purpose,'' said Al From, the director of the Democratic Leadership Council, one of the party's more conservative organizations. ''It's a message Democrats need to hear and it carries real weight when it's delivered by a black.''
In the 10 months since Mr. Wilder was sworn in here on the lawn of the former Confederate Capitol, he has taken his crusade to more than half of the 50 states, touching down several times in delegate-rich giants like California, New York and Illinois and, lest anyone miss the point, also dropping in on Iowa and New Hampshire, where the Presidential caucuses and primaries start.
 
Cause for Concern to Jackson
He has been out of the state so often that there is some grousing that he is an ''absentee governor,'' paying too little attention to Virginia at a time when it is beginning to suffer seriously from the national economic squeeze. The headline on a recent Richmond News Leader article about his travels read, ''Wilder to Visit Virginia During Six-State Week.''
Mention the 1992 Presidential race these days, here or just about anywhere, and Mr. Wilder's name inevitably comes up. Because he is a black moderate, one line of reasoning goes, he would be the ideal Vice Presidential choice for the Democratic ticket, offering reassurance to the party faithful who fear the confrontational liberalism of the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
''I'm not running for anything - or away from anything,'' the Governor says. ''But I want to make one thing clear: I'm a governor who happens to be black, not a black who happens to be governor.''
Whatever the case, Mr. Jackson, who twice has unsuccessfully sought the Democratic Presidential nomination, seems to find Mr. Wilder cause for concern, as do some other black liberals. Mr. Jackson has worried aloud that the ''new mainstream'' might turn out to be a ''backwater'' or ''cesspool'' for the poor and disadvantaged.
Mr. Wilder says there is no reason to worry.
In Virginia, he contends, his ''new mainstream'' government is a compassionate government, but nevertheless a government that puts ''necessities before niceties'' and runs on a balanced budget, without new taxes.
Still, he boasts, by cutting bureaucratic bloat and consolidating programs, he has avoided a tax increase and headed off a $1.4 billion deficit in the state's budget.
''If the Federal Government cut the way Virginia cuts,'' he argues, ''they could save $70 to $80 billion a year and there'd be no need for any new taxes.''
 
Mixed Reviews in the State
Mr. Wilder, who under state law cannot run for a second term, a rare constriction in American politics, receives mixed reviews here thus far.
When he took office, he was careful to appoint cabinet members and agency heads who reflected the diverse voter coalition that elected him. Criticism was minimal.
He also strengthened ties with leaders of the Democrat-controlled State Legislature, where he served as a State Senator for 16 years, cementing those ties so well that the Legislature went along with most of his budget-tightening requests last spring.
But as he has begun to travel out of state more and make more of the everyday decisions that governors everywhere must make, dissatisfaction has begun to build.
In his most publicized move, Mr. Wilder ordered state agencies and schools to divest themselves of stocks held in companies doing business with South Africa. Many blacks, in and out of the state, roundly praised the move. But it was not well received at many schools and agencies, and the order was eventually changed to require divestiture only in cases in which a profit would be realized on the stocks at the time of sale.
 
Appointment Riles Educators
There is also widespread grousing among the state's educators and editorialists about the Governor's appointment of Patricia Kluge, the estranged wife of one of the world's wealthiest men, to the board of the University of Virginia. Critics contend she has little experience in education matters, and they point out that she and her estranged husband, John Kluge, have been major contributors to the university and, not incidentally, to Mr. Wilder's political campaigns.
Further, and perhaps more to the point, the critics note that the Governor, who is divorced, has sometimes been seen squiring Ms. Kluge.
Once he arrived at Charlottesville, her home, by state helicopter, setting off some grumbling that he had used state equipment for a private purpose. Worse, his friendship with Ms. Kluge, who is white, has resulted in some racial sniping, the whispered kind that was notably quiet in last year's election campaign.
 
Problem for Republicans
For Virginia Republicans, Mr. Wilder is a bit of a political puzzle.
They complain loudly about his heavy load of out-of-state travel and speaking engagements. But his rhetoric strikes some harmonious chords with them.
''I call him the 'Absentee Governor,' '' said Steve Haner, the director of the Joint Republican Caucus in the Virginia Legislature. ''On the other hand, I have to admit, with some bittersweet pleasure, that what he's advocating outside the state is basically our agenda. He used to be a tax-and-spend politician himself but now he's stolen our music, hypocrite and opportunist that he is.''

HEADLINE: MENEM'S REFORMS PROVOKE BACKLASH

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 13

 BODY:
For a President who likes to duck his bodyguards, drive his own car, frequent the nightspots and soccer stadiums and generally mix with the throngs, the reviews that Carlos Saul Menem gets from the people these days are disquieting.
While his personal charm and audacity are still popular, the man who likes to be liked is encountering a growing public reaction against policies intended to change Argentina into a free-market state aligned with the United States and other developed nations. Some people oppose those policies on principle, and others are angry because they suffer economically from them.
At a recent public appearance, a young woman approached Mr. Menem with a disarming smile and then proceeded to deliver a tongue-lashing while many in the audience booed him. 
When he went to Argentina's southernmost region, Tierra del Fuego, state workers shouted insults until he gave up trying to speak. 'Puppet' for Bush? Perhaps worse, Congress seldom passes the legislation he proposes and his Peronist party is leaving him to govern largely alone, with a small circle of trusted people, many of them from outside the party. One of the leaders of the Peronist opposition to Mr. Menem recently accused him of playing ''the role of Latin American puppet'' for President Bush.
Since assuming the presidency 15 months ago, Mr. Menem has sought to revive a prostrate economy by turning back a system of heavy state control and subsidies. Over half a century, an interlocking network of increasingly corrupt and inefficient state companies and private contractors and suppliers had drained the treasury; a disillusioned populace had sent most of its wealth abroad and simply refused to pay taxes.
Mr. Menem has been putting state companies and oil rights on the auction block by the dozens. At a time when many other countries are doing the same, it has been a struggle to convince would-be investors from home and abroad that the Argentine firms are attractive business deals.
He has faced and shrugged off complaints from his party and the Radical Civic Union, the chief opposition, that he is giving away the national patrimony too cheaply and too haphazardly.
By those privatizations, Mr. Menem hopes to eliminate the fiscal deficit, wipe out a good chunk of the $65 billion foreign debt by permitting buyers to exchange debt paper for equity in Argentine companies, and bring improved technology and modern business methods to Argentina through foreign buyers or local managers liberated from state controls.
 
Return From Isolationism
The other part of Mr. Menem's strategy is to seek a respectable place for a country that has lived in isolation for most of this century, beginning at a time when Argentina was so rich from the sale of wheat and hides to a poor and war-torn Europe that it thought it could afford to close its doors and enjoy its wealth.
The decision to send two Argentine ships and 300 men to join those massed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf was an important part of the strategy to change the country's isolationist image and convince Washington that Argentina is a reliable ally. But the action has been criticized by a number of other Latin American countries and by many in the Argentine Congress.
So far, most Argentines see few benefits from Mr. Menem's policies, admittedly of longer-term impact. Inflation, while no longer considered out of control, has been running a worrisome 15 percent a month for several months. Unemployment is climbing steadily, mostly due to layoffs in private industry because Mr. Menem has not yet dared to confront the well-organized public workers with the massive layoffs that may be necessary if he is to keep his commitment to cut spending.
 
Tax Collections Falling
While the fiscal deficit has been falling rapidly, that is mainly because of painful increases in tariffs for public services and because of money coming in from privatizations, not because of reduced expenditures. Tax collections are falling, partly because of the slow economy, but mostly because the Government lacks the database on which to make collections.
Economists are also worried over the fact that the United States dollar -the hard currency to which economic life in Argentina is tied - has steadily declined on the free-exchange market, doubling the cost of living here in dollar terms over the last six months.
Government actions at the beginning of the year that froze most bank deposits and left people with nothing with which to trade for dollars, a common practice to hedge against inflation, are said to have caused the increase.. The dollar market in Argentina, as in most of Latin America, has always reacted to internal factors, not to the money markets in Europe and Japan or to the strength or weakness of the United States economy.
The main negative effect of the cheap dollar and expensive austral, the local currency, is that it makes Argentine exports less competitive. There are reports of some industries simply shutting down export operations because they are unprofitable. But the Government fears that loosening monetary controls would set off the kind of inflation that hit 200 percent a month as Mr. Menem took office.

HEADLINE: Hanoi's Foreign Minister Works the U.S. Circuit Seeking End to Trade Ban

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Like a salesman opening up a new territory, Nguyen Co Thach, Vietnam's peripatetic Foreign Minister, is knocking on doors and seeking friends among America's members of Congress, diplomats, scholars and bankers, in the hope of ending Washington's trade embargo against his country.
A 66-year-old member of Vietnam's ruling Politburo and one of its main proponents of economic reform, Mr. Thach is visiting the United States for a meeting scheduled for Wednesday with Gen. John W. Vessey, the special Presidential adviser on issues involving American servicemen missing or taken prisoner in Vietnam.
At the same time, Mr. Thach is telling Americans that it is time to end the hostile aftermath of the Vietnam War and get on with normal relations. He feels, moreover, that an end to the long estrangement is finally in sight. In his words, ''there is light at the end of the tunnel.'' 
In vernacular American English salted with parodies of Washington cliches popular during the Vietnam War, Mr. Thach told listeners last week that no substantive issues remain to bar diplomatic relations between the United States and Vietnam.
 
'Can Be Settled Easily'
''Cambodia and the P.O.W.-M.I.A. issue were the two thorniest obstacles, but I think those issues can be settled easily now,'' he said in an interview.
''I'm going to tell General Vessey that he can have anything he wants,'' he said. ''He can go anywhere he wants in Vietnam to investigate the M.I.A. question. The only places he might not be welcome would be inside our Defense and Interior Ministries.''
Vietnam and the United States agree on keeping foreign troops out of Cambodia, he said, adding: ''At the same time, both your country and ours want to make sure that Cambodia never again experiences the genocide committed by Pol Pot's regime. We have to be sure of that. We must rely on the Cambodian people themselves to make sure the terrible slaughters of the late 1970's never recur. We Vietnamese cannot go back a second time. We have done enough to save the Cambodian people.''
The Khmer Rouge Government of Pol Pot were ousted by an invading Vietnamese Army in 1979, which established a pro-Vietnamese Government in Phnom Penh. After a decade of fighting rebel forces - including rival factions supporting Pol Pot and Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's ruler from 1953 to 1970 - the bulk of Vietnamese forces left Cambodia last year.
Mr. Thach said Vietnam would have no objection to Prince Sihanouk's return to power, ''provided the Pol Pot butchers were not part of the arrangement.''
 
Sees Big Changes in Vietnam
He told a group of foreign affairs specialists meeting at the Asia Society in New York on Thursday that major changes are under way in Vietnam.
''We realized that without large reforms we could go nowhere,'' he said, ''but in this rapidly changing world, we have learned some important lessons both from China and the countries of Eastern Europe.
''From China and the Tiananmen incident, we learned that you cannot have economic reform without political reform. From the troubles we see today in Eastern Europe, we learned that you cannot have political reform without economic reform. These reforms must go together.''
To guide Vietnam in its transformation, he said, both he and Prime Minister Do Muoi have come to rely on a Vietnamese translation of ''Economics,'' a standard college textbook written by Paul Samuelson, an American economist who won a Nobel prize in 1970. ''We keep it on our night tables as bedtime reading,'' he said.
''In 1986 we were on the brink of economic catastrophe,'' he said. ''Today we still have formidable problems, but we have turned things around. For the first time, Vietnam has begun to export rice instead of importing it. Because we devalued our currency, we are now exporting much more than we did. And partly thanks to Paul Samuelson's book, we found loopholes in your trade embargo.''
 
'Government of the People'
Asked if Hanoi's reforms might soften the harshly authoritarian style of its Communist Government, he replied: ''That's an interesting question. After 40 years we have come to realize that government cannot be simply of and for the state.
''What we are trying to do is have a government of the people, by the people and for the people. Before, decisions were made by only 100 people, and some of those decisions were nonsense. What sense is there is an economic decision that makes one duck egg equal in value to five kilograms of steel? We are ending the governmental compartmentalization that led to such rules. We know now that decisions must be made by 65 million people, not just 100.''
In fact, the structure of the Vietnamese Government remains that of a traditional Marxist-Leninist dictatorship, although its economic policies have changed markedly in the last four years.
But Vietnam's bureaucrats sometimes have difficulty adjusting to customs in free-market societies, he said.
 
Asking Beggar for Receipt
''The other day a Vietnamese driver from our United Nations Mission here was stopped by one of those people in the street who ask for money,'' Mr. Thach said. ''The driver gave him something, but then insisted on having a receipt, because at home, we must account for everything. Things are done differently here.''
Asked about the Soviet military presence in Vietnam, notably the American-built naval base at Cam Ranh Bay, Mr. Thach replied: ''The big powers want military disengagement at this point, and it's not in anyone's interest to stress military involvement. The Soviets withdrew from Cam Ranh Bay last year, and we don't intend to ask them to stay on.''
Mr. Thach met on Sept. 27 and 29 with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. It was the first high-level encounter between the two Governments since the 1973 peace agreement. The Vietnamese Foreign Minister did not disclose details of his conversations, except to say they had been friendly.
But he added: ''Americans must understand that international agreements go two ways, not like the streets in New York City. In any case, we can wait a bit longer for trade and diplomatic relations if we must. International relations don't work like fast-food restaurants. It's been many years already, and we can finally see light at the end of the tunnel.''
 
His Movements Limited
Despite the importance attached to Mr. Thach's visit by many officials and economists, his movements in the United States have been strictly limited by the State Department, since the United States does not recognize the Hanoi Government.
Mr. Thach is permitted to visit New York since Vietnam is a member of the United Nations, but he may not travel beyond 25 miles of the United Nations headquarters. As a result, he was unable to go to an informal meeting of foreign affairs specialists arranged last weekend by a Vietnamese-American friend, Dao Spencer, at her home in East Hampton, L.I.
For his meeting with General Vessey, Mr. Thach has been cleared by the State Department to travel to Washington, but only for one day.
He dismissed such inconveniences with a smile, saying: ''One way or another, we get to talk to our American friends. That's certainly progress, isn't it?''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Ethnic Rivalries Push Yugoslavia to Edge

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Intensifying conflicts and rivalries among Yugoslavia's republics are bringing the country dangerously close to the breaking point, say people who favor the process as well as those who fear it.
Nerves are fraying throughout the country. In Slovenia, the Government has deployed its own armed guards to underscore claims that the republic's sovereignty is paramount. In Croatia, gangs of heavily-armed Serbs have blocked roads in the enclaves where they are numerically strong. In Serbia's Kosovo region, ethnic Albanians speak openly of armed uprising. Travel from republic to republic, and the inventory of conflicts grows. 
An international effort may soon be needed to head off a conflagration, Slovenia's Prime Minister, Lojze Peterle, said this week.
A dream of 19th-century Slav Romantics, Yugoslavia is now a crumbling mosaic of peoples of Eastern Orthodox, Roman Catholic or Muslim traditions who have lived since World War II in a federation.
 
Communists Muffled Quarrels
Though conflicts and vendettas laced the region for years, for much of the postwar period national unity was advanced by a modicum of prosperity and the now-defunct Yugoslav Communist Party's monopoly of power, which muffled the quarrels.
Much like the erosion of central power and rise of nationalist emotions in the Soviet Union, the breakdown of Communist-imposed unity and the emergence of democratic openness in Yugoslavia have released long-suppressed national aspirations, envies and antagonisms.
Democratically elected, non-Communist Governments now hold sway in Slovenia and Croatia, the country's richest and most Western-minded republics. Communists, under a variety of guises, still run the other four republics, but elections are scheduled in each before year's end.
Yugoslavia's central political conflict, like the states' rights clash in pre-Civil War America, pits backers of a loose confederation of independent states against advocates of a formidable federal Government.
 
Different Manifestations
The Slovenian and Croatian Governments have already written a model confederal agreement and threatened to secede from Yugoslavia if one cannot be worked out. Serbia, the most populous republic, advocates strengthening the federal Government. The Slovenes and Croats object to it as a veiled attempt to create a Greater Serbia.
While the confederation-federation problem lies at the core of Yugoslavia's troubles, the problem manifests itself differently according to republic.
Unencumbered by minority enclaves, the Alpine Slovenes, who held their own against German cultural domination for centuries, can make a relatively clean break from Yugoslavia.
Two weeks ago, the republic's Parliament took broad steps away from the present federation, approving a motion that said Slovenia's constitution was the supreme law of the land.
The change galled Yugoslavia's federal presidency and its Communist-dominated army, whose officer corps is about 70 percent Serb. When both threatened action to defend the federal Constitution, the Slovenes took offense.
 
Age-Old Conflict Returns
''It seems there are elements that don't want the Slovenes to remain in the country but for them to pull out as soon as possible,'' said Janez Drnovsek, Slovenia's representative to the federal presidency, speaking about Serbia's backers in the presidency. ''They aren't looking for real solutions but are instead forcing conflicts and reducing chances for an agreement.''
In Croatia, a onetime province of Hungary that craved self-rule for centuries, the age-old conflict between the Orthodox Serbs and Catholic Croats has returned to center stage.
The Croatian Government's vow to create a sovereign state has piqued the republic's Serbs, who account for 11.5 percent of its population and live in self-proclaimed autonomy mainly in counties adjacent to the border with the republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
Serbs have a tradition of armed resistance and a memory of atrocities committed by Croatia's wartime Fascist regime. That memory has spawned a deep fear of Croatian nationalism. Crude, sensationalist disinformation spread by Serbian demagogues and Belgrade's Government-backed media has whipped up the Serbs' fears to a dangerous frenzy.
When the Croatian police tried to confiscate weapons from police stations in Serb-populated counties, gangs of Serbs toting automatic weapons, shotguns and hand grenades - often heisted from police and territorial defense arsenals - took to the woods and barricaded Croatian roads. Randon gunfire has crackled across the counties for years, and bomb explosions have gutted stores and cut a rail line.
 
Frequent Reassurance Ineffective
Croatian officials assure the Serbs almost daily that they have nothing to fear, but impolitic campaign language about restoring Croatia's ''historic borders'' and the barring of some 20,000 Serbs from a commemoration at the site of a former concentration camp have deepened the Serbs' paranoia.
Croatian leaders from across the political spectrum charge Serbia's Government with inciting the Serbs in order to smother Croatia's fledgling democracy and create a pretext for army intervention. For now, the Croatian Government has only asked the Serbs to surrender the stolen weapons, but officials have warned that Zagreb will resort to force if necessary.
In Serbia, which reclaimed its independence last century after 450 years of Ottoman tyranny, gypsy street bands are doing a thriving business playing World War I marches.
Serbia's renamed Communist Party, led by the authoritarian Slobodan Milosvic and a host of party careerists, shows no sign of loosening its grip on power. Rather, Mr. Molosvic appears to be positioning Serbia to grab the best deal possible, including territorial gains, in the emerging new order.
Mr. Milosvic has warned that if it comes to confederation, all of Yugoslavia's internal borders would be called into question. In the past two weeks, the main theme of Belgrade's press has shifted from bolstering Serbia's territorial integrity to protecting Serbs outside Serbia. A similar focus preceded Mr. Milosvic's engineering of Serbia's takeover of the troubled Kosovo region last year.
 
Apartheid of Sorts Results
In Kosovo, home to a 90 percent ethnic-Albanian population, Mr. Milosvic's Government is using Procrustean tactics to secure ''rule of law'' and reorganize a third world economy.
An apartheid of sorts has resulted. Schools are divided; thousands of Albanians have lost their jobs, and Serbs have been dispatched to fill key positions.
While Albanians in smoky Pristina taverns speak openly of armed insurrection and secession from Serbia and Yugoslavia, the Serbian police go house to house ferreting out weapons caches.
Western diplomats here predict a bloodbath and a massed forced exodus if an uprising breaks out. But with the regional Parliament dissolved and the Albanian-language press virtually silenced, the Albanians have few legal outlets to vent their frustrations.
Many Yugoslavs fear an eruption of turmoil in ethnically mixed Bosnia-Herzegovina, Europe's original powder keg and a killing field during World War II.
 
Parties Follow National Lines
The campaign for next month's elections has already produced the organization of political parties along national lines. Croat and Muslim-Slav parties back a sovereign Bosnia-Herzegovina and confederation; Serbs, fearing a Croat-Muslim coalition, threaten war if the future Parliament opts for anything other than a federation.
As a compromise solution, Radovan Karadzic, president of the republic's Serbian Democratic Party, describes a future federation that would include Serbia and Montenegro, most of Bosnia-Herzegovina, the Serb-populated Croatian counties and perhaps Macedonia. Not surprisingly, Croats and Muslim-Slavs dismiss this as Greater Serbia.
With memories of wartime brutality still vivid, many people in Bosnia-Herzegovina cling to the hope that the Yugoslav-oriented Communists or the reform party of Prime Minister Ante Markovic will win enough seats to keep the nationalist parties at bay.

In Slovenia, the central government has deployed its own armed guards, who patrolled last weekend in Ljubljana. (Associated Press); map: Yugoslavia, indicating ethnic regions (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Remembering a Tortured Child Who Lived in the Streets of Guatemala City

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUATEMALA

 BODY:
The marble tombstone erected here last week for Nahaman Carmona Lopez says more about his death than his short life: ''I only wanted to be a child and they wouldn't let me.''
The 13-year-old street urchin died in March after four policemen found him sniffing glue to mask his wracking hunger pains. The officers, witnesses said, yanked him into the air by his ears, threw him to the ground and kicked him into unconsciousness, rupturing his liver and breaking six ribs.
The epitaph, added to the tombstone to mark the six-month anniversary of his killing, would serve as well for any of the 40 or so other children killed this year in the underground campaign being waged by the police. 
In one June incident, eight children were kidnapped from a downtown street by men in a jeep. Investigators said the bodies of three of the boys were found shortly thereafter bearing messages written in torture: their ears had been sliced off and their eyes burned out. And in a traditional warning to witnesses against going public with anything they see or hear about the security forces, their tongues had been carved out.
''Hopefully they were killed first, but that's not the way it's usually done here,'' said Bruce Harris, the regional director here of Covenant House, the New York-based child welfare organization that unveiled the tombstone as part of a campaign in behalf of the street children and against the police crackdown.
 
Rise in Abject Poor
The tombstone also serves as a silent protest against the often-hidden economic crisis that is ravaging this country and the rest of Latin America. After a decade of almost uninterrupted recession, a job is little more than a fading memory for the vast majority of Guatemalans. Poverty has swallowed thousands of formerly middle class families, pushing the already poor into desperate straights.
Almost 9 in 10 Guatemalan families now live in poverty - earning just enough money for food, but not for medicine, housing and schools. That is up from one in three a decade ago, according to statistics recently released by the United Nations that concur with other figures and are considered as reliable as any.
According to the United Nations study, the number of abject poor -those who are unable to feed themselves - jumped from one in eight to almost one in three during the 1980's, which has come to be known throughout Latin America as ''The Lost Decade.''
This desperate plight is repeated from country to country across the region. Even in Costa Rica, the richest and most stable of the isthmus's six countries, two of five families are unable to afford basic necessities. In a vicious circle, the economic crisis there has forced the deficit-plagued government to cut social services, hurting those who need help most.
Children, like Nahaman, have been among the hardest-hit victims. A survey completed earlier this year by the United Nations Children's Fund, UNICEF, found that a decade of civil war in El Salvador, Nicaragua and Guatemala had turned two million people into refugees; half are children under 16. In El Salvador, half the children under 5 are malnourished. In Honduras, 60 poor children die every day. Despite plenty of rich farmland in most Central American countries, infant mortality has risen sharply. In several countries it has almost doubled in the last decade in many areas; some put the number as high as 120 per 1,000 live births.
 
Forced into Prostitution
Unable to feed their children, a growing number of families have abandoned them to the streets, where they join orphans and runaways. In a recent report, Amnesty International estimated there were at least 5,000 street urchins in downtown Guatemala. Other officials say there are slightly fewer. While there are no reliable estimates for the citywide total, all officials agree that the number has risen dramatically and that there may be 10,000 street children living in the capital.
''Street children are children who have nobody,'' said Mr. Harris, whose risky campaign in their behalf is a direct challenge to the often brutal police and has earned the praise of Western diplomats and international human-rights groups. ''They have no voice, but their silence is deafening. The abuse is overwhelming.''
Many of the boys and girls are forced into prostitution, which is centered in Concordia Park across the street from the police headquarters. Others survive by petty thievery and by sniffing cobblers' glue. A 50-cent container can last a day, doled out a few tablespoons at a time into a plastic bag. When warmed by pressing the bag against the skin, it gives off intoxicating fumes, which normally are shared by the myriad small gangs that loiter downtown.
''It gives them a high to escape reality and the courage to rob,'' said Mr. Harris as he hugged Moses, a 13-year-old addict who broke the embrace to inhale from a white plastic bag containing an amber puddle of glue. ''It dulls the hunger and warms the cold.''
The police blame the children for much of the omnipresent crime that has turned this city of broad avenues and volcanic ravines into an urban battle ground. Under intense pressure to control what is widely seen as spreading anarchy, the authorities have cracked down. Officers often punish the street children by pouring glue on their heads, forcing them to shave their hair.
 
New Police Commander
But several recent investigations have determined that the police have also started a brutal campaign, similar to ''the dirty war'' against leftists that led to the deaths of tens of thousands of Guatemalans in the early 1980's. In one recent report, Children's Rights International, a Pennsylvania-based child advocacy group, found a pattern that ''includes extrajudicial executions, cruel and life-threatening extrajudicial punishments, beatings and attempts to intimidate witnesses to a fatal beating and the harassment of Covenant House street workers.''
Col. Julio Caballeros Selgne, a hard-liner who was recently appointed commander of the National Police, did not respond to repeated requests for interviews. But in the past the police have denied a pattern of abuse and have announced a program of ''street teachers,'' who are supposed to encourage children to enter special centers.
Under increasing pressure, the police arrested four officers in the death of Nahaman. But Mr. Harris, noting that no Guatemalan security officer has ever been convicted of human-rights abuse, said he was skeptical that they would be prosecuted.
''The kids never believed they had any rights, they never have had any trust,'' he said. ''If they let the four policemen out, I'm concerned it will destroy the little faith they now have.''

His tombstone read, ''I only wanted to be a child, and they wouldn't let me.'' (Vince Heptig)

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Swarthmore;
Governing Board Lifts the Curtain On Its Decisions

DATELINE: SWARTHMORE, Pa.

 BODY:
In an effort to demystify decision-making at Swarthmore College, the school's board of managers last weekend opened its doors for the first time to designated student and faculty observers.
The governing board decided in May to allow two students and two faculty members to attend its quarterly meetings and observe firsthand how the board makes its decisions.
''We didn't want the decision-making procedure to be a mystery,'' said J. Lawrence Shane, the board member who was chairman of an ad hoc board committee that recommended the change. 
Neil Austrian, the board's chairman, said the observers were not full board members and were not expected to engage in discussions as actively as members do. He said they were barred from executive sessions dealing with personnel, salaries and other confidential matters.
 
Opinions to Be Sought
Nevertheless the observers will ''from time to time be called upon for their views and opinions'' and will relay general impressions and issues from meetings to the rest of the community, Mr. Austrian said.
The Student Council selected one student for a one-year term and one for a two-year term after soliciting applications from juniors and seniors. The faculty observers were appointed to similar terms by the Council on Faculty Procedures, which regularly assigns teachers to various campus committees.
For the last few years the Student Council has requested student participation at board meetings so students would be included in decisions that affect them. But until May, the board hesitated to allow observers for fear of stifling discussion.
Mr. Shane said that while he was unaware of a similar push for faculty representation, ''we felt having both groups observing would be a very positive thing.'' He said student and faculty observers would attend meetings for at least the next two years, after which the board will evaluate their effectiveness.
Mr. Austrian said he ''didn't feel that discussion was inhibited in any way'' because of the presence of observers at the last meeting.
 
Narrowing a Gap
Karen Fank, a student observer, said: ''There has been a big rift between the students and the board. That gap has to be filled in order for students to have a legitimate voice here.''
Ms. Fank, a senior political science major from Hamilton Square, N.J., said she wanted to observe meetings to help narrow the gap.
Although Ms. Fank was unable to attend the main portion of the meeting because of a previously scheduled law school exam, she said the interactions she did have with board members were positive. ''I really felt that I was taken seriously,'' she said.
Stephanie Hirsch, the other student observer, said, ''I thought the board members acted in good faith.'' A junior English major from Eau Claire, Wis., she said that although the observers did not speak during the meeting, they were able to talk informally during breaks and at a dinner.
One of the faculty observers, Bernard Saffran, an economics professor, said that while there had not been communication problems with the faculty in the past, having observers ''is a very useful, helpful thing.''
''The more people know about what everyone else is doing, the better people are,'' Professor Saffran said. ''Too much secrecy can get in the way of decision-making.''
The other faculty observer is Nathalie Anderson of the English department.
The observers plan to disseminate information to the community through faculty meetings, the student newspaper and a public debriefing after each meeting.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Raising the Architectural Ante In California

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

DATELINE: LA JOLLA, Calif.

 BODY:
Few careers in architecture are as vexing as that of Michael Graves. From academic modernist in the 70's to post-modernist superstar in the 80's, he could turn in the 90's into a venerable elder statesman or a tired has-been. It's a matter not only of Mr. Graves's architecture but of our architectural culture, of which his career has for years been a kind of crucible. He rode the wave of architectural celebrity as it mounted in the early 1980's, becoming almost a cult figure after his first large-scale works, the Portland Building in Portland, Ore., and the headquarters of Humana Inc. in Louisville, Ky., were completed. He argued persuasively for an expanded role for the architect, designing everything from furniture to teakettles, although when he turned to Bloomingdale's shopping bags, he seemed less like a man eager to broaden the arena of serious design than one willing to put his name on anything that could be sold.
The fiasco of Mr. Graves's three unbuilt schemes for additions to the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, all of which have been criticized (sometimes excessively) as being unsympathetic to the original Whitney building by Marcel Breuer, did his reputation no more good. By the end of the decade, a lot of people had begun to find his work both self-conscious and tiresome. 
Yet through all this, Mr. Graves has continued to design buildings that can be described not only as serious but as reminders that he possesses one of the few truly original American architectural voices of our time. His style, which is a kind of classicism filtered through the lens of cubism, blends elements of several architectural vernaculars - he seems particularly to favor the buildings of the American Southwest and the Spanish Mission style - with Italianate classicism, bathing it all in a rich palette of deep and sensuous color. It will never be un-self-conscious - its virtues are more those of the mannerist than the naif - but at its best it can exert a powerful pull.
I have never been so sure that Mr. Graves's work comes off best at large scale: his unquestioned triumphs, buildings like the library at San Juan Capistrano, Calif., or the redesign of the interiors of the Newark Museum, are fairly small in size. By contrast, the Portland Building is awkward, and Humana, although striking, works mainly because of the elegance of his materials and the inventiveness of its detailing. The two large hotels Mr. Graves recently completed at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., have spectacular Graves-designed fabrics and furnishings on the inside, but their exterior proportions are so far from graceful that it makes one think Mr. Graves may be the only major architect who consistently tries to make a virtue out of clunkiness.
But here at La Jolla, 10 miles north of San Diego, Mr. Graves may have finally proved that he can do convincing large-scale, commercial work. On a hilly, 11-acre site beside Interstate 5, he has just finished a project called the Aventine, named after one of the seven hills of Rome, and it is the smoothest intersection yet between Mr. Graves's style and the demands of conventional real-estate development. Mr. Graves has contended for years that his architecture was neither so strange visually nor so daunting economically that it could not be put up by real-estate developers, and here we have proof that it can, indeed, be done. The Aventine is both striking and appealing - not only one of the few suburban high-rise complexes with real architectural identity but one of the only such projects that try to bring to a suburban site some sense of urbanity.
The $150 million project consists of a 16-story, 400-room Hyatt Regency hotel, an 11-story office building, a health club and four restaurants. The buildings are sheathed in red Indian sandstone on their lower floors, with maize- and tan-colored stucco above. As in most of Mr. Graves's buildings, the geometries are strong: the Hyatt is a slab topped by a low arc, the health club a circular drum, and the office building a cluster of shapes - an oblong low box, a high box with a gabled roof, and a silolike tower. Linking the various sections of this composition of circles and rectangles is a series of pergolas, fountains and courtyards that raise the project above the level of a simple exercise in basic geometries and create a degree of urbanistic interest for the pedestrian.
These buildings were built on a tight budget, like Mr. Graves's Disney hotels, the Dolphin and the Swan. But they are calmer, lower key, than the Disney buildings, in which the intensity of the design sometimes feels like a device to distract us from the underlying cheapness. Here, paradoxically, the effect of lowering the voltage is a sense of greater richness.
The facade of the La Jolla hotel, for example, lacks the spectacular effect of the Swan and the Dolphin, with their huge sculptured figures and swoops of color. But neither does it have the flatness that is so off-putting in those buildings; the gridded windows of the Hyatt are set in slightly from the facade, a small device that means everything in terms of giving the facade texture and depth, making it feel like a real masonry building, which is necessary for Mr. Graves's architecture to work as it should. The sandstone, yellowish stucco and panels of dark green make a superb palette of colors.
Inside, the lobby is understated and modest, but perfectly dignified, with marble-clad columns, handsome hanging light fixtures in glass bowls, Josef Hoffmann chairs and Graves-designed rugs. Stairs lead down from the lobby to the building's great hall, a two-story lounge with potted palms, restaurants, more Graves rugs and a virtual catalogue of Hoffmann furniture. The space is in the spirit of the grand lounges of classic resort hotels, and true to form it leads out to terraces, an immense pool with striped cabanas, and tennis courts. Upstairs, the corridors, elevators and small but serviceable guest rooms are all by Mr. Graves.
The low drum of the health club, clad all in red sandstone, is the visual centerpiece of the project, separating the hotel from the office structure. Its round form, topped by a rotunda, is the hinge on which the whole project turns, re-enacting at large scale the sense of rotation provided by the small rotundas Mr. Graves loves to use inside his buildings.
On the other side of the health club is the office structure, which Mr. Graves broke up into several sections to reduce its sense of mass. For all that this device serves its intended purpose, the office building may still be the least successful element of the project, if only because it seems to wear its classicism on its sleeve, taking itself much more seriously than the rest of the Aventine. (There is a rotunda off the lobby with a piece of Roman sculpture, a headless figure in a toga - not the sort of thing your average office lobby contains.) Yet the details are strong here, and the overall layout, which yields a subtly angled forecourt, is excellent. On balance, the Aventine is most remarkable as a composition, as a series of buildings that, for all their idiosyncrasy, come together in masterly fashion to create what virtually every other suburban high-rise development lacks: a sense of place.
From the freeway the Aventine is a compelling presence, and if its rich color and powerful geometric form are not what we expect from the suburban landscape (making it not surprising that conservative La Jolla is said to have been slow to warm to the project), it nonetheless raises the architectural ante in the realm of Southern California commercial real estate. Here Michael Graves's own architectural language meets the demands of the real world, and both come off the better for the encounter.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Graves's Hyatt Regency hotel in La Jolla and, left, the building's great hall-bringing urbanity to a Southern California (David Hewitt/Anne Garrison)
