HEADLINE: THEATER;
Behind the Painted World of 'Once On This Island'

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
In a time when sets for Broadway musicals can bump and grind with expensive mechanical wizardry and special effects, the design for ''Once on This Island'' is notable for its almost total reliance on extreme simplicity and hand-painted surfaces. The set for this fable-like Caribbean musical, which arrives on Broadway at the Booth Theater on Thursday, consists primarily of three walls and a floor painted with motifs of tropical vegetation. This framework exudes a sense of handmade and homemade more usual to a small, lovingly impastoed canvas or a spontaneously decorated folk art object in an intimate art gallery setting than to theater's communal space.
The ''Island'' set is the work of Loy Arcenas, a 37-year-old designer, born and raised in the Philippines, who has a growing list of regional and Off Broadway theater credits. About his style, Mr. Arcenas, who himself speaks sparely, says: ''I tend to be very lean. You don't have to fill the stage with a lot of things. What you need is the right moment with the right light. The design should be there to help. It has to flow with the way the play is written.'' 
Mr. Arcenas's esthetic of leanness was clearly at work in his pared-down sets for last season's ''Spunk,'' where a lone tree and a slatted backdrop reminiscent of a barn or shanty did most of the scenic work, and in ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' much of which takes place on an empty stage pierced by a heavily framed window into what seems like infinity. And it was especially pronounced in his designs for the original version of ''Once on This Island,'' seen Off Broadway last spring to great critical acclaim at Playwrights Horizons.
But what shines in the intimate embrace of small theater doesn't always translate to big-time, as Mr. Arcenas knows. His attempts to scale up the original ''Prelude'' set, his first design to move to Broadway (it had opened at the Circle Rep), did not elicit critical praise. In fact, Frank Rich, who had given the play a rave review in The Times, compared the scenic revisions to Stonehenge. And ''Island'' seemed to have the words ''small'' and ''intimate'' written all over it.
Based on the novel ''My Love, My Love'' by the Trinidadian author Rosa Guy, and with lyrics by Lynn Ahrens and music by Stephen Flaherty, ''Once on This Island'' is a model of expressive economy. Its circular tale of star-crossed love between a black peasant girl named Ti Moune and a mulatto aristocrat, or ''grandhomme,'' named Daniel, unfolds in 90 uninterrupted minutes of song and dance, storytelling and mime.
While the show's music shifts from calypso to African to soul, the story, which is set on a Caribbean island identified only as ''the jewel of the Antilles,'' moves from village hut to rain-drenched highway to luxurious city dwelling and back again. Similarly, the play's small, versatile cast of 11 assumes the various roles of storytellers and listeners, meddlesome gods, superstitious peasants or gossipy grandhommes.
At Playwrights Horizons, events had transpired on a stage that was small and without wings - far more constrained than the fully equipped stage at the Booth. Mr. Arcenas's solution to the space limitations at Playwrights, worked out with the play's director and choreographer Graciela Daniele, was to leave the stage almost entirely to the performers and to treat its enclosing surfaces like a painter's canvas.
The backdrop and side walls were painted with images of naively drawn palm trees and low undulating hills against a sky of deep patchy blue, while the floor was stained with green and brown, dotted with orange flowers and bordered with red. And all this with no loss of versatility. Despite its illusion of painted opacity, the back wall of the set was actually a scrim that would dissolve at certain points to reveal a starry night, hanging lanterns or the play's musicians.
The sources for Mr. Arcenas's Chagall-goes-tropical look include Rousseau, Matisse, Hockney, Mexican and Filipino Christmas ornaments, American weather vanes and Haitian metalwork. (Despite his stripped-down approach, Mr. Arcenas is also someone who says, ''I love the idea of found objects, of a borrowed look grabbed from different sources.'') The do-it-yourself improvisational quality of the play's few props maintains the story's fantasy aspect, yet also seems true to a reality where craft, ritual and poverty are all longstanding traditions.
The rain summoned by the water god Agwe, which causes Daniel's Mercedes to skid off the road and delivers him temporarily into the arms of Ti Moune, is conjured when the cast members enter carrying macabre yet festive black umbrellas draped with long strands of plastic. Daniel's room in the grandhomme mansion on the other side of the island is indicated by the descent of a large white patchwork quilt. And the flat, painted-wood figurative candelabra wheeled in for the dance at the grandhomme ball, where Ti Moune first meets Daniel's light-skinned fiancee, bring to mind an itinerate salesman's wagon or a traveling puppet show.
The strong marriage of folk motifs with sophisticated minimalist touches is hardly surprising, given Mr. Arcenas's background. The son of a doctor father and a banker mother, he abandoned pre-med studies at the University of the Philippines to become stage manager for the Manila Symphony, where classical fare alternated with fully staged 45-minute versions of opera and Broadway musicals. His sensibility was given more definition a few years later when he went to London and enrolled in the design course at the English National Opera. There, one of his teachers, Hayden Griffin, kept telling his students to eliminate as much as possible, stressing an approach that started from a single environment rather than building scene by scene. ''He would say you have to start from scratch,'' Mr. Arcenas said, ''and put in only what is necessary; otherwise you end up with decoration, and that's not stage design.''
Like an artist in his studio, Mr. Arcenas has spent a fair amount of time during the last three weeks waiting for paint to dry, worrying that his colors aren't deep enough or his surfaces not textured enough. The crew at the Booth learned how to use palette knives and he admits to ''driving the shop crazy. I think they thought it was going to be very simple, but they had to go over and over it to get the roughness we wanted. Otherwise it would have been just cute.''
It seems that the set has weathered the trip uptown in excellent form. In contrast to his ''Prelude'' expansions, it may even be that Mr. Arcenas has turned the demands of the Booth stage to his advantage, making simple additions and subtle expansions that may not only maintain the intimacy, but also clarify the esthetic character of his original set.
Some changes are relatively minor. The quilt, painted palm trees and candelabra have all been somewhat enlarged. The umbrellas are a little gaudier, adding to their sinister, voodoo quality. The brightly flowered tree, reminiscent of a papier-mache garland that descends at the story's end to symbolize the soul of Ti Moune, now does so in three stages. The side walls protrude several feet in from each side, keeping the stage area almost as small as it was at Playwrights and enabling the relatively small cast to maintain the play's compressed, roiling energy, despite the larger theater.
A most significant addition is a proscenium arch, a not unusual solution in translations from smaller to larger theaters. But this arch is a big red Caribbean-flavored post-and-lintel portal, seemingly carpentered of leftover packing crates and painted with stencil-like images of birds and leaves. All these changes, but the portal most of all, push forward the handmade folk-art aspect of the set, making it even more clear-cut than it was at Playwrights Horizons.
Musically, dramatically and visually, ''Once on This Island'' comes across as such a carefully crafted unit that it almost seems to be the work of one person, which also makes it an unusually clear illustration of the collaborative character of theater. The simple folkloric costumes and occasional masks, the work of Judy Dearing, are of a piece with Mr. Arcenas's setting. And Allen Lee Hughes's lighting adds effective suggestions of foliage or architecture, turning the painted blue sky to gold or red, or draining its color entirely. His efforts repeatedly ring in changes of place, weather or emotional tone and further animate Mr. Arcenas's carefully worked surfaces.
''It's not scenic painting, it is a painting,'' says Mr. Arcenas, sounding very much the artist. But his sense of teamwork is never far from the surface. ''My best designs happen when the director and I hit it off very, very well. If I don't have a Ping-Pong game of ideas, the design can be rather stale. Once the concept is in place, it's easy to fill in the blanks.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Loy Arcenas and his set for ''Once on This Island''-Simple, hand-painted images evoke the show's Caribbean setting (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 2920 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
What on Earth Is the Guggenheim Up To?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City is to all outward appearances on hiatus, closed to visitors for another year, until construction ends on an annex. But in fact a kind of revolution is under way there, one that could have an impact well beyond the walls of Frank Lloyd Wright's spiral building - one that it is no exaggeration to say could alter the way art museums across the country do business and visitors experience these places.
During his roughly two-year tenure as director, Thomas Krens has proposed sweeping changes to transform what he seems to believe was a financially and intellectually moribund institution on upper Fifth Avenue into the cultural equivalent of a multinational conglomerate, with branches around the world, money pouring into the coffers and accolades showered on the high-profile team of curators he has assembled. To the cries of poverty that nowadays issue from virtually every public gallery in this country he has responded with a scheme holding out the promise of an enlarged collection and a burgeoning audience of grateful and enthusiastic visitors. Everyone is to benefit. The whole thing sounds too good to be true - and for many of America's leading museum professionals, who privately express reservations about Mr. Krens's strategies, it is. Mr. Krens and his colleagues at the Guggenheim contend that skepticism is the price of change, and even express some pride in the stir that has been caused. ''New York is a tough place, but it also respects achievement,'' said Mr. Krens recently in a wide-ranging conversation. ''You have to take some unpopular positions. If we are not strong enough to withstand moral and ethical challenges, then we shouldn't be here.''
The director believes that he has devised plans to prepare the museum for the fiscal and artistic realities of the late 20th century. But never has this question seemed more troubling or more pressing: At what cost progress?
To hear Mr. Krens, his staff and trustees tell it, the plans can seem inspiring. The Guggenheim owns one of the great collections of 20th-century European art. It has a branch in Europe, the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice. The vast majority of the roughly 6,000 works at the New York museum - as at many museums - is consigned to storage, since the Wright building provides exhibition space for only a fraction of the collection, and while the director says the annex will increase the room for display by more than half, the museum will still not be able to show most of its art when it reopens.
Why not find a way to exhibit the works in storage and, at the same time, use them to generate much-needed cash? And, if the situation presents itself, why not exhibit them abroad, at what are the equivalent of Guggenheim franchises? After all, the museum already has an international affiliation, and wouldn't it be better to care for the works at one's own franchise than to entrust these objects to other institutions? ''I would much rather lend to ourselves than anyone else,'' Mr. Krens says.
With the added money and space to be gained from the franchises, the museum could enhance its collection, expanding its holdings in the art of the last several decades, thereby fulfilling its role as a museum of the 20th century - the entire century. Few museums in the world are equipped to display the sort of monumental art that has become commonplace since the 1950's, including Minimalist sculpture. The Guggenheim, with its franchises, could become one of the few, and this, in turn, would make it all the more attractive to contemporary artists, who might donate or sell works to the museum.
Best of all, the cost of these franchised Guggenheims could be absorbed by the local governments, which would essentially be paying for the privilege of having part of a great collection on view, administered by a staff of Guggenheim curators. The Guggenheim itself would undertake no financial risk, Mr. Krens contends. And New Yorkers would benefit from a financially fortified museum, with a wider selection of works to go on view, many of them rotated from the franchises for occasional display on Fifth Avenue.
There would be other benefits. At a time when rising insurance costs and other problems make it more expensive and more complex to organize the sort of multi-museum loan exhibitions that have become a staple of the art world, the Guggenheim would be in a position to stage its own international touring shows, drawn from its own broad collection. What could be more sensible?
This, at least, is roughly how Mr. Krens and others at the museum explain their recent activities, which, on closer examination, seem to push at the edge of what has been standard museum practice and policy, and raise questions about the Guggenheim's commitment to safeguarding its collection.
 
Do Dangers Lurk In the Bond Sale?
 One key area involves the unusual way the museum has financed, through $54.9 million in tax-exempt bonds, the annex off Fifth Avenue and renovations on the existing building, an expansion plan initiated under Mr. Krens's predecessor, Thomas Messer. Mr. Krens describes the financing as a matter of economic necessity and prudent fiscal judgment. As he points out, cultural institutions like the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art have also issued bonds to finance building projects.
But at both of those institutions the full amounts of the bond issues were secured by funds from the endowments of the museums or from other sources, funds set aside as collateral for the bonds.
This is not the situation at the Guggenheim, where no collateral was put aside and a general agreement was made by the museum to honor its financial obligations. The Guggenheim's endowment is roughly $30 million, considerably less than the amount of the bonds. In negotiating its deal with Swiss Bank Corporation, which has supplied the museum with a letter of credit to secure the bonds, Mr. Krens and his colleagues refused to pledge works of art or the building as a guarantee against default.
Instead, they have come up with what they believe are conservative estimates of the financial growth of the museum, based on a fund-raising drive, higher revenues from a much-enlarged restaurant and bookstore, and an increase in annual attendance from roughly 500,000 to 750,000, despite a projected hike in the admission price from $4.50 to between $6.50 and $7.
Should trouble occur, the museum insists it will be able to avoid selling art. But nothing in the deal precludes the possibility, and Mr. Krens acknowledges that the value of certain paintings came up in discussions about the museum's assets with representatives of Swiss Bank. The bank would not say whether it supplied a letter of credit based on assessments about the Guggenheim's financial strength that took the art into account.
 
Is the Deaccessioning Going Too Far?
 It might be easier to feel comfort in the museum's contention that it would do everything necessary to safeguard the national treasure that is its permanent collection had Mr. Krens and the trustees not taken the troubling step last spring of selling, or deaccessioning, three important paintings.
Many museums sell works from their collections. But few museums lately have done anything involving works as valuable as the paintings by Modigliani, Chagall and Kandinsky that the Guggenheim sold at auction for $47 million - paintings that many other public institutions would have been proud to own. The canvases were sold to pay for more than 200 works from the 1960's and 70's owned by Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo, some of which are only plans on paper.
The museum maintains that the works it sold were either lesser examples by artists already strongly represented in the Guggenheim, as with the Kandinsky, or lesser versions of paintings in other New York collections, as with the Chagall. In return, the museum's collecting activities have received what Mr. Krens calls a kick-start. He insists that the sales were the only way for the museum to raise the roughly $30 million needed for the Panza collection, since it was unreasonable to assume that the Guggenheim, which had not solicited donations on a major scale in years, could find the necessary benefactors in time to buy the collection. He adds that the deal restores some of the artistic heritage of New York by bringing back to the city works that were made here.
Mr. Krens does not mention that the Panza collection had been on the market for years, and that perhaps a more cautious approach would have delayed the sale of at least one of the paintings to see how much the others fetched at auction. Nor does he seem to have considered the possibility of selling the works to other public institutions, as occurred recently when a painting by Thomas Eakins was sold across the street from the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth to the Amon Carter Museum. As it happened, the three Guggenheim works went into private hands.
Mr. Krens repeatedly cites instances of sales by other museums and of financing deals for construction projects by museums outside New York City that resemble the Guggenheim's bond issue. It is also true that the Guggenheim is hardly the first institution to exploit the merchandising possibilities of an enlarged bookstore and restaurant.
In fact, to the nonprofit world of the museum - where the priorities have traditionally been on scholarship, connoisseurship and the conservation of art - the 43-year-old Mr. Krens brings what looks very much like a 1980's brand of corporate strategy, with its emphasis on multinational operations, splashy marketing techniques and risky ventures. The director with a master's degree in business from Yale is clearly hoping that what proved calamitous for businesses will be good for the Guggenheim.
 
Is Franchising The Right Route?
 Nothing points to this attitude more strongly than the prospective franchising of the Guggenheim. The Whitney Museum of American Art has several satellites around Manhattan and in Connecticut. But the Guggenheim is the first to explore the project on such an international scale. As to why the museum does not seek a place in or near New York at which to exhibit more of its collection, Mr. Krens again says that it would not be feasible to raise the money, although money has been raised for a modernized storage and conservation facility on the West Side of Manhattan, not open to the public. Instead, he is involved in feasibility studies for a site in Salzburg, Austria, a second site in Venice, and a site in the economically depressed town of North Adams, Mass., where he proposed three years ago - while still director of the Williams College Museum of Art in Williamstown, Mass. - the idea of transforming a gigantic abandoned complex of industrial buildings into the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art. According to staff members, the Guggenheim has agreed in principle to run Mass Moca, as it is called, like one of its franchises, if the state of Massachusetts comes up with some $35 million. Mr. Krens has also talked about Guggenheims in Japan and Spain.
There are many reasons to be concerned about such talk, for despite the museum's assurances that the works of art will be cared for properly, travel of any kind puts objects at risk. The prospect of having large portions of the Guggenheim's holdings rotating every several weeks or months or even years from one site to another around the world should cause alarm if only because the odds of a disaster inevitably increase as the number of traveling objects goes up.
And the number must rise, between the loans the museum will make to other institutions and the works it will need to put on view in the franchises if they develop as Mr. Krens hopes. Why, it can be asked, should paintings and sculptures donated to the Guggenheim with the implicit understanding that they contribute to the cultural life of New York be put at any risk for the sake of franchises in Salzburg or Tokyo?
There may also be a certain callousness in the Guggenheim's decision to entertain offers from Salzburg in particular, a city that, unlike New York, has no connection to 20th-century art, in a country whose reputation for anti-Semitism has not been lessened by the election of Kurt Waldheim.
To the possibility that the Guggenheim's collection - put together by prominent American Jews - might serve as a public relations device for Austria, Mr. Krens said only that Mr. Waldheim would probably be out of office by the time the museum opened.
As for Mass Moca, projections of a prosperous institution are based in part on attendance figures at places like the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute and the Williams College Museum of Art in Williamstown, a charming college town that could hardly be less like North Adams. Should the financial projections turn out to be wrong, the Guggenheim could find itself in a dilemma. On the one hand it can, as Mr. Krens says, simply walk away from the project, having built up the hopes of the people of North Adams for a revival of their town only to abandon them. It can, on the other hand, demonstrate the commitment to the community that would seem to be a fundamental purpose of any museum by investing money in the project, thus further taxing the Guggenheim's already strained resources.
But even if estimates of the financial situation prove accurate, Mass Moca and the other franchises could drain the Guggenheim in different ways. It is logical to argue - contrary to what Mr. Krens and his curators claim - that for the Guggenheim's staff to make of these smaller institutions something substantial would require an investment of time that could have been spent on New York.
So far, say Mark Rosenthal and Carmen Gimenez - two curators on a team that also includes Germano Celant and Diane Waldman - plans for the exhibitions and long-term displays in these franchises have not been formed, although there are vague ideas about mixing large- and small-scale works from different periods and about developing extensive holdings of works by certain contemporary artists.
The impression that real estate and international gamesmanship figure as prominently in the Guggenheim's planning as scholarship has only been enhanced by the addition to the museum's board of businessmen and politicians able to exercise influence over the projected franchises, like Gianni de Michelis, the Italian Foreign Minister, whose insensitivity to issues of cultural patrimony and whose inclinations to exploit art for financial purposes were suggested by his endorsement of the now-canceled Venice Expo 2000, a world's fair that would have further taxed an already fragile and overpopulated city. The impression has also been enhanced by the Guggenheim's recent schedule of exhibitions, including displays in Salzburg, Tokyo, Madrid and Venice of works from the permanent collection plus a Mondrian show in Venice, all of which serve to underscore to prospective partners the depth of the museum's holdings.
An exhibition in New York of works by Mario Merz, organized by Mr. Celant, and an installation by Jenny Holzer, organized by Ms. Waldman, dealt sensitively with the limitations of Wright's spiral design. But Mr. Krens's own disastrous exhibition of German painting last year, the major artistic undertaking at the museum under his tenure, was so crammed with gigantic paintings that it seemed designed to demonstrate the director's predilection for size as a virtue in itself and at the same time to argue for the annex.
 
A Course Fraught With Hazards
 It must be said that courting curators like Mr. Rosenthal - who has been responsible for such outstanding exhibitions as the retrospective of Anselm Kiefer that came to the Museum of Modern Art in New York in 1988 - suggests a measure of seriousness about art on the part of Mr. Krens that his own exhibition lacked. Mr. Rosenthal is not a full-time staff member, however. He works as both adviser to private collectors and consultant to the Guggenheim.
Mr. Rosenthal's first exhibition will be a large-scale study of abstraction. Ms. Gimenez is working on a display, planned to coincide with the celebrations of the 500th anniversary in 1992 of the voyages of Columbus, that mixes art from the Americas and Europe. Mr. Celant is organizing a show of Italian art of the 1950's. Any full assessment of the Guggenheim under Mr. Krens must, obviously, await these events.
But what already seems evident is that the director has put forward bold ideas. At a moment when cooperation among public institutions might seem like the most constructive response to economic challenges, Mr. Krens is proposing an increasingly self-sustained institution. Most important, he appears to be acting not as the bulwark against the inclinations of business-minded board members - a role museum directors elsewhere have always considered crucial - but as a fellow entrepreneur, one who deals in art as a currency of trade. And for this reason especially, what he does will surely interest board members at other institutions, who may pressure their directors to follow him.
Mr. Krens has chosen to sail his museum on a course fraught with hazards. For the sake of not only the Guggenheim and the city of New York but also for the sake of cultural life in the cities across the country where museums look to his lead, one can only hope he doesn't run aground.

HEADLINE: Mike Milken: Robin Hood or Sheriff of Nottingham?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The sentencing of Michael Milken (''What Punishment Will Fit the Crime?'' Sept. 30) causes me to ask, what value did he create for the American economy? His ''innovations'' are akin to a pyramid scheme. The ''junk bonds'' that flooded the market are being discounted. The pension funds that rushed to buy them and the high-yield mutual funds which were peddled by brokers have large losses. Milken a modern version of Robin Hood? Ha.
 
LISA STEIN

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Enter the Dollar, Stage Left, Falling, Falling

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
In the fall of 1990, there has been no shortage of crises, with great attention being paid to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the budget deadlock, the plight of the banks and the plunging stock market.
But the slide of the dollar has not been deemed of much note. There is no outcry, in Washington or Wall Street. Perhaps there should be. 
There was far more attention paid Friday to the latest reported inflation figure, unsurprisingly showing that soaring oil costs pushed up producer prices last month. But if inflation is viewed as the declining value of a currency, it may be more relevant to note that the dollar last week lost 1.6 percent of its value against the West German mark, and is down 11.1 percent so far this year.
The lack of attention paid to the descending dollar can be traced in part to the fact that currencies have been volatile for years, creating an attitude that what goes down will bounce back. But this move may be more significant, with the drop coming despite a world crisis of the type that used to send flight capital to the safety of the United States. Now, that money seems to be more comfortable in Germany, or even in Japan, the scene of the greatest financial market carnage in 1990.
The message may be that the fiscal irresponsibility of the United States finally has scared investors around the world. The Government in the 80's served as the guarantor of debts for everything from trade school students to real estate promoters. Now, as those guarantees are called, the suspicion is that the Government may end up with little choice but to print more and more dollars to meet its obligations.
For foreign investors, the meaning is that asset values in this country are falling even faster than they appear to be from an American perspective. The Dow's fall of 112.62 points last week, to 2,398.02, was a 4.5 percent drop in dollars, but a 6.0 percent plunge in marks. By either measure, it was the market's worst week in a year. Falling asset values smack of deflation, but a collapsing currency would bring hyperinflation. The two results can occur simultaneously, as third world residents know. In local currencies, asset prices there are far higher than they ever were in the 70's. But in terms of hard currencies, those assets have fallen sharply.
Had Brazil been allowed to borrow cruzeiros instead of dollars in the 70's, there would be no anxious bankers now worrying about debt restructuring talks. They would already have suffered, as Brazil repaid its loans with a devalued currency. It is possible that, in the end, that is what the United States will do.
In Washington, the fears are of recession and of voters who will retaliate if asked to pay taxes to support cherished entitlements. Despite the dollar's woes, there is heavy pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.
Harry S. Truman used to say ''the buck stops here.'' But with George Bush seeming to have no idea what he wants to do about the deficit, other than to find someone else to blame, chances are that the buck's decline will not stop here.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
What Investors Want to Know

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The bear market, the looming recession and the crisis in the Persian Gulf have made everyone jumpy. Investors in mutual funds are showing their anxiety by monitoring their accounts more closely than usual: Telephone calls from investors surged in August and are still coming in at higher-than-normal levels at many funds, marketers at many large fund groups say. What follows is a sampling of the most commonly asked questions and an amalgam of answers from fund managers, economists and other experts.
Question: With the Middle East in turmoil and a recession near, what's going to happen in the financial markets? 
Answer: Nobody knows, of course, because nobody knows whether a war will, in fact, break out. Nor does anyone know just how long - or how deep - a recession might be. But clearly, economic turbulence and uncertainty are not the stuff of market rallies, and one thing seems quite certain: The high-flying investment returns of the roaring 1980's are long gone.
Q. What will happen to my funds if war does break out?
A. Government bond prices might dip in response to inflation fears and then rebound strongly as investors make a headlong stampede to quality, says C. Frazier Evans, senior economist with the Boston-based Colonial Group. He says tax-exempt bond funds stand to benefit because governments usually finance wars by raising taxes, and higher taxes make tax-free income more valuable.
As for stock funds, a war could create ''bargain prices that might not be seen again for a generation,'' said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J. An extended conflict would also push up levels of spending in science and technology. Other likely beneficiaries: energy and natural resource funds.
Q. What's the best place to invest now?
A. Given the uncertainty, diversifying your investments makes more sense than usual. Today, many people have a large chunk of their portfolios in stock funds because stocks performed so well in the last decade, said Cornelia M. Small, director of research for the Scudder Group. But you may want to realign the balance among stock, bond and money-market funds. Adding foreign investments to the mix - but cautiously - also helps reduce risk.
One caveat: Even if your fund group does not assess a fee for switching money among funds, any switch that you make is treated as a sale for tax purposes.
Looking ahead, keep in mind that when the economy slumps, the weakest companies are hit hardest. Quality concerns are already reflected in bond funds, where the yield spread between government and ''junk bond'' funds widened in August.
Q. So should I move out of stock funds?
A. Despite the value of diversification, don't overreact. It doesn't make sense to bail out when prices are so low, and if you have made investments to meet long-term goals, stick by them. You may even want to add shares in stock funds to take advantage of price declines. This is a good time, experts say, to begin dollar-cost averaging - investing set amounts over regular intervals to bring down the average cost of the investment.
Q. What are the fund managers doing to minimize my losses?
A. Some managers are reducing their market exposure by building up large cash reserves. James Craig, who manages the Janus Fund, now has about three-quarters of his fund's assets in cash. Others have to remain invested according to fund bylaws. Vanguard, for example, keeps 90 percent of its assets in stocks. Fund managers should be able to tell you their current cash levels. And some funds, under their bylaws, can use options and futures to protect against falling markets. Check your fund's prospectus.
Q. Should I buy gold funds?
A. The runup in gold prices that began when Iraq invaded Kuwait is already over. But investments in gold traditionally are viewed as good hedges in times of economic and political instability. Nonetheless, gold is an extremely volatile investment. Most investors probably should keep no more than 5 percent of their portfolios in gold.
Q. Why has the price of my government bond fund shifted so much recently?
A. Remember, the ''government guarantee'' on these bonds means the principal is guaranteed when the bonds mature. But interim fluctuations can send the price all over the map. The threat of inflation pushed down bond prices in August, for example, but they stabilized last month. For long-term investors, the interim price fluctuations are unimportant. If you only bought your shares recently, it may pay to wait to sell them.
 
CLOSED-END FUNDS IN SYNC, AGAIN
As a group, closed-end stock funds followed the market downward in the third quarter, losing 14.59 percent against a 14.86 percent drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. Prices for closed-end funds, which trade on listed exchanges like stock, are set by supply and demand and fund shares trade at a premium or discount to the value of the stocks in their portfolios.
Third-quarter performance was a change from the first half. Discounts on closed-end stock funds widened through the first half, meaning that share prices of closed-end funds did not keep pace with the value of the stocks in their portfolios. And the Herzfeld average, which tracks closed-end funds, lagged the Dow by an average of two percentage points through June. Discounts began to shrink in the third quarter, and the funds did a bit better than the market. ''Investors had a strong level of comfort in this group and didn't panic during the market rout,'' said Thomas J. Herzfeld, who specializes in closed-end funds.

HEADLINE: The Pedestrian Sneaker Makes a Comeback

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
They are advertisements with a wink. A playful young mother lies on her back and balances her giggling tot on her ankles and feet, which are clad in plain white canvas sneakers. The caption: ''Keds introduces weightlifting shoes.''
Barbara A. Scott, marketing vice president for Keds, says the intended message is ''you don't have to sweat your brains out to wear our shoes.''
That no-sweat marketing approach by Keds in its new television and print ads is a deliberate contrast to the frenetic athletes and dancers prancing through the typical sneakers commercial. So far, it has helped Keds capitalize on what many industry analysts say is a fundamental change in consumer preferences for casual footwear. Consumers seem to be moving back toward the mostly simple designs of sneakers that are Keds's staples. The shift is already hurting brands like L.A. Gear, whose sales of expensive shoes in elaborate designs and unusual color combinations have plummeted. 
Except for Nike Inc., the industry leader, most footwear companies have seen sales of their most expensive shoes drop off, while the less expensive, and therefore less profitable, brands continue to sell well. Largely because of this trend, Salomon Brothers estimates that 1990 industry sales, in terms of dollars, will grow 10 percent, compared with nearly 30 percent as recently as 1988.
There is much uncertainty in this part of the footwear industry. A lot of it stems from the fact that the companies are really more marketers than manufacturers. Many of the major companies get their shoes from the same factories in Taiwan and South Korea.
''Shoes are all basically the same,'' said David Lubars, whose Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners advertising agency developed the campaign for Keds. ''What you try to build is an image of what's cool and who wears the shoe.''
Owned by the Stride Rite Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., Keds has become the country's fourth-largest brand, overtaking Converse Inc., analysts say. Keds's casual footwear is not really in the same league as the brawny athletic shoes made by Nike and Reebok, or L.A. Gear's fashion sneakers. But analysts note that 80 percent or more of athletic shoes never go near a basketball or tennis court, anyway. Instead they wind up as street shoes worn around the house or out to the mall and movies.
Until recent months, Keds seemed to be out of favor. Sales had slowed so much that Stride Rite announced last December that it expected revenue to grow by just 10 percent in 1990. Stride Rite's stock plunged on the news, prompting a hostile takeover bid by Walsh Greenwood & Co., the Greenwich, Conn., investment concern, which Stride Rite successfully resisted.
Sales have rebounded since then and analysts are now projecting Keds's growth rate will top 20 percent, or double that of the industry, to $270 million in sales this year. Once known mainly as a children's brand, Keds have had especially strong appeal since the late 1980's to working mothers and professional women, who often buy several pairs. At about $20, these canvas sneakers cost a third of the average leather-bound Reeboks or Nikes, which average $60 or more.
Sales are sluggish or declining in much of the $5.3 billion athletic footwear industry, but analysts say Keds could still flourish in an economic recession because of their low price.
Hardest hit among the major companies has been L.A. Gear, the California-based company whose expensive fashionable shoes appeal mainly to young women. Earlier this summer, L.A. Gear announced a sharp drop in net income for the second quarter. Company officials cited reluctance by recession-conscious retailers to stock expensive footwear and sales volume moving toward cheaper L.A. Gear shoes. L.A. Gear's stock plummeted 22 percent. Recently, the company said the third-quarter net would also be down.
Nike continues to prosper using a powerful advertising campaign that features the multiathletic talents of Bo Jackson. With projected 1990 sales of more than $1.5 billion, Nike may post sales growth of 30 percent this year, coming on top of a 20 percent rise last year.
But even Nike's latest results disappointed investors accustomed to runaway growth. When Nike reported last month a first-quarter earnings rise of 31 percent, to $99.7 million, and a 38 percent gain in revenues, to $833.6 million, its stock fell. Nike closed Friday at $30, up $2 a share, in over-the-counter trading.
Reebok, at No. 2 with $1.3 billion in projected 1990 sales, said recently that it expects a third-quarter drop in profits and a flat year for earnings. Converse, Avia and Adidas are expected to show sales declines, analysts say. Most footwear stocks are trading near their 52-week lows.
''In the last six months, there has been a dramatic shift from fashion-oriented shoes back to basics,'' said Heidi R. Steinberg, a footwear analyst with Salomon Brothers. ''People don't want a lot of doodads anymore.''
Steven B. Frankel, an analyst with Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston, noted that Keds, lacking high profile endorsements by expensive celebrity athletes or rock stars, was in a good marketing position.
''Keds are not in as fickle a market as L.A. Gear,'' Mr. Frankel said. ''They don't need Michael Jackson. They don't need Bo Jackson. They are getting Mrs. Jackson from 1234 Anywhere Street, U.S.A.'' Reebok, for one, disagrees. Unlike most footwear companies, Reebok has managed to market its athletic shoes well to men and women, and says it is too early to tell if there has been a fundamental change.
''There's a lot of shifting back and forth going on out there,'' said David C. House, vice president for sales for the Reebok brand. ''Where it stops nobody knows.'' But like other footwear companies, Reebok is seeing an increase in the sales of its less expensive models.
Keds practically invented the sneaker. Around the turn of the century, shoemakers were gluing melted, or ''vulcanized,'' rubber onto canvas tops. In 1917, the U.S. Rubber company introduced Keds, the first popularly marketed sneaker, so nicknamed because the wearer's footsteps were so quiet.
The brand was originally named Peds, Latin for foot, but another company already had registered the name. So Keds, with its evocation of kids, was chosen instead. The first Keds had black soles and chestnut brown canvas tops.
Sneakers changed little until the 70's and early 80's, when nouveau sports like jogging and aerobics gained in popularity. Phil Knight, a runner at the University of Oregon, and his coach, Bill Bowerman, invented Nikes, named after the Greek goddess of victory, because they wanted shoes that were lighter and had better traction than the available tennis and basketball shoes. In the 80's, Reeboks, named after a swift African mammal resembling a gazelle, became popular mainly with women seeking comfortable shoes for aerobic exercises.
As those changes swept by, Keds's sales started sinking. The company tried to compete with a shoe called Pro-Keds, but sales were lackluster. ''Keds was left in the dust,'' said Ms. Scott, Keds's marketing vice president.
But the company noticed that its shoes had become fashionable among some young women who wanted simple sneakers. The shoes gained cachet from photos and mentions in fashion magazines showing them as complements to white pants and khaki shorts. They were also popular in places like beach towns in Southern California and the Soho district of Manhattan, possibly because they were inexpensive and were perhaps considered an ''anti-fashion'' fashion statement.
To expand the shoes' appeal more to young professional women, Keds in 1988 hired a small advertising agency in Providence, R.I., to develop a new approach.
The agency, Leonard Monahan Lubars, conducted interviews with consumers, known as focus groups, and asked them oddball questions like ''If Keds were a building, what kind of building would it be?'' One frequent answer: A country house with a white picket fence around it. Nike, by contrast, was often described as a glass-and-steel skyscraper. Those reactions ''told us a lot of things,'' said Mr. Lubars, executive vice president and creative director. ''It told us 'anti-athletic' might work.'' With a modest budget, it also meant the company would not need to hire expensive athletic stars to hawk the product.
Keds and the ad agency also came up with a new slogan: ''Keds. They Feel Good,'' that they hoped would attract young professionals while still evoking kid appeal. The television ads have the lighthearted approach of the print ads. One TV ad shows a couple playfully arguing. The woman throws a Keds shoe at the man. The tag line is, ''Introducing Keds debating shoes.''
Keds also expanded the product line. The shoes now come in about 20 styles and more than half a dozen colors. The basic design of a simple canvas top remained, however.
Since starting its new campaign, or what marketers call repositioning, Keds sales have boomed. Sales to retailers nearly quadrupled, to $227 million in 1989 from $60 million in 1986. Keds also grew from a quarter of Stride Rite's sales in 1986 to half in 1989.
Following its success with female customers, the next step for Keds is to get more men to buy the shoes, said Ms. Scott. Future ad campaigns will highlight Keds in a more masculine style.

HEADLINE: In Hollywood, Big Just Gets Bigger

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The growing foreign investment in the American entertainment industry, far from being a challenge to this country's longstanding dominance of the business, reflects a worldwide belief that only Hollywood can meet the rapidly expanding global demand for films, television shows and recorded music.
That is the view of industry executives and analysts, who point to the possible acquisition of MCA Inc., the parent of Universal Studios and MCA Records, by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Japan's largest electronics company, as the latest example of the trend.
Even as they attract foreign investors, Hollywood studios and other American entertainment concerns have expanded their output and consolidated into a relative handful of huge communications companies. They have been motivated largely by the belief that sheer size and financial clout will be essential to compete in making and distributing entertainment products both in the United States and abroad.
The result has been a transformation of the American entertainment industry. Over the last five years it has developed an international base of financing and ownership while companies have diversified into all aspects of the business, ranging from cable networks, television stations and movie theaters to videocassette recorders and satellites, all fed by Hollywood's unrivaled, if uneven, creative talents. 
''What Saudi Arabia is to oil, the United States is to entertainment,'' said Raymond Katz, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton, a subsidiary of American Express.
It remains unclear how extensively the changes that have swept the industry will influence the content or style of movies, television shows and recordings. It is also an open question whether bigger will prove to be better among entertainment companies, in creative terms or on the bottom line.
There is no question, however, that the industry has been altered permanently. If MCA is acquired by Matsushita and a pending deal for the MGM/UA Communications Corporation by an Italian investor, Giancarlo Parretti, is completed, five of the seven major studios will have been sold or merged into larger companies in the last five years. Four of the new owners will have come from abroad. At the same time, the number of smaller companies in the business has fallen dramatically as the Weintraub Entertainment Group, the De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and a host of others have collapsed, unable to weather a string of box-office flops or to compete with larger, better-financed rivals.
Moreover, film and television production has become just one element in a broader approach to the business. After long seeing broadcast and cable television and home video as competitors, studios have rushed into those fields. Many industry executives think it is only a matter of time before studios and the television networks begin merging.
Similarly, the Japanese makers of electronic ''hardware'' like videocassette recorders have plunged into the making of movies, television shows, music and other ''software,'' as demonstrated by Matsushita's interest in MCA and the Sony Corporation's acquisition in recent years of Columbia Pictures and CBS Records.
''IT'S been a period of the most dramatic change in the history of the industry,'' said Alan J. Hirschfield, a former head of Columbia Pictures and Twentieth Century Fox who is now a managing director at the investment firm of Wertheim Schroder & Company. ''It's a totally different business from what it was five years ago.''
The changes are being driven to a large degree by the rapid increase in demand for entertainment product around the world. Movies now routinely make more money abroad than in the United States.
The deregulation of broadcasting in Europe has created a host of new channels in many countries and a corresponding need to fill more hours of air time, often with American-made programming. New markets are developing in Eastern Europe, China and elsewhere that are now permitting greater access to films, television and music.
The effect of the changes on films, television programs and recordings in the United States is difficult to gauge. There is a general consensus in the industry that foreign ownership has so far not had a discernible impact on content or on the types of films and programs being made.
Foreign owners and investors, most notably Sony, have left the day-to-day operations in the hands of American executives. The success of movies and television shows still depends primarily on appealing to audiences in the United States, which remains the single largest and most influential market for entertainment.
Still, some industry executives believe the new owners, particularly the Japanese, may in the long run exert a cultural influence, however benign.
Because the interest of Sony and Matsushita in Hollywood stems from how movies and other programming can complement their electronics businesses, some executives say, they may ultimately apply different definitions of economic success to movie and television projects from those used by the industry today, favoring, for example, films that play well on videocassette over movies that are best seen in a theater on a big screen.
Moreover, many people in the industry think foreign owners are likely to become more assertive in imposing their own cultural perspectives and business decisions as they gain experience and seek to recoup their large investments.
''In the short run it may be subtle or not very noticeable, but in the long run you have to believe it will have an impact,'' Mr. Hirschfield said.
IN addition to the outright acquisitions by companies like Sony, the lines between foreign and domestic companies have been greatly blurred by less-publicized deals and joint ventures:
* Carolco Pictures, the maker of the Rambo movies, earlier this year sold a 10 percent stake to Pioneer Electronics of Japan and a 5 percent stake to Canal Plus, the leading pay-television network in France.
* Michael Douglas's production company, Stonebridge Entertainment, is making television movies with financial backing from RAI-2, an Italian network.
* Paramount Pictures has set up a division in London to make movies with European writers, directors and actors.
* The Walt Disney Company just agreed to finance many of its films with money put up by Japanese investors.
Within the United States, most of the studios have purchased television stations and theater chains. The Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation has built a fourth broadcast network. The merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. last year created a company that is at once among the largest owners of cable systems and networks, the largest producer of network television programming, one of Hollywood's most consistently successful film studios and one of the world's biggest recording companies. The big entertainment conglomerates, MCA among them, have been snapping up recording companies, leaving no major independent music labels.
THERE is likely to be more action ahead. Paramount Communications Inc., the parent of Paramount Pictures and one of the two major entertainment companies not to change ownership in recent years, is openly scouting for major acquisitions and has talked to everyone from MCA to an Australian television network. The Walt Disney Company, the other studio not to have been sold or merged, is widely rumored to be interested in acquiring CBS Inc. if Federal rules limiting the ability of networks and studios to own each other are eased, as many in Hollywood expect.
''What you will end up with is a few multinational communications conglomerates that are vertically integrated to the extent allowed by the laws of the various countries they operate in,'' said David I. Weil, an entertainment lawyer who handles many international clients for the firm of O'Melveny & Myers in Los Angeles.
Both Wall Street and industry executives are still waiting to see whether the consolidation pays off. The Time-Warner merger last year brought together a formidable array of businesses, including Time's HBO cable network and the Warner Brothers studio, but the combined company's heavy debt load and lackluster earnings have so far been a disappointment on Wall Street.
And Sony spent $2 billion several years ago to acquire CBS Records and another $3.5 billion applying the same concept to the video field with the purchase of Columbia Pictures.
Although it is still early in the process, industry executives say the Columbia deal so far has proven little except that the attempt to reinvigorate the studio is costing Sony hundreds of millions of dollars in additional and unexpected investment to fund film production and hire a new team of executives.
 
WILL IT PLAY IN PESHAWAR?
TThe surge of foreign ownership in the entertainment industry has had a negligible impact so far on the content of entertainment from Hollywood.
But the growing need to appeal to an international audience has made some difference.
Studios have started choosing what movies to make and who should star in them with an eye to how well they will play abroad.
Movies starring actors with worldwide appeal like Arnold Schwarzenegger are almost certain to get a go-ahead.
''Shirley Valentine,'' a film about a middle-aged English housewife, would probably never have been made if Paramount Pictures had to rely solely on its reception in the United States.
But the studio went ahead because of its confidence in its performance abroad.
The consolidation of the industry is also having an effect on what types of films get made. The studios, which need to support a large amount of overhead and worldwide distribution systems, are concentrating almost exclusively on medium and big budgets.
There is less appetite than everfor low-budget films, and because there are few remaining independent production companies, writers and directors say there is little opportunity to make films that do not have an obvious appeal to a mass audience.

HEADLINE: It's a Bear All Right, but How Big a Bear?

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
Since shortly before Saddam Hussein invaded Iraq, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has fallen about 600 points - from a high of nearly 3000, to the 2400 range. By any standard, such a bruising tumble can only result from a brush with the bear. But how long will the bear market stalk Wall Street? How far will the Dow fall? And will there be safe havens in such a market?
To find out, Joel Kurtzman of the New York Times asked Charles I. Clough Jr., chief investment strategist of Merrill Lynch & Company and a first vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets; Eric H. Sorensen, director of quantitative analysis and co-manager of equity portfolio analysis at Salomon Brothers Inc., and Lewis J. Sperber, founder and president of Sperber Adams & Company Inc., a brokerage firm in Westport, Conn., about their expectations for the stock market for the coming year.
Q. Are we in a bear market? 
Mr. Sorensen: Yes. This market has a lot to do with the perception of deteriorating fundamentals in the United States. Earnings are a key factor here and so is psychology. I expect the market to go another 10 or 20 percent lower.
Mr. Clough: I agree, Eric. This is the first recession we've seen that has been led by the financial sector. Bank balance sheets are still under pressure. What this says is that the normal postwar recession patterns may not be quite so relevant now. We could be be looking at lows that go beyond the normal recession levels in the credit-sensitive sectors of the economy.
Mr. Sperber: I don't think that we have seen the bottom of either the market or the recession. We have another couple of years to go. I'm talking 1991 on the downside, probably starting to come out of it in 1992. We have further to go on the downside in the equities markets. We're not at the bottom yet.
Q. What are you advising your clients to do?
Mr. Sorensen: From a traditional standpoint, where our clients actively manage equity portfolios, they don't have the range of alternatives that some other investors have. A pension fund can move into cash but an active manager who is asked to basically be 100 percent invested cannot.
In lieu of that, clearly there's a rotation going on. And the rotation within the equity market is not for value right now, it is to reduce risk.
I don't think we'll see any sustainable uptrend in this market until there's a rotation into return-oriented investing where people are trying to buy groups of stocks because those stocks have earnings momentum. That'll happen some day but we're a ways from there still.
Given that, we have the utility sector which we all probably have some sympathy for because it is defensive. We've got telephones, we've got drugs, health care and foods. These things looked overbought about a month or two ago - particularly the health sector - but they'll probably go higher on a relative basis as long as we're in this environment. Energy stocks had an overvalued, overbought temporary situation as a result of the Middle East crisis. They have since sold off a little bit. That's a place where I'd begin to build in this bear market.
Mr. Clough: The greatest challenge for investment in the 1990's is secure yield. The actual number of instruments out there - where an investor can be certain of getting high current income for an extended period of time - is shrinking dramatically.
There have been three traditional yield-paying groups: banks and the financial stocks, automobiles and utilities. The first two groups are under stress. That puts you back into utilities as the one area where yield is reasonably assured.
On the fixed-income side, the current situation keeps you very much wedded to the Treasury sector.
Mr. Sperber: You asked what we're telling investors. But the opposite question is also important, namely, what are the investors telling us?
On the retail side, individuals are leaning more towards bonds and fixed-income investments. They say they want secure return. They want safe return, whether it's the Treasury or corporate bond. The individual investor is not running to invest money in equities. Those who want to go into equities are leaning more toward the mutual funds than they did before.
Mr. Clough: That's interesting. The most popular security held today by Merrill Lynch investors is the 90-day certificate of deposit.
Mr. Sperber: I am finding that the individual investor in the equities market is someone who has been an investor for a longer period of time. They are not the peoplewho came in and tried to play in the marketplace in the late 1980's just prior to the crash of October 1987 and then got burned. They are people who were investing in the 1970's and during the 1980's. They are people who know that the market goes through cycles. These investors are willing to buy selected equities at the present time.
Q. And what are you telling them?
Mr. Sperber: We've been advising them to buy securities and sell options against them. It is a time-honored technique and the investor of today is more cautious and seasoned than the investor of, say, five years ago. The investor of today is saying that if there is an upside rally, he or she is willing to limit the upside gain because he's already sold that call.
Q. Should investors wait for the bottom of the market to buy?
Mr. Sperber: My answer is this: You're never going to find the bottom and you're never going to find the top of the market.
Mr. Clough: Yeah, but it's fun trying.
Mr. Sperber: If the world really is gloomy, what do you do right now? I would say you could buy equities. Yes, you don't know where the bottom is going to be, but you do know that by 1993, 1994 or 1995, we'll be going to go through another cycle when things will be better. For individual investors, that means they can buy equities as long-term investments. For the institutional investors, the next couple of years will probably be more of a trading market.
Q. Are any of the markets' problems due to factors like the budget deficit, the ''junk bond'' crisis and the economy's tip toward recession?
Mr. Sorensen: Absolutely. There are a number of areas of deterioration defining this bear market and you just mentioned three of them. But you've also got global forces. We have American interest rates, given inflation here compared with inflation in Japan and inflation in Europe, no longer competitive relative to the German bond and the Japanese bond. Most - but not all -of the global investors I talk to are fairly pessimistic about our currency and about our economic environment. That's not a positive right now for stocks.
Mr. Clough: We are looking at the lowest rate of growth in credit since 1985. Public sector deficits are rising - that's quite visible, and certainly discounted in the marketplace. But private credit is falling at almost an unprecedented rate - mortgage originations are practically disappearing. We have the lowest short-term interest rates in the world right now, and have had for several months.
Q. Aren't low interest rates traditionally associated with bull markets?
Mr. Clough: Yes and no -it depends on what they are reflecting. If it's reflecting an expansion of liquidity on the part of the Federal Reserve system, yes, that would be bullish. But if it's reflecting a runoff of credit, and a credit collapse and a decline in bank deposits, it might have quite different implications. That's the real question for investors right now.
Q. Are there other groups of stocks that look pomising?
Mr. Clough: Well, some of the machinery groups - trucking and related stocks - are pretty depressed. We're not at a point where we see an upmove in those stocks yet, but we're getting there.
Mr. Sorensen: I agree with Chuck. Truckers have performed relatively well, at least a few of them, the last week or two, and the outlook for their earnings has stabilized. I don't know whether that will the case a month from now. They are presumably somewhat volatile, with the economy the way it is. There are other areas, too, like technology. But that doesn't mean they'll go up right away.
Mr. Sperber: You can't take every security that's out there by group. We might all agree that retailing has been in decline. But if you believe that the consumer is still going to spend at least some money, why not look at retailers who are going to fill that need, like The Limited, or Gap stores? They will fulfill the consumer's need in a down economy.
Mr. Clough: I happen to believe that the group decision is a very important one right now. It has been more so in recent times than, say, in periods of bull markets or periods of stable markets.
Mr. Sperber: Even in a recession, Mr. and Mrs. Jones are still going to take their families out to dinner. They may not go to a fancy restaurant, so McDonald's is going to become the beneficiary of that fact. At these price levels, you buy McDonald's - not for three months, but for a two- to three-year period of time. The public doesn't give up drinking beer during a recession.
Banks' balance sheets are eroding, but at these price levels I think you could buy a Chase or a Chemical or a Citibank. I don't believe that Chase or Chemical or Citibank is going out of business. If I'm a long-term investor and Chase is selling at $12, or even goes down to $7.50 or $8, I will buy it and keep it over a three-year or five-year period of time until it recovers.
Q. Where do you forecast the Dow will be in 12 months?
Mr. Sperber: I see the Dow going down as low as the 2200 range within the next 12 months.
Mr. Clough: Our guess is that a bottom is somewhere out there perhaps in the second quarter of 1991. If valuation parameters that have been relevant in the last 10 or 20 years still matter, the low will probably be in the 2000 to 2200 range. You might get a spike below that.
Mr. Sorensen: There will be some rallies, but the Dow will work its way down to the 2000, 2100, 2200 - that range. Those are buying opportunities, given the way the world looks now.
Mr. Clough: Let me have one last comment. If any of us could really predict where the Dow is going, we'd be calling our brokers from our yacht.

HEADLINE: Tense Talks at Chrysler

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Claiming the company has no money to meet union wage demands is a time-honored tactic of collective bargaining. But this time there seems to be little doubt that Chrysler Corporation management is telling autoworkers the truth about its precarious position.
If Chrysler agreed to a labor contract such as the one approved in recent weeks by General Motors Corporation workers and Ford Motor Company negotiators, the company says its labor costs would rise significantly at a time when it already has the highest labor costs in the industry. Chrysler and the United Automobile Workers union began high-level bargaining last week.
With sales and profit flagging, the No. 3 auto maker is struggling to conserve financial resources for the next two years until it can bring out a crucial new midsize car, which it hopes will put sales back on track. (Truck sales may get a boost from a recently introduced new minivan and a new Jeep slated for next year.) But the Persian Gulf crisis and the possibility of a deep recession have raised the likelihood that Chrysler's finances will be stretched more than anticipated in July, when it first told the U.A.W. to consider accepting a less expensive contract. 
While labor costs alone won't drive Chrysler to the brink ''they will have been a nail in Chrysler's coffin if the company dies,'' said Ronald Glantz, analyst for the Dean Witter Reynolds Organization in San Francisco. Analysts generally believe Chrysler has a good chance to survive, but agree with the company's own assessment that it must find a partner to share the enormous cost of developing new models. An expensive labor contract may make Chrysler less attractive to a potential partner, Mr. Glantz says.
He thinks Chrysler is close, however, to a broad development, production and distribution agreement with Fiat S.p.A., but may be waiting to conclude a labor contract before signing the pact.
Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of Chrysler, after leaving what he called ''a nice lively session'' with union bargainers, declined Thursday to reveal precisely what he had said. ''I did not plead poverty,'' he told reporters. But a Chrysler spokesman who had seen an outline of Mr. Iacocca's speech said ''he was going to tell them it will be nice if a contract says they're supposed to be making a lot of money three years from now, but a contract won't help anyone if we're not in business.''
For the record, the union wouldn't talk about the session either. Privately, however, union officials are far from sympathetic to Chrysler's problems, which they acknowledge are real. They believe that hourly workers have sacrificed disproportionately in the decade since Chrysler nearly went bankrupt. All 11 union negotiators who came to the meeting with Mr. Iacocca were wearing buttons that read ''Pattern or Picket.'' According to the union's tradition of so-called pattern bargaining, a contract reached with one of the Big Three domestic auto makers is used as the pattern for the other two.
There have been exceptions. In the early 80's Chrysler workers agreed to broad wage and benefit concessions to help the company recover from near-bankruptcy. By the mid-80's the company had regained its health, and workers regained wage parity with those at other companies.
For the past year, however, Chrysler's fortunes have dimmed again in the face of fierce competition and a softening automotive market. If they were to accept lower pay and benefits, Chrysler workers contend, they would be accepting the blame for management ineptitude. Mr. Iacocca, who concedes he made some strategic blunders, meanwhile is trying to cut $2.5 billion in costs, quickly develop new products and stem an exodus of executives.
In a recent published interview, Mr. Iacocca accepted blame for diversifying into the aerospace and defense business, a move that diverted attention and money from producing cars and trucks. And he admitted he was mistaken in joining forces with Maserati to build a luxury coupe and in moving production of the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon from one plant to another shortly before canceling them altogether.
Although Chrysler workers receive roughly the same pay and benefits as union workers at Ford and G.M., Chrysler's labor costs are higher because it has a proportionately higher number of retirees. In 1989 Chrysler's labor costs were $33.16 an hour, compared with $29.50 an hour at G.M. and $30.98 at Ford. Because Chrysler has a higher proportion of retirees, its hourly labor cost also would be inflated more than that of its domestic rivals by a provision approved at Ford and G.M. that raises a typical monthly pension payment to $1,800 from $1,500. (United States auto plants operated by Japanese companies have lower labor costs because they have almost no retirees.) One method of lowering labor cost is boosting productivity. Chrysler's management was disappointed when workers in St. Louis turned down a proposal for a three-shift operation that would have boosted minivan production. The union accepted the concept, but the sides couldn't agree on overtime pay. Chrysler says that shows an ''attitude problem.''
The union rejects that view, noting that Mr. Iacocca, citing ''brain drain,'' reinstituted stock bonuses for executives earlier this year shortly after announcing that executive bonuses had been canceled to save money.
''When it comes to workers they want a good attitude, when it comes to executives I don't hear Iacocca denouncing Jerry Greenwald for leaving the company to work on the United Airlines deal,'' said a union member who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mr. Greenwald, who was Mr. Iacocca's heir apparent, resigned as vice chairman to lead the group attempting a leveraged buyout of U.A.L. Inc.
Union leaders also are vexed that Chrysler made a public issue of breaking away from G.M. and Ford. Had the company consulted privately with the union, they say, they might have been able to find ways of reducing labor costs without angering the rank-and-file.
Chrysler executives and managers, meanwhile, believe they've also sacrificed plenty in pay and perks. A spokesman said merit increases have been frozen for six months; memberships, travel and subscriptions have been cut back; and the stock bonuses won't be paid until next year. Over the past three years, the cutback of salaried workers has been deeper than that of U.A.W. workers. Chrysler's salaried work force has dropped 25 percent to 27,000 from 36,000, while the union work force has dropped to 63,000 from 70,000 - only 10 percent.
Because Chrysler's financial position is not nearly as desperate as it was in the early 80's, management may have trouble convincing the union to moderate wage and benefit demands. As of three months ago the company had more than $4 billion in cash and marketable securities and several assets, such as financial service subsidiaries, that the company believes could easily be sold in an emergency.
Moreover, the amount of money that would be saved by union concessions probably isn't big enough to decide Chrysler's fate. The hourly-labor component of the total cost of making a car has continued to decline as manufacturing methods improve.
In this atmosphere, if union negotiators agreed to a smaller wage increase than the 3 percent promised at Ford and G.M., or to a lower increase for pensioners, Chrysler workers might fail to ratify the contract, raising the likelihood of a strike.
Chrysler executives aren't certain whether sales will rebound, whether its new car, minivan and Jeep will be big hits, and whether a few hundred million dollars saved in labor costs may be the difference that forestalls another request for government help. A strike, on the other hand, would be extremely costly at a time when Chrysler's redesigned 1991 minivan is just starting to be produced and is in very short supply.
In 1980 Mr. Iacocca cut his own salary to $1 a year to dramatize the seriousness of Chrysler's plight. He's now employed under a multimillion dollar management contract, whose value has diminished because of the fall in Chrysler's stock price. But at this point he and others in top management might have to accept an even bigger pay cut to persuade the U.A.W. to do the same.
 
CHRYSLER-FIAT MARRIAGE?
Once Chrysler has a new labor agreement and knows what labor costs will be, it may be in better position to agree to a partnership that many believe the company is negotiating with Fiat S.p.A.
Bud Liebler, Chrysler's vice president of communications, says Fiat and Chrysler are talking about a broad range of possible cooperation.
Chrysler might sell minivans and Jeeps in Europe through Fiat dealers, vastly reducing costs. Fiat would like to get back into the American market and thinks Chrysler might build a version of its Tipo small car.
Ron Glantz of the Dean Witter Organization in San Francisco says sources at Chrysler and Fiat tell him Fiat may want to build Chrysler's downsized Jeep in South America or Poland. Chrysler's plan to build the Jeep with Renault fell through.
Another possibility, said Mr. Glantz, is that Fiat will accept Chrysler's airbag and emission control technology as payment for what it provides to the partnership. European luxury cars soon will be putting these features in their cars, forcing Fiat's Alfa-Romeo and Lancia models to follow suit.
