LENGTH: 1424 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 7-12

BYLINE: By Sallie Hofmeister

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
After a Week of Negotiations, the Budget Gap Narrows
 
After topsy-turvy budget negotiations all week, Congress and the White House narrowed their differences. Higher gasoline taxes seem inevitable; lower capital gains tax and steeper tax rates for the rich, improbable. Another truth emerged: The cost of financing the deficit will balloon before the Government can meet its debt-reduction goal of $500 billion. Foreign investors were eerily absent at last week's record $8.5 billion auction of seven-year Treasury notes - a void that drove up yields to their highest level since an auction in April 1989. A declining dollar and more favorable interest rates abroad have kept Japanese and European investors, who finance the bulk of the deficit, from Treasury auctions all year. But the breakdown in the budget talks completely shattered their confidence. ''We've come to expect them to buy 20 to 30 percent of these auctions,'' said Ward McCarthy of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a research concern. ''But there was no sign of them. It's a fundamental change that has long-term implications for taxpayers and the economy.'' He expects just as poor a showing of foreign bidders at next month's quarterly auction of 30-year notes, where their absence would be even harder felt. 
 
The Cost of Crude
 
The coming cold weather, shrinking stockpiles and persistent fears about war in the Persian Gulf caused oil prices to graze $40 a barrel last week. Crude closed at $39.69 a barrel on Friday, up $1.70 for the week.
 
Looking to make points with politicians and the public, the five companies that own Alaska's giant Prudhoe Bay oilfield vowed to spend $1.1 billion on equipment to increase oil production. The new plant, which will be ready in 1995, had been in the works before the Iraqi invasion, but the partners, including British Petroleum and ARCO, said they thought it could ''make a welcome contribution'' to allaying concerns about America's long-term oil supplies. Yet the new equipment will actually only slow a steady decline rather than increase Prudhoe production, which now stands at about 1.4 million barrels a day. The new investment should compensate for only 100,000 barrels of oil a day of an expected decline in production of 400,000 barrels by 1995.
 
Oil's Pervasive Impact
 
The across-the-board jump in wholesale prices for September provides the first compelling evidence that the record-breaking energy-price climb has shot through the economy. Wholesale prices jumped by 1.6 percent, which, together with August's sharp increase of 1.3 percent, represents the steepest two-month gain since 1980, the Labor Department said. What startled economists was how quickly the oil runup has translated into higher prices for everything from pharmaceuticals to trucks. The outbreak of inflation probably kills the Federal Reserve's commitment to ease interest rates if Congress makes budget cuts. ''Inflation is a much more intractable problem than the Fed had thought,'' said William V. Sullivan, a senior vice president at Dean Witter. ''The report will send it back to the drawing board.''
 
New Business Starts Off by 3.1%
 In the contracting economy, entrepreneurs could use a transfusion like the one provided under the rejected Federal budget pact, which called for incentives to investors in small companies. After rising through most of the 80's, new business incorporations dropped 3.1 percent in the first seven months of the year, after falling 1.1 percent for all of 1989, according to Dun & Bradstreet.
 
In Brief
 
A service-oriented Soviet airline? It will be called Air Russia, will begin flying from Moscow in 1992 and will be majority-owned by Aeroflot, the state-run airline, in a joint venture with British Airways, which will kick in $39 million.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Scandalous Japan
 
The stench of corruption lingers in Japan Inc. Hisashi Shinto, one of the country's most prominent business leaders, was convicted last week of accepting bribes in the first big court case from the Recruit episode, the stock and influence-peddling scandal that forced the resignation last year of several politicians, including former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita. Mr. Shinto, the former chairman of Nippon Telephone and Telegraph, the world's largest company, appears to have been a scapegoat for political leaders who were looking to prevent further disgrace to the ruling party. But, save for self-respect, Mr. Shinto will sacrifice little: He was fined $170,000 and sentenced to two years in prison - a punishment that was suspended because of his age - 80 - and his ''contribution to the business world.'' Michael Milken should be so lucky.
 
More shocking was the sudden resignation of Ichiro Isoda, the chairman of Sumitomo Bank, one of Japan's most aggressive and profitable banks. In keeping with the Japanese custom, Mr. Isoda said he was taking responsibility for the arrest of a branch manager who was charged last week with accepting almost $750,000 to arrange an improper loan for the corporate raider Matsuhiro Kotani, indicted for stock manipulation in August. The arrest adds Sumitomo to the list of prominent institutions, including Daiwa Securities, implicated in the manipulation scheme.
 
COMPANIES
 
Insurance on a Slide
 
Could the life insurance industry be skewered by the same sword that has done in hundreds of savings and loans? The scenario may not be as dire. Yet insurance stocks got kicked last week - continuing a three-month downward trend - after news that the Travelers Corporation was abandoning its dividend and adding more than $600 million to its reserve to cover losses. Travelers may start a trend, and some even worry that mounting losses could bankrupt dozens of insurers. Competition with other financial institutions has forced insurers to pay higher interest rates to customers, pushing them out on the same fragile limb as savings banks - taking chances on risky investments like ''junk bonds.'' Paying those high rates becomes ever-more painful as income slips with the economy. Sound familiar?
 
The Incredible Shrinking Dividend
 
 Shareholders will indeed suffer from the shaky real estate climate: Chemical Bank on Thursday said it would cut its dividend in half and reported a third-quarter loss of $43.7 million, mainly from increasing its loan-loss reserve. Chase Manhattan has already cut its dividend, becoming the biggest bank yet to lean on its shareholders. In the first nine months, 278 companies shaved their dividends. ''That's more than for any year since 1982 - a recession,'' said Arnold Kaufman of Standard and Poor's. And the march of the dividend cutters has hardly reached its peak.
 
Forestalling Foreclosures
 
Pummelled by rising mortgage defaults, lenders appear eager to forestall further foreclosures, even if it means assuming the role of property manager. Lacking the leverage that allowed Donald Trump to renegotiate lending terms, John C. Portman Jr., the Atlanta developer, did the next best thing: He gave the Equitable Life Assurance Society and Nippon Life Insurance, two mortgage holders, a controlling interest in his sprawling Peachtree Center office complex in downtown Atlanta. The several million dollars Mr. Portman expects from his new partners should help him pay off anxious creditors.
 
Kodak Ordered to Pay Polaroid
 
The Polaroid Corporation will finally collect on the patent infringement suit it won five years ago against the Eastman Kodak Company. In the largest award ever in a patent infringement suit, a Federal judge ordered Kodak on Friday to pay Polaroid $909 million in compensation for lost profits and royalties on its instant photography patent. Yet Kodak's stock may rebound, as the market had prepared for much worse, while Polaroid's shares take a dip.
 
Tumult at UAL
 
A purple rage erupted at the UAL Corporation last week. The board rebuffed for lack of financing the United Airline unions' third buyout bid, a $160-a-share offer. It was a personal defeat for Gerald Greenwald, the former vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation hired by the unions to bring in the banks. Easing his pain: the $5 million he was paid to leave the auto company and a $4 million fee. The unions' token: The company offered to sell employees 20 percent of UAL's stock at a 15 percent discount from the market price - or roughly half the share-price they had pledged for the entire company.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 21, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A report on the Business Diary page last Sunday referred incorrectly to the quarterly dividend at the Travelers Corporation. Travelers recently announced a cut in its dividend to 40 cents a share from 60, but did not eliminate it.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 536 words

HEADLINE: Cut the Deficit, Not the Dividend

 BODY:
After years of pretending that the Federal budget deficit wasn't much of a problem, Congress is poised to plunge fanatically in the other direction, as though it had no other duty than deficit reduction. But Americans can walk and chew gum at the same time. They need to see the deficit reduced, but they also need to invest in disadvantaged children, rebuild dilapidated infrastructure and save the despoiled environment. 
The deficit reduction plan now emerging on Capitol Hill not only ignores these needs; it now contains a little-recognized provision that would make them worse. Meeting these needs is as essential to economic growth as deficit reduction. That means the budget package must be fixed.
The problem with the deficit reduction package is not its size. It would cut the deficit by about $35 billion next year, after accounting for military expenses in the Persian Gulf, and by $500 billion over five years. That's enough to make a sizable dent in the Federal deficit without threatening an already fragile economy.
The problem lies elsewhere: in a provision that would, in effect, block Congress from financing more public investment for three years. That would take Congress out of the business of making choices - its core responsibility.
The proposed budget package would for three years establish separate caps, one on military expenditures and another on domestic discretionary expenditures - everything from education to food inspections. Entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare would not have a cap, although to expand them, Congress would have to raise money by hiking taxes or cutting other programs. The upshot would be chilling. Public investments would be frozen for at least three years.
The end of the cold war warrants much larger cutbacks in the military than called for in the budget package. Yet even if Congress later comes to that conclusion, it could not use this potential peace dividend to rebuild bridges, educate children or train workers. To do so would put total discretionary spending above the cap.
The cap on discretionary domestic spending would turn deficit reduction into a mindless obsession: to spend every last cent of the peace dividend on deficit reduction, every other domestic need be damned.
What's more important: better airports or more missiles? More scientific research or lower taxes? These are difficult questions, but they need to be asked. And there's no good reason for Congress to foreclose them and forbid itself to expand precious programs as long as it is willing to pay for them.
Deficits do matter, powerfully. They siphon private savings away from corporate investment in new plant and equipment. Over time, an economy that does not invest will not grow. The remedy is to commit the Government to steady deficit reduction that will raise national saving, and investment, to prudent levels. A $500 billion hit over five years would be a prudent, indeed handsome start. Once that's achieved, even more deficit reduction is slavish, not sensible.
Congress is elected to govern. That means making hard choices, not lunging for harsh formulas. Clapping arbitrary caps on domestic programs is an unconscionable surrender.

HEADLINE: Let Arms-Sale Profits Aid Poor Countries

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Bush Administration has chosen to sell $20 billion worth of United States arms to Saudi Arabia. No doubt, this sale will be followed by other major arms sales to states such as Israel, Egypt, Pakistan and perhaps even Syria, all of whom are supporting the United States military action against Iraq in the Persian Gulf confrontation. And if the United States economy and its arms merchants are entitled to seize the gulf crisis to make profits for themselves, can the European, Soviet and Brazilian arms industries and economies afford to remain behind? 
Meanwhile, the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait has given the remaining major oil producers windfall profits from the soaring prices of oil. The major beneficiaries are Saudi Arabia, the gulf sheikdoms, the Soviet Union and the Texas and Oklahoma oil producers in the United States. Clearly, Iraq has done a great economic service for the world's arms and oil producers.
Since these arms and oil producers are loudly proclaiming that they are taking economic and military action against Iraq in the ''noble'' cause of upholding the United Nations Charter on nonaggression, may I suggest that all profits from arms sales to the region and from higher oil prices be channeled into a special United Nations fund.
The money thus received could then be redistributed to the poor states of the world, who are more severely affected by these actions of the rich states, who are busy profiteering in arms and oil.
Unless some such form of reverse economic sanctions can be adopted, it may be far too tempting for these arms and oil producers not to seek diplomatic solutions at all, but to prolong the Persian Gulf crisis indefinitely.
 
RA G. C. THOMAS
Milwaukee, Sept. 24, 1990
The writer's most recent book is ''Energy and Security in the Industrializing States'' (Lexington, Ky., 1990).

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Should Protect Economic and Civil Liberties

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Why Liberals May Long for Bork'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 28) Gary L. McDowell overreacts to the likely consequences of a Supreme Court that would be more vigilant in protecting private property rights. He fears, for example, that a Court that protected private property rights would strike down rent control and minimum wage laws. Amen.
Rent control has only produced housing shortages, housing deterioration and condo conversions, which have mainly harmed the poor - especially lower-income minorities - in whose name the laws were enacted. The Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs has estimated that rent control in New York City causes an average loss of 30,000 housing units a year. The Amsterdam News once reported, ''we in minority areas are forced to live in rat-infested apartments that resemble bombed-out war areas,'' and that such conditions are rapidly increasing ''solely because of rent control.'' 
The minimum wage law has also been harmful, despite good intentions, by pricing out of the market the least-skilled members of the work force. Because of inferior educational opportunities and other reasons, minority youth are disproportionately harmed by the minimum wage law.
Mr. McDowell also confuses the relationship between protecting private property rights and environmental protection laws. As the legal scholar Morton J. Horwitz shows in ''The Transformation of American Law, 1780-1860'' (Cambridge, Mass., 1977), until the mid-19th century, American common law upheld the property rights of individuals to sue for damages from industrial pollution. ''Natural uses of land,'' Mr. Horwitz states, were favored ''by strict liability in tort: any interference with the property of another gave rise to liability.''
Class-action suits against polluters were also frequent under common law property rights, but were eventually outlawed by most state legislatures as the legal system moved from the protection of individual property rights under the theory that economic growth was in the ''public interest, and should supercede the protection of individual rights.''
In short, the social and economic problems Mr. McDowell is concerned about have come about or have been exacerbated precisely because the legal system has largely abandoned its protection of individual property rights. What we should all hope for is a Supreme Court that will protect our economic as well as our civil liberties.
 
THOMAS J. DILORENZO
Chattanooga, Tenn., Sept. 28, 1990
The writer is the Scott L. Probasco Jr. Professor of Economics at the University of Tennessee.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Meanwhile, the Bad News From Albany Is Released Quietly

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
So loud was the clamor of bad news from New York City last week that the pessimistic din in Albany was barely audible.
That was probably just as well for state officials, who are up for re-election in three weeks. Until recently, it had seemed as if a conspiracy of silence was gripping Albany - no one would talk about the bad news until after the election. Now, as it trickled out, it was drowned by the cacophony of dire reports from City Hall. 
Even a week ago, when voters' attention was focused on Mayor David N. Dinkins and the city's suddenly worrisome financial prospects, Governor Cuomo called together his top staff members and told them to expect the worst for the state as well. The word leaked out that the state was in for another round of budget cuts. But, compared with Mr. Dinkins's prediction that 15,000 might be laid off, the news from the Governor's office seemed ho-hum.
Then on Thursday, Mr. Cuomo, violating an election year taboo, said in an interview with New York Times editors and reporters that layoffs and tuition increases might be necessary to balance the budget.
Unlike Mayor Dinkins, he refused to estimate how many might be laid off or how much tuition might rise. Still, his tone was grim. ''I believe we're in for a period of pain, and I think we have to be prepared for that,'' he said.
Mr. Cuomo currently enjoys such a wide lead in the polls that it seems that no matter how dim a view of the state's future he takes, his own political future is unlikely to be affected. Nevertheless, mentioning layoffs and tuition increases a month before an election seemed like an unusually splashy move by the normally cautious Governor, and it prompted a good deal of speculation in the world of state politics, where Mr. Cuomo's motives are analyzed more carefully than any mere economic data.
Some officials speculated that Mr. Cuomo had knowingly forecast doom at a time when his predictions, overshadowed by the city's problems, were least likely to attract attention. Others suggested that his comments were a warning to city officials not to expect the state to bail them out.
''I think that what the Governor is doing is sending an alarm,'' said the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat. ''I think he's feeling some pressure from the city.''
And still others submitted that the Governor did not want to be accused later, as Massachusetts Governor Michael S. Dukakis was, of having deceived the electorate to further his own career.
''If he has aspirations for higher office, he doesn't want to be accused of hiding anything,'' one New York City official said.
Whatever motives they ascribed to Mr. Cuomo, few analysts disagreed about the conclusion: New York State is facing dismal financial prospects in the year ahead. Many said that the problem was likely to be even worse than the Governor suggested. And coming after two years of tax increases and record deficits, some of which were filled with ''one-shot revenues'' and adjustments in the state's books, next year's budget problems, they said, are likely to prove particularly intractable.
''I would say the two New Yorks - the city and the state - are both going to be in the very difficult position of making major adjustments to their budgets,'' said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses.
Most state officials were not surprised by the Governor's gloomy predictions. What took them aback was that he shared them with the voters. There are topics that, according to the unwritten rules of politics, are just not discussed during election season.
In addition to the possibilities of layoffs or tuition increases, these include pay raises for state lawmakers, who, under state law must either increase their salaries by the end of this year or wait for a raise until 1993. State legislators, who earn $57,000 a year for what is ostensibly a part-time job, last raised their salaries in 1987. In the State Capitol, there has been quiet speculation that pay would be raised, although lawmakers, all of whom are up for reelection next month, publicly deny the possibility.
Another topic that still seems off limits for now is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's troubles. There will be a special session of the State Legislature in December to deal with them, but discussion of it has been minimized.
The only item officially on the Legislature's agenda in December is an extension of the corporate surcharge that nets the M.T.A. about $325 million a year. But the New York City Transit Authority is predicting a $250 million deficit next year, and the M.T.A.'s commuter railways are expecting one of $50 million.
The M.T.A. has three options: increased state aid, fare increases or service cuts. Increased state aid is unlikely in hard times like these, and who wants to talk about fare increases or service cuts right before an election?
''Everybody's known about the M.T.A.'s problems for months,'' said Cynthia Green, a Citizens Budget Commission analyst. ''After November, one of the big issues is going to be that the M.T.A.'s also in trouble - as big trouble as the city or the state.''
There may be other, equally discomfiting topics waiting to be broached, but they aren't even being discussed in the halls of the Capitol yet.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
As a Climax Looms, One Has to Wonder: Was There a Plot?

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

 BODY:
The budget melodrama that has riveted Washington for the past five months may finally be reaching a climax. Here is a plot summary and brief guide to what may happen next:
First there was a budget summit where 17 congressional leaders and three Administration officials argued about whether to slash the deficit by raising taxes or by cutting spending. The President wanted to cut the tax rate for capital gains; Democrats called thata boon to the rich and acceptable only if income tax rates for the wealthy were also increased. When the sumiteers couldn't agree, the President said some taxes could be raised but not income tax rates. That angered House Republicans, who oppose any tax hikes.
Then summiteers reached an impasse and formed a smaller group, where only top congressional leaders and the three Administration officials argued. The ''mini budget summit'' produced a plan that would raise taxes and cut spending, particularly for Medicare, but it left income tax rates and the capital gains rate alone. That plan was soundly defeated by the House of Representatives, and the Government briefly shut down for lack of money. Democrats blamed the President, the Republicans blamed the Democrats and everybodoy blamed the President's men, the White House chief of staff John Sununu and the Budget Director, Richard Darman. 
Then Congress wrote its own deficit-reduction plans, and the President at first said he might be willing to consider a tradeoff between a lower capital gains rate and higher tax rates for the wealthy. Then he changed his mind, several times.
Now he wants a plan like the one the House rejected. A variation on that plan will be presented to the House early next week, and it will probably fail. Instead, the House is likely to approve a Democratic alternative that raises tax rates for the wealthy and cuts the capital gains tax rate, but not in quite the way the President had in mind. House Republicans will have an opportunity to offer an alternative, but at the moment they can't agree on one.
Meanwhile, the Senate has come up with a bipartisan plan that doesn't touch tax rates or cut the capital gains tax. If it passes, the House and Senate will argue until they reach a compromise.
 
What Happens Next
By tomorrow, the 24 Congressional committees instructed to meet deficit reduction goals must report their decisions to the House and Senate Budget Committees. Budget panels will stitch the recommendations together and present them as a single package for votes in the House and Senate. Floor amendments are permitted. Once each chamber approves its package, a conference committee will meet to iron out any differences in the two versions. Conference agreement must then be approved by House and Senate and sent to the President for signature.
 
The Points Of Contention
 
Taxing
 
GASOLINE: House Democrats would avoid any increase in the current 9 cent a gallon Federal tax on motor fuels, but a bipartisan plan from the Senate Finance Committee would mean a boost of 9.5 cents.
 
EXCISE TAXES: Increases in excise taxes on beer, wine, spirits and cigarettes seem to be on everybody's agenda.
 
MEDICARE TAX: Workers are currently taxed on the first $51,300 of their wages to help finance the hospital insurance portion of the Medicare program. The wage base will almost certainly be increased.
 
CAPITAL GAINS: House Democrats have found a way to cut the gains tax rate to benefit the middle class and limit advantages for the wealthy. House Republicans, and some of their conservative allies in the Senate, are still looking for the type of reduction President Bush proposed in January. The Senate Finance Committee's bipartisan plan would leave the rate unchanged from current law - the same as that for ordinary income.
 
INCOME TAXES: House Democrats would boost the top tax rate to 33 percent, from the current 28 percent for families with incomes over $200,000 and impose a 10 percent surtax on incomes over $1 million. House Republicans vigorously oppose the rate increase, and Senators in both parties decided to leave tax rates alone. The Senate Finance Committee, however, would limit itemized deductions for wealthy taxpayers with incomes over $100,000.
 
Spending
 
MEDICARE: Lawmakers in both parties want to avoid an angry backlash from senior citizens groups who oppose the deep spending cuts initially contemplated. Monthly premiums will increase slightly, and deductibles will also rise, but House and Senate differ on how much. The biggest hit will come for health care providers.
 
FARM PROGRAMS: Crop subsidy levels will be reduced by altering formulas for acreage set asides.
 
DISCRETIONARY SPENDING: Democrats would hold spending to levels needed to keep pace with inflation. Spending increases that exceed the expected inflation rate may be proposed in popular programs like education and law enforcement, but they will require belt tightening elsewhere to meet deficit reduction goals. House Republicans are seeking much deeper across the board cuts, and some Republicans are prepared to take a bigger bite out of military programs. All the deficit plans will mean new ''user fees'' for a variety of Government services ranging from camping permits at national parks, to processing of patent applications to customs inspections.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
An Aversion to Taxing Taxable Substances

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Canadians routinely pay more than $30 for a carton of cigarettes. Italians pay more than $5 for a gallon of gasoline. Danes not only pay $1.50 plus deposit for a store-bought bottle of beer but face such high prices for cigarettes - close to $4 a pack - that a Danish embassy spokesman, Bent Skou, says ''nobody in his right mind'' buys a whole carton at once.
Yet Americans are in near revolt over increases in their own ''sin'' taxes that would leave consumers here still paying small fractions of the prices levied in most industrial countries. 
''We generated well over a million letters,'' said Jeff Becker, a spokesman for the Beer Institute, the industry group behind the highly visible can-the-beer-tax campaign. This drive is intended to head off a proposed increase in a Federal beer levy that has not been raised, not even to offset inflation, since 1951.
The package produced by Congressional and Bush Administration budget negotiators included an increase of 16 cents a six-pack. The negotiators proposed to raise the Federal tax on cigarettes to 24 cents a pack from 16 cents and the gasoline tax to 21 cents from 9 cents. Wine would rise by about 22 cents a bottle. As Congress struggles to reconfigure the budget package, which was voted down because of Medicare cuts as well as the tax proposals, the current versions include few changes in the tobacco and alcohol proposals but scale back the increase in the gasoline tax.
The situation is in part a result of the Federal Government's tacit agreement over the years to reserve these sources of revenue largely for the states, which have come to rely heavily on them. The Beer Institute calculates that state taxes on its product have soared 650 percent since the early 1950's, roughly in line with inflation, and that several states have levies more than triple the Federal one of $9 a barrel, or 16 cents a six-pack. The Federal cigarette tax is 16 cents a pack, while most state levies are higher.
The states are becoming more aggressive, too. California, for example, recently doubled its gasoline tax, from 9 cents to 18 cents, and Montana proposes to slap an additional 25 cents on its cigarette tax, bringing it to 43 cents a pack.
 
Double Dips
 When Federal and state taxes are combined, American motorists - to take perhaps the most glaring example when the country is fielding troops in the Mideast to defend oil supplies - feel burdened. They are furious about the proposed increase in the Federal gasoline levy, which is unlikely to exceed 10 cents and would leave a retail gallon at barely one-third the price in Europe, Japan and Canada.
Since 1951, according to the Congressional Budget Office, the cigarette tax has decreased by half when adjusted for inflation, while the real Federal tax on beer and table wine is only one-fourth as high.
There are, of course, various replies. Many dwell on the regressive nature of excise taxes. Others contend that motorists, say, might be willing to pay higher gasoline taxes so long as the money was used for building or repairing roads and bridges, but not if it was earmarked to pay debts run up by the citizenry at large.
There is also the argument that Americans have tailored their commuting and other patterns to covering vast distances with inexpensive gasoline. ''People have adapted their behavior to this price structure,'' said Michael E. Canes, chief economist for the American Petroleum Institute. ''Then somebody comes along and says, 'Let's change.' ''
Moreover, the increases are proposed at a time when, driven by the situation in the Mideast, oil prices are already surging.
And while the states are jealously seeking to protect their tax sources, Congress is the constant object of lobbying efforts by the industries that know any increase in taxes for their product will reduce demand. They have been especially busy in the last few weeks.
For any number of reasons, the betting is that Washington will continue to tax the American consumer relatively lightly for his indulgences, even while the Federal Government reminds him of the need to conserve gasoline and warns that smoking and drinking are bad for his health.
''To a European,'' ventured Mr. Skou, ''it does sound a little eccentric.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 957 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Socialists' New Class Struggle: How to Survive Communism's Fall

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
The world's most prominent Socialists - the council of the Socialist International - convened in New York last week with certain misgivings. After all, Americans have not been particularly cordial to Socialism since the days of Eugene V. Debs; in fact, they put him in jail. Norman Thomas, the most illustrious American Socialist in modern times, was pelted with eggs and frequently invited out of town.
From a time almost 80 years ago, when there were 56 Socialist mayors and Debs himself garnered 900,000 votes as a Presidential candidate, Socialism in this country has dwindled to two fringe parties whose idealism, it could be said, is in inverse proportion to their political clout. 
Former German Chancellor Willy Brandt, who is president of the Socialist International and who was chairman of the Socialists' two-day meeting at the Waldorf Astoria, spoke to their uncertainties in his opening remarks. ''I know the word 'Socialist' does not have a very favorable connotation for many Americans,'' he said, adding ruefully, ''and nowadays, I am afraid, for people in other places, too.''.
Which may be why it was the first time the International had held a meeting in the United States in over a hundred years. And perhaps the Socialists chose the Waldorf, something of a capitalist icon, to indicate that they are not entirely anti-establishment. More than a few of the delegates grumbled about the venue, observing that a night there costs more than the annual per capita income in some third world countries.
During the two-day session, the Socialists did what politicians do: they argued, they viewed with alarm, and they passed resolutions on everything from the status of South Africa and North-South relations to the unsolved murder of one of their leaders in Guatemala last January. But between meetings they turned to their unpublished agenda: the future, if any, of the Socialist movement.
Since the bitter split between Socialists and Communists more than 70 years ago, the Socialists, or more precisely, the Social Democratic parties around the world, have thought of themselves as the front-line bulwark against Communist totalitarianism. ''The Leninist hubris of a party laying sole claim to unmistakable truths was totally alien to Social Democrats,'' Mr. Brandt said.
But if Socialists define themselves in terms of their opposition to Communism, what are they to become now that Communism is, for all practical purposes, defunct?
In fact, while Communism may be finished, its legacy could still prove troublesome for Socialists. Writing in Dissent recently about the changes in Eastern Europe, Alan Ryan, a former Oxford don who teaches politics at Princeton, noted, ''All the difficulties of the transition will be ascribed to the legacy of a vaguely defined 'socialism' and all the improvements to a vaguely defined 'free market system.' '' In vain, Social Democrats have been arguing that the Eastern European bureaucracies were not really Socialist at all. True Socialism, they have always said, can only exist within a democratic society, under a parliamentary-style government.
''Let's face it,'' former Chancellor Brandt said last week, ''Socialism has been discredited by the mess created in the so-called 'socialist countries.' But there should be no doubt that what existed in Central and Eastern Europe was anything but Democratic Socialism - or Social Democracy, as I prefer to call it.''
The irony here is inescapable: the extinction of Communism represents a considerable victory for Social Democracy - if it isn't dragged down with the very movement it fought so long and courageously to end.
Some say this has already happened. The economist Robert Heilbroner wrote recently about what he calls ''the demise of socialism.'' While still powerful as an organizing idea in the third world, he observed, ''in the materially more advanced nations, 'socialism' as a distinct social objective has disappeared. Nothing is left of it but a better-run capitalism.''
Not everyone is so pessimistic. To some thinkers, the collapse of Communism, far from presaging the downfall of Socialism, could be the source of its renewal. According to this view, the former Communist states of Eastern Europe will swerve rapidly to the right, to old-style, unregulated free market economies.
''Socialism is a dirty word now in Eastern Europe,'' said Jean-Pierre Cott, a French Socialist and the leader of the 180 Socialists in the 518-member European Parliament. ''They will go to laissez faire, then they will wake up with a hangover. Some will want to go right back to Communism, but I think they will look more to Social Democratic principles.''
Social Democracy will, Mr. Brandt believes, provide ''a third way,'' a political and economic choice somewhere between the now abhorrent centralized economies of the recent past and the unfettered capitalism to come.
''We Social Democrats advocate a mixed economy, which does not mean that we have a fixed formula for the proper mix,'' he said. ''No one has to convince us that market forces are indispensable for economic growth, but we also believe that private interest must be attuned to the public interest in social justice and ecological survival.''
Mr. Cott warned that the Social Democrats might be acting too precipitously in Eastern Europe, throwing their support behind anyone who claims to be a free-market Socialist. ''There is a future for Social Democracy,'' he said. ''We must be in a position to provide a true democratic alternative when the time comes. In the meantime, we must be careful - not just go with the winners, but seek out the true representatives of social justice. We have a saying in France: Never go faster than the music.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Willy Brandt, president of the Socialist International, speaking last week to a gathering of Socialists in Manhattan. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1202 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
A Land of Immigrants Gets Uneasy About Immigration

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The incidents span a decade and a continent: Gulf Coast fishermen in Texas harass Vietnamese competitors who are catching more shrimp. A Florida supermarket manager suspends a cashier for speaking Spanish at work. Residents of a Maryland community protest the establishment of a Japanese junior college near the Chesapeake Bay. Two Los Angeles suburbs try to require Chinese store owners to put up English signs. A Massachusetts gubernatorial candidate, John Silber, asks, ''Why should Lowell be the Cambodian capital of America?''
For some observers of American history and politics, the incidents evoke disturbing memories of the virulent, anti-Catholic and anti-Semitic nativism of the 1920's, or, more distant, the open hatreds of the 1890's, when William J. H. Traynor of the American Protective Association opposed granting the right to vote to the ''pauper and criminal riffraff of Europe'' and ''every ignorant Dago and Pole, Hun and Slav.'' 
Some of the same combustible elements of those years are present in America again. With the Northeast already mired in economic hard times and other regions teetering on the edge, will immigrants who arrived in record numbers in the 1980's become a lightning rod for the anger of a swelling crowd of economic losers? ''In the past few months there's been a perception that the pie is not expanding, and those are the times when zero-sum solutions raise their ugly heads,'' observed Gregory Fossedal, the head of the Alexis de Tocqueville Institution, a research foundation based in Palo Alto, Calif., that favors immigration.
Despite some disturbing incidents, there are few signs that the kind of organized anti-immigration movements of decades past are rising again. The strident voice of the nativist has faded. In fact, the House recently passed a bill that would increase annual immigration ceilings by 45 percent, to 775,000. But political scientists say that the immigration debate has created new political fault lines and disrupted old alliances. As often as not, the voices expressing concerns of increased immigration come from people who once would have been called liberals.
As immigration becomes a greater component of population growth, environmentalists and population control advocates have begun to consider more seriously the case for controls. Nancy Wallace, who directs the Sierra Club's International Population Program, argues that ''any immigration legislation should be part of a national population policy moving toward stabilization as fast as possible.''
Immigration has also caused rifts in the civil rights coalition. Recently the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People hesitated before agreeing to support Hispanic groups in their effort to repeal Federal sanctions against employers of illegal aliens. This month, Hazel Dukes, New York State president of the N.A.A.C.P., said, ''Why let foreigners or newcomers have these jobs while blacks, who have been here for hundreds of years, can't support themselves or their families?'' She later apologized.
In fact, her presumption that unskilled immigrants take jobs from unskilled Americans has lost support among most economists. In his book ''Friends or Strangers,'' George J. Borjas argues that ratios of immigrants in major metropolitan labor markets have trivial effects on wage rates and no effect on unemployment.
But provisions in the Senate version of the current immigration bill that would substantially increase the number of skilled immigrants brought in by corporate employers to fill special labor needs has raised fears that immigrants will occupy the higher rungs of the economic ladder, hindering the mobility of those below. ''The question is, should immigration be encouraged or should national policy encourage training to allow those here, including blacks, to take those jobs?'' said Arthur F. Brimmer, a former member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve. ''My own view is that we should do both.''
Although he argued against the issue of economic competition from unskilled immigrants, Mr. Borjas raised a separate issue in a recent paper co-authored with another economist, Stephen J. Trejo. The newer the immigrant, they say, the more likely he is to draw welfare.
Others argue that immigrants may threaten the nation's linguistic cohesion. In 1983 a group called U.S. English was founded to promote ordinances, laws and state constitutional amendments making English the official language of one jurisdiction after another. Early this year, a Federal court struck down a constitutional amendment in Arizona. In 1989 a Federal court overturned an ordinance in Pomona, Calif. - apparently directed at Chinese store owners - mandating that half the space on foreign-language commercial signs be devoted to ''English alphabetical characters.''
But these ripples do not change the conclusion of David H. Bennett, author of ''The Party of Fear,'' a 1988 study of nativism, that hostility toward immigrants has declined significantly as a political force since World War II. Many historians, economists and social scientists are not asking why there were so many echoes of nativism in the 1980's, but why there were so few.
''If you look back on American society 30 years from now, you'll say in the 1980's there was a watershed in American society and one of the indications was that there was a change in the attitudes toward foreigners - though not to foreign competition,'' said Michael J. Piore, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
''I think that what happened in the course of the 1970's and 1980's was that the United States really redefined itself as a multiracial society; there was a general acceptance that society was going to be composed of a variety of different groups and we had to develop a tolerance of them. I don't want to say there's no resentment. There is a lot, more than is being expressed. But it is not being organized, and people don't organize their thoughts around the idea that you can solve these problems by closing the borders.''
Martin Heisler, an expert on immigration at the University of Maryland, said: ''I'm surprised the reaction hasn't been stronger here, compared with some European countries. The limits of tolerance for pluralism should have been stretched by now, and they don't seem to have been. Are we experiencing a linear expansion in our ability to cope with incredible social diversity?''
But nativism may not be gone forever, said Dr. Piore. ''I believe that there are different conceptions of American society that in some ways are contradictory,'' he said. An essential ingredient of America's self-image is its history as a nation of immigrants. That image ''has always been around even in the worst nativist periods,'' he said. ''And the nativist image is always going to be around in the most tolerant periods.
''Whatever happened in American society in the 70's and 80's has brought forth a more tolerant vision. But the problems of working out a multiracial and multiethnic society are immense. I can well believe that at some point those problems would accumulate and we'll go back'' to America's nativist past.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Some Fights, Quitting Is Harder Than Joining In

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Of the panoply of issues the United States and the Soviet Union still face if they are to put the Cold War completely behind them, none appear more nettlesome than resolving the longstanding civil wars fought by their clients in Afghanistan, Angola and Cambodia.
The superpowers have agreed that it is time to end the conflicts, because neither wishes to spend billions of scarce dollars to prolong anachronistic wars that seem unwinnable anyway. But having resolved their own fundamental differences, they still face a difficult problem: pacifying the very factions they once helped inspire to fight. All too frequently, the clients have their own intractable interests, disputes and weaknesses. ''We are finding that it was easier to get into the wars as enemies than it is to get out of them as friends, even as we sit on the same side of the negotiating table,'' said an American military official. 
The Afghan civil war, which froze American-Soviet relations when Moscow intervened with 115,000 troops in 1979, is the regional conflict the two superpowers most want to resolve. The Soviets fear that the war between the Government it installed and Islamic fundamentalist insurgents could spread ill will to nearby Soviet Muslim republics. And some Bush Administration officials privately question the wisdom of sending $300 million a year to fundamentalists who do not share Western values, now that the Soviet Army has withdrawn.
When the Soviets pulled their forces out of Afghanistan two years ago, many officials in Washington expected the Government of President Najibullah to fall quickly. But the rebels splintered into factions and the Government survived.
Rumors of a superpower agreement on organizing elections and an interim Government peaked in August, when Mr. Najibullah arrived in the Soviet Union for what was described as a month-long health check-up - only a day before Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, were to meet in Siberia. American officials noted with interest suggestions in the Soviet press that Moscow was ready to cut aid to Mr. Najibullah and press him to negotiate in earnest with the guerrillas. But Mr. Najibullah returned home pledging to stay in power, and the rebels have expressed little enthusiasm for elections.
American officials insist they are near an agreement with the Soviets, with the role for Mr. Najibullah in an interim Government the only major issue not yet resolved. ''We and the Soviets are interested in responsible disengagement,'' said a senior State Department official. ''They want Najibullah's departure to be part of the process, but they don't want to pull the rug out from under him.''
American and Soviet officials have made the most dramatic progress in their attempts to negotiate an end to the 15-year civil war in Angola, where the United States is still covertly sending $60 million a year to the Unita guerrillas fighting a Soviet-backed Government. A worsening famine has persuaded the superpowers to actively nudge their clients to find a settlement; three weeks ago American and Soviet officials directly took part in the peace talks for the first time, and agreed in principle to jointly lead an international monitoring group to supervise a future cease-fire and elections.
But before that can happen, the Angolan sides must negotiate an enforceable cease-fire, and deep resentment and distrust stand in the way. Jonas Savimbi, the rebel leader, insists on immediate recognition of Unita as a political party and the holding of elections next year. President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, however, says full recognition of Unita would have to await an amendment of the Angolan Constitution to permit a multiparty system; he also says the country will need years to rebuild before elections can be held.
Of the three conflicts, the superpowers share the most similar goals in Cambodia. Both are trying to prevent a return to power by the Khmer Rouge, the violent Communist rebel group that is held responsible for the deaths of more than a million people while it ruled in the late 1970's. It was overthrown in 1978 by a Vietnamese invasion force that quickly installed a less radical Communist Government with Soviet support. Vietnam's troops left Cambodia last year, but the Government, under Hun Sen, remains in power.
Over the last four months, the Bush Administration has begun to talk to Hanoi and Phnom Penh, regimes it had shunned, as part of a multi-pronged effort to end the war. With the other members of the United Nations Security Council, Moscow and Washington together have persuaded the Hun Sen Government, the Khmer Rouge, and the two other guerrilla groups to agree to establish a council that would share power with the United Nations until elections can be held. So far, however, bickering among the four sides has stalled the formation of the body.
One reason Cambodia has proven so difficult for the United States and Soviet Union is that their influence there is limited, in part because China plays a vital role in the conflict and continues to support the Khmer Rouge. Economic depression, corruption and ideological divisions appear to weaken the Soviet-supported regime month by month, and this has only added momentum to the Khmer Rouge march.
''Neither of us can wash our hands and neither of us has overwhelming leverage to dictate solutions,'' said the senior State Department official. ''All we can do is point the way.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Japan's Shrewd New Investment Strategy . . .;;
. . . Moves Beyond Rockefeller Center and Pebble Beach

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
If all goes as planned in the next few weeks, E.T., the cuddly extra-terrestrial, will have a new parent. Matsushita, the giant consumer electronics maker known in the United States as Panasonic, is negotiating what may be a $7 billion takeover of MCA, the owner of Universal Studios and one of the recording industry's biggest labels. And sometime in the next few months, the faltering American automobile industry will have a new car plant: Toyota executives are mulling over the politically proper site for a huge new plant, which has scores of Toyota suppliers here and politicians in several state capitals salivating.
While such mega-acquisitions and new plants seem familiar, this year they are actually the exception. Japan is buying abroad faster than ever - this year its direct investments will be an estimated $55 billion, up 25 percent from 1989. But, suddenly, it is buying small. Japan is acquiring small firms and new technologies, putting less at risk but building an ever-deeper infrastructure to support its late-1980's buying spree. The strategy seems bound to solidify Japan's position in the United States and in Europe, where serious Japanese money is also starting to flow. More important for the Japanese, lots of smaller acquisitions may attract less attention than a few big ones. 
The evidence this year suggests that Japan is learning how to invest with the least possible political resistance, especially from those who have a vague sense that the United States risks turning into an economic colony. Only a handful of the record 328 overseas acquisitions and major investments Japan has made in the first nine months of this year - more than half of them in the United States - has drawn much attention, much less serious opposition. Even the biggest buy this year, Fujitsu Ltd.'s purchase of ICL, Britain's only major computer maker, drew only limited protest.
''The Japanese are learning how to make their acquisitions less high-profile,'' said Andrew S. Grove, the chief of Intel Corporation, who is one of the most vocal critics of the dangers of selling strategic parts of the American industrial base abroad.
Much of the buying is taking place, quietly, in Mr. Grove's own backyard, Silicon Valley. Yet he detects less resistance. ''People are battle weary,'' said Mr. Grove, whose company's microprocessors are among the few products that have held Japan at bay. ''And if they do not crave Japanese investment, they work their way to the point where it is the only option.''
Ever since Sony bought Columbia Pictures and Mitsubishi Estates acquired a controlling interest in Rockefeller Center last year, the Japanese Government has quietly warned industry here against conspicuous purchases. Matsushita's proposed deal is the first to go against the guideline. Yet, big or small, Japanese companies have learned how to portray every purchase as an ''invited'' one, which is often true. With the stock market down and venture capital scarce in the United States, such invitations will keep coming.
To the Japanese, new plants like Toyota's are regarded as the best option of all; they create new jobs without the political complications of corporate takeover. More than 30 states maintain Tokyo offices to vie for such investments. What neither side discusses much is the growing evidence that such factories balloon the trade deficit in their first years of operation, as tons of Japanese-made robots and machine tools are brought in.
One could argue that the investments getting the biggest publicity are the ones to worry about least. The Japanese investor who just paid between $800 million and $1 billion for the Pebble Beach Golf Club is hardly about to move it from the California coast to Hokkaido. And no one suggests that E.T. will be snatched from American screens. The bigger concern is whether Japanese-owned American movie makers will pick up signals from their owners to steer clear of subjects or scenes Japan finds distasteful. Akio Morita, Sony's chairman, says Columbia Pictures is free to venture into taboo subjects such as the war-time role of Emperor Hirohito but the less politically savvy Matsushita has so far voiced no such guarantees for MCA.
But golf clubs and movie studios have little to do with long-term questions of American competitiveness. The small deals often raise exactly those fears, though they usually involve technologies too abstruse to debate about in Congress or constituencies too small to make themselves heard. A few months ago, the Bush Administration toyed with the thought of blocking the sale of a tiny company called Semi-Gas Systems, one of the few surviving American makers of the highly specialized equipment used to turn silicon into computer chips. In the end, the Government decided there was no national security issue at stake, a move Senator Albert Gore called ''absurd and ridiculous.''
But making a claim that national security - or even industrial competitiveness - will be irreparably damaged by the acquisition of any single company is nearly impossible. The damage happens in the aggregate: already some American chip makers say Japanese equipment makers are slowing their access to state-of-the-art equipment.
Some of Japan's purchases have allowed old line companies to break into new territories, such as Nippon Mining Company's $1.1 billion purchase of Gould Inc. in 1988. But most of the recent buying is to support businesses built in the late 1980's. Kubota Ltd., a farm equipment maker, entered the high technology field a few years ago with an investment in a promising computer maker named Stardent and a hot Silicon Valley chip maker named MIPS. Since then it has assembled a cluster of companies making a range of components.
Other companies are building bit by bit. Matsushita is using Solubourne Computer, a maker of advanced workstations, to get back into the computer business. Fujitsu owns a majority stake in a firm making super-small, lightweight PC's, and is transferring some of the technology to Japan. American auto-parts makers complain that Nissan, Honda and Toyota carry in their wake a host of suppliers, who use Japanese transplants to get into the American market.
Japanese argue, accurately, that they are saving many American firms, providing capital they cannot get at home. But it is nothing new for nations to insist that profits and the control of vital industries stay within their borders. It is only new to the United States, which never before had to deal with the question.
So far the Bush Administration has been unwilling to address the issue. But it is up to America, not Japan, to figure out an alternative to Japanese capital. As Mr. Morita said last year, ''If you don't want Japan to buy it, then don't sell it.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 833 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan's Shrewd New Investment Strategy . . .

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
From time to time over the last five years, economists played an intellectual game of calculating what might happen if Japanese institutions halted their massive purchases of United States Treasury bonds, issued to finance the yawning Federal budget deficits. It seemed a flight of fancy, since Japan's appetite for the securities seemed so vast. But last week the United States got a taste of the real thing.
On Wednesday, in the midst of Washington's fumblings over a deficit-reduction package and the simmering Persian Gulf crisis, the Japanese institutions that used to snap up as much as 40 percent of the new securities were conspicuously absent from an important auction. Demand for the $8.5 billion of bonds was the weakest in seven years. Interest rates inched higher, the dollar slipped lower and Wall Street grew nervous. 
The poor auction results were just one knock in a roller-coaster week. But Japanese institutions were less than contrite. After a decade of being battered by broken promises on budget-deficit reduction, volatile exchange rates and disappointing returns, they had had enough.
''The situation has completely changed,'' said Yoshihiko Miyabe, who helps design the international strategies of the Yasuda Trust & Banking Corp., a leading Japanese institutional investor. ''Japanese investors have been through an educational period, where they learned a lot in the first stage and made many mistakes. Companies are getting more cautious now, and they think more about strategies.''
That represents one part of a major shift in the way Japan is investing its cash hoard overseas, a change likely to have far-reaching implications for the financial markets and many American companies. The outflow of Japanese capital, though still large, is slowing, a result of steep if little-noticed declines in Japan's trade surpluses.
Meanwhile, the investments still being made abroad are generally far more carefully targeted. They are being aimed much more clearly at sharpening the competitiveness of Japanese companies. The challenge to American industry is growing as a result, just as the Japanese are making it harder for Washington to finance its fiscal excesses.
One major factor behind the trend has been the sharp reduction in Japan's current account surplus - the broadest measure of the flow of goods and services into and out of the country. It has tumbled from a peak of $87 billion in 1987 to $57 billion last year. In the first half of 1990, the surplus was only $20.5 billion, an annual rate of $41 billion.
In addition, Japanese interest rates have risen sharply, making it more attractive for investors to keep their money at home rather than face the risks, and the political controversy, of placing it in the United States.
Mr. Miyabe of Yasuda Trust said that two years ago the pension funds his company manages had invested as much as 23 percent of their assets overseas, mostly in the United States. Today, he said, the proportion invested abroad is about 15 percent, ''and that will go down further.'' The decline, he and others added, comes not from large outright sales of securities, but from a slowdown in new investments to the States. Japanese institutions, which are heavily invested in the American securities markets, say they are conscious of the need to slow their purchase of securities without jolting Wall Street.
Previously, the largest share of Japanese overseas investment went into securities, chiefly Treasury bonds. They looked stable, and the interest rates were double the level for comparable Japanese Government bonds. But Japanese institutions were net sellers of $8.9 billion of American securities in the first half of this year - an astounding reversal from their purchases of $17.4 billion in such securities in the last six months of 1989.
In another switch, Japanese capital is now going mainly into direct investment - factories, companies and real estate. The Japanese will still acquire factories that help them dominate markets; labs that give them the latest technology, or production studios to provide the movies to be shown on the video machines they manufacture. But they are generally keeping a sharper focus on what will produce a stronger position in the marketplace.
The Japanese are also diversifying their direct foreign investment. The United States is still the largest single target, but increasing amounts are flowing to Europe and Southeast Asia.
In 1987, direct investment made up 14 percent of the outflow of capital from Japan; in the first half of 1990 it made up 70 percent. Japanese capital, in short, is getting scarcer but shrewder. The Japanese are trying to make sure it helps their strategic and competitive goals, and does not fall down the black hole of financial uncertainty.
''This all suits Japan's strategic interests,'' said Kenneth Courtis, chief economist here for Deutsche Bank. ''They have learned some valuable lessons. But in some ways, it is a scary scenario.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1437 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Time of Confusion Draws the Arab World Into Soul-Searching

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia

 BODY:
From Algeria to Bahrain, public opinion in the Arab world is undergoing the most troubled soul-searching it has experienced in modern times. The massacre at Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem last Monday, in which the Israeli police killed at least 21 Palestinians during a riot, has further inflamed Arab emotions already driven to new peaks by the Gulf crisis. But it has done little to clarify the entanglements, confusion and discord unleashed by the invasion of Kuwait and the arrival of an enormous American-led military force in Saudi Arabia, clearly prepared for battle with Iraq.
Uncharacteristically, Arab intellectuals are giving their own countries' assumptions and actions a hard look - rather than looking for more convenient sources of blame abroad - as they seek explanations for the disunity, poverty, antagonisms and social tensions that have been laid bare in this difficult time.
To be sure, Islam remains a potent rallying cry for all the aggrieved parties in the Middle East, but its cynical use to justify diametrically opposed views has rendered it a thin veneer that barely masks a profound change in Arab attitudes - an evolution of major importance far beyond the Middle East, for nowhere else are the West's economic and strategic interests so intertwined with such byzantine regional problems, involving Muslim and Jewish religious passions, oil and money, thousands of hostages, and old political hostilities. 
The Gulf crisis has undone virtually all the regional alliances of the last few years, placing moderate countries like Jordan in the Iraqi camp and militant nations like Syria in the American-Saudi camp. It has driven Arab intellectuals to despair as they try to define primary and secondary Arab vital interests in the crisis, and what links they are to make between Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and Israel's continued occupation of Arab lands.
Among the Arab masses, the crisis in the Gulf, now amplified by the killings in Jerusalem, has brought forth raw feelings of frustration and deep anger, pushing Muslim fundamentalists into the same trenches with secular Arab nationalists - a union of purpose that only a few weeks ago would have appeared unimaginable. In this they were both driven by a deep antipathy toward the United States and the West, which for four decades have supported Israel and, the Arabs feel, neglected the Palestinian cause. Meanwhile, there has been ample room for opportunism, as shown by Syria's tightening of its influence over Lebanon by driving the Christian general Michel Aoun from his redoubt over the weekend.
In grasping for a logical framework that explains the maze of developments that have upset what King Hussein of Jordan likes to refer to as ''the Arab order,'' intellectuals of the left and the right seem to agree on one thing: The chaos of today springs from an accumulation of unresolved political, economic and demographic problems that produced an Arab paralysis over the last decade. While the rest of the world moved on - ending the cold war, widening democracy, and undergoing a dynamic economic expansion in much of Asia, Western Europe and North America - the Arab world's problems festered, only to explode into the open with the Iraqi invasion, laying bare all the intertwined issues that cannot be remedied merely by an Iraqi departure from Kuwait.
''The Arab world was going through an oil hangover, an unprecedented economic recession, a frightening demographic explosion, a $300 billion foreign debt, the strengthening of authoritarian regimes, a deepening gap between rich and poor within each Arab country, and, more importantly, between the gulf area and the rest,'' says Ghassan Salameh, a Lebanese professor of political science at the Sorbonne. As a result, Mr. Salameh explains, the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait ''was instinctively viewed as a stone in the marshy waters of Arab politics, an act of will in times of lethargy, by those Algerians and Tunisians, Palestinian and Jordanians who spontanuously went into the streets.''
It is not so much that these masses admire Iraq's leader, Saddam Hussein, or that they wish to live under a regime like his, Mr. Salameh said in a recent conversation. ''They were longing for change, any change in the prevailing situation.'' But in the absence of Arab leadership that could inspire and direct this change in a peaceful way, the immediate result has been disarray across the Arab landscape and a chaos verging on war.
One salutary effect, however, has been a wave of self-criticism and introspection unmatched in this century, and many Arab intellectuals hope this may produce a brighter vision of the future. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait, there has been an avalanche of articles and commentaries that for once appear to place the blame for the Arab world's chaotic conditions on the Arabs themselves, instead of searching for conspiracies among Western imperialists or other outsiders. If a consensus is emerging it can be summed up as a general accord that Arab leaders have become bankrupt and that Arab ideological and political structures must be swept away to make room for a more realistic approach to the 21st century.
The Egyptian syndicated columnist Mahmoud al-Saadani expressed this sentiment recently. ''All Arab countries have neither a stable political logic nor an identifiable political creed,'' he wrote. ''They are more like a circus with no manager in charge. Sometimes they are moved by regional interests, sometimes class interests, or clan interests. In the end it is all a matter of crass interests and nothing else.''
A revolt against their governments and their condition has been under way for some time among all Arabs. Long before it was invaded by Iraq, Kuwait was in the throes of a debate about democracy, in which many Kuwaitis questioned the right of the ruling al-Sabah family to monopolize power. This debate has now resumed with fury here; hundreds of leading Kuwaiti figures came to this seaside city this weekend to examine their condition in exile, and many of them disregarded an appeal from their rulers that it would be better to talk about liberating Kuwait than about democratizing it.
''We think the time to talk about democracy is now while our Government is out of power and in exile,'' said Abdallah al-Nefeissy, a former member of the Kuwaiti Parliament. ''Later may be too late.''
Within the Palestinian movement, many questions are also being asked about the caliber of the leadership offered by Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman whose vacillation between the positions taken by Arab militants and Arab moderates appears to have finally dented his reputation among Palestinians. His latest swing to support President Hussein has won him some support among the militant Palestinians, but it may have left his whole movement, and his leadership, in jeopardy regardless of the outcome of the crisis.
In Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt, Jordan and even in the gulf region, the passions inflamed by the crisis and the killings in Jerusalem have stripped away layers of fear and caution, opening the way for a muzzled press to touch upon subjects once taboo, ranging from corruption to the status of women in Arab societies.
In the whirlwind of passion that dominates this region, it is impossible to predict the outcome. Cynics say the area is bound to revert to an order that resembles the status quo ante, once Saddam Hussein is defeated. Revolutionaries say a firestorm of Islamic and Arab nationalist sentiment will devour the region, placing all Western interests in jeopardy and sweeping all moderate Arab governments aside.
Optimists see a possibility on the horizon for the international community, led by the United States, the Soviet Union and Western Europe, to move forcefully to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict, which has always found its way to the center of all Middle East crises. They also see a gradual movement toward more open government and greater democracy. For this latter group, as for the militants, there will always be linkage between the gulf crisis and the Palestinian issue, which both see as a time bomb threatening the whole region.
For the moment, the uncertainties and passions were summed by Mohammad Heikal, an author, former editor of the Egyptian daily Al Ahram and one of the most experienced Arab commentators on political affairs. ''I have never seen the Arab world more divided than it is now,'' he wrote in a recent article. ''There is much emotion and little clarity. The old order does not want to die and the future is refusing to be born.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 3; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1266 words

HEADLINE: TWO-FRONT CAMPAIGN;
In Budget Chaos, Democrats See Chance of 'Normal' Off-Year Victory

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
This campaign has been strangely episodic, as if some bored voter were zapping the remote control each time a plot line or theme emerged. There was the early positioning around abortion in the spring, the exchanges of accusations over the savings and loan scandal in early summer, the rallying 'round the flag as the Persian Gulf crisis erupted in August.
Now comes the chaos around the Federal budget, and to the horror of many candidates and strategists, there is little time left to change the channel. ''I've been in politics for 30 years and this is the strangest election cycle I've ever seen and the most unpredictable,'' said Ed Rollins, head of the National Republican Congressional Committee.
The impasse over the budget seems likely to feed the anger toward incumbents that polls have found among the voters this year, many analysts and politicians say. But many Democrats are hoping to gain partisan advantage from the White House's fumbling of budget negotiations last week, including President Bush's repeated reversals of position on the acceptability of higher income taxes on the wealthiest Americans in exchange for a cut in the capital-gains tax. And some Republican strategists privately worry that the Democrats' new optimism is justified. 
''We have now taken the leadership that the President refused to take,'' said Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in an interview on Friday, as House Democrats hailed a Ways and Means Committee plan that would sharply increase taxes on wealthy Americans. ''The way this has played out is clearly that the Republican Party favors the wealthy and the Democratic Party favors the average American,'' Mr. Brown added.
Charles Black, spokesman for the Republican National Committee, countered: ''That's wishful thinking. The voters are not following this blow by blow. They just see every night that there's gridlock and we're not getting the job done.''
Indeed, the New York Times/CBS News Poll this week found that almost two-thirds of Americans blamed the budget mess on both Congress and the White House. And many challengers are trying their best to capitalize on the voters' ill temper toward Capitol Hill and the unpleasant decisions that lawmakers face, from raising gasoline taxes to cutting Medicare benefits.
''Most challengers will simply bash the institution,'' said Representative Vic Fazio, vice chairman of the Democratic caucus in the House. ''If they're conservative they'll talk about no new taxes and if they're liberals they'll talk about no cuts in popular programs.'' In Nebraska, for example, Representative Peter Hoagland faces a challenge from Ally Milder, a Republican whose television commercials declare, ''If you think gas is high now, wait until Congress gets through with you.'' Her ad concludes: ''Let's replace the Congressman who spent us into this mess.''
There is much anxiety among incumbents, even though the House had a near-legendary re-election rate of 98 percent in the last two elections and members enter every race with huge advantages. Consigning the risky budget brinkmanship to the final days of a campaign does not make for easy stomachs. ''I don't think any of us have a very sure sense of how it will play out,'' said Mr. Hoagland, a narrowly elected freshman from Omaha. ''If we have another government shutdown next week because we're unable to resolve these differences, how that will affect incumbents, I don't know.''
The next critical deadline is Friday, when money for government spending runs out and Congress faces the prospect of passing another contentious temporary spending measure - known as a continuing resolution or C. R. - unless a budget resolution is reached.
''If the Democrats are able to pass a budget, we take off a lot of the criticism that Democrats can't govern and the ball is in the White House's court,'' said one House Democratic aide close to the negotiations. ''But there's no way we can go to another C. R. and not expect full-blown outrage from every corner in the country.''
The irritation level is already high. In follow-up interviews after last week's New York Times/CBS News Poll, Americans talked with disgust about Washington's inability to resolve the budget impasse. ''People in Congress give themselves pretty good raises, but they let civil service people hit the street, wondering where they'll get their next meal,'' said Larry F. Smith, a 29-year-old Navy maintenance technician in Norfolk, Va.
A 38-year-old bank worker in Wrightsville, Pa., who declined to give her name, said, ''There's too much fighting back and forth and no compromises. You've got to compromise somewhere. Someone's got to be taxed more.''
Despite their apprehension, many Democrats were delighted as the budget battle assumed more partisan lines. The budget agreement that went down to defeat 10 days ago had the fingerprints of both the White House and the Democratic Congressional leadership, infuriating many political professionals in both parties.
''Democratic members felt they got rolled,'' said one Democratic strategist, noting the plan's cuts in Medicare, increase in the gasoline tax, and what many Democrats saw as gentle treatment of the rich. ''They felt they were asked to go out and pass and defend a package that was fundamentally at odds with why they were Democrats.'' Republicans, for their part, were furious about blurring partisan lines on taxes, just when candidates around the country were campaigning on Bush's 1988 stance.
 
Seizing on 'Fairness'
 Last week, Democrats said they escalated a debate that will echo nicely on the campaign trail. It is old-time Democratic religion, presenting the party as the protector of senior citizens and working people, casting Mr. Bush and the Republicans as the tribunes of the wealthy. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Majority Leader, released a one-page statement on Democratic budget policy Friday that used the words ''fair'' or ''fairness'' seven times.
Representative Mike Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, summed up the week's developments: ''This is the debate we've been wanting for 12 years.''
 
Back to Normal?
 The fairness argument, against the backdrop of an economic downturn, should force this campaign into the normal contours of a midterm election, many Democrats argue, which would be very good for the party outside the White House. The last time a President's party gained seats in a midterm election was in 1934 under President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
''All the recession fears are converging with the budget debacle to create a much more difficult situation for the Republicans and a much better political environment for the Democrats,'' said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker. Privately, some top Republican strategists agreed.
Still, many Democrats acknowledge that, as one strategist put it, ''We've done a better job at defining the Republicans than we have in defining ourselves.'' Moreover, nobody knows how this budget sequence will play out.
Some consultants say they are just steering clear of the whole mess. ''There's no way now to make a partisan spot on the deficit,'' said Bob Squier, who produces campaign ads for Democrats, ''Because between the time you wrote the spot, produced it an shipped it, you might have a change of events two times.'' It has been that kind of year in politics, a year of quick dissolves and shifting scenes, and it appears to be closing as it began.
Mr. Synar, the Oklahoma Democrat, said, ''This is this week's spin. Next week depends on what happens.''
