PUB-DATE: October 14, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1131 words

HEADLINE: Two-Front Campaign;
For Mr. Bush, Holding Together Fragile Coalitions Is Getting Harder

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
George Bush doesn't much care for self-analysis - he said the other day he didn't want ''to get stretched out on the couch too far'' - but he admits that he likes foreign affairs much better than domestic policy.
He took pleasure, he said, in the challenge of the Persian Gulf, where he has had to ''put the coalition together and keep it together and work towards what I think is a proper end, seeing that aggression doesn't succeed.'' Whereas, he said, ''I can't say I just rejoice every time I go up and talk to Danny Rostenkowski, my dear friend, about what he's going to do.''
The irksome problem for Mr. Bush last week, this week, and for some time in the future is that he has to deal with both Saddam Hussein in the Middle East crisis and with Mr. Rostenkowski, the bluff and powerful chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, in the budget crisis, at the very same time. 
What's worse, both matters may be reaching a critical stage simultaneously.
The President has tried, and until recently had largely managed, to keep world attention focused on the need to force Mr. Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. Day by day, the United States and its allies have increased the pressure on Baghdad, deepening the isolation of Mr. Hussein.
To help convince the Iraqi dictator of American determination, one American policymaker said, ''We have to show ourselves almost as monomaniacal as he is, so that he doesn't come to believe that we'll get distracted and lose our resolve.''
That is harder to do with the budget situation so intractable, and it is even harder to do when events, perhaps inevitably, conspire to drive the ad hoc Middle East coalition apart. The killing of at least 21 Palestinians by Israeli police officers was the kind of seemingly random event that exposes weaknesses and contradictions in a policy that were there all along, hidden from view.
The principal United States ally in the region is, of course, Israel, but that relationship has been fraying for some time - enough so that Washington, mindful of the need to keep Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Syria, among others, aligned against Iraq, was willing to take the lead for the first time in proposing a United Nations resolution critical of Israel. But the Palestinians, eager to regain the spotlight, and the Iraqis, eager to complicate Mr. Bush's job, combined to back a stronger resolution, which appealed to many Arab members of the coalition and even to the French.
So the President was obliged last week to turn his attention from the budget at a particularly nettlesome moment, in order to place a telephone call to Francois Mitterrand, the French President, to get him back on board. That helped set the stage for the compromise finally passed in the Security Council Friday, a resolution that condemned Israel in language the United States could join.
Cracks in the coalition, the Bush Administration believes, would be calamitous, not only because they would encourage Mr. Hussein to hold out but because they would cripple any hope for joint military action.
Already, analysts of the situation here at home see some signs of faltering; Barry Rubin of the Institute for Near East Policy in Washington said the other day, ''I wonder if the United States is losing control, drifting, uncertain of what it is going to do next.''
And on the potential killing field, in Saudi Arabia, the Egyptian and Syrian commanders told a Saudi newspaper that their role was largely to protect Saudi territory, not to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, as Mr. Bush has hinted he may try to do if the sanctions authorized by the United Nations do not work. Maj. Gen. Mohammed Ali Bilal, the Egyptian commander, said categorically, ''The Egyptian forces in Saudi Arabia will not participate in any offensive.''
 
A Delicate Task
So President Bush finds himself confronted with the immensely delicate task of maintaining links with the Israelis while at the same time appeasing Arab public opinion so that Arab backers of the United States cannot be made by Mr. Hussein to look like American stooges, and rallying the Arabs behind United States military leadership so that any armed thrust against Mr. Hussein does not look like Washington vs. Baghdad but like Baghdad vs. the world. If shooting starts, said Lawrence Korb of the Brookings Institution, who was a ranking official at the Pentagon during the Reagan Administration, pressures will mount on diffferent countries to act in different ways. ''What if the Saudi commander of Arab troops orders an attack on Kuwait, and Egypt just refuses?'' he asked.
It is the sort of irony especially familiar, perhaps, to students of the Middle East: Just as the United States troop level in the Middle East reaches the level where commanders would be reasonably comfortable with the idea of an attack, the political problems of mounting one are growing.
From President Bush's perspective, the budget problem affects all this in a number of ways. It is, of course, a distraction from his first priority - the gulf, the Americans held hostages in the area and the quarter-million American service personnel he has sent there. But it has also undercut his political standing at home, driving his approval rating in some polls to the lowest point of his Presidency and producing mocking comments on his leadership as his policy swings to and fro like a weathervane in a hurricane.
''The problem with this,'' said a Democratic senator who has been privately critical of his colleagues' attacks on Mr. Bush on the budget, ''is that it could give Saddam the idea that the President has lost the country's backing, and tempt him to conclude that he can now take big risks once again.''
But even more than that, Mr. Bush must worry that the budget mess, combined with the economic fallout of the Middle East stalemate, will send the American economy into free fall just in time to hurt his re-election chances. The plunging stock market, soaring oil prices, a stagnant real-estate market - even boarded-up shop windows along Connecticut Avenue in supposedly recession-proof Washington - are cause for concern to Presidential aides.
''Things will get a lot better once the budget deal is made and once the Israeli question fades,'' said a White House staff member, reflecting the conviction at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue that Mr. Bush is still on top of things. That may be, but he hardly seemed the commanding manager last week as he told reporters with forced jocularity while jogging, ''read my hips.'' And the things he is trying to manage are getting more complicated with each passing day.
Clearly, the biggest tests of the President's considerable diplomatic and strategic skills, and of his more frequently questioned wisdom and vision, lie down the road a bit.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Terence P. Neilan

 BODY:

Horseback Riding in Japan
Q. I will be traveling to Japan next spring and would like to do some horseback riding while I am there. Can you help? - Kathryn Kimlin, Hoboken, N.J.
A. Riding is becoming increasingly popular among the Japanese as they seek to expand their leisure time, and there are two main areas of activity: family ranches and pensions.
Many of the ranches are situated in Nasu-kogen, an area near Nikko, in the Tochigi Prefecture, some 90 miles north of Tokyo. The ranches cater mainly to beginning riders. More experienced riders might be better served at pensions, which are small Western-style inns near tourist attractions and mountain resorts. Many, particularly those in the Japan Alps in the Nagano Prefecture, offer horseback riding. Sometimes the riding facilities are attached to the pensions; at others they are separate and are reached by bus or taxi. 
Pension Bashamichi, 331 Yamanaka, Yamanakako, Minami Tsuru-gun, Yamanashi, is near Mount Fuji and offers riding at $21 for 15 minutes and $36 for 30 minutes. Accommodations are $50 a night, including breakfast and dinner. El Patio, 2305-1 Sanno, Ichinomiya, Aso-gun, Kumamoto, is near Mount Aso on Kyushu, Japan's southernmost island. It offers riding at $21 for 15 minutes; accommodations are $86 a night, also with two meals.
Ten minutes by taxi from El Patio is the Greenvalley ranch, which offers riding at $36 an hour for men and, as a sales incentive, $29 an hour for women. A 20-minute lesson is $15. A half-hour from El Patio is Jyoba Kumiai, a ranch that offers riding from May to November at $18 for 20 minutes and $21 for 25 minutes.
More information: The Japan National Tourist Organization, 630 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10111; 212-757-5640.
 
Travel for the Elderly
Q. My mother is in her 70's and is looking for tours that are reasonably priced, provide at least two meals a day, are not too strenuous and might match her with a roommate. Is she asking for the impossible? - James H. Sugarman, Singer Island, Fla.
A. At least two companies specialize in group tours for travelers who are more mature in years, designing the vacations at a more leisurely pace and paying attention to such details as whether buses have a drop-down step and whether an individual's particular medical needs can be met. In addition, tours would not be booked into a hotel with noisy video games in the lounge, long stretches of stairs or a bar that plays loud music. But both companies stress that in general what is good for travelers in their 60's is usually good for travelers in their 30's or 40's, too. This would include elevators in all hotels, a hand-hold rail in the bath and a private bath in each room.
One company, Saga Holidays, sells some 200 international and domestic tour packages, including cruises, to clients over 60 years of age. It says the average tour price is $1,200 to $2,200 but that some start as low as $750. Groups usually number from 20 to 40 people. More information: Saga International Holidays, 120 Boylston Street, Boston, Mass. 02116; 617-451-6808 or 800-343-0273.
The other company, Grand Circle Travel, offers more than 100 tours, including cruises, for travelers over the age of 50 in the United States and abroad. It also offers a free booklet, ''Going Abroad: 101 Tips for Mature Travelers.'' More information: Grand Circle Travel, 347 Congress Street, Boston, Mass. 02210.
 
Studying Abroad
Q. Could you help me obtain a list of organizations that deal with programs for study abroad? - Veronica Ramos, Edison, N.J.
A. A comprehensive reference book on the subject, called ''Vacation Study Abroad,'' is published each year and describes some 1,400 programs, about 80 percent of them in Europe. Two-thirds of the programs listed are sponsored by colleges and universities in the United States, the rest by foreign universities and language schools. The guide is published by the Institute of International Education, best known for administering the Fulbright Fellowships. Courses vary in length from 3 or 4 to 12 weeks and in a few cases run 16 weeks.
The 1991 edition of ''Vacation Study Abroad'' will be published in December or January and can be ordered from I.I.E. Books, 809 United Nations Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10017; 212-984-5412. The guide, which will cost $26.95 plus $3 postage, will also be available in many reference libraries and the offices of foreign-study advisers on college campuses. This year's edition costs $24.95. Another of the institute's publications, ''Academic Year Abroad,'' gives details of about 1,900 programs, most of them sponsored by American schools. The courses generally run from from late September to early June. Next year's edition will be published in March and will cost $31.95.
The American Institute for Foreign Study is a private organization that has been offering programs for 27 years. Next year its courses will be held in 10 countries, including China and Australia, but a special emphasis will be placed on Eastern Europe. For the first time it will be offering a program in what until the reunification of the two Germanys on Oct. 3 was East Germany. A 16-week academic year program in the German language and culture will cost $6,995, including the one-way fare from the East Coast; all meals and accommodations are with local families. A four-week summer course in the same subject will cost $2,839. Courses will be held at Humboldt University, Berlin.
The 1991-92 catalogue is available free from the American Institute for Foreign Study, 102 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, Conn. 06830; 203-869-9090 or 800-727-2437.
 
Paris to Nice by Train
Q. My husband and I will be flying to Paris next summer on our way to pick up a cruise ship from Nice to Venice. What is the most economical way to get to Nice from Paris by train? - Carol McAllister, New York, N.Y.
A. The Flexipass sold by French Rail would seem to suit your needs. The pass, which allows four days of unlimited second-class rail travel in any 15-day period, will cost $119 next year. By comparison, a single one-way ticket in second class from Paris to Nice costs $127 this year, and is expected to cost $146 in 1991, according to a French Rail spokesman. Seven or eight trains a day leave the Gare de Lyon in Paris for Nice every day; the trip by T.G.V. takes about seven hours. More information: French Rail Inc., 610 Fifth Avenue, Suite 501, New York, N.Y. 10020, or Rail Europe at 800-345-1990.

LENGTH: 4194 words

HEADLINE: In U.S. Schools, A War of Words

BYLINE: By Richard Bernstein; Richard Bernstein is a national cultural correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
In a well-worn classroom at the San Fernando Elementary School, 30 miles north of Los Angeles, Aracelis Tester, a second-grade teacher, is reading ''Cuidado, un Dinosaurio!'' - ''Watch Out, a Dinosaur!'' - with her diminutive pupils. This could just as well be Mexico City or San Salvador, Grenada or Seville: a roomful of Hispanic children and a Hispanic teacher speaking Spanish.
In downtown Los Angeles, at a school called the Wilton Place Elementary, Chan Hee Hong, a first-grade teacher, is talking in Korean with the children of recent immigrants about the wonderful world of frogs. There are public schools in Oklahoma where Cherokee is the language of instruction. In Astoria, Queens, Greek is taught in Public School 122; Haitian Creole is a language of instruction in some 20 public schools in Brooklyn and Queens; New York, in addition, offers schooling in Chinese, Korean, French, Italian, Russian, Vietnamese and Khmer. 
In the San Fernando Elementary School, the teaching of non-English-speaking children in their native language enjoys a virtually religious status: it is seen as a kind of panacea for the generally poor performance of Hispanic children in public schools. But at the Glenwood Elementary School in the San Fernando Valley, a neighborhood of neatly kept stucco homes festooned with bougainvillea, bilingual education is anathema. The Glenwood teachers often conduct classes in Spanish, since they are given no choice by the Los Angeles School District. The school, a political model for some, is notorious for others. Hispanic demonstrators shouting ''racist'' and carrying signs printed ''KKK'' have picketed outside the school, where teachers have been outspoken in their view that teaching children in Spanish is a fraud, a trick played by tendentious adult theoreticians on innocent children. They say that bilingual education is a failure, a tactic that in the end will harm the chances of generally poor, non-English-speaking children ever having an equal share in the promise of American life.
The San Fernando school and the Glenwood school represent the two poles of a debate, already 20 years old, that has lately become more acrimonious than ever. This is a nation that has successfully absorbed millions of immigrants without creating a huge bureaucracy or spending tens of millions of dollars to teach them in the languages of their ancestors. But in the last few years, teaching children ''Watch Out, a Dinosaur!'' in Spanish and talking to them about frogs in Korean has become a matter of deep importance to an ever-growing minority.
Part of the reason for this is that in America today more people speak foreign languages than ever before. Neighborhoods like those in the San Fernando Valley, whose residents were largely white and English-speaking 10 to 20 years ago, today have a Hispanic population of at least 90 percent. In Los Angeles, school-district officials say that there are, besides Spanish and English, seven other major languages being spoken in their district - Korean, Cantonese, Armenian, Vietnamese, Filipino, Farsi and Cambodian.
Why aren't these students being taught only in the language of their newly adopted land? One reason is that organized minority groups are demanding they be educated in their native language, and they have won allies within the local education establishments of quite a few cities. For many of these minorities, the subject evokes deep emotions. Advocates of bilingual education believe that it represents the best chance for non-English-speaking children - who, not so coincidentally, often come from the lower-income groups - to enjoy the richness and opportunities of American life. ''We have found a way to achieve educational parity and, by the way, to have people who are competent in two languages,'' said Raul Yzaguirre, the director of the National Council of La Raza in Washington, an umbrella group of several hundred Hispanic organizations.
This argument, once a minority position, has acquired a new ally in Washington. The Reagan Administration, with William J. Bennett as Secretary of Education, was at best ambivalent about bilingual education. Bennett spoke out strongly against the whole idea, believing that children who were taught in a foreign language were failing in school because of it.'' The revised bilingual-education act of 1988 allows for up to 25 percent of the bilingual-education budget to be spent on alternative teaching methods; that is, programs other than native-language instruction.
Now the Bush Administration has appointed an unequivocal advocate of bilingual education, Rita Esquivel, to take charge of Federal programs in the Department of Education. ''We on the Federal level like to leave it up to the districts to decide on their particular program,'' said Esquivel, the director of the Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Languages Affairs. ''But we certainly would like them to maintain their native languages. That's the President's point of view.''
If the forces in favor of bilingual education have gained an ally in the White House, there are still plenty of people on the other side of the issue, people who are convinced that teaching children in their native languages is bad, both for them and the country. Bilingual education, they argue, is more likely to prepare minority children for careers in the local Taco Bell than for medical school or nuclear physics. ''It doesn't work,'' said Sally Peterson, a teacher at the Glenwood School and the founder of Learning English Advocates Drive, or LEAD, a group of teachers and citizens that has quickly gathered adherents across the country. ''It seemed to make a lot of sense and I bought it at the beginning, but after a year or so I saw that children were languishing in the program.''
The other, more subterranean part of the argument is political. Ethnic pride is involved here on one side, a sense that what is sometimes called ''white, Anglo'' education is demeaning, psychologically harmful to minority groups. On the other side, there is a deep-seated worry that more is involved than an educational program to help minority students. The country is becoming far more ethnically diverse. Immigration is no longer the European affair it was during the first half of this century. Hundreds of thousands of people each year come from the Caribbean Islands, from the Middle East and from a dozen countries in Asia. In other words, just at a time when a more powerful glue is needed to hold the various parts of the society together, some critics see an ethnic and cultural assertiveness pushing it apart.
Bilingual education is only one element in this picture, its opponents believe, a reflection of intensifying demands within the schools for courses that represent the interests of particular ethnic constituencies. It's no longer enough for children to learn who George Washington was. They have to learn to feel good about their own heritage. The much-discussed ''Curriculum of Inclusion,'' produced by a special minority task force in New York State last year, argued that ''African-Americans, Asian-Americans, Puerto Ricans/Latinos and Native Americans have all been the victims of an intellectual and educational oppression that has characterized the culture and institutions of the United States and the European-American world for centuries.''
The solution, the task force concluded, was a new curriculum that, by concentrating on contributions by members of minority groups to the culture, would insure that minority children ''have higher self-esteem and self-respect, while children from European cultures will have a less arrogant perspective of being part of the group that has 'done it all.' ''
What's at stake, then, is nothing less than the cultural identity of the country. Those who argue that bilingual education is a right make up a kind of informal coalition with those who are pressing for changes in the way the United States is perceived - no longer as a primarily European entity to which all others have to adapt, but as a diverse collection of ethnic groups, each of which deserves more or less equal status and respect.
''Rather than see the United States as a melting pot, we like to think of it as a salad bowl, with equal recognition of everyone, and I think bilingual education is part of that,'' said Suzanne Ramos, a lawyer for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, a group that has sued local school boards to force them to adopt native-language instruction for Hispanic youngsters. The fund's goal, she said, is to have Spanish-language instruction in conjunction with the teaching of English for Hispanic students through the 12th grade - in the fund's view, the best means of insuring that Hispanic culture is nurtured as part of the basic public-school routine.
''The disagreement is whether a child has a right to have his native language developed - not just maintained but developed,'' said James J. Lyons, the executive director of the National Association for Bilingual Education, a professional organization that drafted much of the Federal legislation on bilingual programs. ''There is a racist xenophobia about Spanish in particular.''
Those on the other side insist that diversity is all well and good; but they argue that bilingual education could lead to an erosion of the national unity, a fragmentation of the nation into mutually hostile groups. Leading the fight is a group called U.S. English, whose major objectives are to promote opportunities for people to learn English and to get a constitutional amendment adopted that would make English the official language of Government. Founded by former Senator S. I. Hayakawa and including such eminent figures as Saul Bellow, Barry Goldwater and Eugene McCarthy on its board of advisers, U.S. English has seen its membership swell to 400,000 in just seven years of existence. ''Language is so much a part of our lives that it can be a great tool either for unity or disunity,'' said Kathryn S. Bricker, the group's former executive director. ''And we are getting close to the point where we have a challenge to the common language that we share. Just look at what's going on in Miami, where a candidate to be school superintendent wanted everybody to have to learn Spanish.
''We are basically at a crossroads,'' she added. ''We can reaffirm our need for a common language or we can slowly go down the road of division along language lines.''
Bilingual education owes its beginnings less to classroom experience than to ethnic politics. The first bilingual classrooms in recent decades were established in Miami among Cuban refugees - specifically at the Coral Way Elementary School, where, as James Crawford, a former editor for Education Week reported in his book ''Bilingual Education: History Politics Theory and Practice,'' students were judged to be learning to ''operate effectively in two languages and two cultures.''
In 1968, Crawford reported, with the ethnic-consciousness movement picking up momentum, Congress passed the Bilingual Education Act, authorizing funds to give special help in educating children who did not speak English. Then, in 1970, a civil-rights lawyer in San Francisco, Edward Steinman, filed a suit on behalf of Kinney Lau and 1,789 other Chinese students who, he said, were failing in school because they could not understand the language of instruction. In a landmark ruling in 1974, the Supreme Court unanimously decided in favor of the Chinese students on the grounds that ''students who do not understand English are effectively foreclosed from any meaningful education.''
Neither the Supreme Court nor Congressional legislation required that special help for non-English-speaking students include instruction in their native languages. The motivation behind the suit was to obtain special help for these children so that they could learn English. But what is called Transitional Bilingual Education, the program to teach children in their native languages while they master English, was favored by various groups, including the Carter Administration's Department of Education. It was adopted by many school systems as the bilingual concept caught on - rather than the kind of all-English special help, generally called ''sheltered English,'' preferred by some teachers. Meanwhile, Hispanic groups became convinced that the use of Spanish in classrooms would help to overcome the difficulties Hispanic youngsters were experiencing in schools, giving them the second-highest dropout rate of any group in the country.
This does not mean that the Hispanic population is unanimous about the virtues of bilingual education. One celebrated dissenter is Richard Rodriguez, the Mexican-American writer, whose autobiography, ''Hunger of Memory,'' is a vivid portrait of the Hispanic experience. In one frequently quoted passage from his book, Rodriguez remembers how it felt when, for the first time, he found he could use English in school and be understood. ''The belief, the calming assurance that I belonged in public, had at last taken hold,'' he wrote. ''It would have pleased me to have my teachers speak to me in Spanish, but I would have delayed having to learn the language of public society.''
The Hispanic establishment tends to see the matter differently. Organizations like the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Education Fund have brought class-action suits to force recalcitrant school districts to create bilingual programs. Raul Yzaguirre, the head of the National Council of La Raza, claims that bilingual education is the accepted means of reversing the traditionally poor performance of Hispanic students. He enumerates the reasons why these pupils need a kind of treatment that previous immigrants did not require. ''One factor is numbers,'' Yzaguirre said, referring to the large concentrations of Spanish-speaking people in certain areas of the country. ''There's a critical mass. Second, it's a group of people attached to a particular place. The U.S. came to them. They didn't come to the U.S., so the idea of coming to a new country and having to adapt to it is not part of the mentality of many Hispanics.
''Another reason is that it works. I was around when bilingual education was born. The impulse wasn't driven by any need to preserve language. It was driven by a yearning for solutions to help the most undereducated minority in this country.''
In a small, spartan office in downtown Los Angeles, Amelia McKenna, a former teacher who is now the assistant superintendent of the office of bilingual instruction, begins a brief in favor of bilingual education by exploding what she sees as some ''myths'' of yesteryear. Among them: that the old-fashioned teaching methods prevalent in the time of our grandparents worked so well that there is no reason to change them now.
''We don't know what the dropout rate was, but it was probably very high,'' McKenna says. The Los Angeles Unified School District where she works is the second largest in the country after New York, with some 600,000 students in more than 800 schools. ''But it wasn't noticeable then,'' she says, ''because the economy absorbed unskilled labor.'' Now the economy requires quality education for success.
There are 213,000 ''limited-English proficient students'' in the Los Angeles system, according to McKenna, using the standard bilingual-education term for students who need help in English. A year ago there were 184,000. ''With that number of kids, it's clear that we're growing drastically,'' McKenna says. ''And we're not going to be educating them for the 21st century if we just continue what we have been doing in the past.''
Those who need help fill up whole classrooms, whole buildings, McKenna maintains. There are many schools in the Los Angeles District that have a Hispanic enrollment of well over 90 percent. Students live in almost entirely Spanish environments, watching Spanish-language cable-television stations, speaking Spanish in the classroom, in the streets, in the home. Many of the ''limited English proficient'' students - or L.E.P.'s, as they are known - do badly; others, particularly those from Asia, do well, even without any remedial help. ''A lot of the Spanish children are refugees from Mexico, El Salvador, Guatemala,'' McKenna points out. They are poor and do not have much of the preschool experience that will help them to meet the demands of early education. ''The Cantonese, the Koreans and the Armenians are more affluent,'' McKenna says.
At the Los Angeles School District, one of the books most commonly used for reference is a volume called ''Empowering Minority Students,'' written by Jim Cummins of the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education. Cummins's work, printed by the California Association for Bilingual Education, so well sums up the underlying issues of the debate that it is cited by both sides: one side uses it to show the theoretical justification for bilingual education, the other to prove bilingual education's ulterior political motives. Cummins raises all the themes of the bilingual argument: it endorses multiculturalism; criticizes what he calls the ''societal power structure'' of white, English-speaking America, and claims that native-language teaching is not just an educational device, but a blow against an inherent injustice.
''Empowering Minority Students'' does not argue that a child's inability to speak English is what leads him to fail if he is put into an English classroom. Children fail, Cummins says, because they are made to feel ''shame'' for belonging to a minority group, for not being a part of the ''dominant group.'' The only way to ''empower'' such children, he argues, is for teachers to ''consciously challenge the power structure both in their classrooms and schools and in the society at large.'' Bilingual education, he writes, is an ''empowerment pedagogy.'' It is an act of rebellion against white, Anglo domination.
Teachers in the Los Angeles system say Cummins's book is being taught in the special classes required for teachers to learn the bilingual-education methods. ''His ideas are accepted because they are useful to the bilingual-ed establishment,'' said Rosalie Pedalino Porter, a former educator from Massachusetts who has recently written a book, ''Forked Tongue,'' that chronicles her disillusionment with the bilingual-ed method. ''It's the old business of being a professional victim, of not admitting that anything good has ever been done for minorities. Otherwise you couldn't keep asking for special treatment.''
The idea of encouraging children who don't speak English to learn proficiency in their native language sounds like a plausible way to redress social inequality. But Porter is convinced that it could also have a negative effect. ''Before the utopia arrives,'' she said, ''and everyone has equal access, we are going to have generations of children who are going to be in tough shape if they're not able to use the language of the majority.''
She was alluding to a basic element of the bilingual debate that continues to swirl over the heads of some of the poorest and most disadvantaged children in the land, children who drift from one place to another, whose struggling parents cannot afford the luxury of reading them bedside stories, whose neighborhoods are often infested with gangs and drug dealers. ''Maintaining their language and their culture would be nice,'' Porter said, ''but it's not as important as helping them learn to succeed in American life.''
In a fifth-grade classroom at San Fernando Elementary School, Martha Ruiz, who is fluent in Spanish and English, sits at a low table with a group of a dozen or so little boys and girls, speaking to them only in English. She asks what a potion is, and a young girl with long hair and large black eyes replies in what sounds like perfectly mastered English: ''It's something that could change you into a frog or something.'' This class is the presumed end result of T.B.E. - Transitional Bilingual Education, in the pedagogic lexicon - and illustrates another tenet of the bilingual philosophy: that once basic skills have been mastered, children can make the transition from their native language to English without losing ground.
''Before,'' says Candida Fernandez-Ghoneim, San Fernando Elementary's principal, ''in most bilingual programs, the kids were put into English so quickly that third graders would be reading at kindergarten levels and the students' self-esteem was damaged. Now, we take the time to give the kids a real foundation, and they are really reading at their proper level. If they're depressed, if they don't feel good about themselves, they're not going to make it. But if they feel they're learning something, then you've won. Then they want to learn all by themselves.''
It seems to make sense; certainly it does at Fernandez-Ghoneim's school, which imparts a warm feeling to a visitor, a sense that the children of migrant families struggling economically are learning. But Sally Peterson's kindergarten class at Glenwood, where bilingual education is the enemy, also makes a favorable impression. The student constituency here is very similar to the one at San Fernando Elementary, with a high concentration of Hispanic children from migrant families; but Peterson concentrates on children whose parents have opted for virtually all-English instruction and she says that they are learning faster than the others.
Peterson and a junior colleague, Tracy Teitler, preside over 28 5- and 6-year olds sitting at two large tables in a gaily decorated classroom that has an air of controlled disorder about it. Hispanic children number about 20; there are a couple of Japanese; there is a Filipino; there are a few native English speakers. Over at San Fernando Elementary, they say that Sally Peterson is an advocate of what is pejoratively called ''sink or swim'' - just throwing foreign or Hispanic children into English-language classrooms and expecting them to absorb the language as if by magic.
Peterson replies that she gives special attention to the children who might have difficulty understanding English. You have to use drawings and act things out; you can speak a little Spanish here and there when it is necessary. You hug kids; you console them; you make sure that they understand what you tell them. Within about two years, she says, those who started out with no English master it very well, illustrating the near-miraculous speed with which children will learn the language of their environment.
The San Fernando School, one of seven model bilingual-education schools that have been created in Los Angeles (they are named Eastman Schools after the downtown school where the program was pioneered), has the resources to carry out a model program. But what about the other 830 schools in the Los Angeles School District? There, the results are not so promising, Peterson claims. The teachers themselves in many cases speak Spanish far better than English and the children thus end up in Spanish-speaking ghettos.
''I call it bilingualgate,'' Peterson says. ''The stated goal is to teach children English. At least, that's what they say. What they're not saying is that their agenda really calls for Spanish for as long as possible. It's because of the industry that has been created. It's because it's really a jobs program for Spanish-speaking teachers. The whole program actually punishes success, since those jobs and all those subsidies would be threatened if the children actually learned English.''
Among the subsidies in English cited by Peterson is a $5,000 bonus for teachers who are proficient in Spanish. No such bonus is available for any other type of special skill. In addition, there are local and Federal subsidies worth about $350 for each child in a bilingual class. ''If you're against them,'' Peterson says of the bilingual-ed establishment, ''they try to make it look as though you're anti-child. But the fact is that it's their industry that we are threatening.''
In his autobiography, ''A Margin of Hope,'' the critic Irving Howe, speaking about the ''ethnic'' generation of the 1920's and 1930's, recalls his hunger for school as a child of Jewish immigrants growing up in the Bronx; for Howe, mastering the English language was a badge of Americanness. ''The educational institutions of the city were still under the sway of a unified culture, that dominant 'Americanism' which some ethnic subcultures may have challenged a little, but which prudence and ambition persuaded them to submit to,'' he writes.
The question now is: What is the ''dominant Americanism''? Can there even be such a thing in a country committed to a kind of ethnic self-realization that did not exist when Howe was growing up? The answers will be hammered out in the years ahead in classrooms like Aracelis Tester's and Sally Peterson's, and they have to do with more than pedagogical philosophy. In the end, the way language is taught in this country will reflect where the country is going, its very identity.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 50, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 670 words

HEADLINE: CRIME/MYSTERY;
He Almost Got Away

BYLINE: By BEVERLY LOWRY; Beverly Lowry is the author of ''Breaking Gentle'' and is working on a book about Karla Faye Tucker, a young woman on death row in Texas.

 BODY:

DEATH SENTENCE
The Inside Story of the John List Murders.
By Joe Sharkey.
Illustrated. 305 pp. New York:
Signet. Paper, $4.95.
On Nov. 10, 1971, between 8:30 in the morning and 4 o'clock that afternoon, John List wiped out his entire family. Over breakfast, he shot his wife in the kitchen as she sipped her coffee and his mother while she stood by a toaster holding a plate with a pat of butter on it. Around noon, he picked up his 16-year-old daughter, Patricia, from school and shot her in the head. Then he took a shower, drove to town, withdrew his mother's savings from the bank and came home to ambush his two other children: Frederick, 13, and John Jr., 15. An economical man, John List knocked off four out of five of his kin using but a single shot each. Only John Jr. required extra bullets. ''John got hurt more,'' the boy's father explained in a confessional letter, ''because he seemed to struggle longer.'' Silly boy. 
As a genre, true crime usually means murder, most often among the middle class or the rich. John List was a bookkeeper. He lived in a house he couldn't afford in Westfield, N.J., a town that had not had a murder in eight years. What is enthralling about his story, though, is not who, how, how many or why he killed, but what he did after he quit murdering people.
Once he had arranged the bodies of his wife and children side by side in one room, Mr. List turned the central heating system down to a sensible 50 degrees - cool enough to preserve the bodies for a while, but warm enough to keep the pipes from bursting - wrote some confessional letters, switched on the radio so that classical music would fill the house and then drove to Kennedy Airport. He parked his car in the long-term parking lot, locked the keys inside the car and flew west. The bodies weren't discovered for a month. By that time, John List had vanished into thin mountain air.
He didn't get away with murder. After all, he had left behind letters announcing it was he who had done the deed. But he did get away. In Denver, the unburdened John List became Robert P. Clark, a fry cook with no past.
People who disappear usually turn up. They write home or return to their old habits. Mr. List did better than most fugitives, but in time he began to pine for a better job, more money and easier hours. People started to notice how much he talked about accounting. Eventually, Bob Clark fell in love, got married and went back to keeping books.
In 1989, 18 years after the murders, a sharp-eyed neighbor of Mr. List's saw a wax model of him on the television program ''America's Most Wanted,'' and called in to report him. The F.B.I. looked up Robert P. Clark. Discovering that he was a bookkeeper, the same age as List and educated in the same places, they knew they had their man.
In jail he explained his reason for the murders. Before he wiped out his family, Mr. List had been in all kinds of trouble, mostly financial. The bookkeeper could not tolerate such chaos, and so he wiped the slate clean, as methodically as if he were erasing a column of figures. He told a psychiatrist, ''There was no other solution. . . . I killed them all so that no one would survive. . . . It's like I had no control all the while I was doing it.'' ''Death Sentence'' is an original paperback, published fast and hard on the heels of John List's trial last May. (The jury found Mr. List guilty. The judge imposed the maximum sentence, life in prison times five.) As true crime, the book is O.K. The author Joe Sharkey is neither a particularly graceful writer nor a fabulously insightful one, but he gets the job done.
Here is what John List has to say about the coup he pulled off: ''I didn't really think I would get away with it for more than a week or two. . . . I decided to stay free as long as I could. I might have had it in my mind to turn myself in, but I never gave it serious consideration. I was afraid of the consequences. I was afraid I would go to jail for a long time.''
Well, yes.

PERSON: LOWRY, BEVERLY; SHARKEY, JOE JOHN LIST MURDERS (97%); JOHN LIST (92%); ROBERT P CLARK (57%); JOE SHARKEY (55%); 



454 of 1055 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 14, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 50, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 716 words

HEADLINE: CRIME/MYSTERY;
The Blood Covered His Rack of Lamb

BYLINE: By WALTER WALKER; Walter Walker, a lawyer specializing in personal-injury litigation, is the author of the novels ''The Immediate Prospect of Being Hanged'' and ''A Dime to Dance By.''

 BODY:

WHISKEY RIVER
By Loren D. Estleman.
262 pp. New York:
Bantam Books. $17.95.
Loren D. Estleman is best known for his series of mysteries featuring the Detroit private investigator Amos Walker. His new book, ''Whiskey River,'' maintains the Detroit setting, ditches the private eye, slides the time back roughly 60 years and emerges as an enormously entertaining novel of life and death among the criminal element during Prohibition, when Detroit was America's gateway to Canadian spirits and Lake Erie was a free-trade zone for anyone with entrepreneurial instincts and a machine gun. 
''Whiskey River,'' the first volume of a projected trilogy, chronicles the short business life of a young bootlegger named Jack Dance as he slashes his way among the gangs and gangsters that controlled Detroit's politics and economics as a direct result of the 18th Amendment. But this is not so much Jack Dance's story as it is that of his chronicler, a cynical, disillusioned newspaper columnist named Connie Minor, whose vocational rise and fall nearly parallel that of Dance. Each man knows he is the key to the other's success, and each man exploits that fact in his own way. For Minor, who possesses the intelligence and experience that Dance lacks, the symbiosis is a reality never to be acknowledged. But as the charismatic young hoodlum steals, double-crosses and murders his way to fame and fortune, Connie Minor finds himself accompanying him every step of the way: first introducing Jack to the underworld, then observing his illegal activities, then actually and unwittingly participating in his schemes.
Playing off such historical events as the recall of Charles Bowles as Mayor of Detroit and the assassination of the controversial radio commentator Jerry Buckley, ''Whiskey River'' hurls the reader into the middle of the gang wars that raged from 1919 to 1939 among the legendary Purple Gang, the Little Jewish Navy and the Unione Siciliana, and introduces such colorful might-have-beens as the cheapskate multimillionaire Joey Machine and the mobster Frankie Orr, who makes an incomparable dinner companion:
''Frankie transferred his napkin to the table beside his plate. In almost the same motion, he picked up his steak knife and swept it backhanded across the top of Mr. Norman's collar.'' From his vantage point behind his London broil, Connie Minor watches as ''a bright orange arterial spurt arced past my head and thumped the door four feet behind me. The slash opened like a mouth without teeth, dyeing Mr. Norman's shirt, jacket, and tie deep scarlet. The blood covered his rack of lamb like thick marinade, welled over the edge of the plate, and fanned out across the tablecloth, making the white linen transparent as it advanced toward the corners.''
This is not a gratuitously violent scene. It is played out to its detailed conclusion, and it has a profound effect on the ''uninvolved'' and morally inert newsman.
At every opportunity, ''Whiskey River'' strives for authenticity. And the immediacy of its atmosphere never waivers as Mr. Estleman takes us along in Packards and Hornets driven by men in homburgs or fedoras who course through accurately named streets and neighborhoods to get to the ''blind pigs'' that abounded in the social life of the period.
Occasionally the details fail, as when Mr. Estleman attempts to relate the finer points of criminal litigation. But he does a marvelous job of setting clues, bringing seemingly loose ends together and surprising his readers, leaving them nearly incapable of stopping at the end of any given chapter. In all these regards, he shows the signs of a master craftsman.
To the extent that ''Whiskey River'' has a failing, it arises out of its own aspirations. The book has a feel, a structure, a protagonist that remind one of Robert Penn Warren's ''All the King's Men.'' The comparison is bound to be made, and yet ''Whiskey River'' is bound to suffer from it. Mr. Estleman's novel explores none of the rich enigmas of the human condition that make ''All the King's Men'' a classic. Nor is it as reflective or provocative as E. L. Doctorow's ''Billy Bathgate.'' Instead, the appeal of ''Whiskey River'' lies right on its surface. Like a good sculler, Mr. Estleman rows not deep, but with great pull.

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 14, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2416 words

HEADLINE: What's Happened to Heroes Is a Crime

BYLINE: By MARILYN STASIO; Marilyn Stasio writes the Crime column for The Book Review.

 BODY:
''All the heroes dyin' like flies / they say it's a sign a' the times.'' Sam Shepard wrote that dirge back when he was just a Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, before he became a movie star and something of a popular hero himself. It is still my favorite word on the heroic condition, although from time to time someone will issue a snappy update on the subject. Russell Baker's recent comment, that ''heroes are pretty well all washed up in America these days,'' arose from his contemplation of the tarnished public image of Washington Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., a man who the columnist said had terrific ''hero potential'' and blew it.
Looking back at the slippery ethics that determined so much of our national behavior in the past decade, we might well despair, with Mr. Baker and Mr. Shepard, of ever seeing another heroic character in our lifetime. Or we could read more mystery and crime fiction, which is virtually the last literary frontier for the American hero. It's a rough genre, this field that includes police procedurals and private-eye novels along with the more genteel amateur-detective story of ratiocination, so its male and female heroes are not always as shiny as their mythic models. 
''Knights had no meaning in this game,'' Raymond Chandler warned us, in ''The Big Sleep,'' about the type of hero who plies his trade in this sinister world where criminality reigns and virtue is for saps. ''It wasn't a game for knights.'' Indeed, even Chandler's own ''man of honor'' - still the prototype for the modern detective who would walk down these mean streets instead of crawling in the gutter - adheres to a code of behavior that plays fast and loose with the law. ''Their allegiance is not to the law,'' Robert B. Parker observed of Chandler's heroes, ''but to something else, call it order, a sense of the way things ought to be.''
Unlike the traditional hero of English detective fiction, a superior human being of flawless character, the postwar American detective does not assume that crime is an aberration in an otherwise benign and orderly universe. Because he embodies the laws of society, the traditional hero can restore order simply by enforcing those laws. To the modern detective, the law appears impotent, its minions often corrupt, and the universe in chaos. Consequently, readers of American genre literature expect the detective to be an honorable pragmatist, but not a saint or even a law-abiding citizen like the rest of us. We just want him or her to be the person who sees that something has gone badly wrong with the social structure and fixes it.
Chandler got it right again, in ''The Little Sister,'' when Philip Marlowe discovers his client standing over the body of her gangster-lover. ''You fix it, darling,'' she says, handing him the gun. That's all we ask, really, of the hero. To fix this mess we've made of our world.
Fixing messes used to be a lot easier. For a hero with a personal code of justice, right was right and wrong was wrong and that was that. More and more, though, we are watching fictional detectives struggle to maintain their own moral equilibrium, as unnerved as the rest of us by the erosion of systems and values that, however inadequate to contain evil, at least served to define it. Nowadays, when a museum director can be arrested for showing the work of a controversial artist and when savings and loan officers can get off with bilking the taxpayers of hundreds of billions of dollars, the ambiguity of what we call crime is killing.
''I'm not as quick to play God as I used to be,'' declares Lawrence Block's New York private eye, Matthew Scudder. ''Whether or not there's a God, it's beginning to dawn on me that I'm not Him.''
Scudder began his career as a casually corrupt but essentially decent cop with the New York Police Department. He quit the force after accidentally killing a child in the line of duty. The department gave him a commendation; Scudder's conscience gave him a hard time.
Other authors who have pulled their heroes off the force lately include Joseph Wambaugh, Thomas H. Cook and Stephen Solomita; better that than set them up for the worst-case scenario of Kim Wozencraft's ''Rush.'' In this first novel by a former Texas police officer, an idealistic rookie follows procedures for undercover narcotics work (''Be anything you have to be to make the case'') and degenerates into an amoral junkie and street hustler. ''We are the good guys. What we do is right,'' she reassures herself, as she crawls around the carpet sniffing up specks of cocaine. But is the hero any happier on his own? Despite the freedom to stand outside the system, be his own person and dispense his own justice, the unaffiliated private detective suffers his own kind of angst. Some of this comes with the job of being a solo (in the sense of socially disconnected) operator - the ''classless, restless man of American democracy,'' in Ross Macdonald's phrase. The deeper pain, though, is the detective's despair of having any real impact on crime and corruption. Consequently, you'll find many of these characters examining the validity of their own heroic identity.
''I'm not at all sure,'' Robert B. Parker stated in a 1985 interview, ''that in this brave new world of the 1980's a decent, honest, incorruptible, brave and loving man is not an anomaly.''
The dilemma that confounds Mr. Parker and other genre authors is how the hero can change with the times and still function as a hero, when ''the whole point'' of genre heroics, according to Chandler, ''is that the detective exists complete and entire and unchanged.'' Mr. Parker's own Boston private eye, Spenser, experienced a career crisis during the 1980's, when new detectives were entering the genre and he was no longer the smartest, toughest, most sensitive he-man in town.
Spenser tried being tougher. (''A Catskill Eagle,'' published in 1985, was bloodier than a Mad Max movie.) He tried being smarter. (''Crimson Joy,'' 1988, was awash in psychobabble about serial killers.) He tried leaving town. (In ''Taming a Sea-Horse,'' 1986, he shuttled from Boston to New York to Maine to St. Thomas and back to Boston, feeling out of sorts the whole time.) He tried rising above it all. (An unbecoming tone of smugness made its way into ''Pale Kings and Princes,'' 1987, and other books of this period.) Paradoxically, Mr. Parker finally pulled Spenser into the present last year by going back to his own genre roots and completing Raymond Chandler's ''Poodle Springs.'' In this good and faithful rendering of a Philip Marlowe story that Chandler had barely begun at the time of his death, Mr. Parker unequivocally accepts the hero's alienation. ''All I have is who I am,'' Marlowe states. ''If I change, I disappear, because there isn't anything but what I am.'' At the same time, he takes a stand on who he is (''your pal, your protector, your confidant'') and sets limits on what he can accomplish in an imperfect world. ''There are things I can do. I can shoot, I can keep my word, I can walk into dark narrow places. So I do them. I find work that fits what I do, and who I am.''
Mr. Parker puts these words into the mouth of another man's hero; but his own detective must have been listening. On the job again in ''Playmate'' (1989), rescuing a college athlete from the consequences of fooling with drugs, and in ''Stardust'' (1990), protecting a film star so willfully self-destructive that no one else has the patience or sympathy for her, Spenser seems reborn - no longer the aging, impotent knight, but a man who has once again found work that suits who he is and what he does.
On the other side of the room stands the hero least likely to lose any sleep over his failure to contain corruption in a decadent society - the detective who is himself a criminal. Nobody writes these characters with more gusto than Elmore Leonard.
''The typical hero, the guy who's almost invulnerable and an expert in nearly everything, is not interesting to me,'' Mr. Leonard once said. ''My guy on the other side of the law is a decent man. He's an ordinary person who is in some kind of a jam because of the way he is. . . . My guy, he's so unpredictable, he can solve the crime or he can commit it.''
Mr. Leonard's industrious criminals shouldn't be thought of as lacking morals or ethics. These working-class crooks do have their integrity; in fact, they try extra hard to play by the rules whenever they find themselves in an unfamiliar social setting. It's not their fault that they have such a tough time cracking the ambiguous behavioral codes of so-called honest society. Chili Palmer, the Mafia-connected Miami loan shark who is the hero of Mr. Leonard's ''Get Shorty'' (1990), can't even dope out the esthetics of Hollywood movie making.
''There aren't any rules. You know, anybody saying this's how you have to do it,'' Chili realizes, during an inspirational literary exchange with an even bigger crook than himself. ''You know what I'm saying? The movie business, you can do any . . . thing you want 'cause there's nobody in charge.''
In his way, Chili is saying that, in the country of the morally blind, the one-eyed crook can become a national hero.
Genre authors working the territory between Mr. Parker's romantic traditionalism and Mr. Leonard's cynical existentialism are finding other ways to legitimize their detectives in an age that has learned not to trust heroes.
Loren D. Estleman, who writes an admirable series around a hard-bitten Detroit shamus called Amos Walker, took the bold step of satirizing his own hero. In the broadly comic ''Peeper'' (1989), he introduced a private eye, Ralph Poteet, so crass and immoral that one reviewer called him ''Philip Marlowe's evil twin.'' His current novel, ''Whiskey River'' (reviewed on page 50), is the first in a projected historical trilogy set in Prohibition-era Detroit, a time and a place of simpler, less equivocal crime philosophies.
Other authors have chosen to investigate the personal lives of their detectives, a tactic that can either humanize these heroes or lead to vapid confidences about their pets and lovers. Matthew Scudder's never-ending battle with the bottle proves more than a convenient device for Lawrence Block to get his series hero into atmospheric bars where he can chat up the colorful lowlife from Hell's Kitchen. In ''A Ticket to the Boneyard'' (1990), for instance, Scudder's fear of losing control over his drinking problem reflects the futility he feels about his efforts to stop a serial killer.
''Take away the problem,'' Mr. Block has said about Scudder's alcoholism, and ''you take away a dimension of his character.''
A case might also be made for Kinsey Millhone's acquisition of a boyfriend in '' 'G' Is for Gumshoe'' (1990), the most recent of Sue Grafton's alphabetized mysteries. Ms. Grafton's California private eye has a no-nonsense style and an independent spirit that could easily be compromised if she sets up housekeeping in earnest. But domestic relationships are central to this author's plots, which often require her detective to solve crimes by sorting out tense family relationships, especially between fathers and their children. In '' 'F' Is for Fugitive'' (1989), she works the theme into a murder plot about a young woman who attracts older men. Under the circumstances, it should be interesting to see how a man in Kinsey's life might affect Kinsey's ability to resolve the psychosexual conflicts that often motivate the crimes she investigates.
If it's just a matter of staying on the ball, the genre hero has plenty of resources. Police detectives can turn to the new technologies to keep their procedures up to date. Regional detectives can investigate the more sophisticated forms of wickedness spreading to their towns. Private detectives can always find fresh hell on the city's streets. As for the amateur sleuths, so many of them hold down day jobs nowadays - from antiques dealing to horse playing - that their specialty fields can provide endless inspiration.
But the heroes with more important things on their minds - like how to move with the times without losing their inner direction - must have the vision to place the crimes they investigate into a social context, so they can be viewed in the broadest human terms. These are the detectives admired by Ross Macdonald for ''their intelligent humaneness, an interest in other people transcending their interest in themselves, and a toughness of mind which enables them to face human weaknesses, including their own.'' The heroes people remember best are the ones who themselves remember that their job is to look after other people.
Sara Paretsky's Chicago private eye, V. I. Warshawski, brings such a perspective to the white-collar crimes she investigates and evaluates in terms of the people who are left homeless by these crimes, the workers who are thrown out of jobs, the honest citizens who lose heart. So does K. C. Constantine's Mario Balzic, the gruff and compassionate chief of police who bleeds for his economically depressed working-class burg of Rocksburg, Pa. And so does Walter Mosley's new private eye, Easy Rawlins, when he listens with sympathy to the old barbers and bartenders telling their stories in a Los Angeles ghetto.
There are so many people to help in the Navajo and Hopi territory of the Southwest where Tony Hillerman sets his novels that the job takes two detectives, each with his own vision. There's Joe Leaphorn, the father figure: ''He's sort of our supercop. Old as the hills. Knows everybody. Remembers everything. Forgets nothing.'' And Jim Chee, a mystic and the Christ figure of the series: ''He would learn the great curing ways, the songs and the sand paintings, and become a [shaman] for his people.'' Between the two of them, they would not only understand the evil forces infecting their culture, they would heal the people and cleanse the nation.
The times may be hard, but in detective fiction at least, they still breed heroes who fix those lives that criminal mischief has undone, and who have the compassion to rage or weep over the deeper human outrages that are beyond their power. Unlike the mythic giants from whom they trace their ancestry, these modern models don't kid themselves that they can restore order to an ungovernable universe. But they are bona fide heroes nonetheless and they do bring a little Promethean fire to mankind - even when it costs them their livers.

HEADLINE: CRIME/MYSTERY;
A Hopelessly Trendy Killer

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL; Frank J. Prial is a reporter and wine columnist for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE MURDERER NEXT DOOR
By Rafael Yglesias.
282 pp. New York:
Crown Publishers. $19.95.
Molly, a young lawyer, is married to Stefan Weinstein, a successful psychiatrist. They live in a handsome prewar co-op on lower Fifth Avenue. Across the hall live Ben Fliess and his daughter, Naomi. Wendy, Ben's wife, Naomi's mother and for years Molly's best friend, is dead. Ben crushed her skull in after an argument at their weekend place in the Berkshires and tossed her body in a dumpster in the parking lot of a shopping mall. He was arrested soon thereafter. 
He's out on bail awaiting trial and, though charged with murdering his wife, under New York law he has custody of 6-year-old Naomi.
Provoked by the bizarre case of Joseph Pikul, who was convicted of murdering his wife in 1987, Rafael Yglesias' sixth novel is a truly compelling tale of love, hate and moral ambiguity in contemporary New York City.
Emotionally cauterized by her own unhappy past as an abused child in rural Maine, Molly had immersed herself in the lives of Wendy and then Naomi. Repelled by the hateful Ben and enraged by his treatment of Wendy, it was Molly who discovered his bizarre other existence. Ben is a cross-dresser, with a separate apartment where he wears women's clothes. In trying to warn Wendy, Molly succeeded only in getting her killed.
To cope with her guilt, she plans to try to gain custody of Naomi before Ben is convicted and imprisoned and the child is claimed by an unsavory cousin of Ben's in Queens. Molly knows that she must gain Ben's favor to get him to relinquish the little girl. Stifling her revulsion, she begins to cultivate him. And a strange thing happens. Eerily, implacably, as one might be mesmerized by a weaving, deadly reptile, she finds herself attracted to him.
Mr. Yglesias is a talented young novelist who wrote his first book when he was 16 years old. His setting here, as in his novels ''Only Children'' and ''Hot Properties,'' is contemporary New York. Unlike many writers who use the city as their backdrop, he refuses to confine himself to a class - the Upper East Side rich, for example - or a clique - the fashion crowd, artists, intellectuals. To borrow a label from another form, he's a general-assignment novelist, ready to savor the city in all its diversity.
Like Woody Allen in the best of his films, Mr. Yglesias has an ear for the nuance that makes the New York setting unmistakable:
''Ben earned a scholarship to Cornell, majored in economics, and ended up on Wall Street as a securities analyst. He should have been living in the suburbs, I suppose, already married, but he had been detoured - like the rest of us - by the sixties, by drugs, and thus become hopelessly trendy in an effort to avoid his parents' trends.'' And then there's the New York dialogue: '' 'I'm sorry, Stefan, I love you, but you're a doctor, you think everyone can be cured. You think deep down everyone's good.'
'' 'Molly.' He was soft-spoken and gentle, although the wound in his eyes had not healed. 'I know you've done your best to learn nothing about psychoanalytic theory, but you should know that, if anything, just the opposite is true of a Freudian.'
''Condescension is the worst insult to a yellow-haired lobsterman's daughter. 'This isn't an exchange of letters in the New York Review of Books, Stefan. These are people's lives. You've had a lot of opinions about all this, and you haven't been right once.' ''
There are no heroes in Mr. Yglesias' story. Ben is a murderer, a fetishist, a manipulative monster. Stefan sees problems to be solved, never pain to be assuaged. Molly is driven by demons she can't recognize, much less control.
Wendy is the victim of record, but she is hardly the only victim. At the end of the story there is some peace - but little happiness. Lives have been stripped bare, dissected. Yet there's no indication that anyone has really changed. And isn't that the way it really is? ''The Murderer Next Door'' is a disturbing and quite powerful novel.
 
DADDY WORE MAKEUP
 For two weeks I came and went from our apartment without explanation to Stefan, who, wary of me, asked for none. I went to the office, worked through lunch (billable hours were now important in a way they had never been), got Naomi from school, brought her home to a sullen, rather beery Ben, chatted idly like a housewife while I made dinner, supervised homework, hygiene, and faced the thorny problem of Naomi's social life, in particular her upcoming birthday.
Feeling a bit foolish I bought a paperback on good parental manners and discovered that the rule of thumb is: invite as many children as the number of the birthday. Wendy must have ignored this convention - Naomi was going to be seven and there had been more than six children at her previous celebration.
I raised this question with Ben one night after reading Naomi her bedtime story. She still liked to be read to even though of course she was one of the best readers in her class. I left her finishing the chapter on her own, came out of her room, and found Ben in the kitchen, loading the dishwasher. ''Birthday party? Hadn't thought about it,'' he said. His big head glowed under a harsh neon light shed by an ugly kitchen fixture - periodically Wendy had wished she had the money and time to replace it. In the glare his thick skin seemed smoother and darker. Squinting, I fancied I detected a hint of makeup. He watched my eyes study him. He was ashamed of my observation so I must have been correct. Head down, he slunk away in a slow shuffle, like a scolded dog.
Why didn't Ben tell Wendy about dressing up earlier? I wondered. And why did she insist he surrender the Battery Park apartment with its secret wardrobe? What difference does it make if he wants to put on pancake and blush?
From ''The Murderer Next Door.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 966 words

HEADLINE: Evening Stars

BYLINE: By MARY PEROT NICHOLS; Mary Perot Nichols, the former president of the WNYC Communications Group, is a visiting professor of journalism at New York University.

 BODY:

ANCHORS
Brokaw, Jennings, Rather and the Evening News.
By Robert Goldberg and Gerald Jay Goldberg.
Illustrated. 399 pp. New York:
Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group. $19.95.
Do you want to know what makes Tom Brokaw, Peter Jennings and Dan Rather tick? Do you want to know how they got to the pinnacle of their profession? Do you want to know what it takes to get an evening news show on the air on deadline? If so, ''Anchors,'' written by a father-son team (the father, Gerald Jay Goldberg, is a professor of English at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the son, Robert Goldberg, is the television critic of The Wall Street Journal), is the book for you. 
The book is also worth the price of admission for its dramatic accounts of Mr. Rather at Tiananmen Square last year and Mr. Brokaw on the spot as the Berlin wall came tumbling down. One cannot help being thrilled by the author's account of Mr. Rather's sheer physical courage in going back to Tiananmen Square after Chinese officials closed down his live coverage of the student demonstrations. At 1 o'clock in the morning, in spite of a curfew and in spite of an anticipated crackdown by the Government, Mr. Rather returned to capture the event on tape and, the authors say correctly, ''as a consequence, [the students'] heroic deaths and their innocently idealistic message of political change had repercussions all around the globe, from Eastern Europe to Nicaragua.''
Again, ''Anchors'' comes alive as it describes Mr. Brokaw's newscast that began with the words ''Live from the Berlin Wall on the most historic night in this wall's history'' and the sight of thousands of happy East Germans streaming through the gate and tearing down the wall.
But, alas, there is heavy slogging through Mr. Brokaw's hometown, Yankton, S.D., to get to Berlin. As chroniclers of small-town life the writers are not William Faulkner.
It should get better after Mr. Brokaw breaks out of Yankton, but it doesn't. From Nebraska to Atlanta to Los Angeles, it's dull, dull, dull. An absolute paroxysm of dreariness produces the following anecdote from Mr. Brokaw's Los Angeles days: ''Dick Wald, the president of NBC News at the time, flew to the West Coast to look him over. Brokaw took him to a vegetarian restaurant called the Aware Inn, one of those health food places in Los Angeles with plants hanging down from the ceiling - the foliage dense as the Mato Grosso - and sprouts sprinkled on everything. And then, according to Wald, 'this nice young man started talking California politics, the national economy, the environmental movement, and so on, and it was apparent that here was not just someone who was good on the air, but a fellow with a good head on his shoulders.' '' Believe me, this is as exciting as the authors' account of Mr. Brokaw's early life gets.
Dan Rather's beginnings in Wharton, Tex., as depicted by the authors, are only a shade more interesting than Mr. Brokaw's. Both came from blue-collar backgrounds and both raised themselves to the top by sheer energy and ingenuity. Peter Jennings, in contrast, had it all and, for a time in his late adolescence, threw it all away. His father was a famous figure in the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and had come to be known as the ''Edward R. Murrow of Canada.'' The Jennings household was frequented by all the fascinating artists and statesmen who came through Toronto. But young Jennings dropped out of an exclusive private school and then out of a public high school.
His family sent him, at the age of 17, to a place where black-sheep sons were sent in Toronto: a bank. He lasted three years there, then went into his father's profession. Barred from the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation because of an antinepotism rule, Mr. Jennings earned his spurs at a tiny, weak-signaled radio station in the tiny town of Brockville, Ontario. ''He was, in short, a one-man radio band, hosting everything from the news to the late night 'Moods and Music' to a Saturday-morning gospel hour,'' the authors write.
By 1961, Mr. Jennings had made the jump from radio to television. He was working at a station in Ottawa when he was discovered by John Scali of ABC, and the rest, as they say, is history.
Those interested in a career in television or those fascinated by trivia as well as the medium's more important moments may enjoy this book. It would be a good idea, however, to read ''Anchors'' before the increasing numbers of viewers fleeing the evening news render anchormen obsolete. The authors' solution to this problem is not to get rid of the evening news but to slow it down. They would have the first third of the 22-minute broadcast remain the same - that is, midget messages for midget minds (my phrase, not theirs) - and then devote the last two-thirds to in-depth coverage of one or several of those stories. Presumably the larger brains among us would sit still for this. As an example of what has not been covered in this way but should be, the authors mention the savings and loan scandals. While I agree it is just terrible that the American people have not had conveyed to them ''the dimensions of the Savings and Loan debacle,'' unlike the Goldbergs I do not think television is the medium that can explain such complexities. It is a medium designed for short attention spans. While the authors mention the competition of the Cable News Network's daylong newscasts, they do not seem to understand that people don't want to be tied down to 6:30 or 7 P.M. They have been irrevocably spoiled by CNN, by their time-shifting videocassette recorders and by the sameness of all three network news programs, give or take a personality or two.
I, for one, solve the whole problem by listening to the news on National Public Radio.
