PUB-DATE: October 14, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1434 words

HEADLINE: A Portrait of the Critic as a Young Boy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. PRITCHARD; William H. Pritchard is the Henry Clay Folger Professor of English at Amherst College and the author, most recently, of ''Randall Jarrell: A Literary Life.''

 BODY:

WARRENPOINT
By Denis Donoghue.
Illustrated. 194 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.
Warrenpoint is the name of the seaside town in Northern Ireland where Denis Donoghue spent his childhood. To use the name of one's hometown as a title for an autobiography is an odd thing to do - as if John Updike had called his memoirs ''Shillington,'' or Philip Roth had written ''Newark.'' In fact, Mr. Donoghue has taken pains to avoid the familiar sort of autobiographical narrative in which childhood is revisited, sights and sounds are lovingly dredged up from memory and various colorful characters appear on stage to delight or terrify the young hero. The warmth that customarily suffuses such books is notably absent from ''Warrenpoint,'' whose tone is cool, even severe, toward the life it contemplates and aspires to measure with unillusioned eyes. 
From the beginning of his career as a literary critic, Mr. Donoghue has been a keen analyst of style. One of his best books, ''Jonathan Swift'' (1969), is full of acute descriptions of Swift's sentences and paragraphs; more recently, in ''Ferocious Alphabets'' (1981), the styles of a number of contemporary critics and theorists are perspicaciously examined. In ''Ferocious Alphabets,'' as in all of Mr. Donoghue's books, the assumption is that style is a compensation ''for defects in the conditions of writing, with the first defect, that it is writing and not speech''; thus a writer's chosen style is a strategy used to ''make up for the situation.'' Mr. Donoghue's own situation is that of someone who was raised a Roman Catholic in Protestant Ulster, who presently lives part of the year in Dublin and who holds the Henry James Chair of English and American Letters at New York University - a complex fate, to say the least, and in need of a suitably complex style to express it.
We may partially describe that style by noting what it steers away from. Apropos of his studying the violin as a child (there are a number of interesting observations about music in ''Warrenpoint''), Mr. Donoghue tells us that early along he developed ''a scruple about vibrato,'' thinking it ''an effeminate habit,'' and that even though he now knows better, he persists in hearing it as a sign of Romanticism's hymn to the free, mobile sensibility - and thus as something to be resisted: ''If Shelley's 'Ode to the West Wind' were music, you would play it with a lot of vibrato. One point I am sure of: if my father had played the violin, he would not have used vibrato.'' Mention of Denis Donoghue Sr. is wholly germane at this moment of truth, since he - not Warrenpoint and certainly not the son - is the real hero of this book.
Mr. Donoghue's father was a policeman, first in the Royal Irish Constabulary and later, after the division of Ireland in 1920, in the Royal Ulster Constabulary, until he retired in 1946 - at which point the narrative ends. He was also a man who mended his children's shoes, and a description of his performance of that task brings to mind Walter Morel's skills as a cobbler and mender in Lawrence's ''Sons and Lovers.'' Police Sergeant Donoghue was a man who insisted that his son walk ''like an officer,'' head high, no hands in the pockets; he was as ''straight'' in his upright posture as in his moral dealings, though his son notes that ''straight also means unbending, inflexible, unambiguous.'' But the son finds no ambiguity in his feelings about the father: indeed, Mr. Donoghue has harsh words (it is good to hear them) for the ''mischief'' Freud has caused with his insistence that boys grow into manhood only by ''killing'' or displacing their fathers. By contrast, this particular boy felt that his father was ''not only a strong man but the source of strength for me,'' a strength to be developed not by conflict but by example: ''My father filled all the space. . . . I needed from [him] only what he gave me. The rest I could imagine, or find elsewhere, or do without.''
More than once, Mr. Donoghue makes explicit the connection between his father and his own ambitions as a writer. Although as a youth it never occurred to him to attempt a poem or a story, expository prose seemed a possible mode of activity: ''Surely I could write an essay by putting one decent sentence after another one of much the same character, and send them walking forth as my father put one foot after another and walked handsomely.'' Perhaps so, yet it won't do to characterize the style of ''Warrenpoint'' as straightforward or without guile. At least something like guile is involved in the way - so as to avoid writing with a lot of vibrato - Mr. Donoghue strategically denies himself any extraordinary or specially endearing qualities.
His childhood, he tells us, was neither happy nor unhappy; he had a poor sense of smell; he's not sure he remembers exactly the kitchen of the house where he grew up; he was much too tall, no good at games (unlike his brother, Tim, who starred at them) and failed to learn to swim; he admits readily to cutting ''a poor enough figure . . . in many of the episodes I recall.'' He asks, ''When have I ever been heroic?'' - but does not stay for an answer. He can't even remember the plots of novels, has never ''told any of my children a story or read to them a chapter of a novel.'' Opera means nothing to him, oratorios are alien (since, he says, most of them are Protestant) and - here the indictment comes close to the comic - he has ''only once, and recently, seen The Wizard of Oz.'' ''What am I preserving my gravitas for?'' he wonders in a fit of mock-heroic soul-searching.
Such denials and demurrings and mild self-lacerations are really part of a cagey refusal to write some fluid, too-easy success story about how the lad from Warrenpoint grew into a distinguished international scholar and critic. ''My talents are such as to express themselves in circumspection,'' he writes, and this book cultivates discontinuity as well by breaking its narrative into short sections and by effecting sudden leaps and changes in tonality from one section to the next. Furthermore, particular remembered experiences are insistently turned toward the general and speculative, with a heavy use of big-name speculators in Western civilization: from Augustine and Leibniz to Pater and Freud, to Roland Barthes and Susanne Langer and Walter Benjamin.
Only when the air has thus been made ''thoroughly small and dry'' (a phrase from Eliot's ''Ash-Wednesday,'' which Mr. Donoghue does not quote) will the sentences seem to march with requisite character. Mr. Donoghue describes himself as having always been an ''opportunistic'' reader, ever ''on the lookout for phrases, as if I lived for the opportunity of using them.'' Impressive as is the parade of writers he calls up to testify on various subjects, one wishes occasionally that the opportunity might have been refused and the autobiographer been content to relax a bit within the precincts of his own lively mind.
In one of the book's more incisive self-characterizations, Mr. Donoghue writes, ''When I think of my early years, I find myself always in relation to something I revered precisely because its existence and force were independent of my will. . . . Mine was the intelligence that comes after.'' The real action of ''Warrenpoint'' lies not in what the young Denis Donoghue did or (more likely) didn't do, but in the intelligence and boldness with which connections are made by the writer's imagination. This boldness is particularly apparent late in the book, when Mr. Donoghue's reflections on the question of a divided Ireland come together with ones about his father.
With bracing asperity and evident distaste, he rejects ''revisionist'' versions of Irish history that would ''remove . . . the glamour of its sacrifices and martyrdoms'' in the interests of social and economic history. He remarks, mordantly, that ''unfortunately, Ireland without its story is merely a member of the EC, the begging bowl our symbol.'' In an even more wryly withering vein, he says about Conor Cruise O'Brien's repudiation of Irish nationalism, ''Nationalism is a fine flower, so long as it grows in Israel, Tibet, Poland, and Lithuania.'' The autobiographer is no more concerned to present Ireland with a better version of itself than to repudiate or correct his father's character. If, as Mr. Donoghue writes, he needed from his father only what that father gave him, the same can be said about his country. This is a style of accounting not to be easily dismissed, and it gives ''Warrenpoint'' force and a stubborn integrity.

HEADLINE: CRIME/MYSTERY;
Doing In Filthy Jack

BYLINE: By JOSH RUBINS; Josh Rubins writes a mystery column for Entertainment Weekly.

 BODY:

A CITY OF STRANGERS
By Robert Barnard.
287 pp. New York:
Charles Scribner's Sons. $18.95.
How do you make a murder mystery merry? After all, death by violence is hardly an inherently cheerful topic. Yet from G. K. Chesterton onward, gifted mystery writers (English ones especially) have found ways to bring a genial, even jovial spirit to tales of homicide. One favorite way: make the murder victim as thoroughly loathsome, as unredeemably toxic, as possible - someone, that is, who's virtually begging to be done in. Not only does this remove any hint of tragedy from the central demise, it also guarantees an abundance of likely suspects and juicy motives, since such a vile specimen is sure to have a long list of well-earned enemies. 
Robert Barnard, the most reliable and versatile practitioner of English mystery-comedy on the present scene, is a virtuoso when it comes to this man (or woman)-you-love-to-hate technique. ''Death of a Perfect Mother'' (1981) featured the perfectly hateful Lill Hodsden, whose children were only some of the people with good reason to wish her dead. The title character in ''Death of a Mystery Writer'' (1979), the bullying Sir Oliver Fairleigh-Stubbs, deserved everything he got.
And now ''A City of Strangers,'' notwithstanding its somber title and its often stark details, presents Mr. Barnard's most exuberantly nasty corpse-to-be thus far. Meet Jack Phelan, the scourge of the Belfield Grove Estate, a working-class development in the bleak suburbs of a contemporary Yorkshire city called Sleate. (Mr. Barnard lives in a contemporary Yorkshire city called Leeds.) A father of six, contentedly unemployed for nearly 20 years, filthy Jack spends his days guzzling beer, insulting the neighbors, picking fights, breaking furniture, hurting people whenever the opportunity arises - ''like a football hooligan grown up.'' (Says the widow next door: ''He never changed, only . . . ripened, you might say.'') He resents having to send his children to school, however briefly. The vicious Phelan teen-agers, Kevin and June, are already hardened criminals; the younger kids, with one miraculous exception, are precociously depraved. When the family descends on a local supermarket, the townsfolk scatter:
''There were five of them going the rounds of the aisles: the parents, June, Jackie, and Dale. Dale's push-chair and the supermarket trolley made them a formidable group to encounter - practically an armored battalion. Jack pushed the trolley aggressively, shouted instructions, got out of no one's way, cursed old ladies who were peering at prices to save a penny or two on a packet of teabags, and abused one of the shelf-boys who happened to be black. 'I wouldn't go to a Paki shop and I don't expect to see the buggers here,' he shouted ostensibly to his wife, really to all and sundry, and the black youth in particular, who was in fact Caribbean.''
Imagine the uproar, then, when rumors begin circulating that Jack Phelan has won a fortune ''on the pools'' - and intends to move self and family up the road to quiet, lovely, fiercely middle-class Wynton Lane, where one of the splendid late-Victorian houses is up for sale. Jack, a compulsive mischief-maker, revels in the shock and dismay, the fury, of Wynton Lane's current residents. So does Mr. Barnard, who sketches in the five very different white-collar households involved - hotbeds of neurosis and genteel hypocrisy - with a droll shrewdness and ruthless economy that are reminiscent of Agatha Christie at her very best. (Mr. Barnard's critical study of Christie, ''A Talent to Deceive,'' pays tribute to her underappreciated flair for social comedy.) But though the Wynton Lane dwellers band together in a not-in-my-backyard frenzy, they soon realize that they're powerless to prevent the infamous Phelans (who show up in all their slovenly, derisive glory to ''view'' the property) from buying anything they can afford - which means that when the Phelans' old house is torched, with paterfamilias Jack the sole fatality, Superintendent Mike Oddie has no shortage of possible candidates for the role of arsonist. Up on Wynton Lane there are all those respectable but highly motivated homeowners - including such improbable prospects as Mrs. Rosamund Eastlake, a longtime invalid obsessed with the retired school principal Daphne Bridewell. There are also, given Jack's personality (and his supposed recent windfall), more than a few questions to put to the not-so-grieving widow and other family members.
Of course, mystery writers who make jolly good use of the monstrous-victim gambit do inevitably encounter one potential drawback. Their most colorful character disappears - permanently - somewhere in the book's first half, and there's always a risk that things may pale noticeably thereafter.
Mr. Barnard, however, canny pro that he is, more than compensates his readers for the loss of Jack Phelan's entertainingly abominable, almost Dickensian presence. In the novel's second half, he sustains the Phelan flavor by shifting attention to the appalling son Kevin, who terrorizes minority merchants, and his sister June, a blase, small-time tart; they, together with parents and siblings, ultimately become a convincing microcosm of Thatcherite Britain's new underclass -''riotous, savage, with nothing to lose.''
At the same time, Mr. Barnard deepens his wry portraits of the nervous householders, developing a few of them - studies in hypochondria, sexual repression and male complacency - into tidy, satisfying subplots. (The standout: Mrs. Eastlake, who, roused from her sickbed by the invigorating anti-Phelan fuss, reinvents herself.) And Superintendent Oddie's low-key yet firmly paced sleuthing leads, by way of some bona fide Christie-like twists, to the surprise unmasking of the killer: a monster, no less so than Jack Phelan, but one of a distinctly less amusing sort.
In the end, in fact, ''A City of Strangers'' turns out to be not quite so merry after all. Having lured us in and cozied us up with Jack Phelan's extravagant (though never cartoonish) awfulness, Mr. Barnard subtly modulates his tone, from jocular to gravely ironic, as the plot's darker, more suspenseful elements take over. The result is as good an example as any of the humorous mystery novel at its unpretentious best: playful but far from giddy, perfectly poised between drollery (part satire, part human comedy) and the stern realities of crime and punishment.
 
THE FAMILY THE TOWN LOVED TO HATE
 Coming along Wynton Lane [Rosamund] saw a little squad of people: a heavy, dirty man who looked as if he had slept in his clothes for the past week; a slatternly woman pushing a push-chair and shoving forward the toddler who belonged in it, but who was instead walking beside her; a teenage girl, deplorably dressed, making a precocious attempt at sexiness; and lastly a smaller girl, maybe just of school age, but still uncertain on her feet. . . . What a gang!
Suddenly it came to her. The Phelans! This must be the Phelans. With feelings of dread mixed with excitement she watched their progress down the road.
From ''A City of Strangers.''

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
A 50th Birthday For Edsel Ford's Continental

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON

 BODY:
''The Continental, introduced in 1939, was one of the most graceful automotive designs ever executed, a fitting aesthetic sign-off for the age of the American classic car.''
Stephen W. Sears in ''The American Heritage History of the Automobile in America.''
This seems to be my week for Lincoln Continentals. First of all, I have been driving a new one. Then, just by chance, I discovered the hulk of a classic 1956 Continental Mark II on the lot of a New Jersey restoration shop and spent some time running eyes and hands over its lovely lines. That same day, I also spotted a beautiful metal model of the 1956 in an antiques shop and dug into my pocket for more than I could afford. 
The only part of this that was planned, in fact, was the test drive of the silver Continental, which seemed a good idea on a couple of counts.
This year is the car's 50th birthday. And the test seemed to have further merit because, like some other cars today, the Continental's dash provides information on instant and average fuel economy, not a bad thing given the price of gas and the probability that Washington's budget proposals will add further tax to every gallon.
The first Continental was conceived by Henry Ford's son, Edsel, as a special car to use on his vacation in Palm Beach, Fla. Returning from a trip to Europe, he gave sketches of foreign luxury cars to Ford stylists and asked them to give his car a ''continental look'' that would include a spare tire mounted on the trunk.
The vacation vehicle was delivered in February of 1939, and everyone who saw it thought it was sensational - so much so that the company decided to put it into production. The 1940 model, introduced in October of 1939, was built on a Lincoln Zephyr platform, had a 120-horsepower V-12 engine and cost $2,850.
The car has long been a collector's item, and prices now range upward of $30,000. The nameplate disappeared in 1949, but that second Continental, the Mark II, produced another instant classic when it was introduced in 1956, and that car, made only in 1956 and 1957, was priced at $10,000, lofty indeed when you consider that a standard Lincoln hardtop could be had for $4,600.
For 1991, the front-wheel-drive Continental is a four-door sedan in the middle of the Lincoln line, and it comes in two versions, the Executive series at $30,211 and the Signature series at $32,120.
Standard on both are such things as antilock brakes, computer-controlled air suspension, heated sideview mirrors and cruise control. But the Signature models add molded aluminum wheels, combination door locks and a power trunk, among other things.
Upholstery is in leather, with buckets up front and a bench in the rear. There is good room, but lack of storage is a surprising problem. The glovebox is a medium-size bin, containing a single cupholder in its lid, and there are pleated pockets on the doors, but that's it. No place for tapes, none for compact disks. Nowhere for a driver's coffee cup, and no handy place for toll change.
The driver does get an air bag in the hub of the four-spoke steering wheel, and the dash is built to accommodate a passenger air bag as well. However, Ford has had problems getting the larger right-side air bags (the supplier's plant blew up), and a company spokesman said they won't be available until December.
Behind the leather-wrapped wheel, you look at a digital dash whose speedometer paints itself in inch-high green. Buttons on the right side of the panel control the ''Message Display Center'' and show trip mileage, instant economy, average economy and how far you can go on the fuel in the tank. And that gets us back to what turned out to be an exercise in economical driving.
The Continental's 3.8-liter V6 is rated at 18 miles per gallon, city, and 26, highway, and three days' of mindless commuting provided a baseline average of 21.4 m.p.g. - not bad for a car that weighs 3,663 pounds but an average I thought could be improved upon.
With the message display set on instant economy and the constantly changing digits kept above the baseline, the highway figure rose to an amazing 31.6. And despite New York's impossible traffic and ever-present construction, careful driving produced an overall average of 22.8.
That was more than a mile per gallon better, and the process made the commute a lot more interesting. I did wonder, though, what Edsel Ford would think about today's luxury and the notion of fun with feather-footing.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 17, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1276 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Office Report Card;
New York's Business Conditions Get a 'Poor' Rating

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
In the eyes of executives around the country, New York City has grown markedly worse this year as a place to locate offices, according to a new survey.
Nearly one-third of all chief executive officers who claim familiarity with New York believe general business conditions in the city are poor, as reported in the annual ''Business America Real Estate Monitor,'' which Louis Harris & Associates conducts for the Cushman & Wakefield real estate concern. This is a sharp rise from last year, when 19 percent gave New York poor marks.
Specifically, the executives passed a harsh judgment on ''the climate state and local government creates for business through tax policy and the extent of regulation.'' This year, 41 percent think that New York's climate is poor, virtually double the percentage of previous years. 
Another noticeable increase has been registered in the number of executives who give New York poor marks for the cost and availability of labor. That rose to 36 percent this year, from 27 percent in 1988.
Cushman & Wakefield's chief operating officer, Anthony F. Sirianni, had a one-word explanation for the shift: ''Economics.''
If there is any comfort in the survey for local officials, developers and landlords, it may be that in more tangible categories - as opposed to the perceptual ones - New York would seem to be holding its ground.
For example, while Seattle gets the highest marks of any city in the country for its general business conditions, the New York area is nonetheless cited by more executives whose companies are ''actually planning to acquire office space in the next 12 months.''
''Major metropolitan areas are the places where business leaders intend to expand their operations,'' Mr. Sirianni said. ''They already have major investments here and, while they would like things to be better than they are, these are the places where they intend to make additional investments.''
''I think the negative things are a warning, rather than a statement that things are beyond repair,'' he said. ''It's a tenant's market in New York. Rents haven't increased as much as they would have five years ago. But the survey offers a warning that there are other factors that may overcome the benefits New York offers. You see the warning signs in the ways they've answered the questions of labor and quality of life.''
''Quality of life'' encompasses such things as the availability of housing, transportation and recreation. More than a quarter of the executives believe that New York offers a poor quality of life to their employees, while only 4 percent consider it excellent. Both excellent and poor ratings are the lowest in three years. The plurality of respondents, 47 percent, believe that New York's quality of life is ''only fair.''
Notwithstanding these sentiments, 7 percent of executives whose companies plan to lease, purchase, build or renovate new office space in the coming year say they will do so in the New York metropolitan area, versus 3 percent in the Seattle-Tacoma-Bellevue area. Indeed, when it comes to actual acquisition plans, the only locales ahead of New York are Los Angeles and Chicago.
Of those executives who plan to acquire new manufacturing, warehouse and distribution space in the next year, 8 percent plan to do so in the New York area, twice the number for greater Seattle. New York ranks No. 1 nationwide in this category - ''a very strong finish,'' Mr. Sirianni commented.
Moreover, one-third of all executives still give New York City excellent marks for ''easy access to markets, customers, clients,'' with only 10 percent saying it is poor in that regard. That is the category that they consider of paramount importance when thinking about office locations.
And although one-quarter of the executives rate as poor ''the cost, functionality and expandability'' of available office space in New York, that number has not worsened since 1989 and, indeed, has improved noticeably since 1988, when 37 percent of the respondents felt that way.
Yet there is a dark cloud even over the more upbeat statistics. The percentage of executives planning to acquire office space in the New York area is half what it was in 1989.
New York was not alone in the suddenness with which its ratings changed. For example, the number of executives who gave Boston a poor rating quadrupled to 20 percent this year, from 5 percent in 1989.
''We were surprised by the extreme volatility from one year to the next,'' said Warren Wechsler, first senior vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York. ''Even though there is a regional recession, that would not be reflected in so drastic a shift in the ratings of the cities as business operating sites. Many of the ratings given these cities have changed to a much greater degree than economic and fiscal circumstances.''
''I still think there are a lot of high-tech firms that want to be on Route 128 because of the proximity to Harvard and M.I.T.,'' he said, ''and many major merchant banks, both foreign and domestic, that want to be in New York because this is one of the three or four pulse points for the global economony.''
In other words, Mr. Wechsler asked: ''Which of the following does not belong? Paris. London. New York. Seattle.''
As to the dramatic increase in the number of executives who were critical of New York's governmental climate, Mr. Sirianni declined to speculate on whether that was connected to the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins. He pointed out that the very low number of executives who said the climate was excellent had basically remained unchanged since the last years of Edward I. Koch's mayoralty.
''The question isn't really about politics,'' Mr. Sirianni said. ''The question is really about - I hesitate to use the word bureaucracy or red tape - but the elements of a city government that are there to assist these decision makers in getting what they're looking for to expand their businesses.''
Interviews for the survey were conducted from July 2 to Aug. 20. The subjects were 400 chief executive officers or their designated representatives (typically chief financial officers or chief operating officers) in companies with revenues of $250 million or more.
Companies in the East accounted for 35 percent of the sample, with 27 percent from the Midwest, 23 percent from the South and 16 percent from the West. Manufacturers represented 32 percent of the sample, with 19 percent being wholesalers and retailers and 24 percent involved in finance, insurance or real estate.
Opinions on New York were reported only for those respondents - 50 percent of the sample - who said they were familiar with the city as a business location. It is not known whether those who were most critical of New York were executives who actually work or do business in the city.
And that was one of the concerns raised by Mr. Wechsler, of the Real Estate Board. ''There's no indication as to who these C.E.O.'s are,'' he said. ''So it's hard to say how that would affect their preferences. We don't know what we are being told because we don't know who's telling us.''
Cities besides Seattle whose general business conditions were rated as excellent by one-fifth or more of the executives were Sacramento, Calif., 29 percent; Portland, Ore., 24 percent; Norfolk, Va., 22 percent; San Diego, 21 percent; Atlanta, 20 percent and Columbus, Ohio, 20 percent.
Other cities whose general business conditions got a poor grade from one-fifth or more of the executives were Detroit, 30 percent; Miami, 23 percent; New Orleans, 21 percent; Boston, 20 percent; Los Angeles, 20 percent and Washington, 20 percent.

HEADLINE: Homes and Offices for Sterling Forest?

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
The long-delayed effort to develop Sterling Forest - 18,000 acres of woods, wetlands, streams and lakes that sprawl across southern Orange County 50 miles northwest of Manhattan - is gaining momentum as the owner moves to make the most of that region's economic boom.
Later this month, the owner, the Sterling Forest Corporation, the real estate subsidiary of the Home Insurance Company, will learn from consultants and planners how four basic development concepts it has drawn up for the property would affect wildlife, water supply, traffic congestion, solid-waste management, regional employment and local communities.
The company will then seek approvals for a preferred plan, which could be one of four devised so far or, more likely, a composite of elements from two or more of the design proposals. Once the plan is approved, construction could start on a new community with as many as 14,500 homes, schools and recreational areas, up to 7.5 million square feet of office and industrial space, hotels, stores and perhaps even a bus or trolley line.
The forest, the largest piece of privately held undeveloped property in the metropolitan area, embraces more than 27 square miles in the Hudson Valley - a territory larger than Manhattan. 
But the owners are moving forward at a time when New York State may try to buy part of the forest for preservation. On the ballot in next month's election is a $2 billion evironmental bond issue, the largest in the state's history, with $800 million set aside for land acquisition. Sterling Forest is among the properties the state is thinking about buying as part of its inventory of environmentally sensitive land.
New Jersey has already condemned 2,300 acres of Sterling Forest that extend into Passaic County, but the price is still in dispute.
Any development plans for Sterling Forest would have to be approved by the Towns of Tuxedo, Warwick and Monroe because parts of the forest are in each of those towns. The company is still months away from carrying final blueprints to local officials, but the plans drawn up so far offer a broad outline of what may rise on the land over the next 25 years.
''The forest is an asset that the company now wants to utilize,'' said Robert Thompson, chairman of Sterling Forest Corporation. ''But in the case of this property, preservation and development are not mutually exclusive goals.''
Mr. Thompson, a lawyer and former chief deputy attorney for Los Angeles, was brought in from California to steer plans through the development process.
Home Insurance, a property and casualty company, is owned by Ambase, the troubled publicly held Manhattan financial services company. Earlier this month it agreed to sell the insurance subsidiary to an investment group that includes Trygg-Hansa, a Swedish insurance company, and Vik Brothers USA, a European investor group.
A spokesman for Sterling Forest Corporation, which has owned the property for nearly 40 years, said that the transaction would have no effect on development plans.
Any development will face a host of obstacles - starting with the land's topography. As much as 70 percent of the forest is either marshland or steeply sloped hills. The bulk of the forest has no power, telephone, water or sewage lines or sewage-treatment plants that any large-scale development plan would require. And environmentalists in New York and New Jersey have expressed concern over the impact of any development on local water supplies in both states.
Both conservationists and community officials give the Sterling Forest Corporation high marks for its accessibility, its spirit of flexibility and for its having taken account of the communities' views in the development process at each step so far. But none of the four design concepts released by the Sterling Forest Corporation in a series of public meetings in the region last June has the wholehearted support of local officials, conservationists or regional planners.
''The sentiment here leans toward supporting further development of the forest,'' said the Supervisor of the Town of Tuxedo, Annette Dorozynski. ''But from our point of view, all of the plans call for too much housing.''
Ms. Dorozynski said she doubted that residents of the homes in any of plans suggested so far would pay taxes high enough to cover the cost of required municipal services. Whatever the company's final proposal, which is expected to be ready early next year, it has pledged to keep at least 75 percent of the forest open for the estimated 200,000 visitors who hunt, hike, fish and ski there each year.
This is not the first time the owners have sought to exploit both the forest's natural beauty and its proximity to New York City and northern New Jersey. In the mid-70's the corporation put forth a development plan that was turned down by local residents, who argued that further development would spoil the region's rural character. Another attempt at development was postponed indefinitely because of the oil crisis of the late 70's.
Three years ago the Sterling Forest Corporation looked for buyers for the land but later took it off the market before a firm deal could be made.
What has stirred the corporation's recent development ambitions is that while the rest of the metropolitan region struggles with a souring economy, Orange County is an anomaly; it is undergoing an economic expansion and development boom that has made it the fastest growing county in the state.
According to the Orange County Partnership, the county has had a net gain of 35,000 jobs since 1983 and 50 national and international companies have set up operations there since 1986. Among them are General Electric, Anheuser-Busch and Minolta, which last year opened its 90,000-square-foot North American headquarters in Goshen.
The Regional Plan Association has estimated that if Orange County continues growing at its current pace it will need 50,000 more housing units in the next 20 years. And housing is the centerpiece of two of the four development alternatives being considered by the Sterling Forest Corporation.
One plan, which would create a new community, calls for a mix of 14,500 units ranging from one-family houses to multi-family dwellings on sites up to an acre. It places most of the development east of Sterling Lake in the eastern portion of the property, near Route 17A and a yet-to-be-built north-south road.
The commercial component would total about 7.5 million square feet, including 750,000 square feet of retail space. There would also be up to five golf courses, at least one of which would be open to the public, and some sort of a community transit system.
A second plan, which would create the highest density of the four, would bring 13,602 housing units plus about 7.4 million square feet of commercial space, including office and research and design space, as well as a hotel and conference center.
This plan would be confined to the smallest area of the four and would leave the most open space. Most of the housing and commercial space would rise in a corridor between Route 17A and County Road 72, with little building in the western portion of the forest. Most conservationists favor this plan because it preserves the most forest land - 14,000 acres.
A third proposal assumes that no master plan is adopted for development in the forest and that as many as 170 parcels are sold off for development under existing zoning rules. It illustrates what might occur if the property were carved up and sold off tomorrow, but does not take into account changes in current zoning laws that the communities are considering.
Using this model, development would be scattered throughout the forest, rather than clustered in the eastern portion, and would result in 11,959 units of housing - mostly single-family homes - and just over a million square feet of commercial space.
A fourth proposal, which has been structured around the conventional suburban open-space development concept, calls for the greatest number of detached one-family homes - 9,000 - and the fewest multi-family housing units - 1,531. With this plan, commercial space would be kept at about 3.8 million square feet. Conservationists do not see any plan as ideal. ''The consultants have done spectacular design jobs,'' said John Humbach, spokesman for the Coalition for the Preservation of Sterling Forest, an umbrella group for eight environmental and conservation organizations, including local chapters of the Audubon Society and the Sierra Club, ''It is a shame that the forest is where they want to put it.''
''We feel it is the wrong site for any kind of development, no matter how well done,'' Mr. Humbach continued. ''Any development plan would turn the forest into a wooded suburb, and there are hundreds of wooded suburbs but only one Sterling Forest. It is one of the last vestiges of the great Northeastern Forest.''
The Regional Plan Association also has reservations about the four concepts, although its officials say they will not take a formal position until a master plan has been proposed. But in a letter to Mr. Thompson, chairman of the corporation, Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association, suggested that while the design plan that would preserve the most forest had ''some promising aspects,'' even that one would need extensive changes to provide less development and more open space.
Much of Sterling Forest is far from virgin territory. Portions of it were first exploited in the 1730's by Cornelius Board, a Scottish immigrant prospecting for mineral deposits. He discovered the iron ore that was to turn the land that is now Sterling Forest into one of the most active mining, refining and logging regions in the Northeast.
Under the ownership of James Alexander, the Earl of Sterling - for whom the property was named - a furnace was built and mines were added.
Mining was done extensively until the first part of the 20th century. In 1895, E. M. Harriman - father of the late Gov. W. Averell Harriman - bought the property. It remained in the family until the early 1950's, when it was acquired by the City Investing Company of New York, a forerunnner to Ambase.
Over the last three decades six residential developments with 300 one-family homes were built in Sterling Forest, as were office buildings for I.B.M., International Paper, Xicom and other companies. New York University established a medical research center there and for the last 15 years Tiger Mountain has held the four trails for the Sterling Forest Ski Center.
Sterling Gardens is now a 160-acre fairground where a Rennaissance festival is held each September. Moreover, some 400 new residences are to be built in the forest on land still owned by the corporation and on parcels bought by developers.
While preservationists hope that the bond issue passes, the state's acquisition of the land would not automatically preclude development. ''The state has never taken the position that there should be no further development in the forest,'' said Langdon Marsh, executive deputy commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. ''Nor is it likely that we would buy the entire parcel. Our objective is to find the right mix of preservation and development.''
Mr. Marsh said that it appears that goal could be accomplished if a substantial portion of the forest - particularly on the high ground - were left open while limited development was allowed along the corridors that already have residences and commercial buildings. He said that the state has met with the owners several times in the last few years and that it is having the whole forest appraised.
Mr. Humbach of the Coalition for the Preservation of Sterling Forest and others would like to see New York follow the lead of New Jersey and buy up the land. While the Sterling Forest Corporation has not contested the condemnation by New Jersey, it has gone to court seeking more than the $2 million the state has offered.
Mr. Humbach said his members were aware that it is the responsibility of the Sterling Forest Corporation to maximize the value of the forest.
''We recognize that the corporation is obligated to make the best deal for the stockholders,'' he said. ''That is why it is important that the state negotiate a fair price because development, we believe, is not the answer.''
The Sterling Forest Corporation would not be averse to having New York State acquire the forest, but company officials say they do not think the state will have the money to buy more than half the 18,000 acres, even if the bond act passes.
''I think that some sort of development will take place here in the next 10 years,'' said Mr. Thompson, the Sterling Forest chairman. ''It must be done with care and respect.'' The Tuxedo Supervisor, Ms. Dorozynski, agreed.
''The town's population is aging,'' she said, ''and our elementary school enrollment has declined. In order to have the kinds of services that we need and want in the future we will need some economic growth.''
''Another matter that some people don't want to face,'' she continued, ''is that even if the forest remains as it is, we will continue to pick up part of the tariff. As public parkland, even more people will be visiting the area and the pressure on our services will be greater than it is now.''

HEADLINE: Arts Face Lean Times as Patrons Retrench

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
BATTERED by cutbacks in corporate contributions and audience belt-tightening, arts groups are facing hard times.
In Litchfield County, Pilobolus, the contemporary dance troupe, has shortened its season.
In Hartford, the Connecticut Opera, faced with a $100,000 deficit, is playing it safe by offering less risky productions of popular works.
In New Haven, First Night, last year's successful collection of New Year's Eve performances, will not be repeated this year.
These changes come as banks, real-estate firms and other businesses, faced with their own money problems, are curtailing their contributions to theaters, galleries, museums and other arts organizations. 
''This is the most difficult period I've ever seen in 20 years,'' said Robert Gregson, acting director of New Haven's one-person bureau of cultural affairs, which was slashed from a six-person department because of the city's fiscal problems. ''In the past, there's always been a program on the horizon that you could envision, but that's not true now.''
Wilson H. Faude, executive director of the Old State House, a museum in Hartford, said arts organizations must learn to accept the new realities.
''Years ago, groups depended on individuals and foundations,'' he said. ''Then, everyone got on the corporate bandwagon. Now, the cookie jar has been locked in the closet, and the stockholders must be fed first.'' Mr. Faude said.
 
Chilling Forecasts
So the Mattatuck Museum is discovering. The museum, in Waterbury, is in the midst of asking its corporate and business members to renew their memberships. ''We're hearing stories about companies that are bankrupt or have laid off one-third of their workforce,'' said the executive director, Ann Smith. ''And when you're in that situation, they can't write out a $150 check.''
The situation is likely to get worse, not better, warned Thomas Griggs, an assistant vice president at People's Bank, in New Haven, who serves on the boards of several arts organizations, including Connecticut Grand Opera, in Bridgeport.
''When businesses were budgeting last year, they budgeted for 1990 with some degree of generosity,'' he said. ''But the economy has become poorer. So the scary part is that funding for next year is being cut drastically. Arts organizations haven't seen the worst of it.''
In addition to curtailing contributions, businesses, facing staff layoffs, can no longer encourage their remaining workers to volunteer their time, Mr. Griggs said. ''The business people just don't have the freedom and flexibility we had in the past to serve on the boards of nonprofits.''
The state's ''real-estate and banking problems have affected a lot of people,'' said George D. Osborn, general director of the Connecticut Opera, based in Hartford, which is trying to cope with a $100,000 deficit. ''We have a number of people who have seen their investments go down substantially, and, clearly, if someone is losing money on their investments, they're much more careful about making donations.''
To increase ticket sales, the opera company is chosing to perform sure-fire popular works, like ''Carmen'' and the upcoming ''Marriage of Figaro,'' he said.
Such a strategy is also being used by the Stamford Center of the Arts, which has laid off 3 of its 14 staff members.
 
Aiming at 'Commercial Success'
''If financial pressures increase, every aspect of the operation is affected, including the choice of programs,'' said the executive director of the Stamford center, Randall Brion. ''You do those things which have a very high probability of commercial success.
''In the past, we had presented a program of contemporary composers performing their own works. It wasn't big box office, but we had an artistic responsiblity. But that's a program we haven't repeated this year.''
Cutbacks in corporate grants are also hurting the Long Wharf Theater, said David Mayher, a spokesman for the regional theater in New Haven. Rehearsal hours have been cut, he said, plays with fewer cast members are being performed, and more collaborations are being arranged with other theater companies, to save money.
But those in the field say that while the large institutions plan cutbacks, the smaller arts groups face the prospect of going under.
''I don't believe that the community would permit the Shubert,'' in New Haven, or the city's symphony orchestra ''to go away,'' said Michael Bingham, editor and publisher of The New Haven Advocate, a weekly newpaper. ''But I think everything else is in danger.''
One casualty already is First Night New Haven, a collection of theatrical performances, concerts and parades, which had been scheduled for New Year's Eve. Canceling the celebration was difficult, but there was basically no choice, said Mr. Bingham, who heads the First Night governing board. He said he hopes the event can be held next year.
''A lot of the businsses that had committed money to First Night this year said, 'We don't want to back out, but we prefer that you give us a break this year, because we're feeling a lot of financial pain,' '' he said.
Robert Resnikoff, a spokesman for the Greater Hartford Arts Council, said he is worried, too.
''We're trying to give a dose of reality therapy to all of the arts groups, so that we can consolidate and strengthen organizations and come out the other end of the economic downturn stronger and more viable than before,'' Mr. Resnikoff said.
In Litchfield County, the contemporary dance group Pilobolus, based in Washington, is not in danger of closing but has shortened its season, to 27 weeks from 35 to 40 weeks, said the manager, Susan Mandler. Pilobolus often performs at universities, whose budgets are being cut, too, she said.
 
'Hit Coming and Going'
Real Art Ways, a contemporary art gallery in Hartford, moved to a less-expensive location on the outskirts of the city last year, when real-estate prices were high. Now, the cost of real estate has fallen, but so has the organization's income, said the executive director, Will K. Wilkins.
''We managed to be the victim of the boom right when it busted,'' he said. ''We got hit coming and going.''
New Haven has always been a cultural center, but organizations there are particularly feeling the pinch, said the executive director of the local arts council, Frances Clark.
''We have a very small corporate base,'' she said. ''Now, it's getting worse and worse. There is practically no money.''
Performance Studio, a theatrical organization, mounted productions in a vacant restaurant in downtown New Haven, until the owner found he could no longer afford to keep the place vacant and is now trying to find a paying tenant, said the group's artistic director, Amy Seham. This was the latest blow for the theater, which two years ago was forced to end its popular outdoor Shakespeare plays because of declining corporate sponsorship.
 
Bookings Cut Back
Another New Haven group, Orchestra New England, is emerging from bankruptcy into the current tight economy. The group has lost the corporate sponsor for its annual Thanksgiving concert and has found its bookings by public schools and community groups cut back, said the general manager, Russ Rosensweig. She said the orchestra is pinning its hopes on a soon-to-be released compact disk, ''The Orchestral Music of Charles Ives.''
''This is being released internationally, so we're going to look for money outside of New England, where the recession is going to hit,'' Ms. Rosensweig said. No matter how the economy fares, it should not serve as an excuse for business to abandon the arts, said Mr. Griggs, the banker in New Haven.
''It is the responsibility of the corporate businesses to help these organizations through the tough times, because they are what makes Connecticut a nice place to be,'' he said. ''If they go out of business when times are tough, when things get better, we won't have them. You can't just re-create something like Long Wharf Theater.''

Caught between funding cutbacks and audience belt-tightening, Pilobolus has shortened its season (pg. 8) (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: National Attention On Spirited Contest

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
NOT every Congressional race can feature a visit from Robert Redford and a stopover by President Bush. But such political ammunition is being hauled out in the Fifth District battle between a popular three-term Waterbury Alderman, Gary A. Franks, the Republican candidate, and a former Congressman and television newscaster, Toby Moffett, the Democratic nominee.
Mr. Bush's visit, scrubbed last week because of the budget debate in Washington, has been rescheduled for Oct. 23. His appearance underscores the contest's status as one of the most watched among the two dozen House races in the nation. 
Should he win the seat, which is currently held by the Republican gubernatorial candidate, John G. Rowland, of Waterbury, Mr. Franks would become the first black Republican since 1935 to sit as a voting member in the House. If Mr. Moffett wins, it would mark a major political comeback for a 1970's wunderkind who lost bids for the United States Senate in 1982 and for governor in 1986.
The race has also been unusually spirited, with Mr. Franks loudly calling Mr. Moffett a carpetbagger for recently moving to the district and Mr. Moffett repeatedly challenging his opponent to release his Federal and state income-tax returns.
 
'Nice, Clear Contrast'
''It's been rough and tumble,'' said Mr. Franks's press secretary, Stephen R. Beaujon.
The well-funded campaign, like that in the Third District between State Senator Thomas Scott, a Republican from Milford, and Rosa DiLauro, a Democrat from New Haven, presents an unusually stark contrast between the candidates' political philosophies. The Third District seat is now held by the Democratic gubernatorial nominee, Bruce A. Morrison, of Hamden. ''It is a very nice, clear contrast for people,'' Mr. Moffett said. Mr. Franks is a conservative, favors expanding the use of the death penalty, opposes the Federal family-leave legislation, says he believes the Federal budget should be cut principally through spending reductions and opposes the proposed Civil Rights Act of 1990, saying it resembles a quota system.
''Franks takes the Jesse Helms position, and he is out of synch with the entire district,'' Mr. Moffett said. ''He could be representing Grosse Pointe, Mich., more easily than Waterbury.''
Mr. Moffett is a liberal who favors the civil-rights and family-leave bills, opposes the death penalty and generally believes government intervention is a positive and productive force.
''He is a tax-and-spend liberal, a career politician from the past, a Jimmy Carter retread,'' Mr. Franks said.
Mr. Franks, 37 years old, also supports a cut in the capital-gains tax to help stimulate the economy. Mr. Moffett, 46, has said that he is ''not fundamentally opposed'' to such a plan, if it is carefully structured and includes raising other taxes for wealthy Americans.
''Moffett is trying to grab some conservative garb and wrap himself in it,'' Mr. Beaujon said.
Until last fall, Mr. Moffett worked for a New Britain television station. In recent months, he has been a self-employed environmental consultant.
 
'Against the Reagan Era'
He won his party's nomination in a fiercely contested battle with the Mayor of Shelton, Michael Pacowta, who decided against running in a primary after achieving more than 20 percent of the delegates at the Democratic Party's Fifth District convention in July.
''I'm running against the Reagan era, and I make no bones about that,'' Mr. Moffett said.
Mr. Franks has repeatedly criticized Mr. Moffett for his recent move to Newtown, in the Fifth District, which meanders across the western half of the state from Meriden to Danbury and includes such wealthy towns as Weston and Wilton, as well as Waterbury and the old blue-collar mill towns along the Naugatuck River.
Previously, Mr. Moffett had lived for three years in Branford, in the Third District. In his years in the House, representing the Sixth District from 1974 to 1982, he lived in Litchfield. There is no residency requirement for Congressional candidates. ''He is an opportunist,'' Mr. Franks said. ''He took a one-year lease in January, and he is trying to use the district to go to Washington.''
Mr. Moffett countered that he has spent far more time over the course of his political career working in the district. ''The issue here is who is the fighter here, and who does not have a record,'' he said. ''The real issue is who is the stranger and who is not.'' Mr. Moffett characterized the race as a contest between someone ''who remembers where they came from'' and someone ''who forgets.''
Mr. Franks ''shows no interest, no sense of outrage in urban problems,'' Mr. Moffett said. ''He has never fought and bled for people and cities who need a break.''
He said Mr. Franks comes from the ''I got mine, you get yours'' school of politics. ''If you are perceived as selling your soul, you lose respect from everyone,'' Mr. Moffett added.
 
Five-Candidate Field
Mr. Franks, who grew up in Waterbury and was graduated from Yale University, won his party's nomination in July at a seven-hour, nine-ballot, five-candidate convention. The other Republicans who vied for the spot were Steve Watson, of Danbury, State Senator James H. McLaughlin, of Brookfield, State Representative Alan Schlesinger, of Derby, and former State Representative Warren Sarasin, of Beacon Falls.
Mr. Franks, who owns his own real-estate company, defended his decision not to release his tax forms by saying that he had met all the Federal Election Commission requirements. ''I'm not going to be singled out and do something that other Congressional candidates have not done,'' he said.
In response, Mr. Moffett asked: ''Did he pay his fare share? We don't know. It's an issue that won't go away.''
Mr. Franks also dismissed charges that he is a slumlord because several of his properties occupied by low-income residents have been cited for minor building-code violations.
''It is very easy to get a violation, for a missing smoke detector battery or whatever,'' he said. ''This is a way to attack individuals when candidates don't have anything else to talk about.''
 
Visit From Ex-Speaker
Mr. Franks, meanwhile, has continued to hammer away at Mr. Moffett's liberalism. He noted that Mr. Moffett intends to bring former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., of Massachusetts, into the district for campaign appearances. ''He is bringing in Mr. Tax-and-Spend himself,'' Mr. Franks said.
Mr. Redford, who owns a home in Weston, touted Mr. Moffett's environmental record during a stop in Danbury two weeks ago.
Mr. Franks has defused private murmurings by top Republicans in the district that they were unhappy with his campaign. ''With the President coming into Waterbury, that is the ultimate sign of support from the Republican Party,'' he said.
Besides the Presidential visit, Mr. Franks is expecting campaign appearances by Barbara Bush, and Marilyn Quayle, the wife of Vice President Dan Quayle. Mr. Franks said he expects to be aided by Mr. Rowland's political coattails in the district.
''I believe it will play a major role in the race,'' he said. ''John will cause the voters to come out in Presidential-year numbers in the Fifth District, and in Waterbury, a large number of Republicans will turn out.''

HEADLINE: Closter Journal;
A Harvest That Helps the Needy

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: CLOSTER

 BODY:
THE autumn sun beat down on Mary Crain, but that didn't seem to matter because there was the smell of harvest in the air. At her feet, a bushel of just-picked green and red peppers gave off a fragrance not found in supermarkets.
''Try finding these in the produce aisle,'' she said, straightening up and wiping her brow with the back of her hand. ''You don't mind this part of the job so much when you think about where it's going to. What we grow here fills a few empty stomachs, and that's what a farm was meant to do.''
For Mrs. Crain and a core of volunteers who manage the historic Abram Demaree Homestead on the corner of Old Hook and Schraalenburgh Roads here, preserving an 18th-century Dutch Huguenot-style farmhouse and recalling Bergen County's agricultural history are not enough. For the last two years, they have helped farm the land adjacent to the site, and its rewards have been reaped by the needy of two states. 
 
Believing in Something
''I guess some people might think that we're a little odd to do all this,'' said Mrs. Crain, a Haworth resident and the nonprofit group's president. ''But is it too much trouble to believe in something and go out and do something about it? I think not.''
The vegetables, grown on about seven acres of land planted by a local farmer, are aiding regional nutrition programs, like the Salvation Army Meal Project in Hackensack, as well as soup kitchens in New York City. The produce is given free to established charitable organizations, Mrs. Crain said.
The harvesting became a reality, she said, because the homestead wanted to convey ''a sense of what a working farm is all about.''
The roads' intersection, she said, is one of the busiest in the county - a recent county traffic study indicates that about 18,000 cars travel by daily - ''and we wanted people who go by to see that this is how it was long ago, when lives and the economy were not ruled by computer chips and the stock market.''
Rick Henning, a spokesman for the Rivervale Realty Company, which leases the acreage to the homestead group for $1 annually, said, ''What they've accomplished here is incredible and should serve as a lesson to all of us.'' Through the group's need to heighten a sense of historic awareness, the homeless are being reached out of a common effort, he said.
For Lieut. Jorge Diaz, director of the Salvation Army Community Center in Hackensack, the effort comes at a time when more and more homeless people are taxing his limited resources.
''We really don't have enough funds to go around, and these vegetables help to augment our meals,'' he said. ''This is hearty food, and for many, this becomes the bowl of soup served up with a roll that holds them over from day to day.'' His organization feeds about 50 people a day, he said.
John R. Mooney, a spokesman for City Harvest, a New York City nonprofit organization that ships about 10,000 pounds of food every day to more than 100 shelters and assistance programs in the city, said: ''That food is literally helping thousands to get by, and it couldn't have come at a better time. Their foodstuff is good, it's fresh and it's badly needed.''
Mrs. Crain said that volunteers had helped in the harvest but that the amount and variety of the crops - including five types of peppers, three kinds of tomatoes, eggplant, squash, green beans, turnips, lettuce and collard greens, guarded by a scarecrow - were more plentiful than expected.
''We've been able to manage some of the picking, but we kind of fell short,'' she said. But a solution was realized.
''A church group from New York was supposed to come down and pick up a load of vegetables, but they wound up arriving a day early,'' Mrs. Crain said. ''Some of it was picked, a lot of it wasn't and when I told them that, they just said, 'Well, point us to where it's at and we'll do the picking.' ''
Members of the Open Door Church of God and Christ, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, worked for hours filling bushel baskets and have returned often. For many church members, picking crops destined to help others has brought back memories.
''This is nothing for me because I grew up on a farm,'' said Henry Cook, a North Carolina native, as he loaded a bushel of ripe tomatoes onto an aging church minibus. ''As a kid, our days were long out in the field and this ain't nothing,'' he said.
He added that the crop picked would go toward preparing meals for a regularly scheduled Saturday dinner for the needy as well as a twice weekly food giveaway that helps about 500 families in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
''You know, people think about the homeless and all they see are those by themselves in the street, but that ain't so,'' Mr. Cook said. ''It's not what we see. We're seeing people with kids that don't have enough to make ends meet and that's where this food goes, and thank God for it.''
 
'Eating Instead of Needing'
For Melvin Lee Ward, a church volunteer also raised on a farm, the harvest means feeding those less fortunate than himself.
''I put food on the table for others by using my hands,'' he said, holding up two bell peppers the size of softballs. ''Tomorrow or the next, somebody's going to be eating instead of needing.''
Laurence E. Smith, a church member and spot welder by profession, said that ''sometime a while back somebody helped me when I needed it'' and that the harvest was just one means of ''giving back the courtesy.''
''Whether it's us doing the picking or these people here who thought enough to grow this fine food and give it away, we're all choosing to help to give a helping hand to folks that can't help themselves,'' he said. Other volunteers echoed the feelings. ''I heard about what they were doing here and felt that I should do my part,'' said Cindy Kaplan of Haworth, an independent film producer. ''We all need to reach out and make that difference.'' For Mrs. Crain, the planting and harvest are a chance for herself and the homestead organization to help a community that extends beyond the bounds of the farmland and the municipality. ''The homestead exists because of people's concern and generosity,'' she said, explaining that its budget is based on private donations and funds generated by an annual arts and craft sale, from Nov. 8 through Dec. 16.
Though the ground is fertile, some crops do better than others.
 
Bad Luck With Pumpkins
''The last couple of years, we've had bad luck with pumpkins,'' Mrs. Crain said. ''We were able this season to grow a couple of good-sized ones, but somebody came through here the other night and stole them.''
Last year's pumpkins were lost to groundhogs after volunteers had promised to donate them to gravely ill children at local hospitals. The crop perished, but the promise did not. Mrs. Crain purchased pumpkins, and volunteers helped to deliver them.
Next year, the group plans to cultivate additional acreage. ''We're trying to get a corporation interested in underwriting a small tractor for us,'' Mrs. Crain said.
The donations are appreciated in ways that may never be seen, Mr. Cook said. ''Some people don't know what it is to be hungry,'' he said, ''but we see some families where the kids go without because the welfare check goes to drugs instead of what's right. To see a small child smile because he's eating regular, that makes all difference. Kids ain't done nothing to nobody. There's no need for them to suffer.''

GRAPHIC: Photos; Mary Crain, above, and James Dudley, left, during harvest on about seven acres of land that is adjacent to the homestead. The food is to be distributed to the needy through charitable organizations (Photographs by F.N. Kinney for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1201 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Seattle Induces Office Builders to Include Child Care

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
 In four other cities that give developers density bonuses for child care -- Irvine, Calif., Portland, Ore., Cincinnati and Hart ford -- proposed projects have been put on hold until sluggish real estate markets im prove.
In the other areas where child-care centers or fees for a community day-care fund are mandatory -- Clayton, Concord, Danville, Martinez, San Francisco and San Ramon, all in California, plus Boston -- only a handful, mostly in California, have been built in new properties. Most developers have chosen to put money in a community child-care fund rather than meet strict codes or negotiate with day-care operators.
In 1985, a change in the zoning code here gave builders 12 square feet of floor space for every foot of ground-level space dedicated to day care -- twice the bonus proposed for New York City by the Real Estate Board of New York in a package of proposals to stimulate development. New York has no mandated or optional zoning statute on day-care centers. 
The offer here meant Wright Runstad & Company, which provided a 2,000-square-foot day-care center, could add 24,000 square feet to its Washington Mutual Tower.
A moratorium that began in May 1989 and continues through next May on new down town office high-rises has prevented any fur ther use of the bonus. But developers are expected to take advantage of it in the future.

When the 1.05-million-square-foot Wash ington Mutual Tower opened in 1989, Wright Runstad advertised it as "an office building so friendly you can bring your kids to work." The day-care center, with its 22 children, 2 months to 2 1/2 years old, is tucked into a courtyard behind a fountain. The center oper ates at capacity.
The Y.W.C.A. operates the center, which is subsidized by United Way. "It's convenient for parents who work in the building," said Tema Nesoff, its assistant director. "They see what the child is doing during the day."
Costs range from $285 to $650 a month, depending on the child's age, and 30 percent of the children come from low-income fam ilies. Another concern, Harbor Development Company, lets the center use a nearby empty lot as a play area and local architects de signed outdoor equipment free of charge.
Steve Trainer, senior vice president of Wright Runstad, said his company had long wanted to place child care in downtown projects. But state law required that centers be built at street level, eliminating most towers because first floors on Seattle's hilly streets often range from below to above grade. That law has since been eased.
"This is definitely a start on what the city envisioned," said Rebecca Herzfeld, the city's manager of code development and coordination.
But Billie Young, Seattle's child-care coor dinator, noted that the costs of providing care tend to be higher downtown than in neighbor hoods. Centers downtown tend to be smaller, so there are no economies of scale that larger neighborhood centers can achieve.
Staff members are paid more to work in downtown than in the suburbs. Because par ents who want to take their children down town demand high quality in care, more staff members are needed in the city core. But proponents say that day-care centers in downtown offices tend to "humanize" the often sterile environments.
The publicity surrounding the incentive program has encouraged developers to in clude day care even if they gained their permits prior to the zoning change and thus were not entitled to a density bonus, Ms. Herzfeld said.
For example, Pacific First Centre, a Pres cott Development Company project complet ed last year, provides an 8,000-square-foot day-care center for 55 children, operated by Pacific First Montessori. The developer gave the operator a five-year lease at nominal rent.
Dick Clotfelter, president of Prescott De velopment, said he was marketing the 1.07- million-square-foot building with the day-care center as an incentive. A store in the 8,000 square feet the center occupies would have rented for about $12 a square foot, or $96,000 a year, he said.
Kelly Sandy, whose wife, Linda, works in the Pacific First building, said he felt a full day would be too tiring for his 3 1/2-year-old son, Curtis, so a nanny picks the child up after lunch. He chose the Pacific First day-care center over one near his home.
Suzanne Haggard, director of the Pacific First Montessori, took out a Small Business Administration loan to finance her school/-day-care center, which opened in mid-1989. Costs range from $550 to $750 a month, depending on age of the child.
"We're looking for new ways to finance child care and have been pushing for help from developers nationally," said Caroline Eichman, research director of the Child Care Action Campaign. "Seattle has a very good program.
She said San Francisco has seen little success so far with its five-year-old law de signed to promote child care in office build ings. It requires developers of buildings larg er than 50,000 square feet to pay $1 for every gross square foot or to set aside 2,000 square feet of floor space or 1 percent of the total area, whichever is greater.
"The law was written to entice developers to pay the fee," Ms. Eichman said, "so the city can have control over spending and community planning. "
No child-care centers have gone into new San Francisco towers, but one developer, Ron Kaufman Companies, is seeking permits for a new building that would include day care for up to 40 children. Lynne Beeson, director of the Mayor's Office of Child Care, said most developers are paying fees and the city will receive $300,000 by year's end.
"Things aren't changing fast," Ms. Beeson said. "We have got such a long way to go."
Some California cities, like Concord and Danville, have built day-care centers and also collected fees. But in Boston four new office buildings that would include child care in the once-blighted Midtown Cultural Dis trict are on hold, and the same is true of a building in Hartford. Cincinnati has had a bonus law on the books since 1987 but nothing has come about, and in Irvine, Calif., two projects still are pending.
Some of the 14 other cities now considering mandatory child-care laws are running into rebellion from developers opposed to what they see as mandatory zoning. Pittsburgh will decide about mandatory laws this fall. City planners say it is crucial to plan centers now for future buildings because of the num ber of working mothers. Pittsburgh's centers near downtown currently handle only about 680 children and planners expect that within 20 years more than 50,000 women of child-bearing age will work downtown.
"Developers across the country haven't opposed bonus laws, but they have opposed mandatory zoning," Ms. Eichman said. "They see these laws as unfair taxes and feel they're being made scapegoats. They say day care is the responsibility of employers and the community as well."
Developers say they are being singled out because their buildings will create new jobs and new demands on city services like child care. Yet, Ms. Eichman said, "we've found that communities across the country are strapped for funds, and Federal and state monies have been cut back."
