LENGTH: 1227 words

HEADLINE: A Tradition for Tampa Raises Questions of Bias

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla.

 BODY:
For 86 years, the biggest annual event here has been the Gasparilla parade, a winter extravaganza that features 500 of the city's most powerful men - bankers, lawyers, heads of government agencies -swaggering through the streets dressed up as gun-toting pirates. Mayor Sandy Freedman made the parade part of her pitch to the National Football League for Super Bowl XXV.
But after Tampa was awarded the January 1991 Super Bowl, a racial dispute erupted over the parade, which has always been sponsored and organized by an all white, all male private club. It did not end when the club canceled this year's parade.
The club's top officials refused the demands of a coalition of black residents that the club be integrated immediately. Many black residents, as well as whites, say the existence of the club and its parade shows that, despite some gains for blacks in recent years, the Old South mentality still influences this port city on Florida's gulf coast. 
To its defenders, the parade was a harmless day of celebration for the entire city. To critics, it was a painful throwback to Tampa's segregated past. One critic, a lawyer named Warren Dawson, said: ''It was a bunch of white guys dressed up as pirates, swigging joy-juice and throwing coins, and this time they were going to televise it before the whole world.''
 
Scramble for a Substitute
The club paid for the bash, but the city provided police and cleanup support.
Now the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau and a biracial group of residents are scrambling to put together an integrated substitute parade in time for the Super Bowl.
With about 750 members, the club, Ye Mystic Krewe of Gasparilla, is considered the most prestigious of the many private clubs in Tampa. While membership is secret, local newspaper accounts list among its members H. L. Culbreath Jr., the chairman of the Tampa Electric Company; Hugh Culverhouse, the owner of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, and Richard Pittman, the former publisher of The Tampa Tribune.
Walter Baldwin, an insurance executive who is a member of the club and the chairman of the Super Bowl Task Force, said: ''The Krewe is made up of most of the leaders in the community. Unfortunately, it isn't integrated.'' Members say they never set out to make the Krewe all white. Michel Emmanuel, a senior partner of one of Tampa's oldest law firms, and a member of the Krewe, said, ''We've never had a black applicant to consider.''
But Henry Carley, the president of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said: ''No black man has ever been invited to apply.''
 
Parade Had Some Blacks
Krewe members say they meet as a club only a few times a year. They say the high point is when they dress up as pirates, and sail into town on a 165-foot replica of an old East Indian square rigger, shoot blanks from real guns and swill whiskey from hip flasks.
To a degree, the parade, usually scheduled for February, has become integrated over the years by marching bands from black schools and other floats. But to many people here, black and white, Gasparilla means the spectacle of the pirates, all of them white. ''A bunch of good ole boys having a good time,'' says Bob Gilder, a television talk show host who was the president of the N.A.A.C.P. chapter here for 35 years.
Last August, a coalition of black churches and organizations, including the Greater Tampa Urban League and the N.A.A.C.P., threatened to create bad publicity for Tampa if the Krewe did not integrate and if certain other demands, like more management jobs for blacks, were met.
 
Demand to Admit Blacks
Mr. Dawson, one of the coalition's leaders, demanded that the Krewe admit 25 black members by the end of September. The Krewe responded by calling off the parade.
The captain of the Krewe, Warren Frazier, a lawyer, issued a news release stating that the club's participation might have hurt the city's image. He said that the club would probably integrate soon, but that it was too late to admit new members this year.
But in a letter to club members, Mr. Frazier was more blunt. ''Any compromise which suggested that the Krewe has yielded to pressure would only encourage other special interest groups such as 'NOW', which has stated that it was going to push for women Krewe members,'' he wrote.
Mr. Gilder and others say it is not so much that they want to belong to the Krewe. Rather they want a shot at some of the economic opportunities that they say have been enjoyed by the members of the club.
''This whole town, symbolically, is a Gasparilla Krewe,'' said Mr. Carley, who is the coordinator of minority recruitment for Hillsborough Community College. ''For the most part, Tampa is a closed shop.''
Tampa has 286,000 residents, 23 percent of whom are black. One black sits on the seven-member school board, one on the seven-member County Commission and one on the seven-member City Council. There are only a handful of black executives.
If many of Tampa's blacks chafed over the years at the bit part they were asked to play in the Gasparilla parade, they still considered it a minor annoyance. But all the attention over the Super Bowl this year threw the spotlight on the parade and its sponsors.
It was three years ago that Mayor Freedman sold the N.F.L. on Tampa for the 1991 Super Bowl, set for Jan. 27. ''I thought the parade would set us apart,'' she said recently. ''No Super Bowl had ever had a parade.''
Mr. Baldwin, the chairman of the Super Bowl Task Force, had already persuaded the Krewe to reschedule the parade for the day before the game.
Mrs. Freedman said she had not been aware that the parade might offend blacks. ''I don't think it occurred to anybody,'' she said, adding that the city would not support any future parades unless the Krewe integrates.
 
'I Worked My Way Into It'
Blacks and many whites see no defensible reason for the Krewe's exclusion of blacks. Many Krewe members seem bewildered by the charges of racism.
Mr. Emmanuel, who become a member 35 years ago, said: ''I worked my way into it. I got an application and took it to several of my partners - one of whom was a former governor - who were members. They sponsored me, and after several years I was accepted. I was pleased. It meant you had arrived in the community.''
Along with a lot of other people here, Mr. Baldwin and Mr. Emmanuel say it is time to integrate the Krewe.
''I can think of one or two whom I'd sponsor,'' Mr. Emmanuel said.
Jim Apthorp, a real estate consultant who is the chairman of the Chamber of Commerce and a member of the Krewe, said the issue had raised the consciousness of many people. He has been negotiating with the black coalition over some of its demands.
Prompted by the issue, several other all-white clubs in the city are reported to be about to accept black members.
Henry Carley, who grew up here and remembers when schools and lunch counters were segregated, said he is hopeful. He said the publicity over the Super Bowl and the parade may have given blacks new standing.
''Some people have criticized the N.A.A.C.P. for being opportunistic,'' he said. ''They're doggone right; we are. Everybody else - hotels and restaurants - is being opportunistic about the Super Bowl. I don't see why we shouldn't use it to get more jobs and equal opportunity.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: The annual Gasparilla parade in Tampa, Fla. is sponsored by an all-white, all-male private club, prompting angry residents to demand integration. Members of the club, Ye Mystic Krewe of Gasparilla,arrived in Tampa in a pirate ship for a past parade. (Fotobanc Inc.)

HEADLINE: Get New York's Fat Out of the Fire

 BODY:
How can New York City's government climb out of the current fiscal mess? By promptly taking two steps: First, keep matters from getting worse by delaying further labor negotiations immediately. And second, find a way to withhold part of the alarmingly large raise granted the teachers' union.
Stop the Clock. Mayor David Dinkins's administration plans to intensify its talks with unions, in an effort to reach settlements this week. That would be a perilous mistake. The city cannot prudently commit itself to further salary increases until the Mayor and his advisers understand more clearly the depth of the city's economic problems. 
Mr. Dinkins's top aides disagree even among themselves on how much tax revenue is coming in, and estimates of the deficit in the coming year vary wildly. Will it be $1.4 billion, as the Mayor's budget office predicts, or $2.6 billion, Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman's even gloomier projection?
Budget-making always requires guesswork, but when the guesses are so profoundly different something is wrong. There has to be a consensus. Until it's reached, there is no plausible way for the city to continue talking with unions. How can Mr. Dinkins and his negotiators say with any confidence what they can afford to pay workers?
Reappraise the Pension Fund Change. Nearly half of the 5.5 percent raise for the teachers' union would come from a change in the union's pension fund. The city says it can save $104 million by investing in higher-income securities, permitting an assumption of 9 percent in earnings, instead of 8.25 percent. That would go toward the raise.
But many pension experts question the prudence of that change. Even supporters of the contract ought by now to be wary of this proposal. That's even truer for those who believe the 5.5 percent settlement is too expensive for the city right now, and would serve as a dangerously costly precedent for settlements with the other unions.
Whether or not the contract negotiations are reopened, however, the city cannot conscientiously proceed with the package until it can solidly justify changing the pension's earning assumptions. Until that's possible, it would make considerable sense to suspend that portion attributed to the change. Without the pension money, the United Federation of Teachers would be left with a 3 percent increase.
The union would do retirees a favor by insisting on further assurances about the pension change. In the meantime, if the U.F.T. will not renegotiate the entire contract, it would perform a major service to the city by agreeing to the more modest 3 percent increase.
But even if the U.F.T. is disposed to cooperate, it can't unless Mr. Dinkins takes bolder action. He is now in a position to show the public and the nervous financial markets that he can manage scarcity. Rolling back, and holding the line, can bring the city back from the errors of the last two weeks.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Bring on C.S.C.E.

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Upon hearing that the transcendentalist Margaret Fuller had said ''I accept the Universe,'' the historian Thomas Carlyle delivered this withering put-down: ''By God, she'd better!''
I accept the C.S.C.E. My 18-year battle against the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe is over.
Five weeks from now in Paris, amidst posturing and hoo-hahing at the ministerial level, a new regional agglomeration of nations will be institutionalized.
This will ultimately lead to a vast secretariat - limousines, lifetime sinecures, 24-hour cocktail lounges, the diplomatic works - headquartered in Prague or Budapest, to be wedged between an identity-critical NATO and a cumbrous U.N.
It all began in 1972, the heyday of deceptive detente, when Leonid Brezhnev wanted the West to ratify Soviet claims to the Baltic states and a chunk of prewar Poland. 
His bait: He would agree to our desire for a Mutual and Balanced Forces Reduction negotiation (which President Nixon needed to relieve Senator Mike Mansfield's pressure for withdrawal of our troops) in return for an all-European ''security'' conference that would treat present borders as permanent.
Henry Kissinger went for the deal, leading President Ford to a Helsinki signing in 1975. Because hard-liners in the U.S. grumbled, our side insisted on a ''Basket 3'' in the final agreement calling for human rights in each of the signatories, with a follow-up conference to review progress.
The Soviets got what they wanted - de facto border gains - but had no intention of reducing troop levels (M.B.F.R. talks went nowhere) or of honoring human rights pledges.
We righties went ballistic about this double-cross, demanding that we ''rescind Helsinki'' unless Soviet dissenters were freed. After one such diatribe in this space, a Brezhnevian flack at the Novosti agency in Moscow sent a letter to The New York Times:
''In order to cure the cold Mr. Safire claims to have diagnosed,'' wrote Gennadi Gerasimov, ''he suggests, in fact, removing the head. Just think of the consequences for detente.'' Afghanistan followed.
But the hard-line suggestion that the Helsinki agreement could be rescinded if Moscow ignored it was a useful prod. Equally useful, I now admit, was the cottage industry that grew around the world to monitor the accord. ''Basket 3'' turned out to be a propaganda headache for Mr. Brezhnev.
That was then. Now the handsome Gennadi is peddling perestroika and touting C.S.C.E. With the Warsaw Pact in shambles, his latest boss wants to replace NATO with a European alliance in which Moscow and Washington would have equal influence in a ''Center to Prevent Conflict.''
The new Soviet interest in C.S.C.E. is to break up the military alliance facing Moscow's troops before Soviet disarmament, and to enter the West's economy before accepting capitalism.
No, thanks. Before creating a new regional association to provide shelter for homeless ex-superpowers, we should insist on evidence of deep Soviet arms cuts and thorough economic reform.
Asking too much? Hardly; only when we linked the Soviet-sought Paris C.S.C.E. talks to progress on ending the imbalance of conventional forces in Eastern Europe did Moscow stop stonewalling.
The second round of these arms talks, aimed at halving the new balance of troops and tanks and planes, ought to remain the business of NATO and Moscow, with ''prevention of conflict'' outside C.S.C.E., at least in its formative years.
Our interest in C.S.C.E. should be in forming an organization qualitatively better than the U.N. Its primary purpose should be to advance political freedom and human rights within each of the signatories. Tyranny and torture are not ''internal affairs.'' Sanctions should be built in to prevent the decadelong contempt for Basket 3 that the Brezhnevites displayed.
And let's give the group an accurate name. Drop ''security'' from the title, because it is not a military alliance but an association to promote individual freedom; drop ''Europe,'' too, because this grouping stretches from Vancouver to Vladivostok; and save us from alphabet soup. (Send suggestions to Name That League, The New York Times, 1627 Eye Street, Washington, D.C. 20006.) Henry's Baby has come of age. The new trans-Atlantic community of 37 nations - no deal, of course, unless it includes the three independent Baltic nations - could be a freedom forum and an economic discipline. That's why I accept it. (By God, he'd better!)

HEADLINE: What Kind of People Are We?

BYLINE: By Anthony Shorris: Anthony Shorris was Finance Commissioner for the City of New York in 1989.

 BODY:
The budget deficit facing Mayor David Dinkins has been estimated at between $1.5 and $2.5 billion for next year. While the city's budget appears to be huge - $29 billion in its fiscal year 1992 - in fact, only $20 billion are city funds. The rest are Federal and state monies over which the Mayor has little control.
Of the city's own money, over $2 billion is required to match Federal welfare and Medicaid funds - no comparable burden is placed on any other city in the country - and nearly $3 billion goes to fund debt service on money borrowed long ago. And the Mayor lacks discretion over much of the $15 billion remaining. 
Close to $3 billion is used to pay for the pension of city workers, the costs of the city's leases and fuel bills, and other items essentially outside the Mayor's control. Being $2 billion short on a budget of $12 billion is as a close to a fiscal crisis as the city has been since 1975.
With an undeclared recession melting revenue collections, a crime wave in the daily headlines and a million people living past the brink of poverty, the Mayor's choices - and ours - will not be easy. They are not made easier by those who crab about his rhetoric or second-guess his timing of press conferences. What will the choices we make tell us about what kind of people we have become?
First, we'll find out how smart we are. It doesn't take great ingenuity to raise taxes or cut services. What takes brains and commitment is improving productivity. Commissioners are paid to be effective, and in this crisis every one of them should cut their agency's city-funded, discretionary budget by five percent without reducing services. Otherwise, we should get some new Commissioners.
Furthermore, can we afford to have four separate economic development agencies? Should we continue to spend millions on redundant mini-bureaucracies for elected officials whose powers were reduced by the new charter? Productivity could cut the deficit as much as half a billion dollars.
Union leaders should be asked to improve the efficiency of the government by another one percent. Helping to avoid additional layoffs should stimulate their creativity. When services needs to be reduced by as much as $300 million, we'll find out how much we care about the not-very-safe economic safety net that distinguishes New York from every other city in America.
We can slash programs for the middle classes and the wealthy - subsidizing museums, smoothing roads for those who drive to work, sweeping the streets in midtown - or we can increase class sizes in the early grades, close public health clinics and drop homeless housing programs. We can choose to keep the parks as clean as we would like and tolerate hospital emergency rooms that are Dickensian nightmares.
We can cut back on services to small businesses or we can drop poor children from daycare. We can accept third world infant mortality rates or start collecting garbage in some neighborhoods less frequently.
Economics textbooks tell us that localities should never have progressive tax systems, because wealthier people will vote with their feet and leave only the poor behind. But in New York, we have tried to have a local tax structure that reflects our values as well as our pocketbooks. Now those beliefs will be tested.
When we add the billion dollars of new taxes that the next budget will require, who will pay them? We should return to the 4.3% marginal rate on the city personal income tax that we had only a few years ago, rather that institute new, regressive taxes that give those with unearned income a free ride.
We need to change the property tax system that leaves a city homeowner paying less than half what a Nassau County homeowner pays for a house of equal value. And it's time to use the tax system to discourage behavior we don't like (driving in midtown during the day) rather than behavior we need (poor people taking low-paying jobs to stay off welfare).
The lessons of the last decade should have taught us that for a society to function, sacrifice is required. New Yorkers have long understood this, and as late as the 1970's, municipal labor unions, Wall Street and the government work together to save a city on the brink. Will those same players be able to set aside their parochial interests again?
Can the public employees recognize that wage settlements will directly reduce the level of services for everyone else? After all, the workers of Chrysler and The New York Post took pay cuts to save institutions somewhat less important. In today's crisis, what ''give-backs'' are our labor leaders prepared to offer? Perhaps it's even time to offer some of the able-bodied adults on welfare small additional stipends to perform the work of laid-off civil servants.
Great universities, foundations and private hospitals should pay some taxes, or make ''voluntary contributions,'' toward the services they receive just as Yale now does for New Haven. Museum stores should pay sales tax when they sell the same luxury commodities as other merchants. Members of the city's private clubs would feel less guilty about stepping over the homeless on their doorsteps if they gave up their tax exemption.
The city's insurance companies shouldn't be too proud to start paying the same corporate income taxes as every other business. And is it right that the city should have to spend millions of dollars on tax auditors just to make big businesses pay the taxes they owe? We're waiting to hear more from the leadership of the private sector than threats to dive into the swamps of New Jersey.
Is New York still an assembly of people with a commitment to social justice as well as fiscal prudence? Or has it become, as some have said, a city built on greed and gossip? We will find out whether each of us is to live alone in this great city, or live together as New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
White House Urges Decrease In Short-Term Interest Rates

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, said today that he hoped the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates sharply should an agreement be reached with Congress to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
Mr. Sununu said a short-term rate cut of one-quarter of a percentage point, which has been anonymously suggested by some Federal Reserve officials as the likely reaction to a budget agreement, would not be large enough to affect the slumping national economy. 
''We're hoping for a both short-term and long-term movement in a downward direction,'' Mr. Sununu said. Asked how large the movement should be, he replied, ''That's for the Fed to make the final decision on, of course. But we're hoping for significantly more'' than one-quarter of a percentage point.
Mr. Sununu spoke on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
EXECUTIVES PLAN FOR A RECESSION

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 13

 BODY:
Corporate leaders at a conference here urged consumers to remain confident in the American economy, while their companies are laying plans to cope with a possible recession.
Many of the chief executives attending the semiannual meeting of the Business Council at the Homestead Hotel said in interviews today and Friday that they were considering cuts in investment spending and, in a few cases, preparing for possible layoffs. As a result of such cutbacks, some industrial equipment companies are already in a recession, their chief executives said. 
New orders at the Cummins Engine Company dropped by a third immediately after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and have remained low also because of continued uncertainty about the Federal budget. ''Buyers just said, 'I'll stop until I figure out what I need,' '' said Henry B. Schacht, the company's chairman and chief executive.
 
Layoffs Have Started
The Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's second-largest producer of computers, after the International Business Machines Corporation, has already laid off some employees because of a slowdown in capital equipment sales that began two years ago, said Kenneth H. Olsen, Digital's president and chief executive. Further reductions in employment, possibly through layoffs, are likely, he said.
Robert H. Malott, the chairman and chief executive of the FMC Corporation, a large producer of chemicals and industrial machinery, summarized the position of many chairmen when he said that while his company had made no final decision on whether to cut investment, the combination of the budget impasse in Washington, tensions in the Middle East, higher oil prices and the poor health of the nation's banks was discouraging.
''I have told our people to do their 1991 budgeting and planning as if we were entering a recession, a mild recession, and to be alert in case we're wrong,'' he said. ''The thing that concerns me is that whatever scenario we use, the risk on the downside is greater than the gain on the upside in this environment.''
 
'Oil Price Scenarios'
Senior management at the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation has begun requiring higher projected rates of return for the approval of new projects, said William W. Boeschenstein, who was the company's chairman and chief executive until his retirement two weeks ago.
The General Electric Company is reviewing capital spending for next year, along with staffing, inventory and equipment levels, said John F. Welch Jr., its chairman and chief executive. ''Each business is preparing for a high oil price scenario and a $25 oil price scenario,'' he said.
General Electric has a record level of backlogged orders for products that take a long time to produce, like aircraft engines, electrical power generation systems and medical equipment. But its businesses selling consumer products, including refrigerators and dishwashers, are already in a recession, Mr. Welch said.
Some corporate bosses, like Edwin L. Artzt, the chairman and chief executive of the Procter & Gamble Company, which makes everything from Crest toothpaste to Pampers diapers, said they had no immediate plans to cut long-term investments. Mr. Artzt said his company would be conducting a series of seminars for its managers around the world on how to cope with a recession.
 
Slower Growth Predicted
Motorola Inc., one of the world's largest producers of cellular telephones, two-way radios and other wireless communications equipment, has sharply increased research and development spending in the last several months, resulting in lower than expected third-quarter earnings that sent the company's stock down sharply last Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
A Familiar Campaign Trail Is Harder to Navigate

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.C., Oct. 14

 BODY:
In the past two months, Representative William G. Hefner, who has represented this area of small textile towns and farms for eight terms, has been unable to get home to campaign much. The budget debates and standoffs have kept him busy in Washington, so television advertisements stressing his work for farmers, the textile industry and the military have taken the place of personal contact in his re-election campaign.
When he finally returned home this weekend, the Democratic lawmaker ran into a buzz saw of criticism from his Republican opponent, Ted Blanton, who has railed more against the status quo than against Mr. Hefner in particular and pointed repeatedly to the budget impasse in Washington as an example of a hidebound system in which few had the ''courage to take the tough actions.''
Mr. Blanton, a Salisbury lawyer, acknowledged that he was stressing an anti-incumbency message more now than he was before the back-and-forth on the budget. Mr. Blanton said he senses that the voters are receptive, but Mr. Hefner says this notion is more a creation of the news media and Mr. Blanton than a real phenomenon.
The Congressman says he senses that voters have a free-floating anxiety about such things as whether there will be a recession and whether the Persian Gulf crisis will lead to war. They feel frustrated, he said, but not necessarily angry at incumbents. 
 
Frustration at the Fair
At the Cabarrus County Autumn Fest here this weekend, there were indications that both assessments of the voters' mood hold some truth.
Watching his two children romp on a grassy slope to the sound of country music, Bill Caudle said he thought nearly all politicians ''aren't for anything but themselves,'' they ''waffle too much'' and had shown in the recent budget debates that they were not willing to make tough decisions.
''We're frustrated,'' said Mr. Caudle, a salesman with a steel-fabricating company that services military contractors. ''Years of observation tell me that politicians will be for whatever people want. Now, nobody wants higher taxes, but logic tells you that someday we are going to have to pay. I don't have anything against Bill Hefner, but he's a middle-of-the-roader, and sometimes you just have to make waves.''
Seated at a picnic table nearby, Jerry Haire said he was a Republican but still liked Mr. Hefner.
''I don't think there is anything wrong with him, and he hasn't done anything to make me turn against him,'' said Mr. Haire, a draftsman with a textile firm. He said he had been more concerned about Mr. Hefner's attempts last week to override President Bush's veto of a bill limiting textile imports than about the budget debate. Nevertheless, Mr. Haire said, ''I voted for him before, and he's done a good job.''
 
Stress on the Local
Such views are a confirmation of some conventional wisdom to which the 60-year-old Mr. Hefner subscribes. At bottom, all politics is local, he suggested, and the budget contretemps hundreds of miles away in Washington does not matter much to voters back home ''if they are working and aren't sick, and you are performing constituent services.''
But Billy Paul, Mr. Hefner's campaign manager, said the incumbent is not ignoring Mr. Blanton's attempts to ''basically condemn Hefner for being an incumbent.''
Although the Hefner campaign's local polling shows that people are upset with Congress and the President over the budget, Mr. Hefner is making sure voters know that he opposed proposals to cut Medicare and raise excise taxes on such things as gasoline, heating fuel, tobacco and alcoholic beverages. He is stressing that he wants fewer cuts in Medicare and higher taxes for the wealthy.
''And the problem with Blanton is that he isn't proposing anything, just going negative,'' said Mr. Paul.
 
Embraces Farms and Mills
The Eighth Congressional District stretches from the south-central part of the state and its plains of tobacco and wheat farms west and north into the Piedmont, where textile mills are clustered. More than 56,000 people in the district are employed directly in the textile industry, and thousands more depend on it indirectly.
The district skirts the larger urban concentrations of Charlotte at its southern end and Winston-Salem at its northern tip, and is consequently made up of a string of small towns like Concord, Salisbury and Kannapolis, the largest of which has about 32,000 people.
Republican strength has been increasing in the district, but Mr. Hefner has held his own even when strong Republicans like former President Ronald Reagan, President Bush and Senator Jesse Helms have been at the top of the ticket. Two years ago, Mr. Blanton challenged Mr. Hefner and lost in a close race with 49 percent of the vote.
''That was in a Presidential year, when the district went for the Republican Presidential candidate,'' said Howard Schloss, a spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. ''This is basically a rematch, and they can be tricky. But we basically think Blanton showed his best two years ago.''
 
Experience on the Hill
But Mr. Blanton said he believed the ''anti-incumbent'' message sounds better this year than it did two years ago, and that a strong Republican turnout for Senator Helms could be just the margin he needs.
''The thing that comes across to me when I talk to people is that, once politicians get to Washington, they change and become a rubber stamp for the liberal leadership of Congress or for a conservative President,'' said the 40-year-old Mr. Blanton, who from 1977 to 1983 served on the Capitol Hill staffs of a Democratic and two Republican senators. ''I see myself as part of a group of young conservative Republicans in the mold of people like Representative Newt Gingrich, who want to change the status quo and have the courage to do it.''
As Mr. Blanton took his message to people at the Cabarrus County Autumn Fest, there were mixed reactions. Tammy Jordan, a young mother sitting in the tent where children were making balloon dolls, said she agreed that a change was needed and that people like Mr. Hefner had ''lost sight of our needs and been in office too long.''
But seated nearby was Sarah Newberry, who frowned as Mr. Blanton passed through. She said she could not vote for him because he had adopted an anti-abortion stand that was not a strong feature of his last race.
''He's been showing up at these anti-abortion rallies, and I'm pro-choice and will vote that way all the way down the line,'' said Ms. Newberry. ''I don't like the fundamentalist image that we know what's best for you, which a lot of North Carolina politicians are projecting, but I suspect I'm in the minority.''
At 76, Dessie Howell could claim to know more than most about what happens with aging and getting used to something. She is by her own admission set in her ways, preferring to ''live in the country'' rather than move into the city with her grown children. She has voted Republican for a long time but has not talked about it much until recently, and she thinks a change is needed in politics.
Her comments were at once a tonic and a caution for the youthful-looking Mr. Blanton. ''We have to get them old men out of there and get some new ones in,'' she said. ''They get up there in Washington in those jobs for so long, they think they own them. That Jesse Helms has been up there so long he thinks he owns his, but it's time for a change.''

Correction Appended

SECTION: Section B; Page 9, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1376 words

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Crux of Tax Debate: Who Pays More?

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
As the budget fracas continued last week, often in a cloud of confusion, perhaps the clearest point of contention became the question of who should bear the greatest financial burden of increased taxes: rich or poor or the people in between.
On Thursday, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee introduced the first plan that would call for a greater sacrifice from the wealthy than from the middle class and the poor. The plan that Congressional and White House negotiators had produced after months of debate had sought just the opposite, taking the proportionately biggest bites from those lowest on the income ladder.
The Democratic proposal to structure tax increases progressively was called unacceptable by President Bush, who is armed with the power of the veto, and the distribution of a final agreement remains anyone's guess. But no matter what happens, the budget debate has brought into sharp prominence the questions of who gets and who gives. 
''The differences in approach are sharpening,'' said Bob Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington group that advocates progressive taxation. ''The middle class is becoming more conscious of how they're being treated compared to the rich.''
 
An Awareness of Inequity
Kevin Phillips, a Republican political analyst and author of a recent book on the distribution of wealth, agreed. ''I think the whole budget debate has slowly but significantly increased the middle class's awareness of what happened in the 1980's, that the people at the top got a real break that other people didn't get,'' he said.
The current debate about distributing burdens comes after a decade in which an often-quoted saying had come true: The rich had gotten richer and the poor poorer. And tax policy was part of the reason.
With the economic expansion of the 1980's, the wealthiest Americans saw their pretax incomes rise sharply while their tax rates dropped. The Reagan Administration argued that tax cuts, by stimulating investment and expanding the economy, would actually bring more revenue to the Government.
According to a study by the Congressional Budget Office, the top 5 percent of American families will have 45 percent more in pretax income in 1990 than they did in 1980, after accounting for inflation. But the overall percentage of that income they pay in major Federal taxes will have fallen from 29.5 percent to 26.7 percent, a drop of almost 10 percent. #28% More by the Poor Precisely the opposite trend occurred on the bottom of the income ladder. The budget office estimates that the poorest 10 percent of American households will earn 9 percent less in 1990 than they did in 1980, in terms adjusted for inflation. But rather than paying 6.7 percent of their income in taxes as they did in 1980, they will pay 8.5 percent, an increase of almost 28 percent.
For the bulk of the middle class, both pretax income and tax rates remained about the same, the budget office figures show.
The main tax change benefiting upper-income households was the cut in income tax rates, from 70 percent in the top bracket in 1980 to 28 percent today. In lowering the rate, Congress closed a number of loopholes that had allowed the wealthiest to reduce what they paid the Government.
The main change hurting the poorest households was the rise in payroll taxes for Social Security and Medicare, from 6.13 percent in 1980 to 7.65 percent in 1990. Since the amount of income subject to those taxes is capped, they affect lower-income households more than wealthier families.
 
Paying for Others' Fortune
For those in the middle-income levels, the cut in income taxes and the rise in payroll taxes essentially canceled each other out.
Mr. Greenstein argues that the tax policies of the past decade have sharpened the current debate because tax cuts for the wealthy helped increase the deficit, whose enormity makes the proposed tax increases and service cuts so pressing.
''People in the middle and at the bottom ask: 'Why should I be asked to pay more for the tax cuts wealthy people received in the 1980's?'' he said.
Of the current proposals, the one that would hit lower- and middle-income people hardest is the plan agreed upon by the White House and Congressional leaders but later rejected by the House of Representatives.
Among its features were ones that asked the elderly to pay more for Medicare, delayed unemployment benefits for two weeks and raised the gasoline tax by 10 cents a gallon. A rise in the gas tax hurts the poor and middle-class the most since they spend a greater proportion of their income on gas than do the wealthy.
Perhaps most significantly, the negotiated plan contained no increase in income tax rates.
According to an analysis by the Joint Committee on Taxation, the negotiators' plan would have increased the taxes paid by people with incomes under $10,000 by 7.6 percent, while raising the taxes of people earning more than $200,000 by only 1.7 percent.
Liberal lawmakers denounced the plan as an unfair sop to the rich, and House Democrats began to rally around a plan that reversed the burdens. In the Senate, the Finance Committee crafted a proposal late last week that falls somewhere in the middle.
 
Wealthy as Target
The House Democrats' proposal makes smaller changes in Medicare, leaves unemployment benefits untouched and eliminates the increase in the gas tax.
All those measures are of greatest help to those with modest incomes. So is the Democrats' plan for a larger expansion of the earned income tax credit, a rebate given to working families with children and incomes of less than $20,000 a year.
The House Democrats sought to raise a greater percentage of revenue through higher income taxes on the wealthy. They would do this by raising the top income tax rate to 33 percent, from 28 percent; by raising the alternative minimum tax on those with large itemized deductions to 25 percent from 21 percent, and by adding a 10 percent surtax on those with incomes above $1 million.
The Joint Tax Committee estimated that under the House Democrats' plan the amount of taxes paid by those earning less than $10,000 would fall by 1.3 percent, while those earning $200,000 and above would pay 7.4 percent more.
 
Sharp Differences
The plans are also markedly different in the amount of money they seek to raise from the middle class as opposed to the wealthiest Americans.
For instance, the negotiated agreement sought to raise $20 billion in taxes, but only $3.2 billion of it from those with incomes above $200,000. The Democratic alternative would raise $16 billion, and those earning more than $200,000 would pay almost $10 billion of it.
While the proposal from the budget negotiations would raise $8.6 billion from households with incomes between $30,000 and $75,000, the House Democrats sought only half that amount. While the negotiators' plan would raise taxes of those earning between $30,000 and $40,000 by 2.7 percent, the House Democrats sought only a 1 percent rise.
The negotiated proposal would raise $3.9 billion from households in the $75,000 to $200,000 range, while the Democrats would raise $1.8 billion.
Yet another approach came from the Senate Finance Committee. Its plan would raise fuel taxes almost as much as in the original proposal from the negotiations. Compared with the negotiators' plan, it has a higher limit on deductions for taxpayers earning more than $100,000, but it does not change the basic tax rates as the House plan would.
However the current debate is resolved, analysts see it setting the stage for a longer-term move toward increasing the progressivity of the tax code.
''There's going to be more progressivity, said Mr. Phillips, the political analyst. ''That's out of the barn.''
He said the pressure for change is from people in the middle class, who feel squeezed by 1980's increases in payroll and state and local taxes, and who benefited much less than the rich from Reagan-era cuts in income taxes. Middle-class disaffection, he said, has now found political opportunity.
''In the past 10 days, blood has been drawn, George Bush's blood,'' he said. ''Everything he does gets him headlines about favoring the rich.''

HEADLINE: Outdoors: A Gem in the New Hampshire Rough

BYLINE: By NELSON BRYANT

DATELINE: ENFIELD, N.H.

 BODY:
SOME things don't change and Cole Pond is one of them.
Tucked away in a forested, hill-surrounded valley at an altitude of 1,376 feet, 17-acre Cole Pond is one of the jewels of New Hampshire's remote trout pond system that includes relatively small bodies of water, many of which can only be reached on foot. In some instances, logging roads go to or near them, but such roads are often so boulder-strewn, deeply rutted and muddy that they are almost impassable to an ordinary four-wheel-drive vehicle.
Those who fish Cole Pond face no such problem; there's no road at all, just a foot trail that meanders for less than a mile up the thickly-wooded hillside from Bog Road. (Bog Road runs from Washburn Corner and McDaniels Marsh in Springfield north to Enfield Center, and a large, wooden Fish and Game Department sign marks the trailhead to the pond.) I hadn't visited Cole Pond, which is stocked from a helicopter with about 2,000 fingerling brook trout each spring, for the better part of a decade. The trail was well-worn and in one place there was a fork in it that hadn't existed before. The fork led around a swampy area, but I wallowed through the swamp because that was the route with which I was familiar. Ruth Kirschmeier, my non-fishing companion, chose her own course a little to the south of me. 
A ruffed grouse burst from the edge of the trail when we were a few hundred yards from the pond and a few seconds later another throbbed away unseen.
No one else was at the pond when we emerged from the hemlocks at its south end. Orange, red and yellow leaves torn from the hardwoods by a gusty west wind whirled across the water and dark clouds hurtled past over the hills.
Extricating myself from my pack, I set about inflating my new portable raft on the granite outcropping on the pond's west shore. Only fly fishing is permitted on the pond, and, because the woods grow to the water's edge leaving no room for a backcast, those who would fish it must become waterborne. Decades ago, there were usually one or two battered boats on the pond - often they were dragged in over the snow and left there - but none was visible that day.
Those who visit Cole pond should either portage in a lightweight canoe, or an inflatable raft or wading tube, although there is one spot on the pond's south end where shallow water and a hard sandy bottom permit limited fly fishing with chest waders. Cole Pond is within the state's Enfield Wildlife Management Area, which embraces about 3,000 acres and also includes Butternut and Halfmile ponds and a portion of Smith Pond. Camping is not allowed in the management area.
Ruth took over the raft-inflating task while I assembled my fly rod. The raft, sold by Sherpa of Chicago for $385, appears to be a duplicate of one I once owned that was made by the now-defunct American Safety Company. Including its plastic oars and carrying sack, which doubles as an inflation bag, it weighs only 7 pounds, making it ideal for backpacking anglers. It is billed as a two-person raft capable of supporting 375 pounds. I don't doubt its flotation potential, but unless they are relatively small and unusually supple, a brace of fly fishermen would find it impossibly confining.
The literature that accompanies the raft also says that it can be inflated in six minutes. My best time to date is 20 minutes, if a decent wind is blowing. You need the wind to help you fill the inflation bag with air. For what it's worth, the last stage of inflation making the raft's two flotation compartments drum-tight is more easily accomplished with lung power. I'm not knocking this little raft - I treasure what it does for me - just pointing out its limitations. Finding an angular rock for an anchor, I knotted 50 feet of heavy nylon cord to it and set forth. Cole Pond's deepest point in the middle is more than 50 feet, but I do most of my fishing in 12 to 30 feet along its shores, particularly in fall when the surface water cools and the trout are ranging at all levels. The surface water temperature was 60 degrees that day.
A short while after I began fishing, the patches of blue overhead disappeared and the day grew dark. The temperature dropped more than 10 degrees, into the high 40's, in 15 minutes, and fierce gusts of wind veering back and forth from the west and northwest sent me scudding about the pond with the leaves. A cold, stinging rain began and soon I was kneeling, the only position that I find comfortable in that raft, in a puddle of water. I rowed ashore where Ruth and I took shelter under an overhanging ledge.
A half hour later, the black clouds that had carried the rain swept past, the wind abated and the hills were once again aflame. I rowed to a little cove where more than 25 years ago a huge brook trout had made a pass at my fly, its broad side gleaming in the noon sun as it turned away and left my offering untouched. Ruth ensconced herself on a sun-bathed beaver house on the far shore and got out her sketch pad.
On my first cast - I was using a sinking line and a squirrel tail streamer fly - a fish hit but became unhooked. Two casts later, a medium-sized male brookie was mine. That prompted visions of catching enough trout for supper, but more black clouds swiftly obscured the late afternoon sun and a big wind spun me in a circle about my stone anchor. The day was once again dark and bleak, and the rain resumed.
I drove a cast against the gale toward shore. The fly was taken instantly before it had time to settle more than an inch or two, and I was fast to a good-sized fish, a fat female of about a pound. As I was netting her, the wind spun me in another circle. Damp, cold and cramped but somehow satisfied, I called it quits. Had the day been halcyon, I would have remained until after sundown, using the light of the nearly-full moon to keep me on the trail when I left.
Fifteen minutes later, we set a fast pace downhill in the rain and the wind and the gathering darkness.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
How Youth Could Pay A Debt to Civilization

BYLINE: CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Gratitude
Reflections on What We Owe to Our Country
By William F. Buckley Jr.
169 pages. Random House. $16.95.
Surprise! William F. Buckley Jr. is in favor of national service. In ''Gratitude: Reflections on What We Owe to Our Country,'' America's most articulate conservative thinker proposes a plan for universal voluntary national service for men and women 18 years of age and older. 
Mr. Buckley's program would be overseen by what he calls a national service franchise administration, though it would be financed and shaped on the state level. The young men and women who participate would do everything from caring for children and the elderly to planting gardens and repairing damaged library books. If everyone eligible signed up at a cost, say, of $10,000 each, Mr. Buckley estimates, the total expense would amount to less than ''we were paying for the G.I. Bill after the Second World War,'' and who can estimate what the profit to the country might be?
Why should young people be so obliged? Because, as Mr. Buckley writes: ''Those who do not murder, rape, or steal also owe a debt to their society, if only because it pauses to distinguish between those who rape, murder, and steal and those who do not. Call it, broadly, a debt to civilization; more distinctly, a debt to the 'fatherland' - the nation-state into which we were born, or to which we repaired.'' Mr. Buckley's proposal is surprising because it seems to run counter to everything one thinks of conservatism as standing for. To ask the state to sponsor philanthropy hardly accords with the laissez-faire ideal of a free market in which invisible forces determine supply and demand. It's a little as if Mr. Buckley wanted to wire together President Bush's ''thousand points of light'' and to put switches in every state capital and a fuse box in Washington.
Naturally, Mr. Buckley anticipates conservatives' objections to his program, and liberals' as well. In fact, ''Gratitude'' is organized so as to clear the stage of objections first and then to haul in the rudiments of a service plan.
At the heart of his essay, he argues that a nation can have ''afflictions'' that ''are not registered in conventional demand-supply terms.'' He writes: ''I think that one such affliction is the failure to acknowledge a running debt to one's homeland (biological or adopted). That is one deficiency that national service seeks to accost.''
In sum: a ''great, green pasture exists now outside the formal structures of the market and encourages the desire to augment the effort, in order further to satisfy the needy - but primarily in order to give scope to the impulses of those who desire to go to them. To help.'' In response to Mr. Buckley's proposition, conservatives may argue that when you begin measuring and responding to ''signals'' that do not ''travel from the objective situation to the economist's computer screen,'' you start down a slippery slope that leads toward socialism, and even to the pit of the welfare state.
Meanwhile, liberals may question whether there is really much of a distinction between Mr. Buckley's idea of compulsory service and the sanctions he proposes to make sure that everyone eligible volunteers. The sanctions would range from depriving the reluctant citizen of savings-bank insurance to withholding a driver's license until the young person has signed up for national service.
And both conservatives and liberals may object to the imperative of Mr. Buckley's idea of gratitude. Should everyone to feel thankful simply for the chance of being born? Should a crack baby or anyone likewise disadvantaged at birth feel gratitude to the ''fatherland''? Shouldn't expressions of thanks be reserved to those who have reason to feel spontaneously grateful to the system? Actually, Mr. Buckley is more compelling when he weighs the idea of national service as an effect rather than as an obligation. ''To emulate the Swiss example in the United States would be foolish,'' he writes. ''We do not need a universal military draft. We do need a basket of other services, which could absorb the civic energies, were they proffered, of three-plus million Americans, which energies are otherwise at best dissipated, or worse, channeled into activity hostile to home and to the community - drugs, licentious sex, crime.''
And in addition to diverting young people from negative activities national service might lead them to positive ones. ''I am not conversant with the literature of clinical psychology,'' Mr. Buckley concludes, ''and do not intend to become so. But I sense intuitively that while friendship does not necessarily grow out of experience shared, experience shared conduces to a bond from which friendship can grow. I move on to say that my conviction is that friendship is strengthened by such experiences as bring out in us that which ever so lightly elevates us from the trough of self-concern and self-devotion.''
This vision of friendship rising out of shared experience is the most appealing part of Mr. Buckley's argument. Except, perhaps, for his retelling of Anatole France's story about the young postulant at the monastery alongside Our Lady of the Sorrows whose only skill was juggling. ''And so,'' Mr. Buckley writes, ''in the dead of night, driven by the mandate to serve, walking furtively lest he be seen and mocked by his brothers, he makes his ardent way to the altar with his sackful of wooden mallets and balls, and does his act for Our Lady.''
Mr. Buckley has come forth with a sackful of fresh thoughts, witty anecdotes and philosophical speculations, and he has juggled. The result transfixes the reader's mind and provokes one to imagine ways that the United States might reinvigorate itself.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Disney Adding Book Unit In Bid to Be a Top Publisher

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company plans to establish a unit to publish books for adults as part of a long-term plan to become a leading book publisher.
Disney expanded earlier this year into the children's book field. The latest plan, to be announced formally today, reflects the company's conviction that it can be more profitable than other trade, or general-interest, publishers and that a full range of books will complement its other entertainment businesses. 
''We believe that there are opportunities to be much more profitable in adult publishing than exhibited by other companies up to this point,'' said Charles P. Wickham, group vice president for Disney publishing. He singled out marketing - where Disney's aggressiveness is renowned -as an area in which he believes the company can go well beyond other publishers.
Mr. Wickham declined to say how much the company was investing in the new publishing venture. ''It's a substantial amount,'' he said. ''We're not going in lightly.''
The new adult publishing unit, whose first list will be announced next summer at the American Booksellers Association meeting, plans to publish 50 books in its first year. About 75 percent of those books will be nonfiction.
The division's publisher will be Robert Miller, who was previously vice president of Dell.
No authors have been signed up yet, but Disney plans to sell a complete range of books, from highly commercial to serious.
A name has not yet been chosen for the adult book division, but Mr. Wickham said the name Disney would not be used.
The move into adult books by the Burbank, Calif.-based company follows its decision earlier this year to publish children's books. Its children's imprints include Disney Press, which publishes books based on Disney characters, Muppet Press and a yet-unnamed imprint that will not feature Disney characters.
Mr. Miller said the company intended to market its adult books ''relentlessly.''
Disney, he said, would be looking for new authors whose works could be attractive to ''particular audiences,'' adding that direct marketing, special events and other techniques would be used to push up sales.
Charles E. Hayward, the publisher of Simon & Schuster's trade division, said that although Disney was starting the adult book operation at a time when the economic climate is extremely tough, ''it would be a mistake to underestimate them.''
But he added that the fact the company did not have a mass-market paperback division could be a severe handicap in attracting authors, who increasingly want so-called ''hard-soft'' - or hardback and paperback - deals from publishers.
Disney intends to publish some so-called trade paperback books, but it has no current plans for a mass-market division.
Since Michael D. Eisner took over as chief executive of Disney in 1984, the company's profits have surged. Disney earned $703.3 million last year, a sevenfold increase from 1984, and revenues nearly tripled, to $4.59 billion. These results have been achieved through the aggressive exploitation of existing assets like the theme parks and a bold drive into movies, records and the merchandising of Disney characters.
Stuart Applebaum, a senior vice president at Bantam Doubleday Dell, said that if Disney was half as successful at marketing and selling books as it has been with its theme parks and music, ''it will be a great publishing success.''
But, he added, ''such crossovers do not always work in entertainment conglomerates.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Gulf Situation Called Key to Interest Rates

 BODY:
Credit analysts say that despite mounting evidence of a recession, long-term interest rates are likely to remain mired around 9 percent for some time, unless the confrontation in the Middle East is suddenly resolved.
A hint of the kind of tonic a Persian Gulf settlement could be was seen on Friday, when speculation that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was considering a withdrawal from Kuwait was picked up by credit market participants at the end of a volatile, agitating week.
Bond prices rallied by more than a point on the talk, and the gains were sustained even though the rumors were subsequently debunked.
 
Prospect Tied to Mideast
''It seems clear to me that the crisis in Iraq is holding up rates higher than they otherwise would be,'' said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. 
''And if we could get a full percentage point drop in interest rates quickly,'' he added, ''it is conceivable that we could avoid or minimize the damage of a recession. But that prospect hinges on what happens in the Middle East.''
A solution to the crisis in the Middle East would almost certainly give the market more help than an agreement on the Federal budget, analysts said.
 
Different Reactions Expected
''Eventually, probably after the election, Congress will pass a budget that cuts the deficit by $40 billion,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
''But given all that has happened in the past few weeks,'' he added, ''I am wondering if the market and the Fed reaction then will be the same as it would have been a week ago. I don't expect a major improvement in long rates for a while.''
News reports said last week that, in early October, members of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted to ease monetary policy once a budget package was passed by Congress and signed into law. But since then the policy makers have gotten further evidence that inflation remains a serious problem, including a report last Friday that showed that producer prices rose by 1.6 percentage points in September. As Mr. Fine suggested, those fresh facts are likely to make the Fed less generous than it might have been earlier.
''Larger issues still constrain the Fed,'' Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc., wrote in the firm's weekly ''Comments on Credit.'' ''Gathering evidence of recession will set its own timetable for substantive Fed easing,'' he said. ''In the interim, policy makers will likely seek to contain unsettled markets by stalling.''
Aside from inflation worries, long-term interest rates most likely will have to remain high if the Treasury is to sell what likely will be a record amount of securities in the fourth quarter. Particulars of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions will not be announced for two weeks.
Still, some market participants are already fearful that with the dollar falling and confidence in the United States shaken, foreign demand for the new Treasury issues will be modest at best, and that interest rates may have to go even higher to sell the new issues.
 
Lack of Participation
Worries about foreign participation received new urgency last week, when the Treasury struggled to sell $8.5 billion of new seven-year notes. The overseas appetite for securities of that maturity has never been strong, but last week, market participants said, it was nonexistent.
Some analysts have argued that the seven-year auction was an aberration. Others said that, even if foreigners did not participate, interest rates were not likely to rise by much, because domestic customers, worried about credit quality and with few alternatives, would take up the slack.
''The seven-year auction took place in an environment of maximum uncertainty on every front,'' Nomura's Mr. Resler said. ''At least some of those issues, most probably the budget, will probably be resolved before the refunding.''
Foreigners may yet balk, but with corporate bond issues off sharply, commercial banks and insurance companies in the United States would seem to have few high-quality alternatives to Treasury securities.
''With the exception of short-term issues, corporate borrowing programs are on hold,'' said Robert A. Schwartz, a vice president and senior financial economist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. With debt levels at near-record levels and the sharp slowdown crimping revenues, ''I think we are in for an extended period of slow borrowing demand'' from the private sector, he added.
''Without a 9 percent coupon on the bond, selling the long-term securities could be hard,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''But I would think maturities of up to 10 years would not be a problem. The banks and insurance companies, who want to get quality assets, will be big purchasers.''
Aside from observing how much leeway there is in the Friday deadline for Congress to pass a new budget, market participants are likely this week to receive another unwelcome reminder that inflation is at unacceptably high levels. On Thursday the Government is expected to release its September report on consumer prices. Analysts are not sanguine about what the figures will show.
Most forecasters see further increases in prices for gasoline and home heating oil helping to push up the September Consumer Price Index by eight-tenths of a percentage point, a figure that would equal the rise recorded for August. Excluding the volatile food and energy components, the index was seen probably rising by three-tenths of a percentage point, following a half-point August rise.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans Farm Trade Concession

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
In an effort to find a compromise with the European Community over the sticky issue of farm subsidies, the United States will present a plan in Geneva on Monday that modifies its call for an end to such aid.
The farm subsidy issue has proved to be a significant barrier to progress in the broader trade talks in Geneva. President Bush has called the talks aimed at liberalizing world trade his highest trade priority, but he has threatened to pull the United States out of the talks if he does not win meaningful cuts in farm subsidies.
 
A Wide Gulf
The latest United States proposal would cut 90 percent of farm export subsidies and 75 percent of farm income supports over 10 years. Washington had previously called for the elimination of all such subsidies over five years. 
Yet the United States' compromises fall far short of what the community has been seeking.
The 12-nation community, which contains a vocal farm bloc five times as large as that in the United States, is promoting an alternative that would trim supports by 30 percent and do little about export subsidies, Washington's main target.
Even with the new American proposal, the gulf is so wide, said Dale E. Hathaway, former United States Under Secretary of Agriculture, that ''only heads of state now can bridge it.''
The United States considers itself the world's most efficient food producer. If farm protection is reduced, it expects to win back export markets lost chiefly to Europe because of historically high European Community subsidies. The Agriculture Department says protectionist policies in other countries cost American farmers $11 billion a year.
 
Delays Broader Accord
''This is the final phase of the negotiations, and we're trying to move the ball forward,'' a senior Administration official said of the new proposal.
Hit by drought and declining prices, European farmers are fighting any significant cuts in the overall level of European Community support. Twice in the last two weeks, protests by French farmers have disrupted ceremonies involving President Francois Mitterrand.
The division over what to slice from the $250 billion a year of worldwide farmer protection programs has checked progress in the broader trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round because the first talks were held in Punta del Este, Uruguay, in 1986. The talks, under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are scheduled to wind up in two months in Brussels. GATT, the Geneva-based forum that wrote the initial trade charter 43 years ago, serves as the world's trade court.
The success of the talks hinges on complex trade-offs struck by groups of countries. For example, third-world countries are refusing to open their markets to financial services from industrial countries unless those countries make it easier for third-world nations to export food.
The stakes are high. The lower trade barriers that could result from successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round would add $300 billion, or 5 percent, to the gross output of the American economy by the end of this decade, according to a new study by the Stern Group, a trade advisory firm, for a group of multinational companies.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has calculated that the liberalization would raise American exports to third-world countries by $200 billion over the same period.
Washington also sees lower protection as the key to billions of dollars of budget savings.
Under a budget compromise being weighed by Congress, some $13 billion of income support payments would be knocked from the current annual base of $54 billion of farm spending over the next five years.
 
No Unilateral Moves
But the Administration has also said it will not ''unilaterally disarm,'' or cut protection programs, without equivalent reduction abroad.
Still the Bush proposals are making some American farm groups nervous, especially sugar, dairy, peanut and cotton growers, whose quota protection could be dismantled.
Some analysts think the Europeans could be holding back in the belief that Congress will never back the kind of protection cutbacks the Administration seeks.
The European proposal, offered by the community's executive commission but still not finally acted upon by its Council of Ministers, contains provisions that are red flags both to Congress and the Administration.
Washington regards as most objectionable a plan for ''rebalancing,'' under which the community would slap import quotas and tariffs on certain food items on which there has already been international agreement not to increase protection under earlier trade rounds.
The target, most analysts believe, is the $2 billion-a-year market the United States has built up in Europe selling soybeans, oilseed meal and feed grain substitutes. European farmers cannot compete in these markets without special protection. 15 Areas Under Discussion Agriculture is only one of 15 sectors in which negotiators in Geneva are working to put together the overall balance of benefits and concessions that will be necessary for the round to succeed.
Some of the other issues under discussion include strengthening the protection for copyrights and patents, setting up a comprehensive set of market-driven rules to reduce barriers in the service sector and improving GATT's procedures for settling disputes.

HEADLINE: A European Slump Hits U.S. Computer Makers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
A growing number of American computer companies can no longer count on gaudy sales figures in Europe to compensate for slow growth at home, according to some analysts anxiously awaiting third-quarter earnings figures.
High interest rates and economic stagnation in Britain have been the biggest brake on sales growth. But analysts said uncertainty about where to direct capital investment during Germany's reunification had apparently delayed some computer purchasing in that country, Europe's biggest computer market.
 
A Slump Is Projected
Sales of work stations, personal computers and portables are still growing at a healthy clip. But sales of mainframes are slow, and midsized computers may actually end up showing little or no gain for the year, said Bertrand Lebel, who follows electronics equipment for the International Data Corporation in Paris. And some analysts say that weaknesses are beginning to show up even in parts of the personal computer sector. 
''P.C. growth is down to around 10 percent here from 30 percent last year,'' said Michael A. Styles, who follows the industry for Smith New Court Securities in London.
International Data, a multinational market research firm based in Framingham, Mass., projects that total European computer hardware sales will slump to an annual growth average of 7.9 percent for the five years ending in 1994, from 16 percent in the five years from 1984 to 1989. Donald Bellomy, director of worldwide studies for International Data, said the growth rate for the United States was about 6 percent in the earlier period and was unlikely to change much through 1994.
 
Interpreting the Lag
Analysts say that the economic cycle and political conditions are not the only reasons European sales growth may be flagging. Many companies are preparing to introduce product lines, a situation that encourages customers to delay purchases, said Daniel Benton, a computer industry analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The trick in interpreting third-quarter figures, analysts say, is to consider these factors after first taking into account the normal sluggishness of the period, which results from the European practice of taking lengthy summer vacations.
A long-term slowdown in sales growth in Europe puts new pressure on growth-hungry American and European computer makers to build up marketing efforts in Asia, despite the difficulty of going head to head with Japanese, Korean and Taiwanese computer makers.
Although Europe will continue to be a bigger market than Japan and is likely to surpass the United States by 1994, demand for nearly every type of computer equipment is projected to be much stronger in the Pacific Rim countries over the next five years, according to International Data.
Analysts said balance sheets would begin to reflect tougher price competition in Europe as well as slower growth for many companies. Among the rumors that worry observers in the City of London, Britain's equivalent of Wall Street, are reports that the International Business Machines Corporation has growing inventories of unsold personal computer products in Britain. ''When the industry leader has problems like that, it is bound to lead to price wars,'' said one analyst, who declined to be named.
An I.B.M. spokesman here said the company would not comment on its inventories in a particular country.
 
Competition from Japan
Price wars for some products might be inevitable even without slower growth. ''If I were an American manufacturer, I would be even more worried about what the Japanese are going to do than the economic cycle,'' Mr. Styles, the Smith New Court analyst, said. He noted that Fujitsu Ltd. would take control of International Computers Ltd., the largest computer maker in Britain, next month, giving it an established distribution and service network to increase sharply its European marketing.
Mitsubishi has acquired the British manufacturing operations of Apricot P.L.C., one of Britain's most successful personal computer companies, and is said to be looking for other expansion opportunities.
''Then there's Hitachi, which has good technology and is second to Fujitsu in Japan,'' Mr. Styles said. ''We haven't heard much from them here, yet.''
Few computer companies break out regional sales figures before the end of their financial year. A few, notably the Unisys Corporation, reported unexpected European sales slumps in the second quarter. Others like Tandem Computer, cited Britain in particular as a weak spot. With earnings due out shortly, no one is commenting on projections for the third quarter.
 
'A Temporary Uncertainty'
The prevailing climate was summed up by Mark Steinkrauss, a spokesman for the Digital Equipment Corporation. ''Outside of Britain, you don't hear talk of a recession, but the overall tone is more conservative,'' Mr. Steinkrauss said. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., is one of several companies that noticed a slowdown in German investment as reunification approached, but the company sees that development as inconsequential.
''The preoccupation with reunification isn't a negative in terms of computer demand,'' Mr. Steinkrauss said. ''It's just a temporary uncertainty.'' Growth figures are often heavily influenced by where a company is in its product cycle. The Compaq Computer Corporation is riding a heady part of the growth wave for professional personal computers, a market segment expanding than 20 percent annually in Europe.
Compaq figures that 23 percent of the potential European customers for such computers have them already, compared with more than 30 percent in the United States, and that penetration will reach 50 percent in both regions by the end of 1992, according to Gian Carlo Bisone, the Munich-based vice president in charge of European and international marketing for Compaq, which has its headquarters in Houston.

HEADLINE: Expanded Compaq Laptop Expected

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 14

 BODY:
A year after it began selling small, lightweight ''notebook'' computers, the Compaq Computer Corporation has developed a model that matches the speed and power of the most popular larger desktop machines. Compaq is expected to introduce its machine, named the LTE 386/20, on Monday.
''We are now at the point where this technology allows us to make a notebook computer our primary computer,'' said James D. Poyner, an analyst at William K. Woodruff & Company, a Dallas brokerage. He said the Compaq model and similar versions other companies will soon introduce should make the small laptop sector the hottest field for personal computers in 1991. Fate of the Desktops? The outlook for the industry's overall growth is more dismal, particularly if the nation's economy goes into a downturn. Some analysts said the advent of the notebook machines would depress sales for desktop models with the same features. 
A big appeal of Compaq's new model, Mr. Poyner and other analysts say, is its ability to run a new software program, Windows 3.0 from the Microsoft Corporation, which has become popular for its ability to conduct several tasks simultaneously on the same computer screen.
The Compaq model uses the same electronic brain, the 386 SX microprocessor made by the Intel Corporation, and high-clarity graphics systems as desktop models.
Earlier versions of notebook computers were built around Intel's 286 computer chips. The more powerful 386 chips are twice as fast as the 286 at processing data. Most 286 machines also were hampered by poor graphics clarity.
 
Japanese Disk Drive
Japan's Citizen Watch company is making the three-and-a-half-inch disk drive for Compaq, as it did with Compaq's first notebook model last year. Compaq is also making printed circuit boards with a new technique developed for instrument panels in the military's Stealth aircraft programs. The process eliminated most connectors on the circuit board, saving space and permitting more features.
''This is a new, improved version of an already best-selling product,'' said Peter Rogers, an analyst at Robertson, Stephens & Company, in San Francisco. ''It keeps Compaq in a leadership position, but really doesn't further the state of the art that much.''
The new Compaq machine is 2.2 inches thick, weighs 7.5 pounds and measures 8.5 inches by 11 inches. Its screen can show 25 lines of text at a time. The disk drive in one version stores 60 million characters of information, or approximately 30,000 typewritten pages. A smaller disk drive, which stores up to 30 million characters, is also available.
 
Fast-Growing Segment
Dataquest, a research firm in San Jose, Calif., estimated that 156,000 notebook machines with 386 SX microchips would be sold this year, and 615,000 next year. The segment should be the fastest-growing in personal computers through 1994, said Joan Hoelewinski of Dataquest.
Many analysts said Compaq's initial prices - $6,999 for the high-capacity disk-drive model and $6,499 for the lower capacity machine - were too high and that Compaq would be forced to cut them after several competitors, including Epson, Toshiba, Dell, AST and some smaller companies, begin selling similar models priced as low as $4,000 later this year. Most desktop models using the 386 microprocessor are less than $5,000.
Some analysts said Friday that because Compaq's initial price was too steep, they had reduced their earnings estimates for the company. Compaq's shares lost $2.25 each in trading on Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $36.75, their lowest point in more than a year.
Mr. Rogers, the analyst at Robertson, Stephens, said he was not troubled by Compaq's pricing strategy and did not change his earnings estimate. ''This product will contribute modestly to growth and profitability at Compaq in 1991,'' he said.'' Compaq is now in its third generation of laptop computers; Apple and I.B.M. are not even in the market.''
