HEADLINE: NWA Options On Cost Cuts

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The machinists' union at Northwest Airlines said Friday that it was considering a company proposal that it choose between laying off workers or taking a 10 percent pay cut for six months.
Alfred Checchi, the chairman of NWA Inc., the parent company of Northwest, made the proposal on Wednesday to Guy Cook, president of the 24,400-member International Association of Machinists at Northwest, The St. Paul Pioneer Press reported Friday. It quoted unidentified sources.
Mr. Cook generally confirmed the report but said the number of layoffs is ''up in the air.'' He said figures of ''10, 15 and 20 percent were all mentioned.''
Mr. Cook's union covers mechanics, baggage handlers, reservations agents and other ground personnel.
Northwest would not confirm or deny that a proposal was made.
Northwest employs about 44,000 workers, about 16,500 in Minnesota. A 15 percent cut would amount to 6,600 jobs.
Other big airlines, including USAir, Pan American World Airways, Trans World Airlines and the industry heavyweight, American Airlines, have already announced layoffs to cope with a sluggish economy and a 65 percent increase in fuel prices.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
5 Years After Duvalier, Haiti Is Still in Shambles

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
Like many other people in business here, Richard Morse pegged his hopes on plans for democratic elections in 1987 that were meant to put a definitive end to the long Duvalier family dictatorship.
By reopening the venerable Oloffson Hotel just weeks before the vote, Mr. Morse said he ''figured either we would have a good election and a lot of tourists would start coming, or something bad would happen, and at a minimum we'd have a lot of journalists on our hands.''
Instead, Mr. Morris said, in what could well serve as an epitaph for the entire Haitian economy in the wake of the death-squad attack on voters that forced the cancellation of the elections, ''people got killed, they shot at the journalists and nobody came.''
 
Violence and Corruption
Nearly five years after a popular revolution ended the 29 years of dictatorship by Francois Duvalier and his son Jean-Claude, almost everyone who has managed to remain in business in Haiti has nightmarish tales of hardship. They run from incidents of Government mismanagement and outright thievery to the flight of customers and investors alike in the face of violence, neglect and decay. 
''We have had a succession of Governments without economic plans,'' Raymond Lafontant, president of the Haitian Industrial Association, said of the five regimes, all undemocratic, that the country has seen since 1986. ''That has hurt us as much as any strikes, riots or other social problems.''
Elections are planned for Dec. 16, and Mr. Lafontant and others see them as a sort of last call for the revival of Haiti's once-robust economy. ''If we can't honorably pass the hurdle of true elections, we are going to have a major economic crisis here,'' he said.
By the standards under which most countries measure economic performance, Haiti is the Western Hemisphere's poorest nation and already has a big crisis.
Largely cut off from foreign aid since the 1987 elections, the economy has steadily shrunk. According to official trade data, exports contracted to an estimated $153 million last year, from $223 million in 1985. Imports suffered a similar decline, falling to $259 million last year, from $345 million five years ago,. The Central Bank, in its annual report, has warned of a ''growing pauperization of the Haitian people.''
While neighboring islands and some Central American countries rushed to take advantage of the Caribbean Basin Initiative, a United States regional trade incentive program, Haiti has been left behind.
Much the same has happened in tourism. Once a haven for sophisticates who relished its cultural and historical richness even before many of its neighbors had international hotels, Haiti is now plagued by a lack of investment and a reputation for violence. Even though foreigners have rarely been victims, Haiti has all but disappeared from the tourist map.
Sugar, once a big export, is now imported, and coffee and several other agricultural products are also in steep decline.
 
Elemental Weaknesses
Before they can entertain rosy thoughts of an economic takeoff or even plan for a modest economic turnaround, Haitian businessmen say, much needs to be done to stop the country's steep slide.
Lacking its own oil and having lately had low rainfall, Haiti this year began to experience a severe energy crisis that has included long electrical blackouts and shortages of gasoline. The decrease in rainfall has hampered hydroelectric generation.
The Government recently had to patch together deals with the United States, Venezuela and other countries to assure that a tanker carrying petroleum products arrives every three and a half weeks. In August, when negotiations stalled, the country went virtually without oil for 10 days.
Much of the Government's cash crunch has been attributed by the business community to rampant corruption.
''We don't have smuggling anymore in Haiti, we have direct thievery,'' said George Izmery, a grocery supplies importer. ''All of the goods you see in the country are coming in without paying any taxes. If you go to the provinces, you will see ships unloading cars and refrigerators without passing customs. No wonder the state is going bankrupt.''
Like many in the business community, Mr. Izmery said the Government must mount a serious attack on corruption, while streamlining a host of regulations that discourage trade and investment.
 
Reservoir of Aid
Western diplomats in Port-au-Prince say that should Haiti successfully conduct elections and begin the process of economic reform, there is a large reservoir of international aid already in the pipelines - most of it frozen because of instability and violence - that could quickly become available.
''If you had a more predictable environment here you would quickly see more Haitian and more foreign money legitimately invested,'' said a diplomat who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. ''There is a reasonably large and imaginative private sector here, and given a chance, they would make a go of it.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nearly five years after a popular revolution that ended the Duvalier dynasty, almost everyone in business in Haiti has nightmarish tales of hardship. ''People got killed, they shot at the journalists and nobody came,'' said Richard Morse, who reopened the venerable Oloffson Hotel in Port-au-Prince shortly before the 1987 election. (Joseph B. Treaster/The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: October 16, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1482 words

HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS OFFER AN ARRAY OF PLANS TO CUT THE DEFICIT

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Filling in details of a comprehensive plan to reduce the Federal budget deficit, Congressional committees recommended cuts today in programs from veterans' benefits to student loans and proposed increases in a wide variety of fees.
But the committees spared food stamps, school lunches and other child nutrition programs. And in defiance of the prevailing trend, House and Senate committees recommended expanding Medicaid to provide health care to more children in poor families.
After a weekend break, budget deliberations resumed on two fronts. One was the committees' work on a budget package intended to save $40 billion in the 1991 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, and $500 billion over five years. The other was tactical planning by the Congressional leadership. 
 
Democrats to Work Together
Democratic senators, anxious to capitalize on the Republican discomfort over President Bush's proposals on taxes and spending, were promised that their leaders would work with House Democrats to develop a budget plan more favorable to poor and middle-income Americans than what Mr. Bush wants. [Page B8.] The White House has indicated that the President could accept a budget plan similar to the one the Senate leadership has proposed but that he would veto the House plan.
House Republicans, agreeing that any plan of theirs would stand no chance of carrying the House, decided to come forward with a budget plan nevertheless. Their proposal would freeze spending and would not increase taxes at all.
 
House to Vote on 3 Resolutions
The House will vote Tuesday or Wednesday on three budget resolutions: the Democratic leadership plan, a more liberal Democratic alternative and the Republican plan.
While lawmakers on both sides of the Capitol worked on the budget legislation, President Bush was on a two-day campaign swing for Republican candidates. In Dallas, he promised that he would not allow Government spending to continue if authority ran out before a budget was completed.
''Twice now this year, I've signed emergency legislation to add more time to the clock,'' the President said. ''Well, this Friday, time's up. The American people deserve more than this stopgap government.''
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, struck back. ''The President,'' he said, ''often takes the stance of standing aside as if he's not a participant in these budget negotiations.''
Congress is unlikely to finish the budget by Friday night, and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the leaders of the Republican minority in each house, warned against closing down the Government again.
A veto by the President forced most Government activities to close over the three-day Columbus Day weekend while Congress was working on the broad outline of the budget package. ''I would hope we could avoid that,'' Mr. Michel said. ''I think the President takes a bigger hit than Congress.''
The program reductions proposed today by 22 Congressional committees would curtail spending increases planned for some programs and actually cut spending in others. The House proposals will be folded into an omnibus ''reconciliation bill,'' scheduled for debate by the full chamber as early as Tuesday or Wednesday. The bill would make the detailed statutory changes needed to help save $500 billion over five years, in keeping with the goal endorsed by President Bush and Congressional leaders.
Here are some of the recommendations made by various panels:
Veterans: The House and Senate Committees on Veterans Affairs voted to recommend an increase in the fee for home mortgages made or insured by the Department of Veterans Affairs, and a $2 fee for prescriptions filled for certain outpatients at veterans' hospitals. The panels also called for a one-month delay in the cost-of-living adjustment for compensation payments to disabled veterans, including some wounded in combat. This would save $49 million in 1991, but amounts lost by the delay would be paid in a lump sum at the start of the new fiscal year, in October.
The two committees would also require the Government to try to collect payment from private insurers for health care unrelated to a veteran's military service. The panels estimated that all the proposed changes, taken together, would save the Government $627 million this year and a total of $3.6 billion over five years.
Shipping: In a signal of the lengths Congress is going to raise new revenue, the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries recommended that tonnage taxes for international cargo shippers, including American carriers when they are coming from foreign ports, be increased for the first time since 1909. The duty for ships coming from ports in the Western Hemisphere would rise from 2 cents a ton to 27 cents; the duty on ships from other foreign ports, now 6 cents a ton, would rise to 81 cents.
Patents: The House and Senate Judiciary Committees recommended a surcharge of about 50 percent on fees paid by people seeking patents. The basic filing fee for a company seeking patent protection of a mechanical or electrical device is now $370. Some small businesses and individual inventors qualify for a discount; Congress rejected a proposal by the Bush Administration to eliminate the discount.
Education: Under a proposal approved by two other Congressional committees, the Federal Government would no longer offer guaranteed loans to students attending certain colleges or trade schools with high default rates. The number of schools that would be affected is uncertain. Congressional aides said the House provisions might affect 1,000 of the 7,000 schools where students receive guaranteed loans, and the Senate provisions could eventually affect 2,000. Most of the schools would be trade schools, which teach subjects like auto repair and truck driving.
Another provision recommended by the two committees would affect freshmen starting work at colleges and trade schools next year. The first disbursement of their guaranteed loans would be delayed until 30 days after classes begun. A significant number of students get loans, drop out of school and then default.
Medicaid: The Senate Finance Committee and the House Committee on Energy and Commerce recommended expansion of Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for low-income people. The House proposal would require states to cover children through the age of 12 in families with income up to the Federal poverty level. The Senate proposal would require coverage of poor children through the age of 18, and it would give states the option of covering children aged 18 and younger in families with income up to 85 percent above the official poverty level.
The poverty level for a family of four was $12,675 last year. If the ceiling were set 85 percent above that level, it would be $23,448.
Banks: The House and Senate Banking Committees voted to allow Federal regulators to increase premiums paid for deposit insurance by banks and savings and loan associations. Commercial banks now pay 12 cents for each $100 of deposits. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced last month that the premium for banks would rise in January to 19.5 cents for each $100 of deposits, the largest increase in the agency's history.
The two committees voted to eliminate the statutory limit on premiums. They envision a further increase in the premium for commerical banks, to 23 cents, in January 1992. The increase would help control the Federal deficit and would shore up the bank insurance fund, strained by bank failures.
Worker Safety: Senate and House committees both proposed to increase the civil penalties that can be imposed on employers by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. The maximum penalty for a willful or repeated violation, now $10,000, would be increased to $50,000 under the Senate proposal and to $70,000 under the House proposal.
 
Softening the Political Impact
While many proposals in the deficit-reduction package have drawn protests from those affected, they are generally less explosive than earlier proposals to increase health insurance costs for elderly people enrolled in Medicare. Members of Congress say the package is not likely to be approved or defeated because of proposals affecting veterans, college students, banks or shipping companies.
Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, ranking Republican on the Veterans Affairs Committee, said changes in veterans' benefits accounted for less than 2 percent of all the savings projected over the next five years.
''Congress is attempting to balance the budget uniformly and does not intend for our veterans to shoulder an unfair amount of the burden,'' he said. ''At the same time, veterans' benefits will lose their value if the economy that supports them is crushed under the twin burdens of debt and deficit.''

PUB-DATE: October 16, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1604 words

HEADLINE: Banks Cut Business Lending, Hurting Weakened Economy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The nation's major banks, concerned about their own deteriorating finances, are making fewer loans to corporations.
By cutting back on loans that companies use to buy other concerns, build factories and develop products, the lending slowdown weakens the national economy and could precipitate or lengthen a recession that many economists say has already begun.
So far this year, according to Federal Reserve data, existing loans to business by the country's large banks have fallen nearly $5.2 billion, to $315.58 billion - a significant change of direction from 1989, when loans at banks rose more than $18.4 billion. Banks have pulled back on lending and laid off employees mainly in response to their own troubles, especially a growing volume of commercial real estate loans that are not being paid back. And Federal regulators have encouraged the banks to be tightfisted by pushing them to set aside more funds as a capital cushion against further losses. 
 
Corporations Are Crimped
Executives and entrepreneurs across the nation are finding that bankers once eager to lend them money are suddenly reluctant. The recent experience of Carl C. Landegger, an investor in several paper mills and owner of the Black Clawson Company of New York City, a profitable manufacturer of paper-moving and recycling equipment, shows how the financial problems at the nation's largest banks are crimping corporate America.
Mr. Landegger, who has in the past arranged billion-dollar loan agreements with banks, was ready to expand again by buying the Garden City Paper Company, a profitable paper recycler in Richmond.
But Mr. Landegger's plans ran into a snag: His bankers, usually so accommodating, balked at financing the acquisition, even though it was the kind of purchase that he says he would have had little trouble getting approved by banks a year ago or so.
''I have never seen banks so afraid as they are now,'' Mr. Landegger said.
In general, bankers' fears, according to analysts, are understandable given the mounting losses on loans at many banks and the continued softening of the nation's economy. Banking regulators have found the industry's losses so worrisome that they are prodding banks to add to their capital, which can be used to cover losses from bad loans. But the industry's troubles are making it increasingly costly for banks to raise new capital because investors are shunning bank stocks and bonds.
''We don't know yet how bad things will become for banks, and that uncertainty is creating a lack of confidence in banks,'' said Richard L. Pike, banking specialist at Chancellor Capital Management, a New York investment advisory firm.
Accordingly, most banks do not have the option to issue new securities to raise capital these days. Thus, to shore up their capital base, the major banks have typically taken two steps to conserve scarce funds: cut their stock dividends and shrink their business.
Twenty banking companies, including the Chase Manhattan Corporation and Chemical Banking Corporation, have reduced or eliminated dividend payments to shareholders in the last year. Many banks are also cutting their work forces, led by Chase Manhattan, which expects to eliminate 5,000 jobs by the end of the year.
Perhaps even more common than dividend cuts is the willingness of banks to reduce assets, the traditional measure of a bank's size and importance. In accounting terms, banks count loans as assets, which can produce profits from fees and interest payments.
 
To Reduce Risk
But by reducing the amount of loans on their books, the banks can also reduce their risks, and reduce their need to borrow money at a time when investors are very skittish. Among the 25 largest banking companies at the end of 1989, nine were smaller at midyear and two showed growth of less than 1 percent. By the end of the year, that trend is expected to expand as bankers reduce their need for outside financing by shrinking in size, either by making fewer loans, or selling the loans they have made.
''Many large banks are now planning for no growth or a shrinking of assets,'' Mr. Pike said. ''This is creating more of a credit crunch than people realize.''
Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said, ''The process of contraction is painful, but I don't know what other choice there is.'' A delay in forcing banks to deal with their problems ''runs the risk of later encountering difficulties in banks that resemble the savings and loan industry,'' he said.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has told Congress several times this year that he wanted more capital at large banks. By increasing capital, the amount of shareholder funds and long-term borrowings available to absorb future losses, the industry and the Federal deposit insurance program would be better protected from losses, he explained.
 
Capital Plans Needed
Although the Fed has yet to describe in detail its tougher capital standards, bankers and their advisers are preparing. ''If earnings take a hit from loan losses or costs of restructuring, bankers better have a plan to rebuild capital,'' said James McDermott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm specializing in banks.
John F. Kooken, vice chairman and chief financial officer at the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles, said that ''to the extent that banks raise capital under these conditions, it adds to their costs, and to the degree that they elect not to raise capital, they will restrict credit flows.''
Both options have important consequences. If banks' costs increase, customers can expect higher fees and interest rates as bankers pass on their costs. If banks curb their lending, more and more companies can expect a cold shoulder from their bank.
Thomas C. Theobald, chairman of the Continental Corporation, a Chicago banking concern, said cutbacks by banks were becoming evident in the corporate loan market. ''Where you might earlier have had six or seven banks competing for a corporation's business,'' he said, ''there might now be only three.''
 
Less Competition
With less competition, Mr. Theobald said bankers had been able to raise fees and interest rates ''a bit, but not enough to get rich.''
In commercial real estate lending, an area where new bank lending commitments have dropped off precipitously after the rapid growth in the last half of the 1980's, Mr. Theobald said that for those banks still willing to lend, there was sometimes so little competition that ''you can now charge just about anything you want.''
Small businesses, which are often the first to be hit when credit becomes less available, report that banks are increasingly reluctant to lend to them. According to the National Federation of Independent Business, only 33 percent of its members said they were borrowing regularly, a record low.
 
Lending by the Fed
So far, the financing problems of large banks have not been serious enough to require emergency loans from the Federal Reserve, except for the Bank of New England, which borrowed several billion from the Fed early this year. But after decades of relying on short-term borrowings, the availability of those borrowed funds is now being questioned.
Christopher Roberts, head of the New York branch of Credit Suisse, one of the world's strongest banks, said, ''We have been benefiting somewhat'' from the problems at American banks. But he added that foreign banks had not been cutting their deposits or credit lines with large American banks.
So far, the four large American banking companies that have less than top-notch financial ratings and rely on short-term deposits from institutions around the world - Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover - have had little trouble in attracting foreign funds.
 
'Clearly Less Confidence
''There is clearly less confidence today in the American banking system than at any time since the Depression,'' said Robin Monroe-Davies, president of IBCA Ltd., a London-based bank analysis firm. ''But there has been nothing at all like the flight of deposits which hit Continental Illinois in 1984.'' After heavy losses from bank oil-industry loans, Continental suffered a run on its deposits and required a multibillion-dollar Federal rescue.
At home, the standing of the largest American banks in the commercial paper market - another important source of short-term financing - has clearly deteriorated. A proposed rule by the Securities and Exchange Commission limiting money market mutual fund holdings of less than top-rated commercial paper to 5 percent of fund assets has hit banking companies hard, since 5 of the 10 largest banking companies do not carry the highest Moody's rating.
''We do not buy any commercial paper that does not carry top ratings of A-1 and P-1, and that means we buy very few bank names,'' said Ellen Harris, manager of the mutual fund group at Paine Webber Inc. ''The higher interest rates on lower-rated issues are not worth the extra risk.''
Paine Webber estimates that large American banking companies have been paying higher rates on commercial paper than top-rated industrial and financial companies, which are also major borrowers in that $500 billion market. While a top-quality company like J. P. Morgan might pay a rate of about 7.90 perent, or 15- to 20-hundredths of a percentage point less than the offered rate for interbank deposits in London, lower-rated companies like Chase, Chemical and Manufactures Hanover would pay 25- to 50-hundredths of a percentage point more than than the London interbank rate.

PUB-DATE: October 16, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2657 words

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
King Hussein on Kuwait and Dashed Hope

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 15

 BODY:
He is chain-smoking again, and says it is impossible to sleep more than four hours a night. To relieve the pressure, he has taken to riding around his palace on a BMW motorcycle. While his eyes can sparkle at times, he looks at other times as if he is carrying the cares of 200 million Arabs on his shoulders.
Since the Persian Gulf crisis began, King Hussein of Jordan has traveled more than 50,000 miles and met with 15 leaders to avert a war that he warns would be catastrophic not only for his country, but also for this region and the West.
''With or without war, nothing will return to what it was,'' the King says. ''This will be an area of turmoil unless people face up to the need to create new dreams and new realities.'' 
Now, after 10 weeks, he says that war may be imminent, despite statements in Washington indicating that there are still months of waiting to see if the economic sanctions against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq will work.
If war comes, the Jordanian King says, it will be partly because of a failure by President Bush and other Western leaders to respond in time to signals from the Iraqi leader, soon after the Kuwait invasion, that he was ready to withdraw from most of the occupied territory.
The 54-year-old King, now in his 38th year on the throne, says he believes that a peaceful end to the Kuwait dispute is possible, but only if there is a greater willingness to compromise by the United States and its Arab allies, and what he called ''an end to the current embargo on dialogue.''
''A dialogue across the airwaves is not constructive,'' he said. If diplomacy fails, he said, his conversations with Saddam Hussein have convinced him that the Iraqis would fight.
''If it's a question of humiliation and surrender, it won't work,'' the King said. ''Capitulation is unacceptable.''
Back at Nadwa, his yellow granite palace in downtown Amman, the King continues his diplomatic campaign with King Hassan II of Morocco and President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria, sending letters and messages back and forth between Baghdad and other Arab capitals, planning his next moves.
In a series of interviews over the weekend, he spoke at length about his efforts to prevent and later to contain the Persian Gulf crisis, the first time he has given a full public accounting of his actions.
He said that on Aug. 2, the day of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, he had been given 48 hours by President Bush to secure a commitment from President Hussein to withdraw his troops. The Iraqi leader, he went on, had promised to begin pulling out troops if the Arab League did not condemn him, something it did do. This, he said, led to the collapse of his early efforts.
The King's mood, often frustrated and angry, was lightened by occasional bursts of humor as he mused about happier times, or watched the latest news on CNN. At one point, his spirits darkening, he spoke of resigning from a job that many regard among the most dangerous in the Middle East, thoughts he said he has since put firmly out of his mind.
 
A Favored People Now Out of Favor
Jordan was once regarded by the United States and other Western countries as the most dependable of the Arab nations, Now, King Hussein showed his distress at the way he and his country have been criticized since the start of the crisis by the United States and its allies. They have deplored what they regard as his hedging on condemning the Iraqi invasion, a stand that the harshest critics say comes close to condoning Baghdad's action.
What made his isolation particularly stressful, he says, is that he and President Bush are friends of long standing. And he went out of his way not to assail the United States. He was more critical of his former Arab allies.
Of all Arab leaders, King Hussein said, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has disappointed him the most. The King said he had helped bring Egypt back into the Arab fold, after its peace treaty with Israel in 1979, but that the move seemed not to have assuaged Egyptian anger at having been excluded in the first place. At a Cairo summit meeting in August, the King said he had the feeling that Mr. Mubarak was ''trying to pay back Iraq for having led the campaign against Egypt.''
Mr. Mubarak has been bitter, in turn, at President Hussein for deceiving him before the invasion of Kuwait, by telling him that he would not take military action.
The King repeatedly emphasized that Jordan has supported all the United Nations Security Council resolutions on Kuwait. He has, however, opposed the presence of American forces in Saudi Arabia, something he said was neither anti-Western nor pro-Iraqi.
''I am pro-peace,'' he declared. ''I have backed nobody except my conscience and the interests of all in peace and security in this region.''
Nevertheless, in the interviews, he praised Mr. Hussein as ''a friend and a new phenomenon in Arab politics.''
When he was asked if he believed that President Hussein, his namesake but no relation, was justified in having invaded part or all of Kuwait, he seemed momentarily uncomfortable.
''I honestly can't tell, but given the leadership of Saddam Hussein, I know it was not easy,'' he replied. ''I can't justify or condone, but the reason must have been pretty substantial to have had it happen. Both sides, I fear, gradually succumbed to a conspiracy theory about the other.''
 
Quashing Rumors Of Lust for Land
The King seemed especially eager to rebut a conspiracy theory that has gained wide credence in Arab circles since the invasion, that Iraq, Jordan and Yemen had been eyeing Kuwait and Saudi Arabia for themselves, and had been planning for months before the invasion to divide up the oil-producing area among themselves.
According to these accounts, Iraq would have taken Kuwait, securing its long-sought free access to the Persian Gulf; Yemen would get part of disputed Saudi territory, and King Hussein, who is revered as a 33d-generation descendant of the prophet Mohammed, would be restored to his family's traditional role as custodian of Islam's most sacred sites in Saudi Arabia.
He said Jordan wanted nothing but peace, and had not been forewarned about the Iraqi invasion.
The King argued, however, that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait could have been prevented through astute Arab diplomacy, and that American forces would not have been needed if the Arabs had enough time to resolve the problem themselves.
And, he said, the United States' decision to send forces to the Saudi desert was taken before the Riyadh Government formally requested them and, he said, seemed ultimately intended not to defend Saudi Arabia but to destroy President Hussein.
According to the King's account, he received an agreement from President Bush, in a telephone conversation within hours of the Iraqi invasion, that he would be given 48 hours to secure a commitment from Mr. Hussein to withdraw his troops. The King said the commitment was given while he was meeting in Alexandria, Egypt, with Mr. Mubarak.
The King said he told the American and Eygptian leaders that he had talked to President Hussein by phone before flying to Egypt and that the Iraqi had said he was planning to begin withdrawing from Kuwait within days. ''Within a week we'll be gone,'' the King quoted President Hussein as saying. The King told Mr. Bush and Mr. Mubarak that the Iraqi leader had also warned that he ''would not respond positively to threats or intimidation.''
 
Conciliatory Word From Iraqi Quoted
The Arab League foreign ministers were meeting in Cairo, and, the King said, Saddam Hussein suspected that the ministers might call for foreign involvement. ''Let us not scratch each other's eyes out,'' the King quoted the Iraqi leader as saying. ''If things go that way, we may say Kuwait is part of Iraq and annex it.''
Early the next morning, Aug. 3, the King flew to Baghdad, where he found President Hussein ''fine and more relaxed than on my previous visit'' six days earlier. The Iraqi leader, he said, reiterated that he was willing to withdraw from most of Kuwait - exactly to where he did not say - and to discuss other grievances at a meeting of heads of government in Jidda on Sunday, provided the Arab League did not condemn him or call for foreign intervention.
The King said he returned to Amman later that day, confident that agreement was possible, but he said he was unable to get either King Fahd or President Mubarak on the phone. While still waiting to convey the results of the Baghdad meeting, he said, he learned that Egypt had just condemned Iraq's invasion, and that the Arab League was preparing to take similar action that night.
King Hussein said he still did not understand why his initiative was undermined. But the condemnations dashed hopes of an early peaceful resolution to the crisis, he said, adding ''Suddenly, it was all torn apart.''
From the King's version of the crisis, an extraordinary picture emerged of the world of Arab politics - a milieu of secrets and conspiracies; of lies and treachery; of humiliations for him and other, poorer Arabs; of duplicity, revenge and broken promises, and of dashed hopes that, he said, had brought him to consider resignation.
''When you look beyond this,'' he asked, ''what is there for us? I'm proud of what I've done in Jordan, but the region itself is sitting on a time bomb. So before the crisis, I was thinking of quitting. I won't quit in the middle of this. But I'll never be a burden to my country.''
 
When Baghdad Decided to Strike
Ranging back and forth through his experiences in recent weeks, the King shed fresh light on other aspects of the crisis.
Among other things, he said, after the invasion Mr. Hussein had told him that he had decided only late in July that military action was necessary. The King said the Iraqi leader had told him that he had decided to seize all of Kuwait, instead of the part of the territory long in dispute, because he expected the United States to defend the emirate with force, and believed he would be in stronger position militarily and politically if he could eventually withdraw to a point that left Iraq with the disputed territory only.
The King said Saddam Hussein also told him that he never intended to invade Saudi Arabia, a threat that was originally cited by the United States in sending troops there.
Furthermore, the King said, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had told him, during a meeting at her country residence, that the United States troops were ''halfway to Saudi Arabia'' before they were formally requested. The King said he had confirmed this later through what he described as his own sources.
The King of this small country, flanked on three sides by Iraq, Israel and Saudi Arabia, seemed most agitated when expressing the view that the invasion could have been prevented.
On at least five occasions since the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988, he said, he said, he unsuccessfully tried to persuade Kuwait directly or through gulf intermediaries to resolve the financial and territorial disputes with Baghdad that he said triggered the invasion. Saddam Hussein also made repeated, unsuccessful attempts, he said.
He said he first became concerned about an escalation of the dispute five months ago, at the end of May, at an Arab summit meeting in Baghdad.
''We had a closed meeting and he was very frank,'' the King said. President Hussein warned that his debt-ridden country was being strangled by economic warfare waged by ''its brothers'' among Arab leaders, and that these leaders seemed indifferent to the fact that Iraq had protected them and their people with ''the blood of Iraqis'' during the just-concluded war with Iran.
Saddam Hussein had already tried to resolve the border issue during the Iran-Iraq war, the King said. Kuwait and Iraq had formed several different levels of joint commissions to resolve it, but with no success.
 
A Volatile Mixture: Oil and Outrage
The King's ''second jolt'' came when he learned that Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, had sent a scathing public memorandum to the Arab League on July 15 accusing Kuwait of violating its oil-production quotas and of stealing Iraqi oil from the Rumaila field, which the two countries shared. Terrible consequences might result, Mr. Aziz warned.
In retrospect, neither Kuwait nor Saudi Arabia seemed to have trusted him, the King said. But he added that relations with Kuwait had never been easy. An assistant to the King described his visits to Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti Emir, for discussions of financial matters, as a ''tin-cup excercise,'' and said that they had become increasingly humiliating.
By 1988, the gulf states had stopped making payments under a 1978 pledge to support Arab countries threatened by Israel. Some had not made full payments. And Jordan had a $6 billion deficit. After 1988, the payments abruptly ended, he said. ''They were putting the squeeze on us and I realized we were going to have severe internal problems,'' the King recalled.
In the spring of 1989, as he had feared, severe food rioting erupted in Jordan. Kuwait ultimately paid Jordan a modest sum, for which the King said he was grateful.
He said his final effort to warn Kuwait about the potential consequences of its deteriorating relationship with Iraq came late in July. On July 29, he visited Mr. Hussein in Baghdad.
''They were bitter,'' the King recalled, speaking of the Iraqis. They recalled with fury, for example, that after Iranian-backed terrorists had tried to assassinate the Emir, ''Iraq had blasted Iran with everything they had - ground to ground missiles, the works.'' Iran had retaliated, causing 1,500 civilian casualties, but Kuwait would not write off its debt, or end the border dispute, or stop stealing oil.
''I realized then that the situation was really very serious,'' the King said. ''I knew they were hurting badly. The atmosphere was tense; the troops were on the border.''
On July 30, the King said he visited the Emir in Kuwait and expressed hope that a special meeting in Jidda between Kuwait and Iraq, scheduled to open the next day, would succeed. And he warned that the meeting was critical.
''I pleaded with them,'' he said. ''They were warm and cordial, unusually so. But there was no commitment, just hopes that it would not fail.''
 
The View of Doom In Soldiers' Eyes
Before boarding his plane, he said, he had a premonition. ''I looked at some Kuwaiti soldiers on the tarmac. I suddenly had a deep sense of sadness. Sometimes, leaders' failures can cost these young people's lives.''
On the plane back to Jordan, the King said his aides told him that they, too, had failed to detect true concern in their meetings with the Kuwaiti Foreign Minister. ''They said their Constitution does not permit us to give up an inch of territory. We won't give in. If they attack us, we would call the Americans.'' The Kuwaitis' only concern, the King said he was told, seemed to be that relying on American military backing would be ''embarrassing'' because of American support for Israel.
He said he had learned of the invasion at 6 A.M. on Aug. 2, when King Fahd telephoned him and urged him to call Saddam Hussein and ask the Iraqi leader to withdraw to the disputed territory. ''It's all Kuwait's fault,'' King Hussein said, quoting King Fahd. ''They would be this adamant. They've brought this about.''
The King said that he spoke to King Fahd rarely after that. On Aug. 6, the Saudi ruler invited ''friendly forces'' to assist in his country's defense. The next day, he sent an envoy to assure King Hussein that relations between Riyadh and Baghdad were fine, that there was no evidence of a hostile Iraqi buildup on the border, and that despite American assertions, there was no truth to reports that Iraq planned to invade Saudi Arabia. Later that night, the presence of U.S. forces in the Saudi desert was announced.

HEADLINE: U.S. AID JUDGMENT UPSETS PAKISTANIS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The United States decision to suspend military aid to Pakistan because of strong suspicions that Islamabad is developing nuclear weapons has aroused a debate here that focuses less on this country's arms policies than on the extremely delicate issue of America's supposed ''big brother'' role.
In the last few days, relations with the United States have been dragged into a bitter mudslinging election campaign as Benazir Bhutto's opponents in the Islamic Democratic Alliance accuse the ousted Prime Minister of playing to a Congressional lobby in Washington bent on interfering in Pakistan's internal affairs.
She, in turn, charges her critics with having destroyed a good working relationship with the United States. Crowds at her opponents' rallies shout abuses against the American Congress. Newspaper columnists talk about a ''Zionist conspiracy.'' 
American and other Western diplomats are concerned at the rising level of anti-Americanism, and wonder how self-destructive it might become amid calls to renounce American assistance.
 
Gulf Crisis Costs a Factor
Diplomats and officials of international organizations here say that Pakistan, already suffering severe shocks from the economic costs of the Persian Gulf crisis, cannot afford to resupply its military with new European or other weapons systems, or to antagonize nations on which Islamabad depends for a range of non-military aid.
The nuclear issue exacerbates a still-simmering controversy over remarks the United States Ambassador, Robert Oakley, made to an Asia Society audience in Washington in September. In a speech that dealt only in small part with Pakistan, he voiced a personal opinion that it might be fairer if the standards of government by which a Pakistani court is judging Ms. Bhutto's rule were also applied to the administration that preceded hers. For his remarks, Mr. Oakley was dubbed ''the Viceroy.''
Ms. Bhutto's Government was removed on Aug. 6 amid charges of corruption and she could be banished from political life by the court that is to rule in her case.
In Pakistan, where feelings are quickly hurt when Americans say anything about this country's shortcomings, the suspension of military aid draws outrage that cuts across all regions and classes, reinforcing a range of anti-American constituencies, including Islamic militants.
Aid to Pakistan was suspended, at least temporarily, on Oct. 1 because President Bush was not able to certify to Congress that Pakistan's nuclear program was peaceful, as required by the Symington and Pressler Amendments. The action in Washington means that all military assistance will be cut off while no new economic assistance beyond what is in the pipeline will be forwarded.
 
Criticism Is Impassioned
The criticism of the United States action tends to be impassioned and some is vitriolic, with words like ''imperialism,'' ''blackmail'' and ''exploitation'' being used generously in newspaper columns and letters to editors.
One central theme runs through it all, framed by the question, Why only Pakistan?
''When the United States' interest in Pakistan has been minimal, our nuclear program has proved to be the bugbear,'' a long editorial in the sober, independent newspaper Dawn said in an editorial on Wednedsay. ''This approach especially smacks of cynicism when compared to the tolerance displayed the the U.S. toward other aid-receiving countries such as Israel, India and Brazil.''
All major parties in Pakistan have at one time or another backed a nuclear arms program. Public opinion polls support Islamabad's belief that it has the right to develop a nuclear deterrent so long as India, which detonated a device in 1974, has one.

HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN CITES SIREN SONG OF TV

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 15

 BODY:
On the day that The Asian Wall Street Journal decided to stop circulation in Singapore because of press restrictions, Singapore's Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew, blamed television reporting for the deaths near Tiananmen Square in Beijing in June 1989.
Mr. Lee made the remark today in Hong Kong, in a speech to the Commonwealth Press Union, before leaving for China. His trip there will be his first since Singapore normalized relations with Beijing in August.
Mr. Lee said Chinese students had been seduced by television coverage of demonstrations in the Philippines and South Korea into believing that they could alter conditions in China. 
Such coverage, more than any desire for freedom, he said, encouraged Chinese students to protest.
''China's students forgot that China was a very different country from either the Philippines or South Korea, two countries with close links with the United States, where the media and Congress wield immense influence.''
 
Television Is Blamed
Television was responsible for this amnesia, he suggested, saying, ''I believe it is this contextless television experience that led to the tragedy of Tiananmen on June 4.'' On that day, the Chinese Army attacked demonstrators and killed at least several hundred in the streets around the square.
Mr. Lee, who was educated in Britain as well as Singapore, has often spoken of the damage done to Singapore's Asian nature by the individualism of Western values, and often praises his own understanding of Confucianism as a system of communitarian hierarchy and respect.
In a similar fashion, he criticized China's students for not understanding the need for patience and circumspection in their dealings with their aged leaders.
''They had achieved a dialogue with Government leaders,'' he said. ''If they had been patient and circumspect, they could have contributed over 10 years to the gradual opening up of the system, which had already started.''
Mr. Lee, 67 years old, is stepping down as Prime Minister in November after more than 30 years in office. A blunt and combative man, he enjoys annoying journalists and challenging their assumptions about how Asian societies function.
 
Hong Kong Press Criticized
In this vein, he also criticized ''the foreign press'' in Hong Kong, a British colony, for trying ''to foist Western values'' on the citizens there. He said the Western press had ''crusaded for their vision of democracy'' in Hong Kong and had thus caused the Hong Kong stock market to fall after the killings in Beijing.
By the Western press, Mr. Lee seemed to have in mind The Asian Wall Street Journal and its sister publication, The Far Eastern Economic Review, both owned by Dow Jones & Company, which have been regular targets for his criticism and libel suits in Singapore.
The Journal and the Review, whose reporters are not allowed to work in Singapore, are the only regional publications in Asia that try to provide Western standards of objective journalism to the societies there. Mr. Lee has had running battles with both publications since 1987, when he restricted the Journal's circulation in Singapore from 5,000 copies to 400, contending that the paper was interfering in Singapore's internal affairs.
The Journal had published an article about Singapore's plans for its stock market but refused to publish the entire text of a 1,500-word letter the Government wrote in response. Singapore also limited the Review to 400 copies for its reporting on political opposition in Singapore and the treatment of dissidents there. In response, the Review stopped its circulation altogether, causing Singapore to alter its copyright laws to allow a local, advertisement-free reprint of the Review to be sold.
 
Paper Halts Circulation
The Journal fought in the courts to restore its circulation. But after the publication of new regulations on the foreign press, approved by Singapore's Parliament on Aug. 30, the Asian Journal announced in an editorial today that it, too, was halting its circulation in Singapore.
The regulations require foreign publications to post an unspecified security deposit against legal judgments and obtain an annual permit if they distribute more than 300 copies in Singapore and carry articles on politics or current affairs in ''any country in Southeast Asia,'' a requirement that will also apply to the Paris-based International Herald Tribune, partly owned by The New York Times and The Washington Post.
Mr. Lee's announced successor, First Deputy Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, has also said that foreign publications may be required in the future to sign a waiver of rights under the Singaporean Constitution in lawsuits, the Journal's editorial said.
''What worries us is the purpose to which, five years of experience warns us, these powers will be put,'' the paper said. The Singaporean Government wants the foreign press ''to practice self-censorship,'' it continued. ''A facade of factual reporting will be allowed,'' it said, but nothing to disturb what the Journal called ''the political monopoly of the People's Action Party or the pretense of democracy.''
Tonight in Hong Kong, Mr. Lee called the Journal's decision unimportant. ''Besides,'' he said, ''anything of importance is immediately faxed to anyone who's got an interest in knowing it.''

LENGTH: 1111 words

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: Gorbachev's Prize;
Soviet Leader Is Regarded as a Hero Everywhere but in His Own Country

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev today became the second Soviet champion of democratic reform to win the Nobel Peace Prize, and the second to be denied a national celebration in this country so often out of step with the world's enthusiasm.
When Andrei D. Sakharov was honored in 1975 for his campaign against Communist suppression of human rights, the private joy of the country's freedom-lovers was muted by an official chorus of vilification. The official press called the prize ''political pornography'' and mocked Dr. Sakharov as a Judas who had sold out to the C.I.A.
Fifteen years later, Mr. Gorbachev's moment was greeted with ambivalence in his Parliament, widespread indifference on the street and bitterness from Mr. Sakharov's widow.
Mr. Gorbachev's compatriots generally acknowledged that his award was justified, but said it would not distract attention from ethnic conflict at home or the indignity of the food markets, where a dozen eggs now cost two days' wages. 
''I am sure that he deserves the Peace Prize,'' said Georgi A. Arbatov, director of the U.S.A. and Canada Institute and a member of Parliament. ''I wouldn't think he has deserved the Nobel Prize for economics.''
 
Revising Economic Plan
Mr. Gorbachev got the news from the Norwegian Ambassador while he was closeted with aides repolishing a much-postponed program to dismantle central economic controls and create a free market. His plan was scheduled for presentation today but was delayed until later in the week as he tried to strike a balance between radical and conservative variants.
The Soviet leader told a pool of television reporters that he was ''thrilled'' by the award and would go to Oslo for the presentation ceremony on Dec. 10, ''like all other recipients'' of the prize. The comment overlooked one notable exception: Dr. Sakharov, who was refused permission to leave the country.
He said the prize reaffirmed the correctness of his policies and would energize him ''intellectually, emotionally and physically.''
Mr. Gorbachev's spokesman said he had not decided what to do with the cash prize of about $710,000 that accompanies the award. In the past he has shared foreign awards and book advances with the Communist Party and domestic charities. #2 Literature Prizes Recalled While the lack of public celebration had its parallel to the award to Dr. Sakharov, it also formed a stark contrast with the way the Soviet Union responded when two of its citizens, Boris Pasternak and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, were awarded Nobel Prizes for literature in 1958 and 1970 respectively. Under pressure and intimidation from the Government, both men turned down their prizes after first accepting, although Mr. Solzhenitsyn eventually was able to pick up his award four years later after he was expelled from his native land.
In the Soviet Parliament, where a hard-line minority spent much of the day savaging the policies that won Mr. Gorbachev the favor of the Nobel Committee, the announcement was greeted with five seconds of lukewarm applause.
During a rare and freewheeling foreign policy debate with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, critics charged that Mr. Gorbachev had sapped Soviet strength and prestige by his liberation of Eastern Europe and slashing of the military.
''Even I could defend the interests of the Soviet Union in this way, by making concessions, unjustified concessions,'' said Col. Nikolai S. Petrushenko, an army propaganda instructor and a maverick in Parliament.
 
'Award Came From Outside'
Later, in the Kremlin courtyard, Colonel Petrushenko said Mr. Gorbachev's award ''reminds me of the times when Leonid Brezhnev used to pin awards on his own chest.'' He continued: ''My opinion is this will not enhance the authority of the President inside the country. This award came from outside.''
Other deputies praised the award, while agreeing that it would have little impact at home.
Roy A. Medvedev, a historian once persecuted for documenting Stalin's repressions, said Mr. Gorbachev's peacemaking would ultimately help the Soviet economy by cutting military costs and opening the way for Western aid.
Shoppers and sightseers interviewed outside Moscow's two most prominent tourist attractions, Lenin's mausoleum and the new McDonald's restaurant, said the award reflected Mr. Gorbachev's standing in the world, but not his dwindling popularity at home.
 
Suggestion: Buy Big Macs
''The prize is premature, because his work is not finished,'' said Galina Shefkun, a computer programmer. She suggested that Mr. Gorbachev donate the prize money to buy Big Macs for Moscow children.
''The Nobel Committee just doesn't know what it's like here,'' a young teacher told the Reuters news agency. ''Let them spend a couple of months living like Russians and see how they feel. Is peace only for foreigners?''
Some strollers said the Soviet press and television in recent years had recorded so many man-of-the-year awards and peace honors bestowed on Mr. Gorbachev that no one would pay much attention to another.
Few Soviet citizens appreciate the prestige the world associates with the Nobel Prize, perhaps because the Kremlin has traditionally made light of it.
Indeed, a Soviet reporter for the prime-time news program ''Vremya'' asked Mr. Gorbachev how he felt about receiving a prize that has traditionally gone to anti-Communists like Mr. Sakharov and Lech Walesa, the Polish Solidarity leader. The Soviet leader skirted the question.
 
Ill-Timed, Bonner Says
Yelena G. Bonner, Mr. Sakharov's widow and companion in the human rights campaign, declined to comment directly on Mr. Gorbachev's worthiness for the award. But she said it was ill-timed, coming with the world near war in the Persian Gulf and the feckless Soviet leadership fiddling over an economic plan.
''It's shocking, the West's blindness to the tragedies our country has lived through during the five years of perestroika headed by Gorbachev,'' she said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Gorbachev released Mr. Sakharov from internal exile in 1986, and for the next two years the dissident and physicist applauded the Soviet leader while goading him to press farther and faster toward democracy.
But gradually Mr. Sakharov grew disenchanted with Mr. Gorbachev, charging that the Soviet leader was accumulating dictatorial power while losing touch with the public mood. Mr. Gorbachev in turn grew resentful of the pressure from the unrelenting human rights advocate, and today reporters extracted from him only the most cursory praise of his predecessor on the Nobel honor roll.
As Miss Bonner saw it, ''He said what he had to say, nothing more.''

HEADLINE: As Korean Leaders Meet, North Seems Increasingly Isolated

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Six weeks after the start of a new high-level discussion between North and South Korea, a senior South Korean delegation traveled to the North this morning amid signs that Seoul was prepared to offer some limited new concessions to its longtime Communist enemy.
Prime Ministers Kang Young Hoon of South Korea and Yon Hyong Muk of North Korea are to hold their second round of talks on Wednesday and Thursday in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang. The first set of talks took place Sept. 5 and 6 in Seoul.
Diplomats and officials here said that they did not expect significant breakthroughs and that most likely the two sides would do what they did last time: repeat longstanding positions and demands without significantly narrowing their differences. 
North Korea continues, for example, to demand that South Korea expel the 43,000 American troops deployed there and ban American nuclear weapons from the region as a prerequisite for improving relations. South Korea, rejecting these proposals, wants North Korea to recognize its legitimacy as a government.
Despite the broad differences, officials and specialists said they were not certain what would happen this week, at least in part because of the fast pace of changes since the opening round of talks last month. Some recent developments are seen as possibly forcing the negotiators' hands.
 
Isolation of the North
Perhaps the biggest event was the formal announcement last month by the Soviet Union, North Korea's longtime patron, that it would establish diplomatic relations with South Korea. In addition, China, another Pyongyang patron, has said it will set up a trade office in Seoul.
Both steps illustrated the extent to which the North has become increasingly isolated. It has apparently been forced to look for friends elsewhere in the world; this month it welcomed a delegation from Japan and vowed to improve ties with Tokyo.
Although the Korean changes are not on the scale of what has happened in the last year in Europe, diplomats say they have been startled by the degree of uncertainty spreading in an area that largely remains a relic of cold-war tension and confrontation.
The issue of a United Nations seat for Seoul is a sore point in North Korea, which continues to regard its southern neighbor as an illegitimate colony of the United States. North Korea has been reluctant to agree to anything undercutting its claim to sovereignty over the whole peninsula.
But now both China and the Soviet Union are widely seen as likely to support South Korea's bid for a seat at the United Nations, where it has had to attend as an observer in deference to North Korea's longtime insistence that there be only one seat for the two countries. Neither side now has a seat in the General Assembly.
 
Certain Concessions Seen
In the last round of talks, North Korea made it clear to South Korea that Seoul's persistence in pushing for a United Nations seat for itself could jeopardize the future of the two countries' new dialogue, which is the first effort to reduce tensions on the Korean peninsula in nearly two decades.
According to news accounts in Seoul, President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea is eager to gain some sort of recognition of his Government's legitimacy from this round of talks, which many experts rate as a long shot at best.
Mr. Roh was said to be prepared to make certain concessions, like curtailing joint military exercises with the United States and releasing anti-government dissidents if Pyongyang agrees to improve cultural, family or economic ties between the two countries.
In South Korea, diplomats say they have been a little confused about the signals from North Korea in recent weeks. On the one hand, Kim Il Sung, the 78-year-old dictator in Pyongyang, has been quoted as saying that although there was only one Korean nation, there was room for two governments.
Japanese news accounts of a Tokyo delegation's visit quoted Mr. Kim as saying, ''Let's have one country and one people, but two systems and two self-ruling governments.''
On the other hand, Mr. Kim's son and heir apparent, Kim Jong Il, was quoted in more recent reports as taking a harder line, saying there could be no concessions in such matters, and that Pyongyang would continue to look with disfavor toward a United Nations seat for South Korea.
 
New York Film Festival
Beyond those diplomatic steps, there have been several cultural and athletic exchanges in recent days that appear to have lent an atmosphere of optimism to the talks.
This week, for instance, several South Korean musicians traveled to the North, as did a soccer team. And in New York City the two countries lent their names to a film festival with offerings from both sides. The two sides have also agreed in principle to try to field a joint team at the next Olympic Games.
The delegation from South Korea is expected to pay a call on the elder Mr. Kim in Pyongyang on Thursday, conveying a message from President Roh that sought a summit meeting between the two and for another round of talks at a later date.
Mr. Roh was also said to be ready to accept some of North Korea's choice of language in a joint statement if Pyongyang would make its own concessions. But the South Korean leader has had his own problems in recent weeks, and some diplomats say they have weakened his hand.
The South Korean President was forced to dismiss key military and intelligence aides when it was revealed that military intelligence was continuing to carry out extensive illegal surveillance of South Korean citizens.
Such surveillance is against the law, but North Korea and its left-wing sympathizers have long accused the Government of such behavior. In addition, Mr. Roh is trying to get talks going with Kim Dae Jung, the popular opposition leader.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Cheney Says Forces in Gulf Are 'in for Long Haul'

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney said today after conferring for an hour with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that the allied forces arrayed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf were ''in for the long haul.''
''I don't think anyone should make the mistake of assuming that this is the kind of operation that will be over in a very short time,'' Mr. Cheney said tonight. He is scheduled to leave on Tuesday morning for a four-day visit to Moscow as the guest of the Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri T. Yazov.
Asked at a news conference when President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would run out of time for a peaceful withdrawal from Kuwait, which he invaded and seized on Aug. 2, Mr. Cheney said that there was no set timetable. 
 
Discourages Attack Speculation
In brief interviews earlier in the day and before the press at the British Defense Ministry tonight, he sought to play down speculation that the United States and its allies would be forced into a military attack against dug-in Iraqi forces in Kuwait within weeks or months. Last week, the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said that an assessment of how well the current policy of economic sanctions had worked would have to be made within that time.
Tonight, Mr. Cheney said, ''The fact is, we haven't ruled out any options at this point.'' The United Nations sanctions against Iraq are beginning to hurt, he went on, and must be increasing domestic political and economic pressure on President Hussein to withdraw his forces, though he said he could offer no evidence that the Iraqi leader would change his mind.
American forces in and around Saudi Arabia now exceed 200,000, with additional tens of thousands of Arab troops from Egypt and the gulf states. Mr. Cheney told British Independent Television News tonight that the deployed forces had prevented President Hussein from attacking Saudi Arabia after seizing Kuwait.
A British force of about 7,500 troops and 120 tanks from the Seventh Armored Regiment is arriving in Saudi Arabia now, reinforcing several thousand men with British air and naval forces sent to the area in August, and France has deployed an even larger force. Mr. Cheney said he would make a brief visit to Paris at the end of the week on his way back from Moscow.
There, he is expected to discuss the situation in Iraq, where the Soviet Union still has about 180 military advisers, and visit Soviet airborne training centers, Moscow's air defense command, and a MIG-29 aircraft factory.
Asked if he would be pressing the Soviets for more help in persuading President Hussein to leave Kuwait, Mr. Cheney said: ''The Soviets have been, we think, very cooperative to date. I think over all their performance has been consistent with their stated objective of working with the rest of us.''
 
Bush Talks of 'Atrocities'
DALLAS, Oct. 15 (Special to The New York Times) - President Bush accused the Iraqi Army today of committing ''ghastly atrocities'' in occupied Kuwait akin to Hitler's crimes and made an oblique threat to conduct war crimes trials if the United States and its allies succeed in forcing President Saddam Hussein's forces out of Kuwait.
In a speech at a political fund-raiser in Dallas, Mr. Bush said: ''Every day now, new word filters out about the ghastly atrocities perpetrated by Saddam's forces. Eyewitness accounts of the cruel and senseless suffering endured by the people of Kuwait; of a systematic assault on the soul of a nation. Summary executions, routine torture.'' Mr. Bush said the Kuwaiti Emir had told him during a White House visit last month of ''newborn babies thrown out of incubators and the incubators then shipped off to Baghdad.''
''Hitler revisited,'' Mr. Bush said. ''But remember, when Hitler's war ended, there were the Nuremberg trials.''
Mr. Bush did not elaborate.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
U.S. Optimistic That Oil Windfall Will Make Iran Honor Embargo

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials say they are optimistic that Iran, enjoying an economic and diplomatic windfall from the Persian Gulf crisis, will continue to abide by the United Nations embargo on Iraq.
''We don't see any evidence of any significant Iranian violation of the sanctions,'' a State Department official said today. The possibility that Iran might violate the embargo ''is always a concern,'' he said. ''But we have to believe that Iranians know it's in their best interest to help isolate Iraq.'' 
Speaking on condition that they not be identified, American officials say they have no evidence to confirm recent reports from oil industry analysts that Iran might be planning to violate the embargo by swapping food and medical supplies for Iraqi oil.
American officials warn that the Iran's Islamic Government, which has long reveled in its ability to confound conventional wisdom in the West, may yet forge an anti-American alliance with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq designed to foil the blockade.
 
U.S. Heartened by Statements
But the Administration, they say, is heartened by a series of statements from senior Iranian officials, who have vowed that Iran will abide by the United Nations trade sanctions imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran repeated the vow last week, telling Le Monde in an interview that ''if, like Iran, all countires fully applied the embargo, Iraq would be obliged to yield and withdraw from Kuwait.''
The gulf crisis has proved to be a boon for the Iranian economy, which was devastated by the eight-year Iran-Iraq war.
Oil is Iran's major export and, according to some estimates, Iran will take in an extra $3 billion dollars in oil revenues this year because of the jump in oil prices prompted by the invasion. Iran reported this month that its oil exports to Japan, which had once depended largely on Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil, would triple to 750,000 barrels a day.
 
Violation Would End Windfall
The oil bonanza could disappear overnight, however, if Iran breaks its vow and begins trading with Iraq. Under terms of the embargo, a nation that violates the boycott can be subject to a similar boycott.
''Why would Iran want to jeopardize the oil windfall?'' a Bush Administration official asked. ''The Iranians need the money. They are looking for new Western support to rebuild after the war.''
If the Teheran Government violated the embargo, it could also place in jeopardy millions of dollars in development loans that Iran is seeking from foreign lenders, including Western banks.
 
Reassert Regional Power
Foreign policy specialists say recent actions by Iranian leaders suggest that they have come see the gulf crisis as an extraordinary opportunity to wrest concessions from Western nations, as well as from its oil-producing Arab neighbors, and to reassert itself as a regional power.
Shireen T. Hunter, an Iranian specialist at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, said she believes that despite the recent peace agreement between Teheran and Baghdad, Iranian leaders have no desire to strengthen President Hussein's position by weakening the embargo.
''It is not in their interest, in the long term or the short term, to see Saddam Hussein emerge as the master of the Persian Gulf and as a hero in the Arab and Moslem world,'' she said. ''You cannot forget that Saddam is the man who devastated Iran during the war, who set Iran back more than 10 years.''
There is general agreement among diplomats and foreign-policy experts that Iran's peacemaking efforts with Iraq since the Kuwait invasion have not been prompted by any newfound support for the Iraqi regime, but instead by a realization that Baghdad was so desperate for Iran's support that it might relinquish much of what it had taken from Iran during the war.
