PUB-DATE: October 16, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1531 words

HEADLINE: An Old Refrain, Crime, Sounded In New Contests

SERIES: The 1990 Issues - First article of a series.

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Early in his standard campaign speech, Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for governor of Texas, vows to double prison capacity and expand use of the death penalty.
''If you elect me,'' the oil millionaire says in a slow, threatening voice, ''I am going to hurt some drug dealers.''
But moments later he adopts a mellower tone and promotes a package of education programs that he says are intended to keep poor children from turning to crime. He concludes by proposing two years of free college tuition for the disadvantaged.
''About now,'' he adds, ''I bet some of you are thinking I sound like a Democrat.'' Then, changing gears again, he reassures his supporters by asserting that he will pay for his war on drugs by cutting other programs rather than raising taxes. 
 
New Uses for Crime
Across the country this autumn, politicians are developing complex new ways to use crime as a campaign issue. Candidates in several races for governor are blending their positions on crime with stands on other questions, just as Mr. Williams mixes crime, education and fiscal policy into one rhetorical stew.
And crime is being used by a greater variety of candidates to reach a broader swath of the electorate. Republicans emphasized crime most often in the past, and they were usually trying to attract conservative voters, especially working-class Democrats. This year Democrats are just as eager to talk tough, and crime is being used to win over voters across the political spectrum.
The result of all this, according to political scientists and campaign consultants, is a refiguring of some traditional formulas that have distinguished Democrats from Republicans and conservatives from liberals. With voters in a contrary, anti-incumbent mood, they say, many candidates are striving to seem different - to seem anything but a traditional politician - and this is reflected in their use of a classic campaign issue like crime.
''In the past, crime has been more of a character-defining issue,'' said Peter Hart, a veteran Democratic poll taker. ''People dealt with it as a straight up-and-down, stand-alone issue so that a candidate said, 'Here I am on crime, I'm tough, you're not,' and that was it.
''We still see a good bit of that this year, but there is also something a bit different. Some candidates are using more sophisticated tactics by bringing in education and other ancillary issues when they talk about crime.''
 
Talking Tough Not Enough
Talking tough is as popular as ever, but it is not enough this year because virtually all politicians are doing it. Campaign consultants often say they are motivated by the specter of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts floundering in the 1988 Presidential campaign in the middle of accusations that he had treated criminals permissively. Avoiding that fate has meant getting out early with vengeful oratory and anti-crime plans.
''In some ways we are getting a more realistic and mature discussion of crime,'' said Mr. Hart ''It is evolving as an issue.''
Senator Pete Wilson, a Republican running for governor of California, and Gov. Bob Martinez, a Republican who is seeking re-election in Florida, have gone beyond their earlier promises to fight crime to appeal to moderate voters by stressing crime prevention, not just punishment.
Norman Cummings, political director for the Republican National Committee, said, ''A common thread in the gubernatorial races is that crime and quality education go together as issues and one is the key to the other.''
He added, ''Without altering their philosophical framework, Republicans this year are focusing on crime and education to expand their appeal across the political spectrum and to all racial groups.''
 
Campaigning as Outsiders
Among Democrats, Dianne Feinstein in California, John R. Silber in Massachusetts and Lawton Chiles in Florida are running campaigns for governor as outsiders who selectively reject some parts of their party's liberal heritage.
It is perhaps Ms. Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco, who best illustrates the unusual ways that crime can provides the underpinning.
In what campaign consultants have dubbed the ''double death strategy,'' Ms. Feinstein frequently pairs her support for the death penalty with her backing of abortion rights, often highlighting the two disparate points in one brief television commercial.
Facing an electorate that seems to be revolting against traditional political formulas, Ms. Feinstein presents herself as a paradox. Under the slogan ''tough and caring,'' she portrays herself as a maverick who rejects the dogmas of both political parties.
In one of her latest television commercials, Ms. Feinstein promotes a sense of discord between her stand on crime and her lifelong tenure as a Democrat. The advertisement shows her being booed at the state Democratic convention last April when she defiantly told the crowd of predominantly liberal delegates: ''Yes, I support the death penalty. The people of this state want to be protected, and I aim to protect them.''
 
The Essential Counterbalance
For Ms. Feinstein, projecting herself as very tough on crime seems to serve as the essential counterbalance to being a Democrat and a woman. And because she is facing Senator Wilson, who has a long record of promoting anti-crime measures, talking tough is also self-defense.
Dick Dressner, a campaign consultant for Mr. Williams and several other Republicans, said that when it comes to crime, voters respond emotionally. ''They are looking to see if you feel the same way about it as they do,'' he said.
But establishing that link is much more difficult this year. ''There is enormous dissatisfaction out there over the Government's inability to solve problems,'' Mr. Dressner said, ''and the crime problem has been around for so long, it is an obvious target for frustration. The people taking the heat are the incumbents, all over the place, regardless of whether they've been doing a good job or not.''
Democratic officials argue that the public's disenchantment is all the greater because it responded enthusiastically to President Bush's declaration of a war on drugs last year and has been waiting ever since to see a real battle, let alone a tangible victory.
Ms. Feinstein and Mr. Williams, the two candidates who appear to have scored the greatest gains from the crime issue this year, have struck anti-incumbent poses from the outset. And they have addressed crime from the perspective of their own direct experience.
 
An Influential Commercial
Many political experts have argued that a single television commercial played a major role in Ms. Feinstein's come-from-behind victory in the Democratic primary. The advertisement replayed news tape of Ms. Feinstein appearing at a chaotic news conference to announce the City Hall assassinations of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk. She is widely credited with restoring a sense of civic and emotional order to San Francisco after the 1978 tragedy.
Although Mr. Williams's anti-crime proposals have been criticized for being far more expensive than he acknowledges, he rode from political obscurity to a landslide victory in the Republican primary. He campaigned by telling of his teen-age son's drug addiction and rehabilitation. In virtually every speech, he says that is the reason he entered politics.
Both Ms. Feinstein and Mr. Williams started out with major advantages in the contest to establish emotional links with voters. In the critical early stages of their campaigns they could equate themselves with the public and speak with the outrage of victims. Gradually they have joined their rivals in the classic, and this year much more vulnerable, posture of politicians promising to solve a lingering problem.
Crime has often been considered a Republican issue because virtually every Republican Presidential candidate since Barry Goldwater in 1964 has made it a major element. Many races this year have imitated the slugging match quality of those efforts as candidates strive to prove who is toughest, but in other aspects of style and substance the use of crime this year differs markedly.
There have been relatively few allegations by Democrats this year that crime is being used by Republicans in an appeal to racial bias, compared with recent Presidential campaigns, including 1988. The Bush campaign's heavy use of a commercial featuring a black criminal, Willie Horton, who raped a white woman, generated so much controversy that journalists and campaign officials are on watch for the first signs of racial appeals.
Some candidates, like Mr. Williams, have gone out of their way to avoid this problem. For example, he used all white actors for a chain gang in a commercial that promised to teach drug dealers ''the joys of busting rocks.''
And so far, the candidate facing the loudest charges of racial insensitivity is a Democrat, Mr. Silber in Massachusetts. Among other things, he has explained his reluctance to campaign in a predominantly black area of Boston by saying there was no point in going to ''talk to a bunch of addicts'' about fighting crime.

PUB-DATE: October 16, 1990

LENGTH: 344 words

HEADLINE: Bridging Blight in New Rochelle

 BODY:
Davids Island, a spot of land in New Rochelle Harbor, full of promise for development, may forever remain untouched because of a misguided ruling by Gov. Mario Cuomo's Secretary of State, Gail Shaffer. In objecting to a practical proposal for a 1,750-unit housing development on the island, Ms. Shaffer blights the hope New Rochelle sees in it for reviving its failing economic fortunes.
The plan calls for a causeway and bridge to connect the unused, uninhabited island, once the site of Fort Slocum, to the mainland. New Rochelle's assessor expects the project, designed for 3,100 upper income residents who would need few municipal services, to yield $27 million in property taxes. To support her rejection, Secretary Shaffer cites language in the state's Coastal Management Program urging maximum possible public access to waterfront. But she ignores language in the same document that backs ''large-scale development . . . contiguous to, or in close proximity to an area of concentrated development where infrastructure and public services are adequate.'' 
Few places are more ripe for development than decaying suburban cities like New Rochelle. Such cities once contained thriving industrial, commercial and residential activities. Now they are home to many low-income families but not many job opportunities.
Some of New Rochelle's affluent neighbors oppose the Davids Island plan as a precedent for similar development within their boundaries. But their own zoning laws and cherished independence make that threat remote. These communities also worry about pollution produced by the development. But their concerns should be allayed by state regulations plus developers' commitments to build the necessary sewage treatment facility.
New Rochelle's school board, parents' groups and the local N.A.A.C.P. chapter all have criticized Secretary Shaffer for her negative position. She would serve the state better by balancing her concerns for added beach access with New Rochelle's need to encourage a well-designed, fully taxable housing development.

HEADLINE: Inflation Hits Government and Taxpayer Alike

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Is indexing desirable for tax purposes on ordinary income, on capital gains? The function of taxes is to meet the costs of Government operations. Such costs are affected by inflation to the same degree as income in the private sector. Hence, if taxes are assessed to pay for Government operations, it is essential that they pay the entire amount of such costs, including the portion attributable to inflation.
Since Government costs can't be indexed, not even under the Gramm-Rudman Act, it makes little sense to index the income on which taxes are assessed.
 
ROBERT B. AARONSON
Jersey City, Oct. 4, 1990
 The writer is a certified public accountant.

HEADLINE: Inflation Hits Government and Taxpayer Alike;
The Commuter's Share

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Commuters and suburban legislators will balk at New York City's proposed payroll tax. The result will be that city residents will again pay a disproportionate share. 
As a White Plains commuter who spends 10 hours every workday in the city and several weekend hours enjoying the culture, arts, entertainment and sports available here, and not in my suburban city, I pay absurdly low taxes. I generate garbage picked up by the New York City Sanitation Department; I am protected by all of the uniformed services in this city and its underfinanced criminal justice system and by the entire network of health services, and I use the city's roads, bridges and subsidized public transportation system.
Considering that I sleep most of the time I am in White Plains, I generate more government expenses in New York City than I do in White Plains. My New York City nonresident income tax rate is a ridiculously low .0045. If I officially resided in New York City, my tax rate would be more than 3 percent of my income.
Now an essential payroll tax is proposed on wages earned in New York City. My commuting neighbors would vote their legislators out of office if they permitted such a tax to be applied to commuters.
Not only should I pay my fair share of a payroll tax, but also I ought to be taxed at a higher rate of my income. Although I am a White Plains resident, for all practical purposes I live in New York City. If commuters paid their fair share, the extra tax base would raise the quality of life in New York City for residents and commuters alike.
 
GERALD STERN
White Plains, Oct. 5, 1990

HEADLINE: Inflation Hits Government and Taxpayer Alike;
Don't Limit Donations

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The budget negotiations between Congress and the Administration include a proposal to limit the deductibility of charitable gifts to increase Federal revenue. The 1986 Tax Act already severely limited the deductibility of charitable gifts by (1) eliminating the deduction for the 72 million taxpayers who do not itemize, (2) making gifts of appreciated property subject to the alternate minimum tax and (3) lowering the tax rates, in effect, raising the cost of giving. 
It has become more and more apparent that charities are going to have to step in to fill the void for services the Federal Government can no longer afford to provide.
The two top Federal tax brackets are 28 percent and 33 percent: this means for a gift of $1, the charity would receive the $1 for use; if it were not donated, the Federal Government would receive only 28 cents or 33 cents. If charities do not receive these funds, additional pressure may well be placed on the Government to provide assistance to programs to make up for the shortfalls that charities now fill.
Changes in the deductibility of charitable gifts will hamper the ability of charitable organizations to provide important services, not only to our local community, but also to those in need of our support throughout the world.
 
RONALD A. ROSENSWEIG
Vice President, Association of Jewish Federations of New Jersey East Orange, N.J., Oct. 3, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 28, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 427 words

HEADLINE: Inflation Hits Government and Taxpayer Alike;
Relief for Singles

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Single people are heavily discriminated against in the Federal income tax system. For example, on adjusted gross income of $35,000 in 1989, a single person taking the standard deduction paid a Federal income tax of $5,954; a childless married couple filing jointly and taking the standard deduction paid $3,866.
For a Federal tax system fairer to single people and less burdensome on lower income people and most middle income people who derive most of their incomes from wages, I suggest the following changes:
* One tax rate schedule, Schedule X, for all taxpayers, except married couples filing separately, for whom a Schedule Y. For Schedule X, five tax rates: 12 percent on taxable income less than $20,000; 15 percent on $20,000 to less than $30,000; 22 percent on $30,000 to less than $40,000; 27 percent on $40,000 to less than $60,000; 33 percent on $60,000 and up. For Schedule Y, halve the incomes at each bracket in Schedule X. 
* Full taxation of capital gains, interest, dividends and other income, from whatever source. Taxation of all Social Security benefits, in the manner of Civil Service annuities and wage income.
* Standard deductions: No change.
* Itemized deductions: None, except charitable cash contributions and medical and dental expenses as currently allowed.
* Exemptions: No change, except an additional $1,000 for oneself if 65 or older, and an additional $1,000 for one's spouse if 65 or older.
* A tax credit for every married couple filing jointly whose income before adjustments is less than $20,000 and a tax credit for every single person and every married person filing separately whose income before adjustments is less than $15,000, the credit being phased in against taxable income so that those at the bottom of the income scale receive the larger credits as a percentage of taxable income.
Even with mortgage interest payments disallowed as a deduction in this tax change proposal, the vast majority of taxpayers making mortgage payments on gross income of $60,000 or less and nearly all taxpayers with gross incomes of $30,000 or less will benefit from the changes.
Taxing all Social Security benefits in full will reduce the after-tax income of many of the elderly. However, there is no compelling reason Social Security recipients should not pay Federal income taxes on the same scale as wage earners making the same income, most of whom are raising families and have fewer net assets than the elderly with the same income.
 
CHARLES F. MCLAUGHLIN
Philadelphia, Sept. 29, 1990

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Cut the Defense Budget

BYLINE: By William A. Niskanen; William A. Niskanen, chairman of the Cato Institute, was a member of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At a meeting with some war hawks several weeks ago, one of them told me that ''We owe Saddam Hussein a favor. He saved us from the peace dividend.'' That was no favor. Unless there is a war, the major cost of the risky new venture in the Middle East is the failure to reduce our defense budget in response to the dramatic developments of the past year.
The Soviet empire has collapsed. Soviet troops are scheduled to leave Czechoslovakia and Hungary in a few months and East Germany in a few years. Germany is unified and will substantially reduce its military forces. The outcome of this process is uncertain and may still be dangerous in different ways, but the cold war is over and we won! 
Yet the defense budget included in the revised budget resolution approved last week would spend nearly $300 billion dollars in response to the threats of a world that no longer exist. Indeed, real defense spending for fiscal year 1991 - which specifically excludes all present and future expenditures for the Persian Gulf operation - will be about 10 percent higher than total defense spending at the peak of the Vietnam War.
All of the major weapons programs are continued, and only small reductions are scheduled for the U.S. forces now stationed in Europe and Asia. A failure to make major phased reduction in the defense budget is the primary reason why our political ''leaders,'' for the first time in U.S. history, have agreed to a large tax increase after a major war.
A more responsible post cold war defense budget would reduce real annual defense spending by 50 percent by the end of the decade.
At least three of the four new strategic systems in the current budget should be scrapped: the B-2 bomber, the MX and Midgetman missile system and the new D-5 missile for the Triton submarines.
President Bush has proposed to maintain 195,000 troops in Europe and more than 100,00 in the Far East against a threat that is rapidly disappearing. We should remove and demobilize all of our forces in Europe, Japan, Korea and the Philippines sometime before our good friends ask us to go home.
There is no longer any reason to race to develop an advanced tactical fighter or a space-based missile defense system; on the other hand, we need a good close-support aircraft and some limited defense against strategic missiles. None of these opportunities and problems have been addressed.
There is broad bipartisan support to cut the defense budget. While people may differ on how the peace dividend should be spent, that issue requires both peace and a peace dividend, the prospects for both of which have been threatened in the past several months.
Yet even some of those who most ardently support our new Persian Gulf venture recognize that the current defense budget is not responsive to the new political and military realities. Deep defense cuts can be made, and my own preference is to commit all defense savings to some combination of deficit reduction and, not only no new taxes, but a reduction of those taxes that most limit economic growth.
The reason for my preference in a new reality of our own making - the Federal deficit was about four percent of GNP in the eighth year of economic recovery. The growth of productivity has been slow for 17 years. And the economy is now in a period of negative to slow growth, increasing inflation and falling dollar - at a time when our financial institutions are unusually vulnerable and our ability to borrow abroad has been seriously reduced. Our defense budget should be based on the new economic realities at home.
There is still time for leadership. In a world that has turned upside down in the pursuit of individual freedom and a market economy, an expansive and expensive vision of the American role abroad and of Federal Government at home is neither good economics, good politics nor good sense.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: An Orthodox Synagogue Perseveres in the South Bronx

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Each Saturday in the Longwood section of the South Bronx, a handful of elderly Jews slowly converges on the Intervale Jewish Center, uncertain whether enough men will gather to worship at the temple to provide a minyan, the quorum of 10 men needed to perform a full service. If not, Moishe Sacks, who serves as the temple's rabbi, will settle for nine and throw open the doors to the wooden ark, where the Torah is stored, and declare that God is their 10th man.
''The ritual says there have to be 10 men, and I don't doubt at all there have to be 10,'' said Mr. Sacks with a sly smile and a shrug. ''The idea is how you count those 10.''
 
Clinging to Traditions
Such creativity has served him well as the rabbi of the South Bronx's only surviving Orthodox Jewish shul, or synagogue. The building's facade looks like a throwback to the decimated temples of postwar Europe, with its doors seeming to be shuttered and a phantom second story that was never completed for lack of funds. 
But Mr. Sacks and his congregation tenaciously cling to their traditions in a neighborhood in which dozens of other temples have faded into memory and Spanish has long since replaced Yiddish as the language of daily life.
While his twists on Jewish law have drawn criticism from his stricter colleagues, Mr. Sacks said his interpretations maintained the spirit of the religious laws and enabled him to continue ministering to his congregation. ''It's like you want to cross the stream and you can use a boat, swim or go across the rocks,'' he said. ''If you can't swim, you use a boat, and if you're a good jumper, you go across the rocks. The important thing is to get to the goal.''
When the Intervale Jewish Center opened in 1922 for Russian immigrants from Minsk, the streets of the South Bronx and the East Bronx were filled with Jews who had traded their dreary existences in Lower East Side tenements for the roomy apartments that sprang up alongside the elevated trains that rumbled up Westchester Avenue. There were stores that catered to their dietary laws, Yiddish theaters that provided popular entertainment, and, above all, temples that met their spiritual needs.
But the 1950's saw the beginning of an exodus from the area to New York City's growing suburbs as Puerto Ricans and blacks moved into the neighborhood, only to find themselves trapped in a shrinking manufacturing economy where jobs were scarce. The neighborhood began its inexorable descent into the depths of urban blight, leaving behind mostly those older Jews either too poor or too set in their ways to move.
To those who remained, the Intervale Jewish Center was the focal point of their lives. ''The synagogue is my heart,'' said Malachi Parkus, 76, who was born in Abyssinia, now Ethiopia. ''Without the synagogue I see no reason to live for.''
 
Faded and Tattered
Where 500 people once fit into the temple, seven worshipers sat last Saturday on creaky benches that were splattered with paint and sometimes served as makeshift shelves for prayer books. Four men went up to the Torah and gently swayed as Mr. Sacks read in Hebrew from the book of Genesis.
Behind them, faded and tattered banners elaborately embroidered with Stars of David or the Ten Commandments flanked by lions and bearing the names of defunct congregations hung on railings in mute testament to the toll that time has taken on the area. The temple's dank, mildewy air has left curlicues of flaking paint clinging to walls mottled with yellow water stains.
Mr. Parkus stood nearby with his head swathed in a tan and black prayer shawl and one hand atop the unrolled scroll. ''I put my hand on the Torah so the words will go up and reach God,'' he explained later. ''That way, every time Mr. Sacks reads, God gets it.''
In the Orthodox tradition, the women sat apart from the men, but not behind the threadbare white curtain that once designated their section along the far left wall. In deference to their age and the temple's tiny congregation, they sat across the aisle from the men at tables, where they awaited their after-service meal of hallah, gefilte fish and dates.
Elsie Miroff, a 92-year-old retired dressmaker, chattered away with two friends, her hoarse, whispery speech a rapid-fire blend of Yiddish and English. Although she closed her nearby tailor shop three years ago to move into a nursing home in the northeast Bronx at her children's urging, she goes to the Intervale Jewish Center every Saturday and Sunday.
 
'It's My People Here'
''I love it,'' she said of the synagogue. ''It's my people here.'' At the end of the service, the men's voices rose in song as they prayed and approached the women. ''As long as my soul is within my body, the Lord is with me and I am not afraid,'' they intoned in Hebrew as the three women at the service rose to their feet and hummed along.
While Saturdays are devoted to worship, Sundays at the temple are a blend of school and socializing. Former and current neighborhood residents, as many as two or three dozen, come by for brunch and a chance to see friends and join a discussion of the week's Torah reading.
''If they want an oasis of Judaism, this is the place to come,'' said Louis Kaplan, 74, a retired clerical worker.
During the week, Mr. Sacks tends to the business of running the temple, paying bills, answering letters from old neighbors who write to see if the temple still exists, and thanking donors who have helped the temple keep it doors open. Occasionally, he engages in biblical discussions with Seventh Day Adventists or Jehovah's Witnesses from down the street who come to him for accurate translations of biblical passages from the original Hebrew.
Mr. Sacks, a pudgy man with silver hair and dark bushy eyebrows who was born in Lithuania, has lived since 1936 in the neighborhood, where he worked in a nearby bakery unitl he retired five years ago.
He arrived at the Intervale temple in 1962 after the other local temples he had attended closed down, one by one. He was never been ordained, but his boundless energy, intellectual curiosity and ability to weave stories that give a lesson made him a natural for the rabbi's position when it was vacated in the mid-1960's.
 
The Driving Force
His congregation credits him as the synagogue's driving force, a view echoed by an anthropologist who chronicled the five years he spent studying the synagoue in ''The Miracle of Intervale Avenue'' (Schocken Books, 1986). ''Moishe gave me a sense of the creative response to the vicissitudes of life,'' said the writer, Jack Kugelmass, who now teaches at the University of Wisconsin. ''He weaves a narrative through which everybody there fulfills a role.''
Although Mr. Sacks's sons have urged him to move from the area because it has been plagued by serious crime and the synagogue has had burglaries in past years, Mr. Sacks remained steadfast in his commitment to the temple. He said he has welcomed to the synagogue the children of mixed-faith marriages who did not feel comfortable in stricter congregations and he has even offered a wedding blessing for a Jewish woman whose own congregation frowned on her marriage to a gentile.
''This shul has got a significance to each person that comes here, whether it is just a tie back to the past, a little soul-searching on the present situation or a little lamentation on how they got into the present situation,'' he said.
 
A Vote of Confidence
Staying open was a vote of confidence in a community that has begun to shed its image of postwar ruin for that of a neighborhood whose sloping streets have started to be lined with renovated apartment buildings and ranch-style houses with green lawns and white picket fences.
''The community itself wages a fight and when they see someone else waging a fight too, it's like gladiators fighting and looking next to them and appreciating one another,'' he said. ''In the end, we have common enemies -enemies against morality.''
The passage of time may have helped the community begin its slow return to stability, but for the temple's elderly congregation, time brings the threat of extinction. Yet on some days, local merchants or the occasional police officer will drop in, filling out the minyan and enabling the group to say the kaddish, or prayers for the dead, while at other times the congregants' grandchildren and great-grandchildren come by for services, giving Mr. Sacks a glimmer of hope that the temple could survive, even if it meant bending the rules at times.
''As long as there is life in you, you can worship God,'' he said. ''Life is the predominant factor.''

HEADLINE: A Weak Economy Buffets Two Commuter Railroads

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Hit hard by a weakened regional economy, two of the major commuter railroads in the New York metropolitan region find themselves with shrinking tax subsidies, disappointing ridership and rising expenses that could threaten service and lead to higher fares.
The Long Island Rail Road and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad both envision unexpectedly large shortfalls for the fiscal year that begins in January - $27 million for the L.I.R.R. and $20 million for Metro-North. In 1991, the railroads will receive substantially lower tax subsidies, which account for about half of their overall financing, the officials said. The subsidies were cut by the state as a result of its own decline in tax revenue. 
The outlook is worse for the L.I.R.R., which has seen its ridership plummet in the last year, than it is for Metro-North, where ridership is growing but at a much slower pace than in the past. The L.I.R.R. is considering several options, including cutting back service, and closing Penn Station during the early morning hours.
About one-third of 372,000 riders who commute to New York City on the railroads work in industries like finance, banking, insurance and real estatewhere there have been widespread layoffs, the officials said.
At the same time, the costs are increasing, especially as the price of oil rises. Railroad officials estimate that for every dollar increase in the price of a barrel of oil, the railroads pay an additional $500,000 for electrical power.
''We are facing some serious problems here that can only be solved through severe belt-tightening across the board and that may include service reductions,'' said Charles W. Hoppe, who became head of the L.I.R.R. in April.
L.I.R.R. officials said that they now expect $297 million in fare revenues for 1991, compared with their previous estimate of $304 million. The officials expect to receive $311 million in tax subsidies in 1991, compared with the $326 million they had anticipated.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which supervises the railroads, has told them that they will have to cut their expenses by 3.7 percent in 1991 to offset the expected decline in tax revenues and fares. The railroads already have reduced their expenses by 3 percent this year. A third commuter railroad, N.J. Transit, which is not operated by the M.T.A., has not disclosed its plans for next year.
Mortimer L. Downey, the authority's executive director, said that while the commuter railroads are ''being asked to do more with less,'' he is confident that they will find ways to cut costs without sacrificing the quality of service. But, he said, ''if the economic situation gets worse, the railroads may be forced to make more severe cuts.''
To offset its revenue shortfall, the Long Island is considering continuing its current hiring freeze, reducing the total number of employees through attrition, cutting service on all lines and possibly closing Penn Station for several hours in the early morning.
Although a fare increase is not scheduled until 1992, Mr. Hoppe said that if the economy continues to deteriorate, the price of a ticket could increase sooner.
Ridership on the L.I.R.R. declined 7 percent to 5.6 million passengers in August 1990 from 6.04 million passengers in the same month last year. Railroad officials attribute much of the decline to weak economic conditions, but Sheldon Schachter, chairman of The L.I.R.R. Commuter's Council, an independent watchdog group, said many passengers had abandoned the railroad because of delays and dirty trains.
 
Feeling the Crunch
Metro-North, which serves commuters who live in Connecticut and several New York counties, is in much better fiscal and operating shape than the L.I.R.R.
Average weekday ridership has increased 15 percent to 197,800 passengers this year, compared with 172,500 passengers in 1985. And the railroad's on-time performance reached a record high of 92.6 percent last year, Metro-North officials said.
Still, Metro-North officials said they are feeling the crunch of the region's slow economy and expect ridership to drop considerably by year's end.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 20, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about budget problems at the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road misstated restraints placed on their spending in 1991. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which supervises the railroads, has told them to limit spending increases to 3.7 percent in 1991, not to cut spending by 3.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Offers A Plan to Help Small Business

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration yesterday announced a plan to help small businesses, including many owned by women and minorities, get millions of dollars in loans and city contracts.
''We must recreate the old New York where small businesses thrived alongside larger ones,'' Mayor David N. Dinkins said in announcing the plan.
The program would change the city's contracting practices to channel more business to small enterprises, create loan funds to help small businesses grow, and attempt to encourage neighborhood reinvestment and business development. 
The city, facing a budget deficit, will not allocate new funds for the program. Staff members from other economic development programs are being reassigned and $13.5 million will be reallocated from other programs.
Speaking to a crowd of city officials, supporters and minority business owners, the Mayor said the program would particularly benefit companies owned by women and minority-group members, many of which are small, neighborhood-based businesses.
 
Reviewing Past Policies
City officials will also study whether past patterns of discrimination have affected the city's purchasing. If so, the Mayor said, the city will devise programs to set aside some of its business for enterprises owned by women and minority-group members.
City officials emphasized that they had not yet determined whether such a program was needed. They also said any such program would conform to a Supreme Court ruling this year that requires cities to show evidence of past discrimination and to tailor set-aside programs to address specific inequities.
Under the program announced yesterday, four banks - Morgan Guaranty Trust, Banker's Trust, Chase Manhattan and the Bank of New York - will create a $6 million loan fund for small companies. The city will provide $1 million for similar loans.
The city will also award contracts to local businesses whose bids may be as much as 10 percent higher than those by businesses outside the city. City officials said this change would benefit neighborhood businesses and would also keep jobs in New York and increase tax revenues.
In addition, the city will divide larger contracts into several smaller ones to give small companies a better chance to compete.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins discussing his economic incentive program with an overflow crowd at City Hall. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York Municipal Labor Talks Entering Hoped-For Home Stretch

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
New York City's municipal labor talks today enter what both sides hope is the home stretch, in which the negotiators are supposed to go into a room and not emerge until they reach an agreement.
''You lock the doors and don't come out until you have a settlement,'' said Edward Handman, an aide to Stanley Hill, the executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
Mayor David N. Dinkins's press secretary, Albert Scardino, described the talks similarly. ''They stay in until white smoke comes up the chimney,'' he said. 
If the negotiators fail to reach an agreement, they can seek a declaration of impasse. Under state law, a panel of neutral arbitrators would be appointed to review the dispute, decide the issues and impose a contract. While the procedure is used occasionally, both sides prefer to work out their differences.
 
A Backdrop of Gloom
For the unions and the administration, this is a bad season to be bargaining, labor experts agree.
The municipal treasury is limited, the region's economy is deteriorating and city revenues are down sharply. Despite recent tax increases and service cuts, projections of the budget gap are growing. In response to rising crime, the administration has announced a costly plan to hire more police.
There is even the specter of 15,000 layoffs to save money. For the unions, the choice between losing jobs and getting raises is distressing. Eric J. Schmertz, the Labor Relations Commissioner, said that ''layoffs are something we'll certainly be tackling in the negotiations.''
The unions are under pressure from their members to keep up with inflation. Specifically, they want to match the 5.5 percent raise and welfare fund increase of $100 per employee that the city granted the teachers on Oct. 1. The city's position is that it cannot offer more than the 1.5 percent raise already budgeted, unless the unions find new savings. The administration is under attack from financial critics who say the teachers' contract was more than the city can afford.
All those pressures mean both sides are searching for creative solutions. The possibilities include productivity savings, maneuvers in pension fund financing like the one that made possible 2.5 percent of the teachers' raise and ways of delaying raises and revising the steps on the pay scales.
Some critics of Mr. Dinkins's labor and fiscal policies oppose what they see as a potentially unwise rush to settlement. ''I fail to see why the Mayor is so anxious to conclude a contract, since it plays directly into the hands of the union leaders,'' said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-supported organization. He said the other unions learned their lesson from the teachers, and ''they want to get their contracts signed before the roof falls in.''
Today's events start with the officers of several city unions gathering for a strategy session at the Sheraton Centre in Manhattan. Mr. Hill, whose 140,000 members constitute the city's largest union, and Barry Feinstein, president of the 12,000-member Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, will be hosts of the breakfast meeting.
About noon the unions plan a joint news conference with city officials. After that, negotiations begin.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Senators Vow to Form Plan Less Favorable to Wealthy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
With their rank-and-file members smelling the political blood of Republicans, Senate Democratic leaders promised at a strategy session today that they would work in negotiations with the House to develop a budget plan more advantageous to the poor and the middle class and less favorable to the wealthy than the one the Bush Administration wants or the one that will go before the Senate this week.
Senators George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, made that promise at a private lunch meeting of Democratic senators after broad support was expressed for a budget plan to be voted on by the House of Representatives on Tuesday or Wednesday.
That plan, sponsored by Representative Dan Rostenkowski and almost certain to be passed by the House, would force taxpayers earning more than $200,000 a year to bear the brunt of deficit reduction.
A plan approved early Saturday by the Senate Finance Committee would divide the additional tax burden about equally between the wealthy and other taxpayers. This is the plan most likely to be adopted by the Senate and to be sent to a conference with the House to work out the differences. It is in the conference that Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Bentsen said that they would try to make the final legislation more acceptable to the Democratic rank and file. 
 
Another Shutdown Looms
After meeting with President Bush this morning, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said in an interview that he thought the President would back the Senate plan.
The budget agreement struck last month by President Bush and Congressional leaders would place most of the additional taxes on the middle class and would cut Medicare benefits much more deeply than the other proposals.
With the budget battle heading for a climax late this week, Mr. Bush vowed today to shut down the Government once more if Congress did not produce budget legislation before the authority to spend money lapses at midnight Friday. He was immediately criticized by Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House. Republican leaders also said they thought another Government shutdown would be unwise.
House Republicans, meanwhile, struggling to get off the political defensive, prepared a budget plan that would contain no tax increases whatsoever.
 
Senators' Churning Stomachs
Senators Mitchell and Bentsen were clearly uncomfortable at the luncheon meeting today, said senators who were present. The leaders argued that they were compelled to support a budget package less politically attractive than the House bill because they needed bipartisan support to get any legislation through the Senate.
No one at the lunch stood to support Senators Mitchell and Bentsen, but their predicament was widely understood, senators said.
''If anybody's stomach is turning upside down over not being able to support Rostenkowski, it's George Mitchell, but he's in a very tough spot,'' one Democratic senator said.
Senator Bentsen said after the lunch that he had not defended his committee's bill so much as he had explained that it was the best bill that could realistically get through the Senate.
''I told them,'' he said, speaking of his colleagues, ''that the American people are fed up with arguing, and they want this thing to be brought to a successful conclusion. This means you have to have bipartisan support.''
 
Rostenkowski Plan Favored
But Democrats coming out of the lunch said they felt they were on the political offensive for the first time in years. Mr. Rostenkowski's plan, they said, allowed Democrats to be seen as the party of the people and Republicans as the party of fat cats.
Several senators said they expected someone to offer the Rostenkowski proposal as an amendment on the Senate floor but that it would surely be voted down because of solid Republican opposition and because of a Senate rule that would require it to obtain 60 votes for approval. There are 55 Democrats in the Senate.
''The whole question becomes what do you do to the hand in conference,'' said Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota.
After bills are passed by the Senate and House, they go to a conference committee for reconciliation of the differences. For approval in the conference, a measure must have the votes of a majority of the House conferees and a majority of those from the Senate. Because Democrats control both chambers, a majority of both conference delegations will be Democratic.
 
Unknown Factor: Senators
The negotiators are selected by the committee chairmen involved, in this case Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Bentsen, usually strictly on the basis of seniority.
Mr. Rostenkowski always exercises an iron hand over his delegation to conferences, and it usually votes the way he wants.
But senators are more independent, and Mr. Bentsen cannot automatically count on complete support from his fellow Democrats. The most probable Senate Democratic negotiators are Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Mitchell, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and David L. Boren of Oklahoma.
Mr. Moynihan is enthusiastic about the Rostenkowski plan, but Mr. Boren is more conservative and often votes with Republicans on tax matters. The Republican conferees will probably be Senator Dole, Bob Packwood of Oregon and John C. Danforth of Missouri. They can be expected to defend the White House position.
 
Trading on Gas Tax
The cornerstone of the Rostenkowski package is an increase in the tax rate of those with incomes above about $200,000 to 33 percent from 28 percent now, and a sharp limiting of the reductions in Medicare benefits proposed earlier. This plan would not change the Federal gasoline tax, now 9 cents a gallon, and would give a tax break on capital gains that would mostly benefit middle-income rather than wealthy taxpayers. It would, however, affect the middle class by abolishing for one year the indexing of tax brackets and personal exemptions for inflation.
The plan that will go before the Senate this week would not change tax rates but would place a limit on the itemized deductions that the rich could claim. It would increase the gasoline tax to 18.5 cents a gallon and would cut Medicare more deeply than the House plan.
Mr. Rostenkowski is a supporter of a higher gasoline tax, and his colleagues said he would probably be willing to trade in conference his provisions canceling indexing for a gasoline tax raising the same amount of revenue.
 
Hollow Statements
The House Republicans, divided between those who want to support the President and those who want to make a political statement, came down hard on the side of politics.
They announced this evening that they would offer an amendment on the House floor that freezes spending on almost all domestic programs and foreign aid and raises no new taxes. This plan would reduce the deficit over the next five years by much less than the $500 billion sought by Mr. Bush and most others in Congress.
Because they are outnumbered in the House by a 3-to-2 ratio, the Republicans have no chance of their plan's being approved.
Representative Guy Vander Jagt, a Michigan Republican, explained the position this way: ''The decision was made that there was no way we could pass a Republican plan, so let's make a statement of what we stand for.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Budget Turmoil Leaves G.O.P. Bereft and Besieged

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The political turmoil in the Republican Party caused by the Federal budget impasse has left its leaders openly feuding over strategy and struggling to preserve the party's identity just three weeks before the November elections.
Republican leaders admit that the party has taken a beating and that President Bush's wavering on a budget deal and reluctance to impose higher taxes on the rich has only deepened an already pronounced rift between moderate and conservative Republicans.
A party that has long prided itself on putting forth an unmistakable message of lower taxes and less government, reflected for eight years in the steadfast philosophy of Ronald Reagan, is now under siege as the party of the privileged, a party that has been left rudderless by Mr. Bush's failure to convey any clear direction.
The reason for the Republican concern will be amply clear this week, perhaps as early as Tuesday or Wednesday, when the House is to vote on a Democratic deficit reduction plan containing several provisions that would much more heavily tax the rich. Republicans generally do not like the plan, but opposing it would only further paint them as the party of the privileged. 
Many Republicans fear an immediate fallout in next month's elections, but they hope the damage will be softened by a public frustration with all incumbents and with the Democratic-controlled Congress.
 
Loss of Relevance Is Seen
Representative Marge Roukema, a moderate Republican from New Jersey, said: ''We've lost our relevance. Most people rely on Republicans to set forth sound fiscal policy and manage the economy. The whole budget debacle has badly eroded our ability to speak out that way. Our proposal makes it look like we are favoring only the rich and not looking out for our middle-class base.''
Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican, asserted that ''the tarring of the brush of the rich versus poor has probably stuck.'' While he said he did not think that the President had lost his constituency, Senator Chafee conceded that ''their enthusiasm has been dulled so they might not be out there in such force as they might have been in November for our candidates.''
Douglas Bailey, a Republican political consultant, was more blunt about the political danger. ''I've talked to a whole bunch of Republican consultants out there over the last three days,'' he said. ''All of them are jittery and all of them are saying, 'Our numbers don't look good.' ''
Republican candidates are moving quickly to distance themselves from Mr. Bush, even at the advice of party officials. ''I think the Republicans were hurt when Bush's wavering back and forth,'' said Dick Waterfield, a rancher and commodity broker from Amarillo, Tex., running for Congress. ''I'm sorry that the party couldn't get together on 'no new taxes.' It looks to me that the uncertainty has hurt us.''
 
Long-Term Damage Feared
Beyond the midterm elections, some Republicans are more nervous that there will be long-term damage, both in the party's ability to govern and in erosion of political support as the 1992 Presidential campaign approaches.
''If you're speaking for the party as a group, I think they're flummoxed, in a word,'' said Craig Shirley, a leading conservative political consultant. ''The historical imperative of the party for the last 15 years, 20 years, has been tax cuts, spending restraint and less government. What has developed instead is quite obviously an image of being for higher taxes and not necessarily concern about restraint of government.''
Indeed, to hear some Republicans talk, it is as if they have already suffered devastating losses at the polls.
''We've been incompetent - they've been excellent,'' said Senator Malcolm Wallop, a conservative Republican from Wyoming, comparing his party's handling of the deficit crisis with the Democrats. ''The other side has played it for every political advantage.''
Even Charles Black, the chief spokesman for the Republican National Committee, conceded that the party's public image has been hurt. But he insisted the troubles would be short lived.
''They've done a pretty good propaganda job in the last several weeks to try to get the fairness issue raised again,'' he said of the Democrats. ''But I don't see it sticking very long. Look, if the election were Tuesday, I would say this would be a bad week. But it's not. I don't think there's any long-term party slip in the works. Our disagreement has been more over tactics than anything else.''
 
Democratic Unity Hailed
Yet, as the breach in Republican ranks deepens, Democrats are reveling in their new-found unity over making the wealthy bear a larger burden in reducing the budget deficit.
''I believe that we are witnessing the disintegration of the Republican Party,'' said Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman. ''I don't know that I have ever witnessed such internecine warfare. I think they have demonstrated that they are incapable of leading even their own party.''
John W. Kingdon, a professor of political science at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, said he was not so sure the Republican disarray would lead to significant losses in next month's elections, which, particularly in Congressional districts, usually hinge more on local issues.
But he said he expects long-term problems in how Republicans can govern, and said the party could lose conservative, working-class supporters that it won over from the Democrats.
''In order for a Republican President to accomplish anything on the Hill, he needs a solid Republican majority behind him and to chip away at some Democratic votes,'' Professor Kingdon said. ''And that coalition is really splintered now. This image of disarray will eventually get healed. But this image of protecting the rich - that can have the potential of reconstructiong the old-fashioned Democratic coalition that Reagan so assiduously sought to destroy. They could be wooed right back to the Democratic Party.''
 
Republicans Look to Bush
More than any other target, Republicans blame Mr. Bush for the party's identity crisis, and therefore say it is up to him to pull the party out of it. It is particularly important for him to restore its economic principles, they say, because the Republican faithful can no longer rally around other core issues like fighting Communism.
The obvious initial test for the President and the party to begin recovering is for Mr. Bush and Congress to finally reach a budget agreement.
''This is not something where you count bodies daily; this is not a war,'' said Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska. ''The final result is what counts in this political battle.''
Senator Wallop said: ''Republicans need to come under a banner of accountability. The President needs to lay down the markers and get us back on the economic side that brought us to power.''
Still, it is not clear just how Mr. Bush should go about salvaging the party's longtime principles.
Mr. Shirley, for one, said the President must act quickly and dramatically. ''Tomorrow morning,'' the conservative consultant said, ''he should wake up and say, 'I've had it and I'm going to spend the next two years, hopefully the next six years, running against this town, vetoing every bill for every new tax and putting it on the Democratic Congress.' '' Not every Republican is so glum. ''I've seen worse times,'' said Frank J. Fahrenkopf, the Republican national chairman from 1983 to 1989. ''I was around after Watergate.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The nation's leading banks, concerned about their own deteriorating finances, are making fewer loans to corporate America. The slowdown weakens the economy and could precipitate or lengthen a recession that many economists say has begun. [Page A1.] 
 
Domestic car sales rose 1.9 percent in early October, but sales of light trucks fell 10.7 percent. [D5.]
 
Business inventories rose 0.5 percent in August, while sales advanced 2.1 percent, the Government said. [D5.]
 
Mergers and acquisitions around the world dropped sharply in the third quarter. [D19.]
 
A former Drexel trader said Michael R. Milken ''without a doubt'' was linked to stock manipulation in 1986, but he testified that he never heard the former financier give explicit instructions to undertake the illegal action. [D1.]
 
New York took a big step toward becoming the first large city to ban cigarette vending machines from most public places. [A1.]
 
Thornburgh said he had recommended tougher sentences for corporations convicted of white-collar crimes. [A24.]
 
Two New York-area commuter railroads face shrinking tax subsidies, disappointing ridership and rising costs. [B2.]
 
Senate Democratic leaders promised to work toward a budget more advantageous to the poor and middle class. [B8.]
 
COMPANIES
 
I.B.M. reported that its earnings rose nearly 27 percent for the quarter, but analysts said they were concerned about declining international and personal computer sales. [D1.]
 
United Airlines ordered up to $22 billion worth of long-range wide-body aircraft from Boeing. The order is a clear signal by Stephen M. Wolf, UAL chairman, that the airline is putting the long union buyout effort behind it. [D1.]
 
Texas Instruments has become the schoolyard bully of the electronics industry, its rivals say. [D1.]
 
The former president of Emerson Radio and his wife were ordered to pay more than $6 million to Drexel. [D2.]
 
Pepsico said its profit rose 25 percent. The company cited strength in foreign soft-drink and restaurant businesses. [D4.]
 
Polaroid's stock tumbled more than 20 percent, as investors showed disappointment in the Kodak payment. [D4.]
 
Digital Equipment plans to introduce a computer for small businesses with the latest Intel 486 microprocessor. [D4.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Matsushita Electric confirmed reports that it was negotiating to acquire a giant plant from National Semiconductor. [D19.]
 
MARKETS
 
Prices of precious metals were battered, helping send a key barometer of inflation skidding. [D1.] The dollar finished higher against all leading currencies except the yen. [D20.]
 
Oil prices fell nearly $2 as the market took no news as good news. Crude fell $1.74, to $37.95. [D6.]
 
Stocks shook off a sharp decline, largely because of widespread sentiment that I.B.M. was doing just fine. The Dow climbed 18.32, to 2,416.34. [D8.] Prices of Treasury securities moved higher. [D18.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
Motorola is betting on its investment in wireless communications. Talking Business. [D2.]
 
As the Christmas selling season inches closer, the current sticky trend in retailing raises questions about which companies are likely to be winners or losers. Market Place. [D8.]
 
The pilots' union will soon begin a series of TV and radio spots aimed at bolstering its public perception. Advertising. [D21.]

HEADLINE: Banks Have Weak Quarter; Morgan Gains

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Several large banking companies reported weaker profits for the third quarter yesterday because of losses on commercial real estate and a paucity of new lending opportunities. An exception, though, was J. P. Morgan & Company, which rarely makes loans for commercial real estate.
Bankers' problems with real estate loans, which started in New England last year, have since spread widely, hurting the largest banks in the country as well as many regional ones.
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Security Pacific Corporation and the First Chicago Corporation issued earnings reports showing a rise in problems with real estate loans. 
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Chase's shares gained 25 cents each, to $12.75; Security Pacific's added 37.5 cents each, to $20, and First Chicago's advanced 75 cents each, to $15.75. Morgan's stock rose $1.375 a share, to $34.875.
'' 'Business as usual' in the banking industry has broken down,'' said Chris Kotowski, a banking analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. Besides losses from bad real estate loans, he noted that ''there is essentially no loan growth'' and that the fat fees banks once earned from financing corporate takeovers have fallen sharply.
With the economy weakening and a recession more likely, analysts do not have much hope for a quick improvement in bank earnings. A weak economy means it will take longer to find tenants for vacant real estate projects and raises the risk that other businesses, particularly those who are deeply in debt to banks, will have trouble repaying their loans.
 
Chase Manhattan
At Chase Manhattan, the $623 million loss it disclosed yesterday was in line with an estimate it issued three weeks ago. The quarterly loss compared with a loss of $1.1 billion last year. For the latest nine months, Chase lost $527 million, compared with a loss of $840 million in the comparable 1989 period.
The third-quarter loss was caused by the setting aside of $650 million as a reserve to cover loan losses, and a $350 million charge for one-time expenses resulting from a program to cut employment by 5,000 workers. At mid-year, Chase had nearly $9.5 billion in commercial real estate loans.
According to its third-quarter earnings, about $1.5 billion in real estate loans are not paying interest, or are in such serious trouble that they are not likely to continue paying.
Chase's consumer banking business, which includes credit cards and the New York branch system, remains profitable, even though it charged off as a loss $97 million worth of consumer loans, up 37 percent from the third quarter last year.
The third-quarter results at Chase and many other large banks were much improved over the corresponding period last year, because profits in the third quarter of 1989 were depressed by the setting aside of several billion dollars in reserves to cover losses on loans to less-developed countries. Excluding the 1989 losses associated with those reserves, the trend of bank earnings has been down in recent quarters.
 
Security Pacific
At Security Pacific, in Los Angeles, third-quarter profits of $135.3 million were down nearly 27 percent from the $185.1 million reported for the comparable period of last year, and nearly 31 percent below the second quarter of the year.
In addition to bad real estate loans made by its Arizona affiliate, Security Pacific has been hurt the last year by poor-quality loans to companies in Britain and Austrialia. In the third quarter, Security Pacific had to add $240.9 million to its loan-loss reserves, more than twice the amount added a year ago, and up sharply from the $160.7 million added in the second quarter. The increase since the second quarter was primarily because of commercial real estate loans in Arizona.
Although its profits have been hurt by bad loans, Security Pacific's financial condition was strong enough that the banking company could afford to rapidly increase its consumer deposit base by acquiring savings and loan associations in California and nearby states.
Robert H. Smith, Security Pacific's president, noted that the $5.7 billion gain in consumer deposits had improved the company's finances by lowering the amounts it borrowed in wholesale markets.
At a time when business loan growth is slack, Security Pacific and many other banks have been stepping up their efforts to reduce expenses. At Security Pacific, expenses other than interest paid on borrowed funds grew only 1 percent in the last year, despite several acquisitions and an 11 percent increase in its earnings assets.
 
First Chicago
First Chicago announced a quarterly profit of $36.2 million. A year ago, the company lost $23.3 million because of charges related to loans to less-developed countries. In the second quarter, First Chicago earned $87.4 million.
The decline in profits at the banking company was caused by the addition of $160 million to its loan-loss reserves. About $120 million of that was allocated for possible losses on commercial loans, including real estate, and $40 million for losses on consumer loans. In the second quarter, First Chicago added only $85 million to such reserves.
The American National Bank and Trsut Company, a First Chicago subsidiary that specializes in lending to medium-sized companies and has a history of low loan losses, has been hurt by poor conditions in the real estate market, causing it to add $60 million to its reserves for losses.
The increase in the reserves at First Chicago was accompanied by a $242 million increase, to $535 million, in its real estate assets acquired when its borrowers defaulted. Other kinds of troubled loans fell slightly, to $800 million, from $870 million at the end of the second quarter.
 
J. P. Morgan
J. P. Morgan said its quarterly profits totaled $208 million, or $1.08 a share, up from $207 million in the second quarter, and slightly better than some analsyts had expected. In the third quarter of last year, the company posted a loss of $1.18 billion.
Reflecting a lending policy that avoids risky loans that other banks routinely make, Morgan added only $10 million to its reserves for loan losses in the period. Of Morgan's $3.3 billion in loans to highly indebted companies, only $38 million, or about 1.1 percent, were not paying interest or were in such serious trouble that a default was likely. Among other banking companies, loans to highly indebted companies include a far higher portion of troubled loans.
While corporate finance fees fell $16 million from a year ago, to $58 million, Morgan's revenues from foreign exchange and bond trading rose by $188 million, to $300 million in the quarter.

HEADLINE: Earnings Rise 27% At I.B.M.

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. reported yesterday that its earnings rose nearly 27 percent for the third quarter, but financial analysts said they were concerned about declining international and personal-computer sales.
At the same time, market watchers generally echoed management statements that the International Business Machines Corporation appeared to have reached the bottom of a trough financially and was realizing the benefits of the cost controls it initiated in the United States the last year.
''The worst is over,'' said Robert Djurdjevic of Annex Research, a computer industry market research firm in Phoenix. ''I can't find a weakness in their product line.'' 
The company's stock fell $4.375 early yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange from its opening of $100.625 on rumors after a morning telephone conference with analysts that I.B.M. would issue disappointing news. But those rumors proved unfounded, and the stock rebounded quickly to close at $99.25, down $1 from Friday.
 
'Continue to Make Progress'
I.B.M. said yesterday that it believed it was on track with its earlier statements projecting a planned financial recovery based on a far-reaching restructuring in December 1989. But it also noted that a worsening economy might undermine its progress.
''Despite weakening economies in the U.S. and other parts of the world and a major product transition, we continue to make progress on the course we have set for the business,'' I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, said.
For the quarter, I.B.M.'s earnings advanced to $1.11 billion, or $1.95 a share, from $877 million, or $1.51 a share, in the 1989 period. Revenues rose 6.8 percent, to $15.28 billion, from $14.31 billion in the comparable period of 1989.
The company attributed a 1.5 percent decline in hardware sales, to $9.07 billion, to the shift away from an older line of its most powerful computers. In last year's third quarter, hardware sales were $9.2 billion.
 
Shift to New Mainframe
Several analysts gave I.B.M. high marks for its managing of the transition to its new ES/9000 mainframe family of computers. Such transitions, which come only once or twice a decade, entail great risk because customers tend to stop buying existing machines.
''They've done a remarkable job,'' said Daniel Mandresh, a computer industry analyst at Merrill Lynch.
While the company said that it had continued to grow both domestically and internationally during the third quarter, analysts said the weakened dollar had a positive affect on its financial situation. I.B.M.'s revenue actually declined internationally in terms of local currency, the analysts said. Mr. Djurdjevic said he estimated the currency impact at $1.4 billion in revenue, or about 26 cents in earnings, for the third quarter.
During its morning conference call with analysts, I.B.M. said softening was evident in the Japanese market.
''International revenue fell 2 to 5 percent in terms of local currency,'' said Rick Martin, a computer industry analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y.. also had a difficult quarter in terms of personal computers sales, he said. ''At the high end of the PS/2 line they were flat, and at the low end they were down a ton,'' he noted.
Infocorp, a Cupertino, Calif., market research firm reported that personal computer-industry sales declined 25 percent in the United States in September from September 1989.
Separately, Joseph R. Canion, president of the Compaq Computer Corporation, said in an interview yesterday that the Houston company was standing by its earlier positive forecasts but that the European market had been sluggish recently, although England had been one of the company's brightest spots.
 
The Recession Issue
The possibility of a recession was still the largest question mark for financial analysts. Mr. Martin said that he would take $1 billion to $1.5 billion out of his forecasts for I.B.M.'s annual earnings if the country entered a recession.
I.B.M. refused to comment on a report on Saturday in the British newspaper The Guardian that it planned significant job cuts through a new early retirement plan in England, which has been hard hit as the European economy has slowed in recent months. Yesterday an I.B.M. spokesman said that because of poor financial conditions in Britain, the company was evaluating options but had not yet reached a decision. Over all I.B.M. has said the number of employees will continue to decline for the foreseeable future, but the spokesman said that he knew of no specific planned cutbacks ''in the next several months.''
Surprising many analysts, the company said that revenues for its midrange AS/400 computer were in double-digit figures worldwide. The strength of the AS/400 has contrasted sharply to the rest of the minicomputer business, which has been suffering because of the growth of the personal-computer and work-station markets.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Weaken, Falling 2.5%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Domestic car sales rose 1.9 percent in early October, but sales of light trucks fell 10.7 percent, resulting in an overall decline of 2.5 percent in sales of American-built vehicles.
Analysts said concerns about a weakening economy might be catching up with vehicle sales, which had been surprisingly strong for six weeks.
''This is the sort of weakness that I expected to see develop much earlier,'' said Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers' Association, which represents 16,000 dealers. ''People simply don't have the money or confidence to buy.'' 
 
Loans Are Harder to Obtain
Consumers who do venture into dealerships are finding financial institutions ''demanding more money down, or otherwise making loans harder to obtain,'' Mr. Webb said.
''The killer for this industry is not the cost of energy,'' said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco. ''The killer is the cost of financing.''
On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 6.5 million units in the Oct. 1-10 period. Last year, cars sold at a 6.1 million rate in early October. So far this year, cars have sold at a 7 million rate.
Ten manufacturers that produce vehicles in the United States sold 183,925 cars in early October, and 86,935 light trucks, a category that includes mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles as well as pickup trucks.
There were nine selling days in the period this year, compared with eight in the comparable period of 1989.
 
A Sign That Mileage Matters
Dealers and analysts said softer sales of light trucks might be an indication that prospective customers were having second thoughts about vehicles that were not fuel efficient.
Jack Simmons, sales manager of Orange Buick-GMC in Orlando, Fla., said sales of Buicks were steady. ''But sales of GMC trucks are only fair,'' he added. ''Some of the full-sized trucks with V-8 engines - the gas guzzlers - are feeling the pinch.''
The Big Three posted a collective sales decline of 1.5 percent in car sales during early October, while Japanese companies that build cars in the United States reported an overall increase of 42.6 percent, reflecting the new production capacity that several Japanese manufacturers have added to their American operations.
These ''transplants'' raised their share of the American car market to 10.6 percent in early October from 7.6 percent a year earlier.
 
G.M. Gains the Most
Of the Big Three, the General Motors Corporation was the biggest gainer. G.M.'s car sales rose 15.9 percent, to 89,040, compared with abnormally weak sales a year earlier. G.M.'s light-truck sales rose 7.3 percent, to 35,306.
''G.M.'s sales results last October were horrible,'' said Joseph S. Phillippi, an analyst with Shearson Lehmann Brothers in New York. The largest auto maker held clearance sales in September 1989 to sell off huge inventories before the model year ended. Many people who might have bought vehicles in October jumped to take advantage of the deals, and October results suffered.
The Ford Motor Company reported a drop of 23.8 percent in car sales, to 49,190, and light-truck sales fell 17.2 percent, to 32,052. Ford executives attributed the sharp declines to a reporting anomaly. Because the new model year started a few weeks later last year, generous rebates to clear the backlog of older-model cars and trucks generated brisk sales in early October 1989.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales increased 2.6 percent, to 26,234. ''We're seeing a little strengthening of demand,'' a Chrysler spokesman said. But Chrysler suffered a 30 percent downturn in sales of light trucks, to 16,758; those include Jeeps and mini-vans.
The Honda Motor Company reported a sales increase of 22.5 percent, to 9,313, of cars it builds in Marysville, Ohio.

HEADLINE: Gulf Quiet, Oil Falls by $1.74 a Barrel

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The oil market, which alternates between believing that no news is good news and fearing that silence is ominous, took the former tack yesterday, and oil fell nearly $2 a barrel on world markets.
With the Persian Gulf quiet, oil for delivery next month closed at $37.95 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, down $1.74 from Friday's close. The market hit a record close on Thursday of $40.42 on war jitters, but those seemed more distant yesterday.
''No news, no rally,'' said Christian D. Gohler of Merrill Lynch Futures. Mr. Gohler said the momentum since Wednesday was down. When the momentum was in the other direction, traders sometimes said that quiet meant lack of movement, which meant a drift toward war. 
But at the Pegasus Econometric Group of Hoboken, N.J., Peter C. Beutel said after yesterday's close, ''There was a palpable sense this morning that the tension level had dropped.'' A report from Soviet officials that Saddam Hussein was willing to withdraw from all but a small slice of Kuwait, although later denied by the Iraqi President, added to the more relaxed atmosphere, traders said.
 
Further Decline Expected
At United Energy Inc., Tom Bentz, the director of trading, said, ''The market is getting kind of tired of the news we've had; every kind of bullish story and rumor is built into the price.'' Tension has kept prices high, he said, but looking at the fundamental factors of supply and demand, ''everyone agrees that prices should probably be lower.''
The shift downward yesterday, he said, ''opens the door up for the possibility of moving back towards $34.''
Mr. Beutel said that several factors beyond the sense that tensions were lower pushed the price of crude down. Refineries are beginning their seasonal shutdowns for maintenance and for reconfiguring, to produce more heating oil and less gasoline, and thus their demand for crude is lower. And, he said, because prices for refined products have not continued to rise as sharply as crude, some refiners are reluctant to pay $40 for crude and are using stockpiled supplies instead. That has depressed demand. Numerous market experts say that production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is nearly as high as when Kuwait and Iraq were still exporting oil. The Department of Energy has predicted for weeks that by next month world production without those two countries will be a scant million barrels a day short of what it was before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, and some traders think the shortfall is smaller than that.
Products for November delivery also moved lower yesterday. Heating oil closed at $1.0207 a gallon, down 3.29 cents, and unleaded gasoline closed at 94.95 cents a gallon, down 2.18 cents A secondary effect of the embargo against Iraq, the change in the fortunes of oil companies, will become evident next week as the major companies report their third-quarter earnings. While the price of oil has slipped from its recent peak, it is still roughly double the level before the Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
 
Varied Effects on Companies
The effect will differ from company to company. Those that drill for oil will see the value of their production multiplied, but many of those that refine or sell oil will see profits shrink, because costs have grown faster than revenues.
The Oryx Energy Company of Dallas, which was formerly the exploration and production arm of the Sun Oil Company, reported yesterday that its profits rose eightfold in the third quarter. Net income rose to $48 million, or 45 cents a share, from $6 million, or 6 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1989. Revenues were $514 million, up from $295 million.
