HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Falls

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Robust domestic demand and higher oil prices helped to trim Japan's bulging trade surplus in September, the Government said today.
The surplus, unadjusted for seasonal factors, shrank to $6.9 billion last month from $7.19 billion a year earlier, the Ministry of Finance said. 
Imports rose 10.3 percent, to $18.89 billion, from $17.13 billion a year ago, the third straight monthly increase, while exports grew 6.1 percent, to $25.8 billion from $24.31 billion.
The trade surplus with the United States, Japan's biggest trading partner, shrank slightly, to $4.31 billion, from $4.78 billion a year ago. September was the 12th straight month that Japanese exports to the United States declined.
Japan posted larger surpluses with the European Community and many Asian countries.
Japan's trade surplus should narrow further in coming months, economists said.

HEADLINE: 1515 Broadway In Chapter 11

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 15

 BODY:
A partnership known as 1515 Broadway Associates L.P., whose sole investment is an office building in Times Square, said today that it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
The building is owned by a partnership consisting of an affiliate of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States as a general partner and a group of 25 limited partners. 
The building has had low occupancy rates and a declining rental income, which is insufficient to service its debt, the partnership said. The largest part of the debt has interest rates fixed in excess of 13.6 percent.
The partnership is a stand-alone entity, and the filing does not have a significant impact on Equitable.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Inch Up in Light Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher, and interest rates inched lower, in quiet trading yesterday, as credit market participants shrugged off a big drop in the price of leading commodities, including oil.
Paced by a sharp drop in gold prices, a widely watched inflation barometer, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 basic food and industrial futures prices, fell by more than 4 points yesterday, its biggest one-day decline in more than three years.
''If you look at what is going on outside of oil, there is almost a deflation going on,'' one Government bond trader said. ''But the market, which has a reasonable bid to it, really isn't focusing on that fact right now.'' 
 
Sliding Since Summer
Even with a near-doubling in oil prices, the bureau's index has been sliding since the summer. Nevertheless, the message it has been sending has been lost on credit market participants.
The drop in the index is saying that ''outside of oil, it is going to be hard to make goods price increases stick,'' said Joseph R. Liro, a vice president and economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc.
''But with the budget accord still grinding in Washington and sabers still rattling in the Middle East, there is no hurry for accounts to commit money to the market,'' he added. ''People were happy to let the bond market sit yesterday.''
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.18 percent, little changed from the average 7.19 percent rate at last week's sale. Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 7.22 percent, up from 7.21 percent a week ago.
 
Budget Pact Needed for Sale
Although various Congressional committees continued to work on budget legislation, it appeared unlikely yesterday that an agreement would be reached before Thursday, when the Treasury is scheduled to sell one-year bills.
''The only way you are going to have a one-year bill auction is if the budget is passed,'' a Treasury bill trader said. Indeed, when it announced the auction last week, the Treasury said it might postpone the bill sale if a budget agreement was not in place.
Barring a budget agreement and another increase in the Federal debt ceiling, the Treasury will run out of money on Oct. 25.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 98 3/32 late yesterday, up by 7/32, to yield 8.93 percent, down from 8.95 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 25/32 in late trading, up by 5/32, to yield 8.78 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 13/32, unchanged from late on Friday, to yield 7.89 percent.
 
Penney's Debt Offering
In other developments, the J. C. Penney Company offered investors in the investment-grade corporate bond market $200 million in seven-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 10 percent notes, which mature on Oct. 15, 1997, were priced at $100, or par, 1.33 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was very light, dealers reported.
Prices of most corporate issues rose by about an eighth of a point, traders said. Meanwhile, actively quoted municipal bond prices were unchanged to up an eighth of a point.
In the market for high-yield ''junk bonds,'' traders said prices of most issues were little changed to up slightly in thin trading.

HEADLINE: Mergers Around World Down Sharply

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Mergers and acquisitions around the world dropped sharply in the third quarter, partly because of the economic uncertainty created by the threat of a recession in the United States and Britain, the Iraqi crisis and the doubling of oil prices.
The United States appeared headed to a strong quarter of purchases that would have pushed it ahead of Britain as the leading purchaser of companies abroad in the first nine months of the year. But early this month, the Bell Atlantic Corporation's plan to purchase half of Argentina's telephone system fell through.
This was caused by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company's inability to raise the $2.3 billion in existing Argentine bank debt needed to swap for the control of the telephone company. But United States companies still managed to out-purchase British concerns in the third quarter. 
 
Market Viewed as Repressed
''The gulf crisis and the subsequent upheavals in the oil and stock markets have combined with the warnings of a recession and higher interest rates in many countries to repress the M. and A. market,'' said Herbert Adler, international mergers and acquisitions partner for KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm, in New York.
At a value of $19.4 billion, the 478 cross-border deals around the world reported in the third quarter were down 48 percent in value and 32 percent in the number of deals, to the lowest level in two and a half years, according to the data collected by KPMG Peat Marwick.
In the second quarter of this year, 705 deals were reported, with a value of $35.1 billion for the transactions in which prices were disclosed. The deals recorded have been announced but have not necessarily been completed.
 
Drop in Nine-Month Period
For the first nine months of the year, the total number of deals reported around the world dropped to 1,884 with a total value, when prices were reported, of $84.3 billion. This was down from 2,052 deals in the first nine months of 1989 with a reported value of $88.2 billion. Several very large deals kept the reported price levels close, although the number of deals was down by 8 percent.
Acquisitions of food and beverage companies, including the $3.8 billion purchase of Jacobs Suchard by Philip Morris, and the privatization of telephone companies from New Zealand to Chile were the largest sources of deals.
In the third quarter, American companies announced or completed 141 deals with a value, in the cases where prices were reported, of $4.3 billion, after knocking out the Argentine telephone deal. This was twice the number of deals in the second quarter, but the reported value was down 39 percent, from $7.2 billion. In comparison, British deals fell to 139 with a value of $2.67 billion after a total of $11.7 billon in the first six months of the year.
 
Positioning for 1992
Despite the overall drop in acquisitions, the pressure of the economic unification of Europe in 1992 is still driving European and other companies to position themselves through mergers and acquisitions before then.
Among these countries was Sweden, where companies are making a major push to be ready for 1992, although the country is not a member of the European Community. For the first nine months, Swedish companies were involved in 110 deals with a reported value of $8.95 billion, up from 80 deals with a reported value of $827 million in the similar 1989 period.
There was also a surge during the nine-month period in acquisitions by Spanish companies, which were involved in 21 deals with a value, where prices were reported, of $3.52 billion, far above the 11 deals and $244 million in the period last year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher, But Loses Ground to Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher yesterday against all leading currencies except the Japanese yen.
''Most of the activity was in cross trading, with movement out of high-yielding currencies and movement mostly into yen,'' said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer with the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago. He said traders moved out of Australian dollars after that country lowered interest rates.
In New York, the dollar finished up against most major currencies, after also rising overseas.
One British pound fetched $1.9498, down from $1.9675 on Friday. In London, the pound fell to $1.9545 from $1.9740.
But the dollar fell against the yen across the board. It closed in New York at 127.73 yen, down from 129.05 on Friday. In Tokyo, it fell to a closing 128.83 yen, from 129.98 on Friday. Later, in London, it fell to 128.05 yen. Other selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday rates, were: 1.5262 German marks, up from 1.5243; 1.2905 Swiss francs, up from 1.2860; 5.1120 French francs, up from 5.1055; 1,143.00 Italian lire, up from 1,142.25, and 1.1540 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1471.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's, were: 1.5230 German marks, up from 1.5175; 1.2870 Swiss francs, up from 1.2780; 5.1035 French francs, up from 5.0555; 1.7165 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7110; 1,141.50 Italian lire, up from 1,137.25; 1.1520 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1470.

HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING;
Track Faces A Fading Night Life

BYLINE: By Steven Crist

 BODY:
For more than a decade after opening its doors in 1976, Meadowlands Race Track offered something completely different in the New York area every fall: nighttime thoroughbred racing, a game with a look and feel of its own and an appeal so strong that some in the racing industry predicted racing under lights was the way of the future.
Sparkling and beeping with the latest in technological gadgetry, the Meadowlands touched something in the urban horseplayer that the fields of Belmont or Saratoga never could. There was neon everywhere, loud voices, and an electric energy. The bettors were far less sophisticated than their New York brethren, and there were generous payoffs to be had. 
Devoted customers called it the ''House of Action,'' not only because of the profusion of exotic bets and tempting payoffs, but also because of the current that ran through the place. The racing was never as good or as important as New York's, but there were 10 opportunities a night to pick a winner.
Pegasus, the swanky dining complex with its own glass elevator riding up the side of the clubhouse, offered a casino-style ritziness: marble floors, brass fixtures, polished wood, recessed video monitors and old racing prints lining the walls. For a dedicated horseplayer, it was a place to feel like a swell, and for casual fans, it was a fun night out. Then last year, the people suddenly stopped coming. Attendance and handle, static for nearly a decade, suddenly fell by nearly 20 percent. No one had seen the drop coming and no one could figure out why everyone had suddenly decided to stay home. Track officials could only round up the usual lineup of excuses when racing slumps: a recession, increased competition for the gambling and entertainment dollar (primarily casinos and lotteries), an aging fan base and insufficient television and press coverage of the sport.
The exodus continues. This year, attendance is down another 12 percent, despite management's best efforts to reverse the trend. A $10 million renovation project has made the place even more inviting. The track has tried clever advertising (a sign on the New Jersey Turnpike warns gamblers, ''Meadowlands: 5 miles; Atlantic City: 128 miles), an expanded track program loaded with information, mini-theaters and sports bars. Nothing seems to be working, and for the first time in its history, there are nights when the track is failing to show a profit. For most of its history, it has supported the entire Sports Complex, and continues to generate two-thirds of the operation's revenue.
The track gets from 12.11 to 16.61 percent of the betting handle with only 0.5 percent going to the state of New Jersey. (In New York, the state takes 10 times as much, a full 5 percent, and the track gets only 8.5 percent.) Meadowlands Race Track, operated by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, continues to pay for the entire Sports Complex and remains a bigger moneymaker, even in hard times, than Giants Stadium and the Brendan Byrne Arena.
Track officials are hoping that two initiatives on the Nov. 6 ballot will help, one to permit Sunday racing and another to allow the Atlantic City casinos to take bets on races. These measures, though, will not address the larger problem of shrinking business.
One school of thinking is that more racing has led to less revenue, and that less racing could be the answer. Horseplayers' bankrolls are being depleted by too many opportunities to lose, and the sport has no sense of season - it is a continuous grind without enough openings and closings.
One possibility that Meadowlands officials are exploring is a full restructuring of the New Jersey racing season. One idea is to switch the track's thoroughbred racing dates to the spring, to trade in on heightened public interest in the sport around Triple Crown time.
Some Meadowlands' officials would like to operate a 10-week meeting from late March through the middle of June instead of the current 15-week meeting that runs from Labor Day until almost Christmas. Monmouth would then run a month longer than usual, through September, and the Meadowlands could begin its harness-racing season in October rather than January.
For such a switch to work, approval would be needed from Garden State Park, which currently runs throughbreds in the spring and harness racing in the fall. Neither of those meetings is flourishing, though, and there are nights when Meadowlands customers are betting more on the Garden State races through simulcasts than the on-track customers are. The two tracks might both benefit from some date swapping. New Jersey is the only state in the union with all three major forms of legalized gambling - casinoes, lotteries and parimutuel racing - and it also has five racetracks. Obviously, gamblers do not have infinite bankrolls, and their action is being spread too thin.

HEADLINE: Hospital Cuts Aren't Hurting Care for Elderly, Study Says

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
A comprehensive national study has found that measures to limit Federal health costs have not reduced the quality of hospital care for the elderly, as many experts had feared.
Measures imposed in 1983 to shorten hospital stays for people 65 years of age and older who are insured by Medicare have not disrupted a trend of improved chances for their survival, said the study, which is being reported today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
But the cost-cutting measures did increase the likelihood that an elderly patient would be discharged in a medically unstable condition. The percentage of such patients rose to 14.7 from 10.3 before the measures began, said the team of 19 researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles and the Rand Corporation who did the study. 
 
Survival Rates Compared
Those who were discharged in medically unstable condition were 50 percent more likely to die within 90 days than were those who were medically stable. The researchers said the rise in deaths slowed the overall improvement in survival rates, but did not reverse it.
Dr. Bruce C. Vladeck, president of the United Hospital Fund in New York City, a nonprofit research and philanthropic organization whose goal is to improve health care, said it was ''reassuring'' to find that hospital costs could be lowered without sacrificing quality. The study provided ''a more powerful methodology to pull together the bits and pieces of evidence'' that the cost-containment measures had not harmed the overall quality of care, Dr. Vladeck said in an interview.
Medicare now reimburses hospitals at a fixed amount for specific categories of illness called diagnosis-related groups, or D.R.G's, a system that the medical association has opposed. Previously, the payments were simply based on what the hospital charged.
 
Cut in Short-Term Stays
The impact has been significant. Stays in short-term hospitals were cut to 8.5 days last year compared with 10 days in 1983, according to the Health Care Financing Agency, the Federal agency that administers the Medicare program.
The study of 14,000 Medicare patients found a 1.1 percent drop in death rates for the five most serious diseases covered by Medicare in the critical 30 days after admission, when most deaths occur. The drop was from 16.5 percent to 15.7. The 180-day death rates were essentially unchanged at 29.6 percent, compared with 29 percent before the measures were imposed, the researchers said.
The study involved patients who were treated at 297 hospitals in 30 areas in five states. The patients suffered from five diseases that make up 19 percent of Medicare admissions and 32 percent of deaths within 30 days. The researchers compared representative cases of patients cared for in the same hospitals in 1981-1982 and in 1985-1986.
 
Medical Records Reviewed
Over all, the length of hospital stay declined 24 percent, to 11 days from 14.4 days The length of stay fell for each of the five diseases: 21 percent for congestive heart failure, 18 percent for heart attacks, 14 percent for pneumonia, 32 percent for strokes and 28 percent for hip fractures.
To measure the quality of care, the researchers reviewed medical records and developed statistical tools to adjust for how sick the patients were at the time of their admission. With the cooperation of Health Care Financing Agency and the hospitals, the researchers said they had successfully accessed 96 percent of the records requested.
The study showed that physicians and nurses appeared to be providing better physical examinations, diagnostic testing and treatments for elderly patients. The percentage of patients receiving poor or very poor care declined to 12 percent from 25 percent.
But poor care remained a troublesome issue. For example, 30 percent of the patients were judged to have received very poor care, and their death rate 30 days after hospital admission was almost double the 17 percent rate for those receiving very good care.
 
System Imposed by Fiat
The Government imposed D.R.G.'s not as a result of an experiment but nearly simultaneously by fiat in 1983, raising fears that the cost-cutting measures would lead to more deaths and a serious decline in quality of care.
Contrary to widespread belief, the study found no statistically significant increase in the number of patients spending prolonged periods in nursing homes after discharge.
Another surprising finding was that patients were sicker at admission than before the system was introduced. Many experts had predicted that financial incentives to cut the length of stays and substitute lower cost services would favor admission of the less seriously ill. The researchers said they presumed that the finding was the result of stringent admission reviews by professional review organizations that the Government established to monitor quality and appropriateness of care.
Patients who were discharged ''quicker and sicker'' in medically unstable conditions were more likely to die within 90 days than were those who went home in medically stable condition. Among the problems contributing to the medical instability of such patients were rapid heart beats, fast breathing rates and urinary and fecal incontinence, problems that were not present at the time of admission.
 
Lower Death Rate Likely
The senior author, Dr. Robert H. Brook, said the nature of the study did not allow his team to determine ''how many deaths could have been prevented if patients were kept in the hospital longer or if there had been better plans for their care at home.''
The researchers estimated that the 180-day death rate would have been at least an additional two-tenths of 1 percent lower by 1986 if there were no deaths because of instability and other problems at discharge.
''Learning at a hospital level what causes instability at discharge and how to reduce it should become a major joint activity of the hospital administration and medical staff,'' the researchers said.
To reduce the risk of premature death and the burden on families caring for such elderly patients at home, Dr. Brook said in an interview, Federal officials, hospital administrators and doctors need to develop plans that are as explicit for the care of patients after discharge as those made at time of admission to a hospital.
Dr. Gail Wilensky, the administrator of the Health Care Financing Agency, which paid $3.9 million for the study, wrote in an editorial that ''the reports place the burden of proof on those who doubt that we can provide better care at lower cost today.''
In another editorial James P. LoGerfo, medical director of the Harborview Medical Center in Seattle, wrote that restraint of capital improvements might have prevented hospitals from providing even better care than what was noted. But Dr. LoGerfo said the study could not answer the question because the effects may take years to detect.
Because the D.R.G. system is still in transition, Dr. Brook's team said the program needs continual monitoring to make sure future cost restraints do not have adverse effects.
''We have a long way to go to make hospital quality as good as we would like it to be,'' Dr. Brook said.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
HOUSE APPROVES DEMOCRATIC PLAN TO REDUCE DEFICIT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Eleven days after it rejected the budget compromise struck by President Bush and Congressional leaders, the House of Representatives voted tonight for a new Democratic plan that would sharply raise the income taxes of the wealthy.
The focus of the effort to reduce the deficit now shifts to the Senate, where a vote is expected Wednesday on a package supported by President Bush that would force the middle class to bear more of the brunt of higher taxes and lower spending.
A showdown is likely at the end of this week, when the Government's authority to spend money lapses. The President promised again today that he would veto any measure like the House's and that he would close most of the Government if a budget suitable to him had not been enacted. 
 
A Highly Partisan Vote
This evening the House approved the tax and spending plan, offered as an amendment to an overall budget measure, by a highly partisan vote of 238 to 192. Only 10 Republicans joined 228 Democrats in supporting the plan; 164 Republicans and 28 Democrats voted against it.
After the vote on the amendment, the House voted, 227 to 203, to approve the full legislation, which is the core of a five-year package meant to reduce the deficit by $40 billion this year and $500 billion over five years. The deficit is now about $300 billion. At a campaign rally in Glen Ellyn, Ill., today, Mr. Bush called the measure in the House ''a Democratic tax plan'' and added, ''It raises the income taxes of the working men and women in this country, and I am not going to do that.''
While the House plan would delay the adjustments in taxes for inflation, which could cost middle-class taxpayers a few hundred dollars a year, by far the biggest increase would affect people with incomes over $200,000. The plan the President supports would leave income taxes alone but would raise other taxes, like those on gasoline, that primarily affect middle-income people.
Late today, Mr. Bush canceled plans to attend the second game of the World Series in Cincinnati on Wednesday after a phone conversation with the Republican leaders in the Senate and House, Bob Dole of Kansas and Robert H. Michel of Illinois. The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said the two leaders had told Mr. Bush that the talks were ''all coming to a head in a day or two.''
Today's House votes followed a spirited debate in which Democrats took the political offensive on an economic issue for the first time in years. With all factions of the party united, they seized the chance to portray themselves as the party of ordinary Americans and their Republican opponents as the patrons of the fat cats. ''Soak the rich'' became a Democratic war cry as well as a Republican epithet.
 
'Economic McCarthyism'
''The middle class is angry,'' said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader. Americans, he continued, believe that ''everybody's got to pay their fair share; the people at the top should have the highest rate.'' And he asked, ''Doesn't that make sense?''
But Republicans accused the Democrats of pandering to voters without grasping the dire economic consequences. ''In the last few weeks,'' said Mr. Michel, ''we've heard the sounds of economic McCarthyism, the savage cry of class warfare.''
Republicans maintained, in the word of Representative Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, that they had been ''gagged,'' prohibited by the Democratic majority from offering a plan that would have slashed spending for domestic programs and foreign aid but raised no new taxes.
Democrats countered that the Republican proposal broke the rules of the budget outline approved by Congress last week because it would have reduced the deficit by only $400 billion over five years, not the $500 billion required by the outline.
 
'They Come Up With a Mouse'
''When it's time to put up, they come up with a mouse,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the Budget Committee.
On a procedural motion that amounted to a test vote on the Republican plan, the Republicans lost on a nearly straight party-line vote of 241 to 184.
The party-line votes tonight were in sharp contrast with the vote early in the morning of Oct. 5, when the House handily turned down the budget compromise that President Bush and the Congressional leaders had reached after a month of intense negotiations. Then, liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans joined forces to defeat a package that both found objectionable.
Today Representative Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat, made one of the few statements both sides could agree on. ''This is a debate about the direction of the country,'' she asserted. ''It is about what gets cut and how much. It is about who pays and how much.''
 
Taxing the Richest
The plan approved tonight would raise the taxes of all but the very poor by suspending the adjustment of taxes for inflation by one year. But unlike other budget plans, it would raise the top tax rate, put a surtax on millionaires and allow most of the benefits of a capital-gains tax break to fall on the middle class. The taxes of the richest 1 percent of taxpayers in America, those with incomes over $200,000, would rise by an average of $11,000 a year.
Furthermore, the House scrapped many aspects of the deal struck by the President and the Congressional leaders that had generated the most opposition. Gasoline taxes would not be raised, Medicare cuts would be limited, home heating oil would not be taxed and people thrown out of work would not have to wait two weeks for their first unemployment check.
The budget debate has galvanized House Democrats like no other issue in years. Late in the debate, with the House chamber jammed but the outcome no longer in doubt, Representative Guy Vander Jagt, Republican of Michigan, argued that rich Americans were already overtaxed.
From a seat in the back, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, called out, ''Let's hear it for the rich!''
But the Democrats' euphoria may be short-lived. The more conservative Senate is considering a budget bill that has the backing of the Bush Administration, goes easier on the wealthy and harder on the middle class than does the House bill, though many provisions are identical.
It will be up to a conference committee to reconcile differences in the Senate and House versions.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
IRAQIS ARE HINTING AT A COMPROMISE; U.S. REJECTS TERMS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had indicated tentative interest in a compromise settlement of the Kuwait crisis but that Washington considered the terms unacceptable and continued to insist that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait before any talks begin.
Mr. Baker said at a news conference that the vague compromise proposals being floated by Baghdad suggested it might be willing to pull out of Kuwait if it were allowed to retain ''Bubiyan Island, access to the gulf and things like that.''
Bubiyan is an uninhabited island off Kuwait that controls access to Umm Qasr, Iraq's only military port on the Persian Gulf.
 
Dispute Over Oilfield
The Rumaila oilfield in northwest Kuwait is considered another strategic prize that Baghdad would insist on retaining, even if it pulled out of the rest of the country. The huge field is partly under Iraq and partly under Kuwait and Baghdad has accused the Kuwaitis of stealing oil from Iraq's part. 
The overall oil production of Kuwait averaged 1.8 million barrels a day in 1989, but it has never disclosed how much oil it has pumped from Rumaila.
Administration officials say they believe that the Iraqi feelers are part of a strategy of President Hussein aimed at limiting Washington's room for maneuver. By hinting that he is ready to consider diplomatic solutions, they say, the Iraqi leader hopes to reduce the prospect that the United States and its allies will soon use military force.
 
Pressures Start to Build
By floating diplomatic hints, the officials added, he also hopes to create cracks in the coalition aligned against Iraq. This coalition includes countries with different interests, different staying powers and different attitudes toward the use of force in the gulf.
Administration officials also acknowledge that pressures are starting to build to at least try negotiating with Baghdad as the United Nations sanctions produce no change in Iraqi behavior and the costly resort to military force increasingly seems the only way likely to force a total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
This was apparent today in Rome where Yevgeny Primakov, a member of the Soviet Presidential Council, met the Italian Prime Minister, Giulio Andreotti, on the first leg of a trip that will also take him to Paris and Washington, where he will meet President Bush on Friday. Mr. Primakov, who returned from a visit to Baghdad on Oct. 6, was said by Italian officials to have told Mr. Andreotti that President Hussein would be ready for a negotiated settlement provided the West did not make ultimatums or threaten military intervention.
Officials said Mr. Baker's remarks were deliberately planned to puncture the trial balloons being floated by Baghdad and to quash any suggestions that a compromise be struck with President Hussein. The Secretary spoke at a news conference called to announce a new program for rewarding people who provide information to convict terrorists.
 
No Formal Proposal
Mr. Baker said that since the Iraqi leader's first overture two months ago when he said he would withdraw from Kuwait if Israel were to withdraw from the occupied territories, Washington had ''seen some suggestions that would indicate that other things are negotiable as far as Baghdad is concerned.''
The Secretary did not elaborate on those overtures, but officials said he was referring to suggestions by Arab leaders like King Hussein of Jordan, Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, Arab diplomats at the United Nations and Arab foreign ministers who have recently been to Baghdad, all indicating that Iraq might be ready to make a deal for Bubiyan Island or some oilfields. The officials emphasized that no formal proposal had been made by President Hussein or anyone else.
Had the Iraqi leader confined his initial invasion of Kuwait to the seizure of strategic areas such as Rumaila and Bubiyan, it is likely the United States would not have mounted the international campaign it has undertaken. The American Ambassador to Baghdad, April Glaspie, said in an interview last month that Washington never thought Iraq would seize all of Kuwait. But since it has done so, Washington is not prepared to consider any compromises.
''If the international community were willing to go for that, we would be permitting an aggressor to profit from his unprovoked aggression,'' Mr. Baker said. ''Let me say that our diplomatic agenda has been clear from the very beginning. We seek full implementation of the Security Council's resolutions. We are indeed unwilling to participate in a search for partial solutions. We think that the United Nations resolution should be implemented and implemented fully.''
 
Baker Recalls the 30's
Pressed on whether the Iraqi leader had shown any interest in an unconditional withdrawal, Mr. Baker responded: ''All we've seen so far has suggested that there may be some interest in what we would characterize as a partial solution. That is, some interest in a negotiated arrangement that would enable him to claim benefits from his unprovoked aggression against a small neighbor. This is the principle that the United States and most of the international community are standing against.
''We made this mistake in the 30's,'' added Mr. Baker, ''We did not stand up in opposition to unprovoked aggression. And we remember what happened in Europe when we refused to take a principled stand.''
The Administration's official position is that to approach the Iraqi leader now and offer him a diplomatic way out would only signal to him that bargaining had opened and that he could expect at least some reward for pulling out of Kuwait. Administration officials are therefore always careful not to even hint at a compromise.
The weakness of this approach, as former President Jimmy Carter argued in an essay in Time magazine this week, is that the notion that Iraq would unconditionally withdraw under the pressure of economic sanctions alone and without any negotiated settlement is questionable.
 
Credible Threat of Force
''So far, the Bush Administration has not acknowledged the need for negotiations or exploratory talks, which might imply weakness or willingness to reverse adamant public statments,'' Mr. Carter argued. ''Only unconditional surrender following a total military victory can remove the need for negotiated settlements.''
Administration officials acknowledged that for sanctions to be effective in pushing Iraq out of Kuwait they would have to be coupled with a credible threat to use force. The Iraqi leader, they say, has to be convinced that he really has only two choices: to stay in Kuwait and lose everything or leave and survive. Unless Mr. Hussein believes that, the officials say, he will never be serious about withdrawing.
The problem, Administration officials increasingly acknowledge, is that it is difficult to make the Iraqi President believe that he has only two choices when the United States must work within an international coalition, some of whose main members are reluctant to use force under any circumstances.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Orders Agencies to Draft Plans for $1 Billion in Cutbacks

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration told city agencies yesterday to prepare to cut more than $1 billion in programs and services from their operating budgets over the next 21 months to help close expected budget gaps.
Most agencies were ordered to recommend cuts equal to 4 percent of their budgets for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, and 10 percent of their spending plans for the fiscal year that starts July 1.
The public school system, the City University, city-run hospitals and the Fire Department would be spared to some degree. They would only be forced to cut half the amount of other agencies. In addition, the Police, Correction and Probation Departments, district attorneys and other criminal-justice agencies would be asked to trim from 1 percent to 5 percent of their budgets, but through internal productivity gains over the next two years. 
The largest cuts would be more than twice the size of the biggest such annual cuts made over the last decade, and 10 times the size of other annual cuts. City officials have not calculated the concrete effects of such reductions on services, but they said they would be severe, from sharply scaled-back street cleaning and garbage pickups to closing libraries and firehouses, and possibly thousands of layoffs.
Most agencies must propose contingency cuts of an additional 2.5 percent in their budgets for the coming fiscal year in case projected city budget gaps of at least $300 million for the rest of this fiscal year and $1.4 billion for the next year worsen. Because by law the city's budget must be balanced, cuts are needed to close the gaps between expected revenues and projected expenditures.
''New York City is on track,'' Mayor David N. Dinkins told a luncheon meeting of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce. ''And economic storms will not overwhelm us. Without a doubt, and beyond debate, we maintain our fiscal integrity.''
 
'Extremely Unfortunate'
In a memorandum to all agency heads, the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said, ''It is extremely unfortunate that large layoffs may be an inevitable part'' of the plans for the next fiscal year.
Ten days ago, Mr. Michael warned that 15,000 layoffs would be needed, but he said yesterday that it was too early to say just where the cuts might come and that the targets did not mean decisions had been made on just what would be cut.
The Budget Director issued his memo after Mayor Dinkins held a meeting with his commissioners and agency heads at City Hall. The gloomy orders came on the same day that the city opened a new round of joint talks with two of its major labor unions, and it inevitably put more pressure on the bargaining.
 
A 'Benchmark'
Outlining the possible cuts was the sort of ''benchmark'' that Mr. Dinkins promised members of the State Financial Control Board last week that he would make public as he prepares to submit the required modifications of the city's budget to the board next month, and in January.
''I'm not prepared,'' Mr. Michael said, ''to give you specific programs, other than to say that it will be massive cutbacks as far as agency services are involved. You will see that across the board.
''Layoffs should be the final piece that an agency would layer on in order to hit their target.''
Agencies are to submit their recommendations to the city budget office in stages over the coming weeks, with the first of them, aimed at cuts in the current fiscal year, due next Wednesday, and final decisions about next year's major cuts to be made by the Mayor by January.
 
'The Right Direction'
Commenting on the latest action, Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, said, ''I think it's definitely a move in the right direction. Whether that ultimately is the best solution, we'll see. But fundamentally, they've started a process to identify the source and feasibility of substantial reductions in spending, and that's abolutely the right direction.''
Even if fully put into effect, the proposed targets would produce enough savings to close only part of the projected deficit for next year. Officials have acknowledged that the rest might have to be made up through new taxes or other revenues.
For the current fiscal year, Mr. Michael said, all the reductions would save about $330 million to help close an estimated gap of about that size, including a projected $150 million shortfall in tax revenues and a similar amount in increased costs.
In the next fiscal year, the reductions would save $840 million, against the estimated gap of at least $1.4 billion. If the contingency cuts were made, they would save another $195 million, officials said.
 
'A Heavy Lift'
Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for the City Council, which would, in practice, have to approve most major budget changes, said, ''This appears to be prudent, but it is a heavy lift for this year, and the Council will carefully monitor the agency plans to insure that quality-of-life services are not disproportionately cut.''
Ms. Breen said the Council's Speaker and majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, a Queens Democrat, was especially concerned that essential services like garbage collection not be ravaged by any cuts.
Mr. Michael's memorandum warned agency heads that ''this is not an exercise to be taken lightly'' and said the Mayor would meet with the officials himself to assure that they adhered to the required timetable.
 
Productivity Gains
The Budget Director said all agencies should first try to save money through productivity gains, including better cost controls, better deployment of workers, increased use of computers and technology and, in the uniformed services, for example, using civilians to free officers doing desk jobs for other work.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said Mr. Dinkins had told the commissioners that ''maximum efforts ought to be made to streamline administrative areas before sacrificing line operations or services.''
But, Mr. Steisel added, ''inevitably, there may have to be some very difficult choices about what programs go forward or do not.''
City officials said savings generated from a previously imposed partial hiring freeze and a moratorium on most raises could be applied by the agencies toward this year's cost-cutting targets.

LENGTH: 934 words

HEADLINE: Old Marxist Returns, With Hope for South Africa

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
In the world of emerging political movements Joe Slovo is an anachronism, an avuncular white man lionized in South African black townships as a symbol of resistance against apartheid, a committed Marxist with an ideology that many thought had collapsed with the Berlin wall and a politician glad-handing his way across South Africa after years as a clandestine guerrilla leader.
Mr. Slovo, the leader of the South African Communist Party, is the highest-ranking white in the African National Congress. He was in Manhattan, on his first visit to the United States, for the International Conference on the Future of Socialism, a meeting of Marxists from about 20 countries that was sponsored by The Monthly Review and the New York Marxist School.
Mr. Slovo's return to South Africa in May ended 27 years in exile, where he helped lead the struggle against white minority rule, and has already made him an important South African political figure. 
 
Greenwich Village Hospitality
But the 64-year-old Mr. Slovo, the son of Lithuanian immigrants, has had to adjust to South Africa, just as many of the five and a half million whites in the country have had to adjust to him.
''There is a marked difference in the relationships between people since I left,'' he said in an interview. ''The way blacks walk down the street is different. They walk like people who are about to take over.''
''When I left the country, blacks couldn't be loitering in any part of the white city area without a special permit,'' he said, seated at the kitchen table in the Greenwich Village apartment of a friend. ''Now they are actually living there. The whole atmosphere is different, in quite a radical way.''
''I remember when I first got back to Johannesburg, I saw a black man walking down the street holding the hand of a blond white woman, and I went into a sort of panic,'' he said. ''I was sure a mob was about to appear to attack them. The whole integration of blacks into the society, into positions in business, is new. When I left, you would never even see a black behind a cash register.''
On his United States visit, he said, ''I never expected a year ago that I would get here and even less that I would get here from Johannesburg.''
 
Familiar Places
Mr. Slovo flew back to Cape Town as part of the African National Congress's negotiating team last May. But when he broke away from talks with the Government a week later, he headed to the neighborhood in Johannesburg where he and his first wife began their married lives.
His wife, Ruth First, was killed by parcel bomb in Maputo, Mozambique, in 1982. His family life was often in shambles because of his political activity.
''They went through a lot of pain,'' he said of the couple's three daughters. ''They went through periods of terrible insecurity as a result of our commitment.'' He married his present wife, Helena Dolny, about three years ago.
Mr. Slovo was outside South Africa in 1963 and 1964, when most of the members of the congress's military high command were arrested and sentenced to prison. He worked to resurrect the armed movement from outside the country. During the last decade he traveled incognito from country to country and house to house.
Now, back in South Africa, he is trying to make peace with a whirlwind of experiences and emotions.
''Each day new memories are evoked, driving or walking around the city,'' Mr. Slovo said.
''Not all my memories were happy ones,'' he said. ''There is a great deal that people went through, and one pauses and remembers all over again the sort of tribulations of friends.''
 
Sympathetic Welcomes
Mr. Slovo, labeled a terrorist by the white Government, said he was unprepared for the reception he has been given by both whites and blacks.
''Before leaving in 1963 I was increasingly feeling a sense of isolation from the community in which I lived, because of fear,'' he said. ''This has changed completely. Not only the whites I knew, but the whites I didn't know, come to me in the street and say that while they do not agree with what we believe in, they want to wish us good luck because we are their only hope.'' But it was his reception in black townships that overwhelmed him.
''I realized what the regime had done for me,'' he said. ''They were a very effective public relations firm. Most of these people who expressed their adulation for me as a person, and what I stood for, had never heard me, or ever seen me, or even considered what my ideas were like.
''I was astonished to find names of streets put up after me, schools and songs. It is quite worrying, because one realizes one has to try to measure up to something that perhaps one doesn't even deserve.''
Mr. Slovo remains a driven man who, while casting off his Stalinist past, firmly believes in socialism. He says that in South Africa, capitalism has only enriched the white minority. He sees the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as the guiding light for the modern socialist movement.
He spends much of his energy trying to assure whites that he has no intention of swooping into their homes to confiscate their property. At the same time, he insists that the nation's economic structures must change.
''We are all doing our best to de-demonize our movement,'' Mr. Slovo said. ''We find that when we are together with even some of the most hardline whites, they at least begin to have a doubt about their impressions of us.''
''I have the advantage,'' Mr. Slovo said, ''of starting off with such a bad reputation that if they see me smiling, they think maybe I'm not so bad.''

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Tatami or Colonial, a House Is Wishful Thinking

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Hiroshi Akizuki, a 27-year-old computer programmer, wandered into a Queen Anne-style model house with his girlfriend the other day, peered up the giant central staircase, inspected the elegant brick fireplace in the parlor and pondered the question of whether he would ever live like this.
''It's probably impossible,'' Mr. Akizuki said, shaking his head as he stood on the stoop of the building, which would look more like home in the New Jersey suburbs than the center of Tokyo. ''The house is not so expensive, but who could afford the land underneath?''
He consoled himself with the thought that for three-quarters of a million dollars ''you don't even get a single tatami room,'' referring to the traditional straw-mat rooms found in almost every Japanese house. 
The house he was looking at, in fact, is sitting on some of the world's most expensive real estate: an entire village of oversized American- and European-style houses, complete with some suburban streets, improbably situated in a vacant railroad yard just steps from the neon and noise of Shimbashi, once this city's most famous geisha quarter.
 
'The Kids Want Western'
The idea was to fuel the huge popularity here of Western-style Colonials, ski chalets and stately English country houses - all imports, the Government notes - which Japan's nouveaux riches jam into tiny lots and fill with Jacuzzis, gold-plated faucets and computer-controlled kitchens.
But the housing display, it turns out, is teaching Tokyoites about more than just the novelty of two-by-four construction. It is also debunking one of this country's favorite myths: that the Japanese are a decidedly middle-class society, where few are much better off than their neighbors.
The only serious buyers in Shimbashi are people like Kozo Kayo, a 70-year-old retiree, who bought his land long before the Imperial Palace was worth more than the state of Florida. Now the site of his apartment building in Kawasaki is worth millions and he is preparing to sell it in order to build a ''two generation'' house.
''If it was just me, I would build something Japanese-style,'' Mr. Kayo said, wandering out of a house done half in Japanese tatami, half in automated luxury. ''But the kids want Western. And if I don't build it for them, where will they live?''
 
Building Spree by the Elderly
Mr. Kayo is one of the millions of elderly Japanese who are on a rebuilding spree. But for everyone else, the model houses in Shimbashi just drive home the fact that the possibility of home ownership seems more remote than ever.
For young couples, Tokyo's housing show is almost a cruel joke, a chance to walk wide-eyed through three-bedroom houses the way tourists in Beverly Hills gawk at the mansions of stars.
''At one time building a house was a symbol of success in life,'' Kazuro Santo, an official of the Federation of Home Construction, said recently. ''For many men, that is still the case. But now young people come to see the houses simply to serve their dreams. When they can build, no one knows.'' Once, the land crisis was Tokyo's problem, not Japan's. No longer. A recent Government survey showed that, at long last, the huge runup in the price of land in the nation's capital was finally leveling off, increasing only 10 percent last year. But in Osaka, the country's second largest hub, prices shot up 45 percent last year, and in Kyoto, the ancient capital, nearly 50 percent.
The survey suggested what many people have long suspected: The Government's much-publicized effort to put a lid on property prices - ordering banks to cut back their lending and giving Government agencies the right to reject big, speculative transactions - has largely failed. Increasingly, young house-hunters are beginning to wonder whether national leaders who talk about the ''land crisis'' as Japan's most urgent domestic issue have the incentive to solve it.
''It is difficult to believe politicians on any subject,'' said Norio Ishikawa, a 31-year-old builder trying to scratch together the money for a ''Sweden House'' he saw on display in Tokyo. ''It is impossible to believe them about land.''
More than 60 percent of Japanese families are landholders. They are also the bedrock of the Liberal Democratic Party, and few seriously believe that the party is interested in diminishing their constituents' biggest single asset.
While it is hard to find a Government official these days unwilling to issue the standard line about how skyrocketing land prices pose a grave national threat, it is harder still to find one who, in the next breath, fails to note that those property values are the foundation of Japan's booming economy.
A committee put together by the Prime Minister's office suggested that the Government adopt an official policy to put home ownership within reach of ordinary working people. That idea was greeted with silence. A Government plan to impose a tax on corporate land, especially unused tracts that could be freed up for housing developments, has met a storm of opposition from business.
 
More Disputes Taken to Court
Families themselves are increasingly doing battle. The Mainichi Shimbun, one of Japan's leading dailies, reported recently that the number of disputes over property inheritance spilling into the courts was up by more than 30 percent in the last four years. And more and more people tell polltakers that they identify themselves as members of the ''lower class'' rather than the great, undifferentiated middle in which they have long felt secure.
But if there are resentments, most Japanese are well mannered enough to keep them well hidden. The apartment renters who jam their families into tiny three-room apartments at night emerge in the morning smiling as they sweep the streets with next-door neighbors who own fairly spacious houses.
More likely than not, those homeowners are tearing down their old, drafty, wooden Japanese houses and replacing them with something in brick and stucco, often with a carport.
The other day in a quiet neighborhood in the southern part of Tokyo a middle-aged woman whose family rents a tiny apartment stood and watched as workers unloaded big kitchen cabinets for a new house under construction next door.
''Those cabinets,'' she said flatly, ''are bigger than my kitchen.''

HEADLINE: EARLIER HARM SEEN IN GLOBAL WARMING

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
After two years of study, an international group of scientists working under United Nations auspices has found that global warming could cause serious environmental damage starting in the early years of the next century, long before the maximum temperature levels predicted by many scientists are reached.
And for the first time, they recommended establishing limits beyond which the average global temperature and sea level should not be permitted to rise, lest the world be subjected to serious and ever-increasing risks.
These limits are well below the levels that another international scientific panel said last June will ultimately result if heat-trapping gases, mainly carbon dioxide, continue to pour into the atmosphere at the present rate.
A report issued yesterday also includes a detailed analysis of measures that might bring the expected warming under control and concludes that if the measures are aggressively pursued, the limits can be achieved. 
 
Steps Toward Formal Treaty
The conclusions, recommendations and supporting analyses will furnish grist for the Second World Climate Conference starting in Geneva on Oct. 29, a gathering sponsored by the United Nations at which governments from around the world expect to take the first steps toward what they hope will be a formal treaty aimed at controlling global warming.
Two international groups of scientists have been studying the problem, both with United Nations sponsorship. One, operating as part of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, was formed in late 1988 to advise the governments attending the World Climate Conference. The other, which was formed in 1986 and was the progenitor of the intergovernmental panel, has no government affiliation but rather is an association of independent scientists called the Advisory Group on Greenhouse Gases.
The independent group's report, issued yesterday in London, Stockholm and New York, goes beyond the scientific assessment of the intergovernmental panel, made public last June, in attempting to set targets for the control of global warming.
Among the practical measures that the scientists said might be taken to limit the warming were improved energy efficiency, greater reliance on natural gas, reforestation and the adoption of alternative energy sources that are both technologically and economically feasible. The sources include solar, wind, geothermal and biomass technologies. ''Limiting emissions so we can stay below the minimums should be attainable,'' said Michael Oppenheimer, senior scientist for the Environmental Defense Fund, who was the chairman of the working group on control measures.
 
Rate of Increase Forecast
In June, the scientists advising the intergovernmental group predicted that under what it called the ''business as usual'' scenario, the average global temperature would rise by nearly two degrees Fahrenheit by the year 2025 and by more than five degrees by the end of the next century. The rate of increase, which scientists say is as important as the absolute increase because of the difficulty of adjusting to rapid climatic change, was predicted at about half a degree per decade.
In the report issued yesterday, the independent scientists said that to minimize the risk of environmental damage, the rate of increase should be held below one-fifth of a degree per decade.
An absolute increase beyond 1990 of more than about two degrees above pre-industrial levels, it said, ''may elicit rapid, unpredictable and non-linear responses that could lead to extensive ecosystem damage.'' Non-linear responses refer, for example, to sudden jumps in global temperature rather than even, gradual increases.
The report last June of the intergovernmental scientific panel said that the world has already warmed by about half a degree to one degree since the industrial age began, but scientists do not know whether this rise was caused by greenhouse gases emitted as a result of human activity or whether it is attributable to natural climatic variability and therefore, possibly, is temporary.
 
'Severe Impacts' Without Action
The report said that the atmosphere may already contain enough heat-trapping gases to push the global temperature above the two-degree target. ''This means that unless we take very prompt and significant actions to reduce greenhouse emissions, we're very likely to experience severe impacts,'' said Peter Gleick, a co-chairman of the working group dealing with targets. He directs the global environmental programs of the Pacific Institute in Berkeley, Calif., a non-profit research institute.
The report established an ''upper limit'' of about 3.5 degrees in temperature increase since the start of the industrial age ''beyond which the risks of grave damage to ecosystems, and of non-linear responses, are expected to increase rapidly.''
While the voluminous study was reviewed in detail by other scientists before it was issued, not all authorities were initially prepared to give it unqualified endorsement.
''It sounds as if they've taken the worst-case scenarios and tried to make the case for a maximum effort,'' said William D. Nordhaus, a Yale University economist who cautioned that he had not yet had a chance to read the report. He has been the chairman or co-chairman of a number of National Academy of Sciences panels looking into global warming.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Iraq's Seesaw Diplomacy: Threats and Entreaties

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein is sending decidedly mixed political signals about his intentions toward Kuwait, thus causing Arab and Western moods and expectations to shift and complicating efforts by the United States and its allies to forge a coherent strategy for getting Iraqi forces out of Kuwait.
With every new Iraqi statement, stock and oil market prices rise or fall, and analysts alter their assessments about whether the prospects of war grow more imminent or more remote. As a result, policy makers in Washington and other allied capitals are being constantly kept off balance, drawing up contingency plans for war one day and for diplomacy the next.
Moreover, Saddam Hussein, by alternating between hints that Iraq might compromise and end the Persian Gulf crisis and denials of any such possibility, has attempted with some success to exploit tensions in the American-led alliance against him. No Negotiating Room, but . . . The latest signal from Baghdad has been hard-line. On Sunday, officials insisted that not even a war would prompt Iraq to relinquish Kuwait as its 19th province. Taha Yassin Ramadan, deputy to Saddam Hussein in the leadership, said Iraq was prepared ''to confront whatever happens'' to hold onto the emirate. On Monday, Latif Jassem, Iraq's Information Minister, said similarly, ''There is no room for any compromise about Kuwait.'' 
The tough stance followed reports over the weekend that President Hussein might be prepared to show some flexibility on withdrawing from Kuwait. The softer line was delivered, as usual, through private diplomatic channels the week before, almost always to those to whom hints of compromise would be particularly welcome.
Last week, for example, Yevgeny M. Primakov, a member of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Presidential Council, said after a meeting with Saddam Hussein in Baghdad that he was more optimistic about the chances for a peaceful resolution of the crisis.
While the Soviet Union has condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and has endorsed all the United Nations Security Council resolution, Soviet officials have repeatedly said that they would send troops to the gulf only as part of a United Nations force. And on Monday, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze took the further step of reassuring Parliament that the Kremlin would ask for legislative approval before committing Soviet forces.
 
Signals Through Jordan
President Hussein has sent similar conciliatory signals in recent weeks through King Hussein of Jordan, whose determination to do what he can to avert the use of military force has been reinforced by what he called the few ''positive signals'' he has received in written messages from the Iraqi leader.
As a result, King Hussein has pressed on with his attempts to devise an Arab solution to the crisis with the help of President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria and King Hassan II of Morocco. He has done so despite the fact that some of his closest advisers are skeptical about whether Iraq is ultimately willing to compromise.
King Hussein's statements, in interviews over the weekend, reflected the twin messages emanating from Baghdad. Based on discussions with and letters from President Hussein, the Jordanian ruler said, he felt that the Iraqi President was willing to leave most of Kuwait if some of his requirements were met. On the other hand, he emphasized, President Hussein was willing to fight rather than walk away from Kuwait with nothing.
The mixed signals have also served to enhance tension in the American-led alliance by driving a wedge of sorts between those countries who have sent soldiers to the Saudi desert and those who have refused, or been reluctant to do so.
 
Allies Who'd Rather Talk
''The Soviets and French are simply much more keen on letting the economic sanctions and diplomatic options run their full course than the British and the Americans,'' a diplomat here said. ''So Moscow and Paris have responded more enthusiastically and less skeptically to hints that a diplomatic settlement may be possible than Washington.''
Thus, the softer line serves Iraqi interests in that it forces those who are opposing Saddam Hussein's occupation of Iraq to check continuously with one another to see that both currents in this delicately balanced alliance continue to emphasize a determination to drive Iraq from Kuwait, but not appear insufficiently sensitive to pursuing chances for a diplomatic breakthrough.
Finally, Saddam Hussein, by setting up the possibility of a diplomatic and a military option for ending the confrontation, has left himself the greatest room for maneuvering.

LENGTH: 1221 words

HEADLINE: Quake-Damaged City a Year Later: A Slow Recovery Amid Grim Ruins

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.

 BODY:
The downtown of this seaside city still resembles a war zone - empty lots surrounded by cyclone fences. Frustrated with the pace of recovery from the huge earthquake a year ago, townspeople compare what remains of the Pacific Garden Mall to downtown Beirut.
But local officials, developers and even some merchants say the physical ruins of the downtown area belie the progress they have made toward rebuilding it. Although only one new building is under construction, five more have been approved and others are expected to be approved soon. 
While they concede that recovery is taking longer than anticipated, they remain hopeful that several significant buildings will be completed and open for business in time for the 1991 Christmas season.
In Watsonville, a farming town 14 miles south of here, rebuilding of the downtown business district is also proceeding slowly; no buildings are under construction. But there the major concern is housing. With one in eight Watsonville homes destroyed by the quake, more than 80 low-income families are still living in trailers supplied by the Federal Government.
Downtown redevelopment projects typically take several years to complete, but Santa Cruz's historic antipathy to development of any kind means that the process here is even more difficult. For years officials went out of their way to restrict development along the Pacific Garden Mall, a tree-lined street of turn-of-the-century buildings that anchors downtown Santa Cruz.
 
Brief Ceremony Planned
''You have a city that proudly limited growth by slowing down the planning process, so there are no mechanisms in place to do things quickly,'' said Mark Primack, an architect and chairman of the Santa Cruz zoning board. ''Given how self-obstructive we were, we are doing O.K. The earthquake caught Santa Cruz sleeping, and that's part of the reason it's taking us so long to get things together.''
Santa Cruz has planned a brief ceremony today to mark the first anniversary of the earthquake, which registered 7.1 on the Richter scale last Oct. 17. The ceremony, to be held from 4:45 to 5:15 P.M., Pacific daylight time, will be at the Town Clock, at the north end of the mall. Mayor Mardi Wormhoudt is scheduled to speak, and at 5:04 P.M., the precise time the quake struck, all the church bells in Santa Cruz County will ring. Separately, a nondenominational service will be held in a tent that now houses the nearby Holy Cross Church.
Local residents say that they have grown accustomed to the holes where downtown used to be, and that somehow the area has again become a lively gathering place.
''The first few months were so depressing, a few people I know left the area simply because they couldn't stand to face the mall,'' said Gary Young, a poet and printer who lives in the hills north of here. ''Now, although they've done very little to fix the mall, more and more people are hanging out down there, leaning on the cyclone fences and talking, just as if there was still a downtown.''
 
The 'Phoenix Pavilions'
In the first few days after the quake, merchants, property owners and civic leaders mobilized to keep the downtown alive. They relocated 45 shops to a row of huge tents that they dubbed the ''Phoenix Pavilions.'' A public-private redevelopment foundation, Vision Santa Cruz, was formed to help reach a consensus on the mall's future.
''It has been tricky to find the balance between holding people off to spend two years planning the perfect town and just approving everything that's come in,'' Mayor Wormhoudt said, adding that people's expectations of a rebuilt downtown in one year were simply unrealistic.
An outpouring of community support created a record-breaking Christmas season for many of the businesses in the Pavilions last year, but there have been long dry spells since. This year some businesses' sales are up, while others are down. Given the downturn in the nation's economy, few merchants here are sanguine about the coming season. And many are skeptical about the pace of the rebuilding.
''It's definitely taking longer than it needs to,'' said Mark Sanchez, co-owner of Kelly's French Pastry, which has been able to move back into its permanent home at the north end of the mall. ''There are so many meetings about how the town should be and what kind of businesses should be allowed to come in - as if we had any choice.''
 
Six-Screen Theater Planned
Still, the apparent paralysis has not frightened away developers. A six-screen theater built above retail shops is to be constructed on the site of an old department store, and a combination retail and office building is to be built behind the facade of the demolished County Bank Building.
At the same corner, the Jay Paul Company, a developer based in neighboring Scotts Valley, is planning a $12 million project on the site of the Cooperhouse, a former county courthouse converted to shops and restaurants. The company bought the building for $1.7 million in 1988 and spent $1.2 million more refurbishing it, only to lose it to the wrecking ball when it was deemed unsafe after the earthquake.
Leonard McVicar, president of Jay Paul, remains optimistic about downtown Santa Cruz but concedes that getting financing is difficult. ''Going to the bank to get money is not the easiest thing in the world right now,'' he said. ''We couldn't have done our building and gotten funding without the city's commitment to rebuild downtown.''
But significant obstacles remain. Besides rebuilding the commercial buildings downtown, Santa Cruz must also rebuild the area's infrastructure, including water and sewer systems dating to the turn of the century.
''The handicap in Santa Cruz is the financial resources,'' said Ceil Cirillo, executive director of the city's redevelopment agency. ''I've never been in a community where the resources are so strapped.''
Ms. Cirillo is counting on voter approval of a 1/2-cent sales tax on the November ballot. Without it, she said, redevelopment will be significantly hampered.
 
Thousands Left Homeless
While only a few of the buildings proposed to replace the 25 destroyed in downtown Santa Cruz contain housing, many of the new retail buildings planned for Watsonville include apartments on their upper floors. Even before the earthquake, Watsonville had a vacancy rate of less than 1 percent; the quake left thousands of people, many of them poor farm workers, homeless. Some are now living in trailers; others are in motel rooms paid for by the Red Cross.
Charleen Shaffer, executive director of the Watsonville Chamber of Commerce, said she hopes that new downtown housing will help generate traffic and customers for retailers. Changing demographics had hurt the downtown merchants, she said, as many of Watsonville's newer and more affluent residents patronized a shopping center at the western edge of the city or went elsewhere.
Watsonville's downtown, like Santa Cruz's, is marked by holes where buildings once stood. Indeed, throughout the county there are signs that, while the quake lasted just 15 seconds, its impact will be felt for years.
''We're still in the middle of this crisis,'' said Ms. Wormhoudt, the Santa Cruz Mayor. ''We're not past that. ''It's neither wonderful or dire. It's going to be O.K. It's just hard right now.''

HEADLINE: Kansas Journal;
Russians and Americans Bury an Era

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Russians are conquering the hearts of people in America's heartland, if the warm receptions given so far to a Soviet delegation here for a weeklong series of conferences with American citizens are any indication.
In the spirit of harmony that has prevailed here, the son of Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader who caused a stir in this country when he declared, ''We will bury you,'' buried once and for all his father's threat.
''He proved to be wrong, in the sense that socialism would triumph over capitalism,'' acknowledged the son, Sergei Khrushchev, who is part of the 290-member Soviet delegation.
The son made the observation at a convocation here Monday after a weekend of Middle American hospitality. The Russian visitors were feted at a football game, a midnight basketball practice and a Soviet-American art show, were entertained in nearly 150 Kansas homes and joined a circle of Indian dancers at a gala at the University of Kansas. 
Privately, Sergei Khrushchev said through an interpreter that his father continued, until his death in 1971, to believe firmly that Russian socialism was the better political system.
When organizers first began to plan these sessions more than two years ago, they envisioned them as a way to further the cause of peace between the East and the West. But world events have raced far ahead of anything they thought possible.
Now, the ''people to people'' meetings and satellite conferences being held here and in other Kansas cities are focusing on issues like market economies, science, the environment, trade and ways to increase contacts between citizens of the two countries. The meetings and workshops will continue through Thursday.
Nowhere was the change in the world mood better illustrated than at the opening assembly on Monday. It was at the session that Americans and Soviet visitors learned that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. The response was an instant of stunned silence and then a deafening burst of applause from both Kansans and guests.
The announcement was made by Robert Ivanov, an official of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Mr. Ivanov is co-chairman of the event along with Bob Swan, a Lawrence insurance agent who, associates say, has been pursuing the dream of a Soviet-American conference here for six years.
Mr. Ivanov noted in an interview that the sessions, titled ''Meeting for Peace,'' were being run on a shoestring. The organizers were helped by the hospitality of Kansans, who agreed to take in Russians as guests in their homes, and by the Soviet Peace Committee, a nominally nongovernment Soviet group that raised funds for the air transportation.
The visitors include business and trade officials and groups of specialists in agriculture, the environment, government, international relations, communications, education and health, as well as many interpreters.
That camaraderie had survived a weekend of guest-and-host relationships and language difficulties was evident from smiling faces and comments from many of the visitors, including two daughters of the late Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, a wartime friend of Dwight D. Eisenhower.
The daughters, Era and Ella Zhukova, had just accompanied other visitors to Abilene, Kan., for the centennial celebration of President Eisenhower's birth. There they presented to the Eisenhower Library nine photographs their family had saved of a meeting between General Eisenhower and Marshal Zhukov at the end of World War II.
''I like Kansas,'' Era Zhukova said. ''It's a quieter here.'' In similar vein, Viktor Vavilov, a television news producer from Penza, a Soviet city of about 500,000 people, told of being enthralled by the warmth of his reception here but not surprised. ''I come,'' he said, ''from the heart of Russia to the heart of America.''
In the spirit of the occasion, The Lawrence Daily Journal-World has been offering front-page coverage of the conference, as well as a daily column of domestic news from the Soviet Union, provided by Tass, the Soviet press agency.
''I thought it would be a good idea to give them some news from home,'' said Dolph C. Simons Jr., the editor and publisher. ''And our people here might enjoy reading it, too.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sergei Khrushchev, son of the former Soviet leader, speaking at conference in Lawrence, Kan. (David Hutson for The New York Times)
