HEADLINE: 'Baby Boomers' Donate More, a Survey Says

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Americans in the 25-to 44-year age group have substantially increased their contributions of money and volunteer time to charities, belying the popular perception that they are an ego-centered generation, a new survey shows.
Giving by all age groups last year totaled $96.4 billion. The most striking trend was the increase in gifts from Americans born since the mid-40's. The number of individuals within this group who gave increased, and those who made donations gave more. In addition, the survey said, the rate of increase of the 25-to-44 group exceeded that of other age groups. The group's financial contributions rose to 43 percent of all charitable donations last year, from 39 percent in 1987. The same age group provided 46 percent of all contributed volunteer time in 1987 and 55 percent in 1989. The age group makes up about 45 percent of the adult population. 
''The dramatic increase in charitable behavior by these baby boomers is particularly encouraging because the sheer size and youth of this group likely forecasts two generations of continuing growth in giving,'' said Brian O'Connell, president of the Independent Sector, the country's largest philanthropic coalition, with 750 foundations, companies and nonprofit organizations.
The coalition commissioned the survey by the Gallup Organization, which interviewed 2,727 adults in their homes from March 27 to May 20. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Previously a Poor Showing
Previous surveys reported disappointing response in giving and volunteering by 25-to-44 age group, said Virginia A. Hodgkinson, vice president of the Independent Sector, who has led its research programs.
She said: ''The behavioral patterns we are seeing now reflect a number of influences on this population group: Young adults in their child-bearing years tend to become more altruistic. This group is more highly educated than preceding generations. They are at the peak of their earning careers. They are more concerned about values. They were in the vanguard of the peace movement in the 60's. These influences add up to more charitable giving and more volunteering for community service.
''If these encouraging trends continue, we truly can predict a renaissance of philanthropy in America,'' Ms. Hodgkinson added.
The survey, called ''Giving and Volunteering in the United States,'' reported that more than 98 million Americans, an increase of 23 percent since 1987, volunteered their time last year to help charitable oranizations, and 75 percent of all households made financial contributions.
But the survey also found a shift in giving to youth programs and to health and human services, a change to programs that suffered the deepest Federal budget cuts, Ms. Hodgkinson added.
 
Giving by Wealthy
Giving and volunteering among blacks continued to increase markedly, a trend reported in earlier surveys. Sixty-one percent contributed money last year - up from 51 percent in 1987 - and volunteering also increased to 38 percent, from 28 percent.
Even though giving among the wealthy has increased, Mr. O'Connell said, most of America's affluent families are not generous: Ninety-five percent of households with incomes exceeding $1 million yearly averaged only $16,000 in charitable gifts. The remaining 5 percent in the same class averaged $125,000 annually, he said.
''In comparison to the proportion of giving by lower-income families with little disposable income, most wealthy Americans have to be characterized as stingy,'' he added.
In 1989, households with incomes under $10,000 gave an avergae of 5.5 percent of their income to charity.
Last year $54.3 billion, or 47.4 percent of all charitable contributions went to religious organizations, according to Giving USA, the annual report of the Trust for Philanthropy of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel.

HEADLINE: Dukakis Still Buoyant Despite Tough Times

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
This has not been a good year for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.
With Massachusetts in recession and the State Legislature paralyzed over a prolonged budget crisis, the man who only two years ago was the Democratic nominee for President has had to watch as his popularity rating has plummeted to below 20 percent.
In last month's primary election, virtually every candidate for statewide office who had any connection to him was trounced. And Mr. Dukakis's wife, Kitty, has written a best seller candidly describing her addiction to pills and alcohol, saying his actions fed into her addiction. 
But Mr. Dukakis retains an uncanny equilibrium, a detachment, even a sense of optimism, that friends praise as strength and critics deride as a lack of feeling. In an interview in his office in the gold-domed Statehouse on Beacon Hill, Mr. Dukakis said he does not feel personally rejected by the people of Massachusetts.
''People are angry generally across the country,'' he said, wearing a familiar button-down shirt, his hair a little grayer than during the Presidential campaign.
 
'Camelot All Over Again'
He acknowledged that voters in Massachusetts are particularly bitter. ''What happened here was, we were on a tremendous high,'' he said. ''The Governor of the state was running for President. Everybody knew I was a long shot, including yours truly, and lo and behold, it gets better and better, and suddenly he's won the nomination. It's Camelot all over again. ''And then we crashed. Kaboom. We did a lousy job in the general election. I've got to take responsibility for that.'' At the same time, he said, the state's economy, which he had been trumpeting as ''the Massachusetts miracle'', began turning sour. With that, Mr. Dukakis said, ''You've got the makings of a lot of anger and a lot of frustration.''
He added, ''People said, 'He kind of let us down in the campaign, and now he's back here and the thing isn't working.' ''
Asked how his wife's addiction and now the publication of her memoir had affected him, Mr. Dukakis answered eliptically, as he often does. ''I love her more today than I did the day I married her,'' he said.
''I'm married to an extraordinary woman,'' he added. ''She has dealt in a remarkably courageous way with a difficult personal problem.''
 
Accompanying Wife to Therapy
In her book, ''Now You Know'' (Simon & Schuster), Mrs. Dukakis says that in the weeks after her husband's defeat by George Bush, she began drinking so heavily that she sometimes passed out in the mornings in their bedroom, leading to calls to the Governor's office that brought Mr. Dukakis home to find her lying in vomit. Later, he would drive her to clinics for treatment, or accompany her to therapy sessions.
Mr. Dukakis rejects the suggestion that his wife's troubles interfered with his work, compounding the difficulty of ending the state's budget mess. ''Of course, you're concerned by it, you carry it with you,'' he said. But his 10 years of experience as Governor, he added, enabled him to get through his job.
 
Anger for Bush and Reagan
When Mr. Dukakis does display some emotion, some anger, it is saved for Ronald Reagan and President Bush. ''Bush is paying the price for 'Read My Lips,' '' he said, refering to Mr. Bush's campaign slogan promising no new taxes that was used so effectively against Mr. Dukakis. ''And we're all paying the price for Ronald Reagan.''
As a Presidential candidate, the thing Mr. Bush did that Mr. Dukakis found ''the most outrageous'' was to promise he would never raise taxes. ''That's a commitment no chief executive can keep,'' Mr. Dukakis said, ''He knew that.''
Part of being elected to office, Mr. Dukakis said, is ''you've got to be prepared to do things that are unpopular.'' Mr. Dukakis noted that he himself has cut $1.4 billion out of Massachusetts's $13 billion budget in the past 14 months. For Mr. Bush to do the equivalent in Washington, Mr. Dukakis said, he would have had to cut the Federal budget by more than $100 billion.
Mr. Dukakis indicated he is not holding a grudge against another candidate who ran a campaign against him, John R. Silber. Mr. Silber, the president of Boston University, won the Democratic nomination for governor last month with icy attacks on Mr. Dukakis's stewardship.
Mr. Dukakis said he would nonetheless vote for Mr. Silber in November because the candidate is oppposed to a popular ballot initiative that would drastically cut state taxes and fees, forcing the state to cut the $13 billion budget by an estimated $1 billion in the first six months of next year and by another $2 billion the following year.
 
'Silber Is Absolutely Right'
''On that fundamental issue, our friend Mr. Silber, whatever one thinks of his peccadillos, is absolutely right,'' Mr. Dukakis said. Mr. Silber's Republican opponent, William F. Weld, a former United States Attorney, supports the tax-cutting measure.
Mr. Dukakis also insists he is optimistic about Massachusetts' future. He spends much of his time traveling the state, spreading the gospel of salvation through high tech, the source of much of the Massachusetts boom of the 1980's.
Mr. Dukakis will not comment on what his plans are after he leaves office in January. One report says he and his wife will accept teaching positions at the University of Hawaii, at least temporarily.
He admits no self-pity. ''We are all volunteers in this business,'' Mr. Dukakis said. Nobody asked us to do this job. Through good times and bad I've loved public service.''
But Mr. Dukakis does have one wish. ''I would have loved to be President of the United States,'' he said. ''I'm sorry I'm not.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, whose popularity rating in Massachusetts has plummeted. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Plan Would Revise Farm Subsidies

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
House and Senate conferees reached agreement today on a $41 billion, five-year farm policy that changes the structure of commodity price supports and includes the strongest environmental provisions of any farm legislation in history.
The changes in rules that have provided subsidies to producers of grain, cotton, rice and other commodities for more than five decades are intended to save the Government $13.6 billion over the next five fiscal years.
The conferees estimated that, at $41 billion, farm program spending from fiscal 1991 through fiscal 1995 would cost slightly more each year than the $7.8 billion that was spent in fiscal 1990. Before the agreed changes, conferees estimated that the five-year cost of the bill would be $54 billion to $56 billion. 
 
New Course for Agriculture
Over the long-term, experts in both parties said, the broad package of economic, scientific and environmental provisions agreed to today is intended to set a new course for American agriculture, making the farm sector less costly to the Government and less threatening to the environment.
The agreement on programs to protect the environment come after both committees for decades rejected the notion that farm chemicals needed to be closely regulated to reduce contamination.
Edward Madigan, Republican of Illinois and the ranking minority member of the House Agriculture Committee, said today that the provisions had been adopted by the House committee to head off even more stringent regulations that were being proposed.
The legislation is expected to be considered and approved later this week or early next week by both houses of Congress and signed by President Bush. ''It is a respectable work product that balances well inumerable sensitive, often divergent, interests,'' Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said today.
The most significant change was introduced late last week to respond to the demand by Congressional leaders that farm program spending be cut by more than 25 percent to reduce the Federal deficit. The conferees said they met the demand by agreeing to change the structure of the price support programs.
 
Decades of Control
Since the program was established in the 1930's, the supply of grain, cotton, rice and other commodities has been controlled by the Government through contracts with hundreds of thousands of farmers.
In exchange for letting a specified amount of land lay fallow each year, typically 5 percent to 15 percent of their tillable land, farmers who signed up for the program are paid for every bushel of grain, bale of cotton or pound of rice they produce. Under the new bill, the amount of land on which farmers can grow crops eligible for payments would be reduced by 15 percent.
The conferees also agreed to set a limit of $100,000 on payments to any farmer.
According to an analysis by an economist at Oklahoma State University, a farmer who has a 1,000-acre wheat farm in Kansas could lose nearly $13,000 as a result of the change.
The reduction in the amount of a farmer's harvest that is eligible for Government support, together with the $100,000 limit on payments, opens the commodity price support programs more than ever before to market forces.
 
Some Might Drop Out
Experts in both parties said today that under the proposed new program, farmers might be eligible in some years to grow crops that receive Government payments on just 70 percent of their land. If market prices are high enough, thousands might drop out of the program, they said. If farmers abandoned the program, Congressional support could diminish and lead to more substantial structural changes, even elimination of the programs as early as 1995.
''You have a farm bill where farmers now can make a real choice about whether to farm on the program or off,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the conference committee. ''In the past, you really didn't have a choice. The programs were the only game in town.''
Several conferees said that they were anxious about the rule changes and that they might vote against the final bill. ''It will cause in the short-term a reduction in net farm incomes at a time when costs are up. It's going to squeeze cash,'' said Senator Bob Kerrey, a Democrat of Nebraska. ''It's going to have a negative impact and it's apt to be felt the worst in the Great Plains because it's drier and farmers don't have the same options'' as farmers in other parts of the country.
Several farm groups said today they were very unhappy with the proposed reduction in harvests that are eligible for payments. They also criticized fees that producers of milk, sugar, tobacco, peanuts, honey and wool are expected to pay when they market their crops in a new plan expected to raise $1 billion or more.
''Congress has gone tax crazy,'' said Wayne Cryts, a spokesman in Missouri for the American Agriculture Movement, one of the nation's largest farm groups. ''It is our opinion that we have enough tax writing committees in Washington, but it appears now that we have two more in the Senate and House Ag committees.''
 
New Enrivonmental Provisions
The 1990 farm policy law also contains an array of new provisions that the conferees believe will make farming less polluting and result in safer food for consumers.
Perhaps the most significant is a ten-fold increase in the amount of money that Congress wants the Department of Agriculture to spend on research into cultivation practices that use little or no toxic chemicals. The department spent $5 million in fiscal 1990 to develop such practices; the conferees authorized the department to spend $80 million a year.
The conferees also established rules that require farmers to keep records on how they use 125 toxic pesticides. The records could be reviewed by the department for studies on pesticide use across the United States and must be made available for review by medical specialists in the investigation of poisoning accidents.
One provision sought by environmental groups to bar the export of pesticides outlawed for use in the United States was dropped from the bill after the White House, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Agriculture agreed with the pesticide industry that it was unnecessary and would cost hundreds of jobs.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: WASHINGTON AT WORK;
Dole, in Twist of Fate, Leads Charge for Bush, The Rival He Scorned

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct 16

 BODY:
On the private balcony that adjoins his office and commands a sweeping view of Washington's monuments, Bob Dole is squinting into the autumn sun and plotting a budget strategy to save face for George Bush's White House.
It is a twist of fate that escapes no one who has watched the leader of the Senate's 45-member Republican minority operate on Capitol Hill in the two years since Mr. Bush trounced him in the New Hampshire Presidential primary, all but ending his hopes for a chance at the White House.
''Senator Straddle,'' Mr. Bush called Mr. Dole then, for refusing to sign a no-tax pledge. Whatever pleasure Mr. Dole may take in seeing the President awkwardly straddle the tax issue now, it is private. A politician who is fiercely proud of being a pro, he gives careful, correct responses to questions about his relation to the former rival he once scorned as a lightweight. 
 
No Time for Dancing
''I get people who say, 'You ought to call the President,' '' Mr. Dole said in an interview this week. '' 'You know, call him up and talk to him.' I say, 'I called Ronald Reagan three times in eight years.' I don't bother them. I figure they're busy, we're busy. We meet.''
The closest he would come to criticizing Mr. Bush's seeming changes of mind and direction on taxes was in his account of the advice he gave the White House on Monday. ''I did say we ought to know in advance where we want to come out,'' Mr. Dole said. ''I mean it ought to be clear. We ought to let everybody know in advance, including the Democrats. We don't have time anymore to dance around the bottom line for three or four weeks.''
The Senator is not often so direct. One reads him between the lines, in the famous quips and barbs that serve him as both weapon and shield. They hide the emotions of a complex man, capping the well of raw anger that flashed across across national televison two years ago, when in an interview after Mr. Bush's New Hampshire primary victory, the Vice President wished him well in the contest ahead.
Eyes blazing, the Senator replied, ''Stop lying about my record.''
''Outrage,'' he says now. ''You have to watch that sometimes.''
 
An Arrow for Gingrich
His penchant for political trench-fighting serves him better as a legislative leader than it did as a national candidate in both 1988 and 1976, when he was Gerald R. Ford's running mate. But his job in the next few days is also that of conciliator: to repair weeks of miscalculations and ham-handed negotiating by Mr. Bush and his top advisers; to keep the Democrats from tagging the Republicans as champions of the rich; to try to salvage the framework of a budget compromise that he and his friend Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, have worked out with Senate Democratic leaders.
''Some of my colleagues say: 'Why are you up there doing this? You ought to be out there with us: No new taxes,' '' Mr. Dole said. ''But I'm the leader; I'm the Republican leader. I'm not Newt Dole, you know.'' That arrow is aimed at Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, who led the rebellion two weeks ago that toppled the budget compromise between the White House and top Congressional leaders of both parties.
 
Next, the Hard Part
The Senate's new bipartisan plan, intended to divide the burden of new revenues equally between the wealthy and other taxpayers, will come to the floor on Wednesday or Thursday. Mr. Dole's first job is to make sure it passes. The hard part will come later, when the Senate plan must be reconciled in a conference committee with a rival Democratic measure approved in the House today.
''The test is going to be whether we still have the Democratic leadership in the House, or whether they are going to abandon us for Rosty,'' Mr. Dole said. The reference is to Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee and who devised the Democratic plan to raise the rates of upper-income taxpayers while avoiding unpopular taxes on gasoline or deep cuts in the Medicare program.
Although Mr. Dole called the Democratic plan a blatant example of partisan grandstanding, he did not hide his admiration for Mr. Rostenkowski's political gamesmanship. ''He's got a great staff,'' Mr. Dole said, ''but who knows how much he's put in there for mischief and how much he really means?''
 
'Hard-Bitten Conscience'
It is in such calculations that Bob Dole is in his element. The son of a cream and egg man in Russell, Kan., he thought about being a doctor. A near-fatal wound in World War II shattered his right arm and put that dream out of reach, but left him with a burning drive to prove he could make it. Instead of medicine, he turned to law and politics.
After a term in the Kansas House of Representatives in the early 1950's, he was elected to Congress in 1960 and the Senate in 1968; from 1971 to 1973 he served as Republican national chairman under Richard M. Nixon. During the Reagan years, he and his second wife, Elizabeth, now the Secretary of Labor, were known as Washington's ''power couple.''
Ask his acquaintances what his hobby is. They say politics. Many also say, as does Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, that he is ''a man of conscience, a certain hard-bitten conscience.''
He brandishes income tables, the newest tactical weapon in the battle over the budget. For months, Democrats have made effective use of them to brand Republicans as the party of the rich, turning fairness into a new litmus test of acceptability.
Sure, he says, the House Democratic plan would place a surtax on millionaires. But what about its proposed one-year delay in inflation adjustments for tax exemptions and tax brackets? ''A married couple with children and a taxable income of $34,000 would pay $313.50 more next year,'' he said triumphantly. ''That's a 6 percent tax increase.''
 
Taxes: The Tough Sell
The provisions of the tax code that index brackets and exemptions for inflation were Senator Dole's handiwork in 1981. A third of the tax increases in the new Senate package would fall on taxpayers of upper-middle and upper incomes, he says, noting that he made this point to the President. It's a tough sell, he agrees, not the sort of thing that wins points on television, and maybe not enough to persuade a majority of Senate Democrats and Republicans in the end.
''You have to give people some reason to vote for this,'' he continued. ''The real reason, deficit reduction, ought to be good enough, but they have to have something to take home and say, 'I won this.' For some that was a capital-gains tax cut; for the Democrats it was a rate hike.''
And it was the drive to win a capital-gains tax cut, he said, that cost the White House tactical leverage and political high ground. ''We hung on to that issue too long,'' he said; it was clear, at least to him and other Republican senators, that the Democrats would never permit a capital-gains tax cut on terms the White House could accept.
''I think I know the players here pretty well,'' he went on, ''and I think I know when when there's a genuine exchange, or when somebody's holding back something. And when somebody tells you, in effect, 'This is our bottom line . . .' '' His voice trailed off.
Conversation with Bob Dole is like that, lurching unpredictably from topic to topic, leaving his listeners to complete half-finished thoughts or sentences that end ''you know'' whether you do or not. Did he give other advice that the White House ignored?
''I just hate to get tagged with the fairness issue,'' he said, and called the White House preoccupation with a capital-gains tax cut a ''tar baby'' that needlessly stalled and dominated the budget negotiating. Never as wedded to the gains cut as Mr. Bush, he publicly proposed to separate it from the deficit-reduction plan a week before the White House dropped its insistence on it.
Privately, he had argued in vain that the Administration was losing sight of its original objective: a deficit-reduction measure that could pass both houses. ''There's always a tendency in the White House for people to believe that the members of Congress are a sort of fraternity up here,'' he said, ''and that if they're not pushing their point of view it's not going to be heard.''
That anonymous ''they'' was a reference to the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, who happens to have been the architect of Mr. Bush's campaign in New Hampshire, and to Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director. But before the point could be pressed, Mr. Dole broadened it to speak of Ronald Reagan's budget director, David A. Stockman, and to note that the syndrome may be universal.
Mr. Stockman would come to his office seeking spending cuts ''hundreds of times, push, push, push, trying to get one million more, or ten million, or a billion,'' said the consummate legislative politician, who added: ''So from that standpoint, I don't think it's much different. But there's got to be a time when you sort of let go, you know.''

HEADLINE: Fooling Around With Taxes

 BODY:
The House is on the verge of passing a $500 billion deficit reduction package. But it is hard to take the bill seriously. It includes amendments imposing stiff tax increases, aimed at the rich, that are unlikely to pass the Senate and that President Bush is sure to veto. 
The principle of taxing the rich more than the poor to pay for deficit reduction might be noble. But the amendments amount to demagogy. They would eliminate an increase in the gas tax, undermining energy conservation. They would postpone correction of the income tax code for inflation, leaving an invisible tax on the middle class. They would lower the capital gains tax for exactly the wrong kinds of investments.
The House plan was well designed to embarrass Republicans into voting against a package weighted in favor of the poor. The Republicans responded with some demagogy of their own, proposing a deficit reduction package that pretended to cut the deficit without raising taxes. Congress owes the country a responsible deficit reduction package. Three days before the deadline for closing down the Government again, the country is still waiting.
Last month's budget summit produced a plan to cut the deficit by $500 billion over five years. But it would have raised taxes on the poorest families three times as much as on the richest. That was the main reason the House rejected the package.
The alternative plan approved last week by the House Ways and Means Committee, similar to one before the Senate Finance Committee, would have increased taxes on gasoline, alcohol, cigarettes and several luxury items. It would also have reduced the total amount of deductions for rich families and expanded tax credits for the working poor. Roughly speaking, it would have affected most income groups proportionately.
The plan voted in the House yesterday drops the tax hike on gasoline and postpones for a year the indexing of tax rates and personal exemptions for inflation. That's a cynical way to hit the middle class with an invisible rather than a visible tax. And it would undo a boost for energy conservation.
The House plan would also raise the tax rate on the highest incomes to 33 percent from 28, and raise the tax on wealthy families that take advantage of enormous amounts of deductions and exemptions. But the Democrats surely know that Mr. Bush would veto any package that raised income taxes unless it also capitulated to his obsessive quest for a capital gains tax cut.
It is precisely on capital gains that the House plan reverberates with ignorance - or cynicism. It would allow individuals $100,000 of capital gains free of income tax over a lifetime - but only on the sale of real estate, farms, businesses and timber, not stocks. The tax code already heavily favors investments in real estate and timber. To direct more precious resources their way is shameless.
The budget clock is still ticking. Congress is still fooling around.

HEADLINE: Holes in the Fish Safety Net

 BODY:
While meat and poultry have long been subject to mandatory Federal inspection, there is no comparable program to protect the public from contaminated fish - despite a marked rise in fish consumption by consumers seeking to cut down on dietary fat. Legislation set for a vote today in the House would begin to close this gaping hole in the food safety net.
The risks are real. Fish and shellfish come from waters where sewage and toxic chemicals abound. Data from the Centers for Disease Control suggest that the chance of contracting an illness from fish is about 25 times greater than for beef, and about 16 times greater than for pork or poultry. It's estimated that 1 in 250 people who eat raw shellfish will become sick. Such fish poisoning can cause nausea, severe abdominal cramps, chest pains and, in severe cases, death. 
A big problem is inadequate inspection. The Food and Drug Administration, though technically in charge, has lagged in setting legal limits on fish contaminants. And it has monitored seafood processing plants sporadically, testing only a small percentage of the four billion pounds of fish consumed. Meanwhile, state-by-state regulation of shellfish beds is weak and inconsistent.
Industry, wary of losing consumer confidence, supports sensible legislation that would require the F.D.A. to set strong standards for chemical and microbiological contaminants. The legislation would also require the Department of Agriculture, which now inspects meat and poultry, to carry out stepped-up fish inspections and product samplings.
Consumer groups are split. Some would prefer that the F.D.A. run the entire program. Nevertheless, the legislation promises a reasonable measure of protection.
A bill sponsored by George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, who represents fishing-dependent Maine, has already cleared the Senate. There's a similar version in the House, sponsored by Representative Kika de la Garza, Democrat of Texas, which adds strong protection for whistle-blowers. The House version deserves prompt support.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Cracking the Coalition

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
The deaths of 21 Palestinians from Israeli police gunfire have made it clear that the U.S. could not keep Arab nations in its shaky Middle East military coalition if it launched a military offensive against Iraq and Saddam Hussein.
This is so whether you accept Israel's contention that the 21 deserved what they got, or the more general view that the police barrage was unjustified. Either way, the events on the Temple Mount raised the possibility of renewed Arab unity against Israel and the breakdown of the U.S. coalition against Iraq.
So serious was the threat considered by President Bush that his Administration introduced in the Security Council a U.S. resolution condemning Israel, and designed to make it possible for Arab nations like Egypt and Syria to remain in the coalition. That's as far as any U.S. Government has gone in chastising Israel, and defying its powerful U.S. supporters. 
Even so, the Palestine Liberation Organization and other Arabs unsuccessfully sought a stronger resolution against Israel, which did not ease the problem by its intransigent stand against even the U.S.-backed resolution. If Israel, as promised, rebuffs a U.N. investigating mission, the crisis could be rekindled.
Yet the shooting of Palestinians produced a relatively minor Arab reaction compared with what would follow a U.S. assault on Iraq. Arabs who have joined in a justified international effort to stop Iraq from invading Saudi Arabia will not take part in a military attack on another Arab nation and on a man many Arabs regard as a hero and leader.
''Egyptian forces in Saudi Arabia will not participate in any offensive,'' their commander, Gen. Mohammed Ali Bilal, has said. Syria's attitude is not so clear, and Hafez al-Assad no doubt would like to see the end of Mr. Hussein as a rival for Arab leadership; but he could hardly stand alone with the U.S. in an attack on Iraq when other Arab nations were holding back or aiding Mr. Hussein.
It's not even certain that most non-Arab allies would join the U.S. in a desert offensive against Iraq. Mrs. Thatcher, as if nostalgic for her Falkland Islands triumph, did make a warlike speech to the Conservative Party last week. But the U.S. would need more than British backing if it were to make war on Iraq under supposed international auspices. Is the Soviet Union likely to join the U.S. and Britain in an anti-Arab war?
Up to now, Mr. Bush has admirably succeeded in putting together, leading and maintaining a collective-security effort in the Mideast that has restored credibility to the concept. It would vitiate that success and dash the concept if, in the end, the U.S. were to act alone, or in concert only with the British, to assert a military settlement of a political crisis.
But what about Kuwait and Mr. Hussein's aggression? If belligerent talk from Washington and London were muted, a settlement that restored Kuwaiti independence - but not the Emirate - and gave Iraq access to the Persian Gulf might not be impossible. Mr. Bush would have to swallow a few tough words, but that's what makes a compromise.
Even if that could be arranged, hawkish Americans and Israelis point out that Mr. Hussein would be left with his army, his chemical weapons, his nuclear ambitions, his savage dictatorship and his aggressive intentions. How, they ask, can the U.S., paragon of peace and democracy, permit any such thing?
Two responses are in order. The first is that if Saddam Hussein remains in power after a Kuwaiti compromise, he might cause trouble in the future, even after the massive international rebuke to his first aggression. But then again, he might not; predicting what may happen in five years, or ten, is an uncertain art, not necessarily improved by experience. And preventive war is only aggression with good intentions.
Second, if collective security could shut off the possibility of an invasion of Saudi Arabia, and impose a punishing blockade and embargo on an offender nation, it's possible collective security could provide the Mideast and the world with needed future protection against Iraq. Peace-loving nations, of which the anti-Iraq coalition supposedly is composed, owe it to the world to take that approach.
Mr. Bush, unfortunately, has encouraged without explicitly stating the idea that war is the only alternative if economic sanctions don't cause Mr. Hussein to surrender. The President has suggested, for example, that ''Nuremberg trials'' await Iraqi leaders. But tough talk is cheap; war costs real lives.

HEADLINE: Regan Sees Large Rise In Budget Gap

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
Providing the first hard evidence of how severely the state's fiscal fortunes may be sliding, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, announced yesterday that New York State ran up a budget gap of almost $250 million for the first half of the fiscal year.
Mr. Regan also predicted that the state could face a shortfall of between $2 billion and $3 billion for the next fiscal year, which begins on April 1. Last January, before the Persian Gulf crisis or the full impact of the national economic downturn could be predicted, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget division forecast that the gap would be $941 million.
''Given these unforeseen events, the state must now prepare for a downward slope in budget numbers - at the very least for far slower growth in the next six months than had been projected,'' Mr. Regan said in a statement. 
 
A Difficult Economic Future
For several months, Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Regan have been predicting that the state, like New York City, was facing a difficult economic future. But today's report from the Comptroller gave those dire warnings a statistical edge and added to the fears that the next round of state budget negotiations could be even more painful than the last.
The Governor and Legislature approved a budget last spring that set records for lateness and for new taxes, which amounted to $1.8 billion. In the middle of the budget talks, the state's credit rating was dropped to its lowest level in history.
Mr. Cuomo, who is seeking re-election on Nov. 6, has taken the unconventional political step of sounding a loud siren about the state's fiscal condition before Election Day. He declared late last week that New York was in a ''mild recession'' and he argues in his latest campaign commercials that the state needs his experience to manage tough fiscal times that lie ahead. The Governor did not dispute Mr. Regan's numbers yesterday, but said he would await a report from his budget director at the end of this month before deciding if the state must take measures to erase a deficit. If the deficit is real, he said he would push for a plan that relies solely on spending cuts rather than tax increases and short-term borrowing.
The $246 million budget gap for the first half of the current year has been created by a plummeting downturn in tax collections that has not been offset by a spending slowdown ordered by Mr. Cuomo. A budget gap is a projected shortage of state funds created when either revenues are lower than anticipated or spending is higher than expected or both.
Tax revenues fell about $200 million below expectations during the first six months of the fiscal year, largely because of a $178 million shortfall in collections of the personal income tax, according to Marvin G. Nailor, a spokesman for Mr. Regan. Sales taxes also declined, while business tax collections were up, Mr. Nailor said.
Perhaps the most foreboding aspect of Mr. Regan's report is that the budget gap appeared only in August and September, an indication that the economy may be slipping quickly. A report he released in mid-August showed that the state budget had a $6.5 million surplus as of July 31.
Mr. Regan and Mr. Cuomo declined to estimate yesterday how wide the budget gap might be by the end of the fiscal year. But Carl Carlucci, who as secretary to the Assembly Ways and Means Committee is a top financial adviser to the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, said he ''would not be surprised'' if the number reaches $1 billion.
 
Speed Would Be Essential
Mr. Regan and Mr. Cuomo both said yesterday that speed would be of the essence in reducing a deficit. Mr. Cuomo, who appeared at a forum on state fiscal reform at New York University, said he would ask the Legislature to return to Albany ''immediately'' if he concludes there is a deficit.
The Legislature has tentative plans to convene a special session in December to consider a new capital plan for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, but Mr. Cuomo's comment raised the possibility that the lawmakers might have to return earlier.
''The best thing to do is to start sooner rather than later,'' said Cynthia Green, an analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses. ''Once you get into the 10th, 11th, 12th months, it's very hard to realize any substantial savings.''
Mr. Cuomo said he would try to reduce a deficit without a tax increase.
 
'Do It Without Taxes'
''We will plan to do it without taxes,'' he said.
But he refused to take an absolute no-tax pledge. ''President Bush had a no new taxes pledge,'' he said, referring to the campaign promise that Mr. Bush broke this year. ''That's why I don't have one. I don't want to get into the box that the President found himself in.''
While Mr. Cuomo came close to ruling out new taxes as a solution to any deficit, at least one legislative leader was reluctant to do so.
''That's nice,'' said Mr. Miller, when told of Mr. Cuomo's comments on taxes. ''Is it feasible? It depends on how far down you go.
 
'Do It on the Spending Side'
''Two hundred and forty-six million dollars is not an overwhelming sum in a $33 billion general fund budget. It's not even 1 percent. If the shortfall is on that level then I think you can do it on the spending side. The question is how much more deterioration is there going to be by the end of the fiscal year.''
Although state officials were reluctant to quantify the potential budget gap, they were not optimistic.
Mr. Cuomo's budget director, Dall Forsythe, who is not prone to hyperbole about fiscal matters, said flatly today, ''We expect it to get worse.''
And Mr. Miller said there was a very good reason to solve this year's deficit early, unlike last year when the state had to borrow $775 million to cover its budget gap. ''I think every attempt is going to be made to finish the year in balance because I don't think next year is going to be any better,'' he said.

Mr. Cuomo said he would ask the Legislature to return to Albany ''immediately'' if he concludes there is a deficit. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times) (pg. B2)

LENGTH: 1001 words

HEADLINE: Rinfret's No. 2 Hopes for Nibble from Voters

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: SODUS POINT, N.Y., Oct. 14

 BODY:
Some politicians give out campaign buttons or bumper stickers when they take to the hustings. George F. T. (Geff) Yancey Jr. hands out cheese.
He talks about it as well. In most campaign appearances, before he talks about taxes or the death penalty or Pierre A. Rinfret, whom he hopes to serve as lieutenant governor, he talks about cheese. 
''Has anybody here ever eaten Heluva Good Cheese?'' he asked a cheering crowd at a Republican unity rally in Albany the other day as he stepped to the microphone to introduce Mr. Rinfret. Campaign workers passed out cheese sticks. Mr. Rinfret spoke. ''Great cheese, isn't it?'' Mr. Yancey said before introducing the next speaker.
The 44-year-old Mr. Yancey makes the cheese, $36 million of it a year, in this small town on the Lake Ontario shore. He says the cheese, with blue ''Yancey/Rinfret'' stickers on the package, is simply a device, a trademark if you will, to attract attention to a low-budget campaign for the state's No. 2 job. He laughs off suggestions that he is looking for free publicity for his cheese, or that he would rather talk about cheese than about Mr. Rinfret, who has conducted an erratic campaign.
''A heckuva lot more people know the name Heluva Good Cheese than the name Geff Yancey,'' he explained in an interview here at the cheese company, which markets cheese and cheese spread in supermarkets across New York and 16 other states.
''It's all in fun,'' continued the buoyant, mustachioed Mr. Yancey, the president of Heluva Good Cheese Inc. and a father of two and grandfather of two. ''Talking about it simply leads me into the real message of this campaign, which is that Mario Cuomo has been a disaster for this state.''
Whether the cheese is advertising the man or the man is advertising the cheese, Mr. Yancey is on a grueling promotion schedule these days: 31,000 miles so far, in 52 of the state's 62 counties.
But many voters in the New York metropolitan region have yet to see much of Mr. Yancey - among the counties he has not visited are Brooklyn and Queens - because his campaign is concentrated upstate, where party leaders hope he will galvanize Republican voters to come out for him and Mr. Rinfret on Nov. 6.
In some ways, swaying these crowds is not exactly an uphill battle. Although he is officially running against incumbent Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, he reserves most of his venom for Governor Cuomo, blaming him for rising taxes and what he considers too lenient treatment of criminals.
Just before Mr. Yancey was introduced at the annual meeting of the Wayne County Women's Republican Club here on Saturday afternoon, at the Sodus Bay Heights Golf Club, the speaker offered this invocation:
 
Mario Cuomo is my shepherd, I shall not want;
He leadeth me beside the still factories;
He restoreth my doubt in New York politics;
He guideth me to the path of unemployment;
He anointeth my wage with freeze.
Nevertheless, even if the Governor is vilified in some of the precincts where Mr. Yancey campaigns, the candidate must also generate enough enthusiasm for Mr. Rinfret so that Republican voters will not boycott the polls, or defect to other contenders like Herb London, the Conservative Party candidate, or Louis P. Wein, the nominee of the Right to Life Party.
Unlike the campaign of Mr. Rinfret, Mr. Yancey's bid for office has not been marked by bluster or condemnation of his fellow Republican leaders. And with the exception of vigorous attacks on Mr. Cuomo's record on crime and the economy, Mr. Yancey has conducted an upbeat campaign. Some party leaders have even privately wondered whether a ticket topped by the articulate and relentlessly enthusiastic Mr. Yancey might have worked out better than the one headed by Mr. Rinfret.
 
Holes in Big Cheese Jokes
At the height of Mr. Rinfret's quarrels with Republican leaders, now said to be smoothed over, one county chairman said Mr. Rinfret was ''out of control'' while another said he needed to get some bed rest. Mr. Yancey, however, has shown fealty all along.
He described Mr. Rinfret in glowing terms as a ''nonpolitician,'' and says that some of his more unconventional ideas, like putting armed vigilantes on the streets of New York City, simply reflect the way that good businessmen tend to consider ''a ton of ideas,'' not all of them practical.
''It's kind of a no-holds-barred strategy,'' said Mr. Yancey. ''The approach is: just give us any ideas you can, and we'll sort 'em all out later.''
Asked by a reporter whether Mr. Rinfret would make a great governor, Mr. Yancey whistled softly through his teeth and said after a moment, ''I think he would give us solutions to problems that have never been solved before.''
Mr. Yancey has not run for public office since being elected student body president at North Rose High School, although he has served as the Republican Party chairman of Wayne County and is active in a dizzying variety of local committees and charities in this county about halfway between Syracuse and Rochester. On the day this year's Republican convention in Rye ended, he was drafted to run for lieutenant governor by exhausted party leaders who had spent weeks trying to find someone to take the gubernatorial nomination.
Since then he has endured innumerable jokes about trying to be a big cheese in New York politics. Many local reporters have speculated that if he does not become lieutenant governor, he may have his eye on another position: a seat in Congress.
For now, however, Mr. Yancey says he is ''having a ball'' in the campaign, talking up conservative policies and talking down Mario Cuomo.
Once the voters know who he is, Mr. Yancey says, he'll be seen as a viable choice. ''Having Heluva Good Cheese behind me in this campaign is very important,'' he told the Republican Women's group here. ''In fact,'' he added, ''I've been thinking of changing my name. From now on, no more Geff Yancey. Just call me Heluva Good Yancey.'' Wessanen, U.S.A.d(Heluva Good Cheese)

B1); ''I understand that the better way to treat people is to listen, to respond, to show a little bit of humor,'' said George F. T. Yancey Jr., left. He talked with Eleanor Stuart at a campaign luncheon in Sodus Point, N.Y. (pg. B3) (Bob Mahoney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Can a Mall at a Toxic Dump Revive an Ailing Syracuse?

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: SYRACUSE

 BODY:
Just moments from the heart of downtown oozes Oil City, an industrial wasteland of oil tanks, junkyards, toxic dumps and corroded buildings hugging the shore of Onondaga Lake, itself a hazardous waste site.
For decades Oil City has stood as a kind of monument to 20th-century environmental arrogance, its future written off by government and business alike. ''It was a joke,'' said the city's development director, Joe C. Mareane.
But now, despite daunting environmental and economic hurdles, city officials and developers - in particular the Pyramid Companies, the mall-development giant based here - have joined to remake the 800-acre eyesore into what they hope will be the city's salvation.
They envision a thriving waterfront in the spirit of Baltimore's reborn harbor, ringed with parks, condominiums, canals and offices that could reverse a 30-year exodus that has sent the city's population to 165,000, from 225,000. 
The linchpin of this vision is Pyramid's first project in its hometown, the new Carousel Center, a mall to end all malls atop a former hazardous-waste site. With 1.4 million square feet of retail space on seven levels and an atrium soaring the equivalent of 17 stories, the mall will introduce Syracuse to such upscale outlets as Bonwit Teller, Ann Taylor, Banana Republic and Williams-Sonoma. But despite the great hopes for rebirth, there is concern whether the rest of Oil City - about 600 acres - will be revived. And with the Northeast shrouded in deepening economic gloom, there is skepticism that even the mall can succeed.
''I hate to sound like a doubting Thomas, but the mall could be a big souffle,'' said Susan Monagle, the owner of a downtown clothing boutique, TDF. ''It's going to be wonderful and the stores will knock our socks off, but there aren't enough people with enough money to support it.''
 
Rashes and Breathing Problems
The source of much of the skepticism over the rest of Oil City is Pyramid's troubles at the 75-acre mall site, on Hiawatha Boulevard overlooking Onondaga Lake. With the State Department of Environmental Conservation's approval, Pyramid volunteered to clean up 1.5 acres that were contaminated with solvents.
The cleanup cost the company $15 million - $13 million more than expected. Several construction workers on the part of the property not listed as a hazardous-waste site, the former Marley junkyard, were treated for skin rashes and breathing problems.
The Department of Environmental Conservation fined Pyramid $55,000 for allowing eight pounds of solvents to seep into a barge canal. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration fined a Pyramid subsidiary and consultant a total of $4,920 for violations, including failure to provide training and washing areas for workers.
In addition, Ward B. Stone, a Conservation Department wildlife pathologist nicknamed the ''toxic avenger'' for frequently contradicting the agency's official position, rode into Syracuse and took his own tests. He said he found a contaminated pocket on the Marley site with PCB's at four times the state's hazardous level of 50 parts per million.
The agency's local engineers had declared the Marley site safe, and they repeated that assessment after Mr. Stone left town and they were unable to replicate his findings. But the infighting among state environmentalists caused a stir in the local media and infuriated Pyramid officials.
When Pyramid proposed the Oil City redevelopment three years ago, it committed itself only to the two projects it saw as catalysts, Carousel Mall and Franklin Square, another part of Oil City whose decaying brick warehouses have been converted into condominiums and offices connected by brick walks, Victorian-style lampposts, benches and a park with a $35,000 bronze statue of Benjamin Franklin. But it was assumed that the company would do more. Now Pyramid says it will only promote Oil City's development, primarily because of the environmental problems.
''I fear our history will deter other developers, but the promise of Oil City is still there,'' said Bruce A. Kenan, a Pyramid partner in charge of the Lakefront Redevelopment, as Oil City's renewal is called.
Other factors could also leave the rest of Oil City fallow.
The city government now faces two uphill struggles. The first is the condemnation of 80 acres, dotted with 67 oil storage tanks and owned by nine oil companies. Although Pyramid has created a new oil tank farm for their relocation six miles away in the town of Van Buren, several oil companies want to stay put, and legal battles loom.
 
A New Federal Regulation
The second is the acquisition of the barge canal from the State Department of Transportation, so that a harbor can be developed with promenades and boat slips. The agency would rather consolidate its barge operations than abandon them.
A deterrent to more private investment is a new Federal rule with the effect of classifying petroleum-contaminated soil - of which there is much in Oil City - as hazardous waste, therefore making any cleanup of the oil-tank areas more complex and costly.
The Department of Environmental Conservation has petitioned the Environmental Protection Agency to drop the stricter regulations since New York has a thorough program for getting rid of petroleum-contaminated waste.
Finally, the economic downturn and sagging real-estate market in the Northeast bodes ill for Oil City, at least in the short term. Tightened lending policies are a concern since the prospect of an environmental cleanup could worry banks, making financing hard to come by for the thousands of condominiums and rental units and hundreds of thousands of square feet of office space envisioned.
 
'It's a Grave Threat'
''That's something that is more than a pall on this project, it's a grave threat,'' said Eric Mower, vice chairman of the Greater Syracuse Chamber of Commerce and owner of both a condominium and advertising and public-relations company with offices in Franklin Square.
Despite all this, state and city officials assert that Oil City's renaissance will come to fruition, maybe not overnight but certainly over several years.
''The economy may slow things down, but the internal logic of that project, which is to restore to a vibrant area a magnificent resource based upon Onondaga Lake, will push it forward,'' said Thomas C. Jorling, Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.
Environmental officials hope that Oil City's redevelopment could be a spur to cleaning up Onondaga Lake. The lake floor is lined with mercury, and the bottom third of the lake is without oxygen. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has pledged to revive the lake, asking Congress this year for $1.75 million to study its cleanup.
 
Syracuse Would Suffer
The city expects Carousel Center to yield $165 million over 25 years from Pyramid in payments in lieu of taxes. The city has already committed that money to improving Oil City's utilities and systems.
Susan E. Hopkins, director of the city's Lakefront Development Office, said she was talking with a ''half-dozen developers who are seriously interested,'' but declined to name them.
If Oil City does stumble, most agree, Syracuse will suffer. One reason is the limited potential for growth in the downtown, severed by Interstates 81 and 690.
''There are a lot of other cities looking for more jobs and more companies, and some communities will win over the next 10 years and some will lose,'' Mr. Mower said. ''To have a lake and harbor flourishing in downtown Syracuse - that is more than just another gemstone in this community's tiara. It may well be the centerstone.''

HEADLINE: Labor Talks Begin With Charges of Meddling

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Negotiations between New York City and its labor unions began yesterday on a bitter note with union leaders assailing what they called meddling by two prominent public figures.
The union leaders singled out Felix G. Rohatyn and Andrew J. Stein, accusing Mr. Rohatyn of poisoning the labor relations atmosphere and Mr. Stein of trying to thwart their efforts to gain new contracts.
''Felix Rohatyn has made it impossible for us to play on a level playing field,'' Barry Feinstein, the president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said at a news conference. ''We won't come to a table with Rohatyn at it. He is now the enemy. We are talking about a man who tries to bust unions. We will not deal with him in any capacity. So let's have the fight, let's have the war.'' 
Though Mr. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a state watchdog agency set up during the city's 1970's fiscal crisis, has no direct role in labor negotiations, he has attacked the teachers' 5.5 percent raise as excessive and has urged rescinding it. He has proposed that other unions get no raise because of the city's faltering economy. Yesterday Mr. Rohatyn declined to comment on Mr. Feinstein's statements.
 
Opposition to Raise 'Resented'
After Mr. Feinstein criticized Mr. Rohatyn at the news conference, Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37, attacked Mr. Stein, the City Council President. Mr. Stein has opposed the teachers' raise as excessive. Mr. Hill said that Mr. Stein ''was'' a friend of labor, emphasizing the past tense, and that the unions ''resent'' his recent stand.
Mr. Stein said in an interview that he still considered himself a friend of labor but warned that the teachers' raise, if followed for the other unions, would result in widespread layoffs, higher taxes and sharply reduced services. The unions represented included transit workers, firefighters, correction guards, hospital workers and physicians.

HEADLINE: Quebec Hydropower Battle Entangles Utilities in U.S.

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREAT WHALE, Quebec

 BODY:
New York and New England power officials have become reluctant participants in a dispute over whether one of Canada's biggest utilities should expand its generating capacity.
Utilities in the Northeast have purchased substantial amounts of power from the Canadian company, Hydro-Quebec, since the late 1970's. New contracts would extend those ties well into the next century. But environmentalists in the United States are hoping to derail the sales as both economically and environmentally unsound. 
In New York, purchases of Hydro-Quebec power have accounted for as much as 9 percent of the electricity supply in a year. Utility planners expect that by the year 2000, Canadian power sources will supply 30 percent of new electricity demand in the state.
 
A Buy-or-Build Choice
If the state cannot buy Hydro-Quebec power, said Richard M. Flynn, chairman of the New York Power Authority, new power plants would be needed to meet expected demand. The authority, Hydro-Quebec's largest customer outside Canada, supplies one-quarter of the state's electricity.
Hydro-Quebec wants to increase greatly the hydroelectric power it generates from the remote James Bay region in northern Quebec. It plans new hydroelectric projects on the Great Whale River near here, 650 miles north of Montreal, and on several rivers south of the huge La Grande hydroelectric complex, now operating.
Indians and Eskimos in the region and environmentalists in Canada and the United States oppose the new projects. They say Hydro-Quebec has given short shrift to energy conservation, the environment and the rights of the Cree and Inuit people who live in this isolated, subarctic territory.
The Sierra Club and the Crees have sued the authority, trying to block two new contracts to buy electricity from Hydro-Quebec. One contract would extend until 2018 an agreement to supply 800,000 kilowatts from April to October each year. A second, 21-year contract, effective in 1995, would commit Hydro-Quebec to supply one million kilowatts year-round, enough for one million households at any given moment.
The total cost of the purchases would be about $19 billion. The Sierra Club wants the power authority to study the environmental consequences of a power purchase from Hydro-Quebec.
''Energy conservation in New England, New York and Quebec could meet many times the demand that the new dams would serve,'' said James A. Dumont, a Middlebury, Vt., lawyer for the Sierra Club and the Cree.
The authority says buying Canadian hydroelectric power is cheaper than building plants of its own and does not carry the environmental problems of oil- and coal-fueled plants. Judge Kenneth Shorter of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is expected to rule soon.
Canada's National Energy Board recently approved Hydro-Quebec's proposed sale of power to New York and Vermont utilities. But the board made the sales contingent on a study examining the environmental impact of the new James Bay projects.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Student Protest Movement Expands, and Its Voice Is That of the Consumer

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
It was a situation guaranteed to warm the heart of any campus radical of the 1960's.
For nearly two weeks, the main campus of the University of the District of Columbia echoed with the chants of students occupying the school's administration building. They threatened to keep the school closed until they got the resignations of certain members of the school's board, child care for students with children, longer library hours and other demands, 45 in all.
There would have been only one puzzlement to any aging 60's-era protester: The students' chief demand was not ''Peace Now,'' or ''Free the Chicago 7.'' It was, quite simply, a demand for a better education. 
Unlike their counterparts a generation ago, college students today are increasingly as likely to protest over the quality of their education as over the many social causes usually embraced by undergraduates. Across the country, recent student protests have been generated by concerns about class size, cutbacks in the number of classes and courses, other curriculum issues, unavailability of professors and foreign teaching assistants who cannot be understood by English-speaking students.
 
Students Are More Vocal
''We're seeing students be more vocal on their insistence on high quality in all aspects of their educational experience,'' said Dan Abrahamowicz, dean of students at the University of Toledo. ''They're acting in a way like consumers. They're saying: 'I'm paying top dollar for an education and I expect to get it.' ''
Part of the reason for this new educational consumerism at some schools may be the nature of the clientele. The University of the District of Columbia is a 13-year-old, publicly financed urban institution that caters to a largely working-class, predominantly black pool of students, most of whom are older than typical college students and go to school part time, and more than half of whom are women, many with children. These students - who achieved 42 of their 45 demands before the university reopened Oct. 9 - are first and foremost pragmatic.
Across the Potomac River, Northern Virginia Community College's suburban, predominantly white, working-class students were just as pragmatic about the quality of their education, but they took a different action.
When Gov. L. Douglas Wilder's budget cuts threatened to eliminate personnel and classes at the Virginia college, the second-largest community college in the nation, the students did not shut down the five-campus, 59,000-student institution. Instead, they petitioned for a temporary increase in tuition.
 
Higher Fees Sought
The students succeeded in getting a one-semester surcharge of $3 added to the $28.60 fee for each credit hour. Without the surcharge, a college official said, the administration would have had to increase the number of students in classes and some courses would not have been offered.
''Education is so valuable that that insignificant increase is worth it,'' said Milton Hodges, president of the Black Student Alliance and one of the students who presented the petition. Mr. Hodges started United Student Leaders for Quality Eduation, which led the push for the surcharge.
Elizabeth Grizzard, dean of students at the college's Annandale campus, said that because the majority of students work they were attuned to the marketplace and getting value for their money.
''They think about the marketplace all the time,'' she said, ''and they realize that sometimes you need to pay more to get a better product.
''Our tuition is very, very reasonable, and the students believed they could relieve some of the financial stress through this. They worked that out in their heads and nobody influenced them to do this. They led the charge.''
''They were really humorous about it,'' Ms. Grizzard added, ''translating the surcharge into six-packs and suggesting that by merely foregoing a six-pack or two, a student could pay the surcharge.''
 
Cutbacks Raise Concerns
Money is not the only thing necessary for quality, but cutbacks raise concerns about it, said Janet Hanson, director for policy analysis for the College Board, a non-profit educatinal company.
''If the decade of the '90s is, as is expected, a difficult one economically,'' Ms. Hanson said, ''it will be a period when institutions are under pressure to keep costs under control. That will raise issues of quality.''
Educational consumerism has not displaced other student concerns. Students continue to protest racism on campus, apartheid in South Africa, United States involvement in Central America and various environmental issues.
But concerns about educational quality are on the rise, and students are equally vocal about quality at many private institutions. In 1986, students at Syracuse University formed Undergraduates for a Better Education to push for smaller classes and teaching assistants whom English-speaking students could understand.
 
Survey at Syracuse
The Syracuse group is currently surveying undergraduates about their views on education quality, the size of classes, access to professors and other education issues.
''At these big, research-oriented private universities, you're paying $15,000 to $20,000 a year,'' said Catherine Sessler, president of Undergraduates for a Better Education. ''Students realize that there are problems out there. They had better ask questions now because that is a lot of money to be shelling out. Given the constraints on the economy, students are going to be the asking what they're getting for their money a lot more.''
William Coplin, director of the public affairs program at the Maxwell School at Syracuse University, said: ''U.B.E. has had a really big impact here at Syracuse.'' But he added that students often do not understand the long-range problems a university must take into account.
''Students want better quality,'' Mr. Coplin said, ''but the institution is so complex it is hard to focus on how to get it. You can't just demonstrate. They don't know what forces are at work -why the curriculum is this way, why adjunct professors are used to the degree that they are. And they better watch it when they start asking for academic 'quality.' They may just get some very esoteric courses.''
 
Training for Assistants
Nonetheless, student demands, expressed in various ways at various campuses, have brought action. Syracuse, the University of California at Los Angeles, Pennsylvania State University and Purdue University, among others, have instituted training programs and proficiency standards for teaching assistants from foreign countries, to make sure they can communicate well in English. Other universities have put students on various boards and committees in their search to satisfy rising student demands.
But what exactly quality is and who determines it are areas fraught with wranglings. Arguments abound over the validity of ethnic studies and women's studies, even which departments such courses belong in and which professors should teach them.
At San Francisco State University, students and faculty in the School of Ethnic Studies have been protesting the placement of a black politics course in the political science department, arguing that it is a first step toward eliminating the 20-year-old ethnic studies school by dispersing its courses. School officials maintain that the course was moved to woo a more diverse student enrollment to the political science department.
As the student population becomes more ethnically diverse, experts say that whether these courses should be incorporated into the traditional curriculum or be separate departments will be a primary area of student activism.
''This new consumer movement has taken universities very much by surprise,'' said Charles Sykes, whose book, ''Profscam: Professors and the Demise of Higher Education,'' published in 1988 by Regnery Gateway, was a widely read and harsh critique of higher education. ''It really challenges the schools. You're going to see this grow exponentially.''
Or as one of the student protesters at the University of the District of Columbia said to administrators when the school reopened: ''We will police you until we get all that we can get -a quality education, a better education.''

HEADLINE: FOOD NOTES

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Celebrating the Harvest
It's harvest time and some chefs who buy produce at the Union Square Greenmarket in Manhattan are helping the market celebrate. In the next couple of weeks, they will hold cooking demonstrations starting between 10:30 and 11 A.M. and food will be will be sampled at noon.
On tap today is Michael Romano, chef of the Union Square Cafe; on Saturday, Wendy Rubin and Michelle Nemer of the Macrobiotic Center of New York; on Oct. 26, Sarabeth Levine and Steven Picker of Sarabeth's Kitchen; on Oct. 27, Eric Stapelman and Robert Smith of Luma, and on Nov. 3, David Bouley of Bouley.
A pumpkin carving-contest will be held on Halloween, Oct. 31. Admission to all events is free. Oil Change Villa Nicola olive oil, the brand sold under the label of the estate in Tuscany owned by Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, is now in supermarkets. The three styles are top-of-the-line, fully loaded extra virgin; pure, for everyday cooking; and an extra light, a highly refined variety of pure. 
The extra-virgin oil is fairly lush and fruity without the peppery intensity of other extra-virgin Tuscan oils. The oils carry a sticker price of about $7.50 for a liter of extra virgin, and about a dollar less for the others.
 
It Wasn't Truffle Weather
Northern Italy's white truffle harvest limps along. Rosario Safina, president of Urbani Truffle, a major importer, said: ''There was no snow last winter, no spring rain and a dry hot summer. It was great for tourists but terrible for truffles.''
Prices for large white truffles are close to $1,000 a pound. At Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street), they are $900 a pound, $600 a pound for small ones. At Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street), they are $55 an ounce.
Lou Todaro, the importer who owns Todaro Brothers, at 555 Second Avenue (31st Street), said: ''Forget about it. I doubt if I will bring any in at these prices, especially considering the economy.'' Fair or Tare Weight? Mark Green, the New York Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, is warning consumers about overcharging by salad bars, delicatessens and bakery counters.
On Friday he announced that 115 stores had been fined for not deducting the container's weight from the total. Containers weigh a fraction of an ounce, translating to pennies in the price of a salad, but adding up to $12 million a year citywide, Mr. Green said.
Members of his staff visited 254 salad bars, delis, bakeries and supermarkets in the five boroughs to purchase food anonymously. Fines from $30 to $100 must be paid by the violators. Mr. Green advised consumers to ask that purchases be reweighed properly if the container weight is not deducted.
 
Filtering Aid to Forests
Manufacturers of coffee filters are backing reforestation. Melitta of Germany, the world's largest producer of coffee filters, is donating money to the American Forestry Association's Global Releaf program, hoping to pay for planting two trees for every one used in making filters. Melitta uses pulp from America and Canadian trees for filters sold here.
Not to be outdone, Mr. Coffee Inc., based in Bedford Heights, Ohio, has also joined with the American forestry association's program to help finance needed tree plantings in cities around the country. The project began yesterday in Limon, Colo., with the replanting of trees destroyed by a recent tornado.
 
2 Books, Boiled Down
 
A PAIR of informative cooks' guides are now available in handy paperbacks. For the historically minded, there is the Dictionary of Cuisine by Alexandre Dumas. Edited, abridged and translated by Louis Coleman Fireside, $9.95), it is based on ''Le Grand Dictionnaire de la Cuisine,'' published in 1873.
The striking photography of the original ''Cook's Ingredients'' stands out as well in the new version, edited by Adrian Bailey (Reader's Digest, $14.95). But instead of having the photographs and text in separate sections, as in the book published in England by Dorling Kindersley in 1980, the sections are combined.

HEADLINE: Reappraising Home Ec

 BODY:
To The Living Section:
As a home economics teacher, I was delighted to see an article related to my specialty in The New York Times [''In the New Home Ec, Choices for Life,'' Sept. 26]. However, a large part of the story of home economics was not included in the article. As stated, ''home and career skills,'' as it is now called in the New York education curriculum, is not a required subject. It is an elective and a poorly promoted one at that. The ''major'' subjects - social studies, math, sciences and English - are usually studied for 12 academic years. Special topics in these areas plus languages, art and music are suggested elective courses in high school. Business and computer courses are promoted by guidance counselors because, of course, we must prepare for the outside world! 
But home economics, well, it's a minor and its topics, which include parenting, child development, family relationships, consumer education, nutrition, food preparation, decision making, career choices, clothing and textiles and interior design are considered minor ones in academic circles.
The young girl and/or boy upon graduation, however, will rarely multiply fractions or discuss the War of 1812, but will be faced daily with decisions relating to the home economics topics.
Teen-agers might prefer to prepare a hamburger rather than go to McDonald's if they knew how, and they might prepare minestrone soup rather than the hamburger if they had studied home economics. They might choose to use birth control if they had participated in a challenging course in child care.
Schools are called upon to assume a greater share of the child-care role and academic standards continue to decrease, not because schools aren't trying hard enough but because parents aren't trying hard enough. And parents aren't trying hard enough not because they don't want to but because they don't know how. The problems will increase in the next generation because we withhold access to this ''minor'' subject. When will there be an educator brave enough to mandate even two years of home economics in the 12-year educational life of our future generation?
 
PHYLLIS LEVIN
 Spring Valley, N.Y.
