HEADLINE: WINE TALK

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
FOR many years, there was an excellent Greek restaurant on Eighth Avenue between 43d and 44th Streets, just around the corner from my office. It was called the Parthenon, and some of the freshest fish in New York came from its kitchen. For the regulars there was always a simple oinos lefkos, an expensive Greek white wine, with just the right acidity to match the oil in the fish. What was the name of it? What difference? The restaurant is gone now, and with it, one of the few chances to find decent Greek wines in New York. Oh, they turn up now and then, but almost exclusively in other Greek restaurants. They are considered an ethnic item, like taramosalata or sweet coffee with the grounds in the cup.
This may sound like heresy, but, for the moment at least, it isn't actually necessary to have access to Greek wines to enjoy them. 
There is no substitute for the real thing, of course, but a new book will do quite well until the real thing comes along. It is Miles Lambert-Gocs's ''The Wines of Greece.'' (Faber & Faber, $24.95 cloth, $13.95 paper), which is just now reaching the book shops.
Let's be frank. These are lean times in the wine business. Even the French and the Californians are threatened by mineral water. An advocate of Greek wines these days is truly a voice crying in the wilderness.
Mr. Lambert-Gocs, ardent proselyte though he may be, knows that he is not about to change things. Few retailers will rush to stock their shelves with Mavrodaphne and such on the basis of one book. No matter. Mr. Lambert-Gocs rises above the exigencies of the marketplace. He well knows that his readers are not about to descend on their local merchants demanding obscure vintages from Samos and the Eastern Sporades, or the red wines of Crete that, in Hugh Johnson's telling phrase, are ''more suited, perhaps, for Minoan than modern man.''
What he offers is an exciting armchair voyage through one of the oldest, least-known and, ultimately, most intriguing wine regions in the world. Mr. Lambert-Gocs, whose name is a nom de plume, is an agricultural economist in the service of the United States Department of Agriculture specializing in Greece and Eastern Europe. He is also a scholar, as anyone who has encountered his work under the same name on zinfandel and tokay in The Journal of Gastronomy will readily attest.
In his preface, the author says ''contemporary Greek wine is my focus.'' And so, perhaps, it should be. Happily, each of the 11 regional chapters includes a section on ''classical reflections,'' and the book itself concludes with a chapter on, as the author puts it, ''what I think is a vital and relevant picture of Greek wine in antiquity.''
And that, for this reader, at least, is the core of the book. Few of us are likely to be tasting our way through the Cyclades in the near future, but who among us has never thrilled to an allusion to the ''wine-dark sea''?
Certainly the current scene has its fascination. For example, on the windswept island of Santorini, some 70 miles north of Crete, the largest winery is that of the Koutsouyanopoulos Brothers.
Mr. Lambert-Gocs has good things to say about the brothers' white wines - one called Volcan, the other, Lava - but even if he did not, it would be worth a visit just to see their label.
More to the point are his comments on Crete where, he says, ''to explore the sources of the Cretan tradition is to trace the essentials of wine-growing back four millenia.'' The remains of an ancient vineyard found at Kato Zakros in eastern Crete, date from the early second millenium B.C., Mr. Lambert-Gocs goes on to say, and provide ''the earliest conclusive evidence of systematic cultivation of grape types destined specifically for wine production.''
According to the author, Greek wine production persisted, with considerable vigor, from antiquity through most of Byzantium and did not seriously wane until the five-century rule of the Ottoman Empire from the 14th to the 19th century.
After that - the last of the Turks didn't leave until 1913 - the Greek vineyards suffered from wars and disease, but most of all from emigration. Phylloxera, the insect that devastated the vineyards of Western Europe in the late 19th century, did not arrive in some areas of Greece until the 1950's and 1960's, but emigration, particularly in poor regions such as Epirus, left vast areas once covered in vines virtually abandoned.
Nevertheless, winegrowing is thriving in Greece, and according to Mr. Lambert-Gocs, wine quality is improving almost exponentially. He credits the introduction of appellation controls beginning in 1969. By 1972, 21 wine-producing regions had been given appellation status. Four additional regions were added in the 1980's and, the author says, more are to come.
Still, as any wine lover can attest, finding good Greek wines is not easy. Mr. Lambert-Gocs agrees. ''Few of the better ones have been exported at all, even fewer are exported on an ongoing basis, and still fewer are ever distributed abroad outside Greek ethnic channels.''
A few serious Greek restaurants stock some of the better Greek wines, but finding something to compare to the best of Italy or France or California is not easy. Mr. Lambert-Gocs is optimistic. He notes that Greek wine makers are convinced that the 21st century will see them regain the reputation they had in ancient times.
The 21st century is nine years and a few months away. Get ready for it by reading ''The Wines of Greece.''
 
TASTINGS
La Vieille Ferme Cotes de Ventoux, 1989, $4 to $5. A bottle of decent French red wine for about $4? Yes, it can be done and La Vieille Ferme proves it. This wine - the name means the Old Farm - is made by the Perrin family, who also own Chateau de Beaucastel in Chateauneuf-du-Pape. Beaucastel is relatively small and special. La Vieille Ferme is a huge operation that specializes in good, inexpensive wine. Originally the Vieille Ferme appellation was Cotes-du-Rhone. The Gold Label version still is. But the standard wine - and the most popular - is Cotes de Ventoux, which comes from vineyards in the Vaucluse. The grapes are the same as in the Cotes-du-Rhone - grenache, carignan, syrah, cinsaut, mourvedre - and the alcoholic content is about the same, 11 percent. Once these were light wines, but in recent years the style has changed to give them more body and color. Some special Cotes-du-Rhones stand out from the crowd, but the Vieille Ferme Cotes de Ventoux will match most others and at a lower price. These wines represent very good value.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:

Paz a Known Quantity
Octavio Paz is not only the first Mexican to win the Nobel Prize in Literature. He is also one of the few foreign Nobel laureates in recent times whose books were widely available in the United States when he won the award. It was next to impossible, for example, to find the works of such previous Nobel winners as Camilo Jose Cela (1989), Naguib Mahfouz (1988), Claude Simon (1985) and Jaroslav Siefert (1984).
In the case of Mr. Paz, ''widely available'' may be stretching things, since none of his books have enjoyed huge printings. But 20 of his volumes of poetry or essays are still in print; his best-known book, ''The Labyrinth of Solitude,'' from Grove Weidenfeld, has been readily available for several decades. 
Grove Weidenfeld has two other Paz books in print; New Directions, which has published the poetry of Mr. Paz for 40 years, has six of his books in print; Harcourt Brace Jovanovich has available two collections of Paz essays, and Seaver Books, now distributed through Arcade, an imprint of Little, Brown, has five Paz titles; so, too, does the Harvard University Press, the University of Texas Press and such smaller houses as Latitudes Press, Riverrun and George Braziller.
 
Reissuing 'Bernstein'
Ballantine Books said yesterday that it was going back for a new printing of ''Bernstein,'' by Joan Peyser, a biography of Leonard Bernstein, who died on Sunday. The book, published in hard cover by William Morrow & Company, was reprinted by Ballantine in a mass-market paperback edition in July 1988.
 
A Tiny Toons Line
Longmeadow Press, the publishing arm of Waldenbooks, has taken a major step forward as a publisher in recent weeks with its new line of children's books, based on the Warner Brothers Looney Tunes characters. The new characters, known as Tiny Toons, are the offspring of a joint venture between Steven Spielberg and LCA Entertainment, the licensing division of Warner Brothers.
Ron Jaffe, the senior director of marketing at Waldenbooks, said his company had acquired the license to publish books based on those characters for prices ranging from about $5 up, while the Western Publishing Company has the license for the lower-priced books. (Western's Golden Books and Whitman imprints are a staple in supermarkets and similar retail outlets.) Five of Landmark's Tiny Toon Adventures, as the series is called, are already in stores, aimed at ages 2 to 9 and selling for $4.95 and $5.95. They were published last month to coincide with the debut of the television series, produced by Mr. Spielberg and Amblin Entertainment. Longmeadow plans to publish as many as 25 Tiny Toon titles during the next three years.
 
Appeal Still Weighed
A spokeswoman for Simon & Schuster said yesterday that the company had not yet decided whether to appeal the recent decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, upholding the constitutionality of New York's ''Son of Sam'' law. That law decrees that convicted criminals cannot profit from their crimes, and that money they earn from books or motion pictures must be used primarily to repay their victims. Thus the New York State Crime Victims Board sought $96,250 that the publisher had deposited in an escrow account for Henry Hill, a mobster whose life is the subject of ''Wiseguy: Life in a Mafia Family,'' by Nicholas Pileggi, published in 1986.
The publisher contended that the law violated constitutionally protected free speech, and could make such books unavailable in the future. But the appeals court, by a 2-to-1 vote, declared on Oct. 3 that concern for victims' rights outweighed free speech rights, adding that the law does not prevent criminals from writing about themselves, only from making a profit when they do so.
 
On the Soviet Economy
When in 1971 the University of New Mexico Press published ''Alienation and the Soviet Economy,'' by Paul Craig Roberts, a book analyzing the inherent weaknesses of Soviet planning, the book did not make much of a stir and eventually went out of print.
Next month, however, it will be reissued by Holmes & Meier Publishers, a New York house that specializes in scholarly books.
It is being co-published with the Independent Institute, a nonprofit organization that publishes a series of books on public policy. The book will also be published early next year in the Soviet Union, where it has been widely praised by members of the Academy of Sciences.

LENGTH: 1115 words

HEADLINE: Ideas That Changed Wall St. And Fathered Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Few Nobel awards in economics, it is safe to say, will be as enthusiastically received within the profession as this year's award to Harry M. Markowitz, Merton H. Miller and William F. Sharpe.
To academics, they are top-shelf theoreticians whose quarter-century-old insights into the economics of finance still dazzle the brightest graduate students. To nuts-and-bolts types, they are researchers whose ideas have changed Wall Street and the investment habits of millions of people.
''You can view them as the intellectual fathers of the mutual fund business,'' said Robert Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution. 
Harry Markowitz's work came first, in the early 1950's, and probably had the greatest intellectual fallout. The prudence of not putting all of one's eggs into one basket had been understood intuitively for centuries. But it was Dr. Markowitz who refined the economic logic of diversification and offered a practical way to choose an ''optimal portfolio'' of assets.
Assets, whether General Motors stock, barrels of crude oil or building lots in Florida, can be classified by the likely return and the probability that the return will deviate from expectations. Investors might decide, for example, that G.M. stock will pay a $3 dividend, but there is a 10 percent chance that it will be higher than $3.50 or lower than $2.50.
Diversifying - say, buying $25,000 worth of each of two stocks rather than $50,000 worth of one - will change both the likely return on the investments and the risk that the actual return will be larger or smaller. Mixing G.M. and Ford stock might not change the risk-return prospects much because each of the American auto makers is subject to similar market shocks.
 
Mixing Assets to Cut Risk
But mixing G.M. shares with those of, say, Exxon would probably allow the investor to achieve the same return with less chance of losing a lot of money. The high oil prices that would hurt G.M.'s sales would be offset by Exxon's higher profits at the pump.
Dr. Markowitz showed how to measure the risk associated with different assets and how to mix assets in ways that would achieve the maximum likely overall return with the least possible risk. Those techniques, greatly enhanced by subsequent research and the number-crunching ability of computers, are now routinely used by sophisticated institutional investors - ''even by money managers who have never heard of Harry Markowitz or portfolio theory,'' Burton Malkiel, an economist at Princeton, points out.
William Sharpe built on Dr. Markowitz's foundation. And along with James Tobin of Yale (who won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1981) he greatly enriched the concept and the practical value of the portfolio theory.
Dr. Markowitz had offered investors a menu of portfolios, different blends of assets that generated the best possible trade-off between the virtue of high expected return and the vice of high risk. Dr. Sharpe had the simple but elegant insight to approach the same questions from the other side of the equation.
 
Adjusting Prices of Assets
All valued assets have to be in someone's portfolio, because all assets are owned by someone. Thus buyers and sellers must adjust the prices of assets to make them attractive enough to fit into someone's ''optimal'' portfolio.
Now for the shocker: once assets are properly priced, a single mix of risky assets fits into every investor's portfolio, regardless of one's taste for taking chances. Those with less appetite for risk than the blend afforded could mix it with a ''riskless'' asset - putting, say, $10,000 in stocks and $40,000 in an insured bank deposit. Those with more appetite for risk could borrow money to buy more - say, borrowing an extra $100,000 to buy $150,000 worth of stock.
One direct consequence of Dr. Sharpe's work was the emergence of ''beta,'' a measure of the portfolio risk that clever diversification could not vanquish. Beta, which is widely used by Wall Street (and ignored by less sophisticated investors at the peril of their purses) compares the risk of holding one mix of stocks with stocks in general.
A mutual fund with a beta of, say, 1.3, is likely to go up (or down) by 13 percent if the stock market goes up (or down) by 10 percent. When assets are properly valued, Dr. Sharpe's work suggests, the expected return should be roughly proportional to beta. Thus if a mutual fund is twice as risky as the market in general, the managers are not doing their job well unless, on average, it delivers twice the return of the average stock. To Borrow or Sell Equity? Merton Miller took the Markowitz concept and ran with it in an entirely different - and possibly even more important - direction. Collaborating with Franco Modigliani of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (who won the Nobel award in 1985), he vanquished the conventional wisdom on how corporations should structure their finances.
Before the Modigliani-Miller theorem was published in 1958 it was generally assumed that companies could raise capital cheaply by borrowing or raise it safely by issuing more stock. The best mix of debt to equity - the mix that would make the company most valuable to its owner-investors - was one that somehow balanced the cost of capital against the risks inherent in greater financial leverage.
To Dr. Modigliani and Dr. Miller, that did not square with portfolio theory. More debt might make profits vary more from year to year. But the extra risk should not affect the price of the stock because conservative investors would always have the option of ''deleveraging'' their assets by holding more of a low-risk asset like bank deposits. Thus the optimal mix of debt and equity was simply the cheapest mix. It follows that in equilibrium, the cost of raising capital by selling stock or selling bonds should be equal.
Two real-world phenomena, taxes and potential losses in bankruptcy, do muddy this crystal-clear insight. In the end it may still serve investors' interests for companies to pay more (or less) for borrowed money. But as Dr. Litan argues, the Modigliani-Miller theorem ''clarified what it was that explains the difference.''
Portfolio theory changed - or more accurately, created - the modern discipline of financial economics. But Fisher Black, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, says its contributions to economics do not end there.
The portfolio theorists, he says, ''were far ahead of mainstream economists in analyzing uncertainty.'' Many of the techniques now used to predict, say, the impact of changes in money supply on changes in interest rates can be traced to earlier investigations of asset risk.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Five Big Drug Companies Show Strong Income Gains

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Riding high in the face of economic weaknesses that have reduced profits in other industries, five major pharmaceutical companies reported strong gains in quarterly earnings yesterday.
Helped by new product sales and favorable currency exchange rates, net income rose 20.9 percent in the quarter that ended Sept. 30 at Eli Lilly & Company, 19.1 percent at Merck & Company and 16.7 percent at the Warner-Lambert Company. The American Home Products Corporation had a 14.2 percent gain and Pfizer Inc. an 11.9 percent increase.
But the five company's shares all dropped yesterday in a general decline in stock prices. 
 
Eli Lilly
Lilly, based in Indianapolis, said sales in the quarter increased by 29.3 percent, to $1.28 billion, from $991.0 million in the 1989 quarter. Net income rose to $256.8 million, or 90 cents a share, from $212.4 million, or 73 cents a share.
Richard D. Wood, Lilly's chairman, said sales and earnings set records, rising in each of the company's three main businesses: drugs, medical devices and diagnostic products. Ronald Nordmann at Paine Webber Securities, said that Lilly's drug sales rose by 31 percent, with overseas sales particularly strong.
Mr. Nordmann added that Lilly's earnings per share in the quarter would have shown a 38.5 percent increase, if ''extraordinary items'' reported in the third quarter of 1989 were taken into account. He said that Lilly had attributed about $42.4 million at that time to renegotiation of the debt instrument it got from Faberge Inc. in the 1987 sale of its Elizabeth Arden unit, and income from the settlement of a patent dispute.
Mr. Wood said important contributors to the sales growth included Lilly's antibiotics, genetically engineered human insulin and Prozac, an anti-depressant drug. Mr. Nordmann said Prozac sales in the period rose nearly 17 percent, to $210 million, from $180 million in the preceeding quarter, ''in spite of signficant negative publicity and lawsuits.'' Critics say that some people who took Prozac have experienced life-endangering side effects; many psychiatrists have said that the drug is effective and relatively safe.
Lilly shares were $74.75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, down $1.375.
 
Merck
Merck, the world's largest pharmaceutical company, said sales rose 17.2 percent in the quarter, to $1.91 billion, from $1.63 billion in the 1989 period. Earnings rose to $465 million, or $1.19 a share, from $390.5 million, or 99 cents a share, a year earlier.
Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, chairman of Merck, which is based in Rahway, N.J., said that ''sales growth was led by newer products.'' He added, ''Both our domestic and international operations reported solid gains in units sold.''
Mr. Nordmann at Paine Webber said that sales of Vasotec, the nation's largest-selling blood-pressure drug, rose by 25 percent in the quarter over a year earlier and would be $1.4 billion for the year. Merck also had sales gains in the quarter for Mevacor, a cholesterol-lowering agent that rose 43 percent; Pepcid, an ulcer treatment, up 67 percent, and Prilosec, a new type of gastrointestinal drug, which was introduced late in 1989.
Dr. Vagelos said the dollar's decline raised Merck's sales by one percentage point in the first nine months. Merck calculates its overseas earnings in dollars, closely reflecting currency changes. Mr. Nordmann attributed 4 percentage points of the 17 percent quarterly sales gain to the dollar's slide, 11 points to growth in numbers of products sold and 2 percentage points to price increases.
Merck stock fell 62.5 cents on the Big Board yesterday, closing at $77.875.
 
Warner-Lambert
Quarterly sales at the Warner-Lambert Company, based in Morris Plains, N.J., rose 7.1 percent, to a record $1.19 billion from $1.11 billion. The company said that sales growth would have been 5 percent if currency rates had not changed.
Net income climbed to $124.8 million, or 93 cents a share, from $106.9 million, or 79 cents a share, which was restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1990.
Joseph D. Williams, Warner-Lambert's chairman, said that the gains were fueled by worldwide sales of prescription drugs, which rose by 15 percent, to $390 million. Analysts said that quarterly pharmaceutical sales were led by its cholesterol-regulating drug, Lopid, which rose 19.4 percent, to $91 million.
Warner-Lambert closed at $60.375 yesterday, down 62.5 cents.
 
American Home
American Home Products, based in New York, said that third-quarter sales declined 1.6 percent, to $1.74 billion, from $1.77 billion a year ago, reflecting the sale in June 1990 of the company's Boyle-Midway household products unit. Nevertheless, earnings rose to $317.6 million, or $1.01 a share, from $278.2 million, or 89 cents, reflecting a 2-for-1 stock split on April 19.
John R. Stafford, American Home's chairman, said that taking out the effects of the Boyle-Midway divestiture, sales in the quarter rose 5 percent.
Mary Ellen McCarthy at Shearson Lehman Brothers said that the results were encouraging. Pharmaceutical sales increased by 10 percent, she said, ''the best showing for American Home in a long time. The synergies from American Home's acquisition of the A.H. Robins Company are really there.''
American Home Products lost $1.125, closing at $45.625.
 
Pfizer
Pfizer, which is also based in New York, said third-quarter sales rose 14.2 percent, to $1.64 billion, from $1.44 billion. Net income climbed to $243.3 million, or $1.45 a share, from $217.5 million, or $1.29 a share a year earlier.
Pfizer said drug sales increased by 22 percent and hospital products, 17 percent. Consumer products were up 10 percent and chemicals 13 percent. Specialty mineral sales declined 16 percent, reflecting the sale of Pfizer's pigments business this year.
Edmund T. Pratt Jr., Pfizer's chairman, said new products like Procardia XL, a heart drug, and Diflucan, an anti-fungal agent, accounted for more than one-fourth of the growth in drug sales. Analysts said Procardia XL sales were $127 million in the quarter.
Pfizer dropped 87.5 cents yesterday, to $72.25.

HEADLINE: 3 U.S. Economists Win Nobel

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science was awarded today to three Americans whose pioneering work provided new tools for weighing the risks and rewards of different investments and for valuing corporate stocks and bonds.
The three are Harry M. Markowitz of Baruch College of the City University of New York, William F. Sharpe of Stanford University and Merton H. Miller of the University of Chicago.
Their work is known individually as Portfolio Theory, the Capital Asset Pricing Model and the Miller-Modigliani Theorem. Collectively, their theories are widely applied today. They influence the investment decisions of stockbrokers, bankers, mutual fund managers, government agencies and millions of individuals. 
 
Theories Now Taken for Granted
These theories, although taken for granted today, were considered innovative when they were developed in the 1950's and 60's. For investors, the research offered a way to tailor one's holdings to mirror one's willingness to take risks. For financial specialists and economists, the theories explained how the weighing of risks and rewards helps to determine securities prices and how factors like tax changes and bankruptcy affect those values.
Corporate finance experts use the theories to value potential acquisitions and to make decisions about dividends and financings. Governments use them to assess the potential impact of a tax change on different parts of the economy. And a public utility commission might use them to determine the prices that would give an electric company enough return on its investments so that it could build needed power plants.
 
'They Are All Pioneers'
James Tobin, the Yale University professor who won the economics prize in 1981 and is now retired, said that in many ways the school of thought that believes financial markets are rational or efficient - that is, that the value of a company is always accurately reflected in the price of its stock - rests on the three men's work. ''They are all pioneers in finance theory, which has been flourishing in recent years,'' he said in a telephone interview from New Haven. ''But these guys were way ahead of the fashion.''
Assar Lindbeck, chairman of the prize committee at the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, noted that while the three did not collaborate, their work was a continuum.
''Each one of them gave one building block for a unified theory of financial economics,'' he said. ''This theory would have been incomplete if one of these pieces were missing.''
In a telephone interview from Cambridge, Mass., Franco Modigliani, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, called the prize ''the final seal of approval'' for recognizing ''for the first time that finance is a major area of economics.'' Dr. Modigliani won the economics prize in 1985, partly for his theories about savings and partly for work on corporate finance theory, which he did with Dr. Miller in the 1950's and 60's.
He added, ''These three pieces of research work in a span of about 10 years changed finance from a field of purely institutional interest, where there was no theory or basic models to explain what was going on, into a flourishing area of economics that has given us a completely different understanding of what finance is all about.''
As with most of the other Nobel Prizes, the award for economics is given for work that has often been completed decades ago but has stood the test of time. Sometimes theories or projects that at first seemed arcane wind up gaining wide application, often with modern technology like computers as a catalyst.
The three will equally share the prize, which this year totals four million Swedish crowns, or about $710,000, paid by the Swedish central bank.
The economics prize was established in 1968 by the bank and first awarded the next year as a memorial to Alfred Nobel, the Swedish industrialist who invented dynamite. It is distinct from the Nobel Prizes in physics, chemistry, medicine, literature and peace, which were set up under the terms of Mr. Nobel's will and are financed from his legacy.
 
'Growing Branch' of Economics
In seeking out the three professors, said Lawrence Klein, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania who won the economics prize in 1980, ''the prize committee wanted to broaden the concept of economics, and these people represent a new, growing branch of the field.''
Dr. Markowitz, the Marvin Speiser Distinguished Professor of Finance and Economics at Baruch, developed the portfolio theory, which analyzes how wealth or savings can be optimally invested in assets that differ in terms of expected return and risk.
While investment managers and academic economists had long recognized the need to weigh potential returns against risks, Dr. Markowitz provided a formula to do so.
Dr. Sharpe, the Timken Professor of Finance at the Stanford Business School, used Dr. Markowitz's theory to develop a model for explaining how securities prices are established in the market to reflect risks and potential returns. His theory - the Capital Asset Pricing Model - is now widely used by investment firms to predict, for instance, how a stock will perform in relation to the overall market.
The committee noted that several other researchers independently contributed to this area in the mid-1960's, although it called Dr. Sharpe ''the leading figure.''
Dr. Miller, currently the Robert R. McCormick Distinguished Service Professor at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, is widely considered to still be the dominant force in theoretical and empirical analysis in corporate finance.
He was awarded the economics prize for his theory explaining the relation between manufacturing companies' capital asset structure and dividend policy on the one hand, and their market value and cost of capital on the other.
Before the Modigliani-Miller theorem, many economists and corporate executives believed that if a company raised money by selling stock rather than borrowing, its value - based on the price of its securities -would rise because it would appeal to investors who thought the company was less risky than others with large debts.
But the theorem states that corporate executives should instead leave it to investors to reduce their risks by diversifying their portfolios. Corporate managers can best safeguard the interests of stockholders by maximizing their companies' net wealth.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.E.'s Net Rises 9% In Quarter

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Although its performance was hampered by the weakening of the economy, the General Electric Company said yesterday that its net income climbed 9 percent in the third quarter, to $1.03 billion, from $945 million in the 1989 period.
Revenues rose 9.2 percent from last year's third-quarter levels, to $14.2 billion from $13 billion. Earnings per share rose more rapidly - up 12 percent, to $1.16, from $1.04 a year ago -because the Fairfield, Conn., conglomerate had purchased 35 million of its own shares since November as part of a $10 billion buyback plan.
Slower economic growth and the unsettled situation in the Middle East hurt General Electric's lighting, plastics, and appliance businesses, said John F. Welch Jr., chairman. The company said operating profits also fell at NBC, G.E.'s broadcasting subsidiary, and were about flat in the company's industrial products group. 
But a number of other G.E. businesses that operate on much long production and sales cycles, notably aircraft engines and power systems, had strong performances. The company said its financial services group and medical systems business also posted strong gains. And the appliance group managed to increase profits thanks to productivity gains, even though demand stagnated.
 
Stock Declines
Mr. Welch said the results added up to a good quarter, but investors were uneasy. The company provides only the sketchiest of information on the performance of its many subsidiaries, except for its year-end report. G.E.'s shares fell $2.875, to $51.50, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts tended to agree with Mr. Welch. ''Given the state of the economy, they are doing extremely well,'' said Russell L. Leavitt, who follows the company for Salomon Brothers.
The productivity gains in the appliance group were among the more pleasant surprises for Wall Street. Changes like moving refrigerator production from a high-cost Chicago plant to Decatur, Ala.; productivity improvements in Louisville, Ky., and programs to improve the quality of parts from suppliers helped the group report increased profit on flat sales. Big competitors like Whirlpool and Maytag are expected to report earnings declines, said Robert Cornell, who follows the industry for Shearson Lehman Hutton.
Both the aircraft engine group and the power systems group benefited from sales momentum, which has been a growing factor in G.E.'s performance for the last year. G.E. said that the power group received $300 million in new orders in the quarter, bringing the total for the year to $3 billion. The backlog of aircraft engine orders has climbed to $14.1 billion from $13.3 billion this year, with new orders 13 percent ahead of 1989 for the first nine months.
Aerospace systems also had higher profits in the quarter, but the gains were tied to higher revenues that reflected the timing of product deliveries rather than underlying strength, the company said.
 
Financial Services Gain
G.E.'s financial services reported a 19 percent gain in profits for the quarter, which the company attributed to the activities of the General Electric Capital Corporation, a subsidiary that provides financing and credit for a wide range of industrial and consumer activities. ''The fact that the financing company is contributing a growing share of earnings and that they continue to make acquisitions worries some investors,'' said Mr. Leavitt of Salomon Brothers.
Analysts said that the Kidder, Peabody Group, the securities firm that is 80 percent owned by General Electric, had a flat quarter. A company spokesman declined to comment.
G.E. also declined to elaborate on the performance at NBC, which suffered an unspecified ''modest'' fall in revenues and operating profits. ''I think NBC is doing O.K.,'' said Martin Sankey, who follows G.E. for First Boston. ''Prime time ratings are down but so are expenses.''
Mr. Welch did not comment on the fourth-quarter outlook directly, but concluded that General Electric expected 1990 to end up as the company's fourth straight year of double-digit increases in earnings per share.

HEADLINE: Professors With Influence Far Beyond Their Schools

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:

Harry M. Markowitz
City University of New York
By many accounts, Harry M. Markowitz, professor of finance at Baruch College of the City University of New York, is the gentlest of the three recipients of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, and perhaps the most scholarly.
His colleagues at Baruch talk of his ''intellectual fervor'' and bookishness. And Fisher Black, a former finance professor now applying Dr. Markowitz's theories at Goldman, Sachs, tells of how he reversed himself after Dr. Markowitz, with great courtesy, poked holes in a paper that Mr. Fisher had written.
The paper called for automated, computerized stock trading, in lieu of the present exchanges. But after a cross-examination from Dr. Markowitz, Mr. Black reversed his conclusion, rewriting the paper and endorsing the exchanges. 
At age 63, Dr. Markowitz still teaches graduate students three days a week at Baruch, and this semester he is a lecturer at the University of Tokyo - his first big foray abroad. He is to follow that with a teaching stint at the London School of Economics.
Dr. Markowitz first developed his portfolio investment theories in his 1955 Ph.D. dissertation at the University of Chicago.
He has taught since 1982 at Baruch and now also works as a consultant to Daiwa Securities, the Japanese investment house. Before Baruch, he had worked at the Rand Corporation and was an I.B.M. researcher, developing Simscript, a computer language used to write programs for economic analyses.
 
Merton H. Miller
University of Chicago
The time was early 1958. Merton H. Miller, a young professor at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, was sitting in the back of a classroom, auditing a lecture by a colleague, Franco Modigliani, when Dr. Modigliani started to discuss issues Dr. Miller had been trying to investigate.
''I had collected some data,'' Dr. Miller recounts, ''but had no theory to serve as a framework, and he had some theory.''
The two professors had adjoining offices and were soon exploring the topic in daily discussions. Their first pioneering paper appeared a few months later, and took them a distance from their starting point. Pushing aside debt and stock outstanding as the key to a corporation's value, they concluded that what really counted were the skills of a company's managers and how much cash plants and equipment generate.
Such a conclusion might seem obvious today, notes Dr. Miller, who is now 67, but in 1958 - when companies seemed to earn money without great regard to operating strategy - the Miller-Modigliani thesis was counterintuitive and produced enormous debate.
The son of a Boston lawyer, Dr. Miller graduated from Harvard University in 1944, worked as a tax expert at the Treasury Department and enrolled at John Hopkins University to earn a Ph.D. in economics.
He went on to Carnegie-Mellon, and eight years later, in 1961, moved to his present post. In Chicago, he has emerged in a new role - as a consultant and director of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and a staunch defender of the exchange's trading in stock-index futures.
 
William F. Sharpe
Stanford University
The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science comes to William F. Sharpe when he is more or less retired from teaching but, at age 56, very much engaged in practicing the theories for which he was honored yesterday.
Dr. Sharpe had elaborated on the earlier work of his mentor, Harry Markowitz, who also won a Nobel yesterday. While Dr. Markowitz focused on how investors evaluate risk and reward in trading portfolios, Dr. Sharpe explained how markets actually moved as investors made their decisions.
Today, as the chief executive of William F. Sharpe Associates - his wife, Kathryn, is the administrator -he applies his findings as a consultant to various pension funds.
Dr. Sharpe was a 27-year-old Ph.D. candidate at the University of California at Los Angeles, working on the side at the Rand Corporation, when he first met Dr. Markowitz, a fellow Rand employee. The entrepreneurial Dr. Sharpe persuaded the economics department to let Dr. Markowitz be the mentor for his dissertation, although he was not connected with U.C.L.A.
Three years later, as a professor at the University of Washington in Seattle, Dr. Sharpe published the lengthy paper with the findings and conclusions, now known as the Capital Asset Pricing Model, for which he has won the Nobel.
From the University of Washington, Dr. Sharpe went briefly to the University of California at Irvine and in 1971 to Stanford University, where he is professor emeritus of finance. And through most of those years, he refined his original findings - although the 1987 stock market crash shook his confidence.
''My theory assumes that at any given time, market prices reflect investors' opinions of the future course of the economy,'' Mr. Sharpe said. ''The crash certainly raises serious questions about the efficiency of the markets.''

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Contrarian Bets On Soviet Future

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
THERE have been shortages from cigarettes to bread. The troubled Government is still seeking the right plan for a quick, but still painful, transition from the centrally run Communist economy to a market system. And the staying power of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, despite his Nobel Peace Prize, is in doubt.
But Batterymarch Financial Management, an investment management company known for the contrarian views of its founder, Dean LeBaron, still thinks this is the right time to bet as much as $1 billion on the future of emerging companies in the Soviet Union. So with an official backdrop provided by the auditorium of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations in New York, Mr. LeBaron and Vladimir F. Petrovsky, the Deputy Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union, announced the start of the Soviet Companies Fund yesterday. 
The fund, which will charge up to 2 percent in marketing and management fees, is the first such Soviet investment vehicle, Mr. LeBaron said. But the fund is also another in a growing list of approaches to the economic opportunities that promoters see in the Soviet Union and in Eastern and Central Europe. There have probably been more announcements than actual investments so far. And given the risks involved in ventures where both the governments and economies are moving into untraveled territory, all the investments face some real problems.
In the case of the Soviet Companies Fund, the initial investment appears to be an attractive way for a large corporation to get a small piece of the Soviet future. Unlike a joint venture, there is not the difficult process of choosing the right mate. But the longer-term bet is dicey. Getting the investment out depends on the development of a liquid Soviet stock market relatively quickly and an appetite for Soviet stocks both in the Soviet Union and abroad.
Mr. LeBaron acknowledges the risk but is not deterred. His answer sounds like a contrarian's mantra. ''Many good investments are made when there is public skepticism,'' he said. ''By the time the skepticism is gone, often the opportunity has passed. This is the contrarian idea.''
The fund, which hopes to raise $400 million to $1 billion, is only for big corporate investors who may have a long-term interest in joint ventures and want to have access to developing Soviet technology. The investors will be limited to 20 companies with a minimum investment of $20 million. Mr. LeBaron, who is beginning the solicitation process, is looking for investments from companies like Raytheon, Lockheed, Bechtel Power and others around the world.
The targets in the Soviet Union are the technologically advanced military contractors that are now beginning the transition to civilian and consumer production. Mr. Petrovsky said the Government wanted the conversion process to focus on food processing, retail trade and catering services, communications, including radio and televison broadcasting, civilian ships and aircraft and environmental protection. Mr. LeBaron is also interested in pharmaceuticals, chemicals, optics and the commercial use of space.
The fund, which would hold only 2 percent to 5 percent stakes in these Soviet companies, would not get the investing companies as involved in the Soviet Union as a joint venture. It would allow them to survey the opportunities in Soviet technology. With this introduction - and the knowledge gained through their part ownership - they could decide on joint ventures in the future.
After three years the Soviet Companies Fund would be dissolved, leaving the investing companies with the choice of holding their stock in the Soviet companies or selling out. But this could be difficult if the hoped for Soviet stock market is still underdeveloped and the Soviet ruble is still relatively unconvertible.
Mr. LeBaron said the money he raises would depend on the outlook for the new Soviet economic plan, which is being hammered out in Moscow right now, and the chances for convertibility of the ruble. The more uncertain the outlook, he added, the less he will be able to raise.
But he is not worried about convertibility or about the future of the stock market or the economic plan. ''We don't know the answer to those questions,'' he said. ''Nor do I want this fund to stop and do nothing until we do.'' In fact, he hopes that the fund itself will help force some answers to these questions sooner rather than later.
This comment points to the less-talked-about motive that many backers of such investments have. The Soviet-American flag pins in the lapels of the Americans at the news conference yesterday seemed to signal an extra commitment to the successful economic and political development of the glasnost and perestroika Mr. Gorbachev began. And Mr. LeBaron will probably have to find the same sympathy in his potential investors for the fund to be successful.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops by 35.15, Despite Late Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday as oil prices rose, but rallied slightly in the final 15 minutes on a report that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq might accept a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis.
After two days of gains that lifted the market 51 points, the Dow Jones industrial average slid 35.15, to 2,381.19, recovering a few points in the final quarter-hour. Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, said that heavy program selling knocked the Dow down close to 49 points.
Analysts and economists also began saying cautiously that the bear market could be coming to an end. 
''There's a major bull market going to unfold,'' said David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist for the investment firm of Jesup, Josephthal & Company, ''probably in 1991.'' He said he had advised clients ''to cut cash levels to the minimum and invest in high-quality bonds and stocks.'' Beginning of the End? ''You're looking at a wounded bear,'' said Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist for Brown Brothers, Harriman. ''The beginning of the end of a bear market comes when bond prices perform better than stocks, as they have since Sept. 25. That's generally the first step. The next requires greater investor confidence and that's the hang-up right now,'' Mr. Hill continued. ''They have to step up to the plate and buy stock.''
He argued that continuing uncertainty about the budget and the Iraqi crisis ''are holding people back,'' but that ''if we get a positive resolution on those, it'll be much easier for people to come in and buy.''
Trading volume slumped to 149.6 million shares, from 165 million Monday, as 1,077 shares dropped in price and an unsettling 276 fell to new lows. Only five touched new highs and 487, or less a fourth of the total, rose in price.
 
Near Certainty on Fed
Mr. Bostian of Jesup, Josephthal argued that ''it's almost certain that the Fed is going to ease monetary policy in a matter of days because a budget accord is expected in a matter of days.''
A budget agreement seemed close indeed. After the market closed, the White House said President Bush had canceled a trip to Cincinnati, were he was to attend the second World Series game, so that he could monitor the budget talks in Washington.
Mr. Bostian also said that ''the probabilities are fairly high that the Middle East crisis will be resolved in a month or so.''
''You can't be sure if it's war or peace,'' he said, ''but it's another positive because even if it's war, it could be decisive fairly quickly.''
As a result, he said, ''One should be focusing on the stock and bond market to rally in the near future.''
 
No 'Follow-Through'
But Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures for Shearson, Lehman Brothers, said: ''In the last six weeks, there hasn't been a rally where the market's been up more than twice in a row. That means there's no follow-through. Traders can't get any conviction that we've seen the lows for the year.''
In a sign, however, that traders were prepared to believe good news from almost anywhere, the stock market turned up a bit in the last 15 minutes - after four hours of weakness - when a news report from Bonn said Iraq might be willing to accept mediation to end the gulf crisis.
The report said reporters had gotten that impression after interviewing Dieter Schinzel, a German deputy in the European Parliament and a member of the opposition Social Democrat Party.
 
Busy Day for Shorts
Earlier in the day, crude oil declined, bonds rallied and stocks followed. Speculators who had sold short rushed to buy back stock before it rose further. When the rally faded, the short sellers sold stock short again, driving down the market.
By the end of the session, crude rose 94 cents a barrel, to $38.89; bonds rose sharply, yields on 30-year bonds fell to 8.88 percent, and stocks stood 619 points, or 21 percent, away from their all-time high in mid-July.
Amid concern about the state of many American banks, Citicorp, the biggest banking company, topped the Big Board active list falling 1 1/8, to 13, with 3.6 million shares changing hands. It said third-quarter earnings per share fell 43 percent largely because of provisions for poor real estate loans.
Nynex, the phone company, fell 3 7/8, to 72 7/8, after administrative judges of the New York Public Service Commission recommended smaller rate increases than it had requested.
General Electric reported a small rise in profits but the stock fell 2 7/8, to 51 1/2, on concern about future quarters. PPG Industries, the glass and chemicals company, fell 3 3/4, to 34 5/8, after a new low of 34 1/2.
Student Loan Marketing, known as Sallie Mae, fell 6 5/8, to 36 1/2, in heavy trading. The F.B.I. said it was investigating allegations that Sallie Mae bought canceled loans to inflate its assets; Sallie Mae called the charges, from two former employees, ''without merit.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Late Rally Lifts Treasury Issues

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A late rally pushed up prices of Treasury securities and moved interest rates lower at the end of a generally slow session yesterday.
Traders said the spurt had much to do with yesterday's slide in stock prices, particularly bank stocks. To credit market participants, the drop in the price of bank shares, prompted in large part by weak third-quarter earnings, gave added weight to comments made earlier in the day by Martha Seger, a Federal Reserve Board Governor.
Speaking in Washington, Ms. Seger said that the Fed's move in July to lower interest rates had not completely offset the tightening of credit conditions in the financial sector. 
Traders interpreted those comments as suggesting that Ms. Seger and others at the Fed favor moving interest rates lower now rather than waiting for a budget package to be approved by Congress and the President.
''The argument about the fragility of the financial system gained some credence after the bank earnings came out,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''That caused some portfolio managers to buy some bonds.''
The fact that budget votes in both the House and Senate appeared likely last night, signs that the process is moving forward, also helped the bond market, participants said.
 
Further Drop in Gold Price
Prices were also helped by a further drop in gold prices and more Middle East peace rumors.
A sharp drop in the dollar, which fell to new lows against the German mark, and a rise in oil prices contributed to a drop in prices early in the session. But those negative factors were largely forgotten as the day wore on.
Traders and analysts said they did not attach much significance to yesterday's price action.
''The market is frozen, and the Fed is frozen'' until something happens in the Middle East or on the budget in Washington, said Kristen Foster, a financial market economist at Citicorp Investment Bank.
Under current circumstances, ''positions in short-term securities look pretty safe,'' Ms. Foster said, ''because the likelihood of a rise in short-term rates is very low. But the long end is a very scary place to be because of what could happen in the Middle East and on the budget front.''
 
Bonds Post Biggest Gains
Despite those risks, bond prices posted the biggest gains.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 98 19/32, up 1/2 point, or $5 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.88 percent. Late Monday, the bellwether issue was offered at a price to yield 8.93 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/32 late yesterday, up 1/4 point, to yield 8.73 percent. And the price of the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes rose by 1/8 point, to 100 17/32, to yield 8.35 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.15 percent, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bills fell by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.18 percent.
During the afternoon, the Treasury said that if a budget was passed in time it intends to increase the size of next week's bill auction to a record $19.2 billion, from $18.8 billion.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by a competitive sale of $327 million bonds for the Florida State Board of Education.
A bid from a group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets won the issue, which consists of serial and term bonds.
Maturities on the serial bonds run from 1990 to 2013, with coupons ranging from 5.90 percent to 7.40 percent in 2013.
A term bond maturing in 2020 carries a coupon of 7.45 percent.
The securities are rated AA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said that the increasing likelihood of Federal tax rises and a trickle of new tax-exempt issues helped to push up prices of most widely quoted bonds by about 1/4 point.
Traders in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues were unchanged to up about 1/4 point in very thin trading.
The drop in stock prices had little adverse impact in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market, participants said. Prices of most issues dipped by 1/4 point to 3/8 point in slow trading.
''People were not motivated to be aggressive buyers or sellers'' yesterday, one trader said.

HEADLINE: Revenue Bonds For Illinois Project

 BODY:
The Village of Hoffman Estates in Cook and Kane Counties in Illinois has tentatively priced $111.5 million in tax-increment revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The financing, for a Hoffman Estates economic development project, is backed by a letter of credit issued by the Union Bank of Switzerland through its Chicago branch office. The letter supporting the financing is good for seven years.
For serial bonds with shorter maturities in the pricing, yields range from 6.50 percent due in 1994 to 7.35 percent in 2000 and 7.65 percent in 2003. Investors interested in a longer maturity were offered a 7.625 percent bond due in 2009 priced at about 97.306, to yield 7.90 percent.
Because of the letter of credit, underwriters expect the issue to be rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Low Against Mark; Strength Is Shown by Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar sank on foreign exchange markets yesterday, reaching new lows against the German mark and tumbling against the Japanese yen.
Traders cited economic difficulties in the United States as the reason for the dollar's slide. They pointed in particular to the Government report on housing starts expected today and tomorrow's report on September consumer prices, which are expected to show a further economic weakening and higher inflation. 
The dollar has been under a strain in recent weeks amid speculation that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates to revive a slowing economy, a development that would make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors.
Tim Barton, an assistant vice president at the Chicago-based Harris Trust and Savings Bank, said the dollar ''doesn't seem to have much of a bounce,'' and that there are no signs of a willingness to step in and support the currency.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell in New York to a new low of 1.5115 marks, down from 1.5262. That was its lowest level since the mark was created in 1948.
In New York, the dollar slid to its lowest point since January of 1989, settling at 126.79 yen, down from 127.73 yen on Monday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar had fallen 0.10 yen, to a closing 128.05 yen. In London, it was quoted at 127.20 yen.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9575, compared with $1.9545 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.9655 to buy 1, more expensive than Monday's $1.9498.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.2770 Swiss francs, down from 1.2905; 5.0660 French francs, down from 5.1120; 1,132.75 Italian lire, down from 1,143.00, and 1.1564 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1540.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.2780 Swiss francs, down from 1.2870; 5.0732 French francs, down from 5.1035; 1.7070 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7165; 1,134.25 Italian lire, down from 1,141.50, and 1.1551 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1520.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Plummet Again On Mine Companies' Woes

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Gold prices dropped again yesterday, with the latest burst of selling attributed largely to mining companies that are selling future bullion output because of their increasing inability to obtain bank financing.
At the close on the Commodity Exchange in New York, the major gold and silver futures market, the spot October gold delivery settled at $362 an ounce, down $13 on the day. This returned the price of gold to where it was before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 sent precious metal prices soaring. 
Other futures contracts, including grains, oilseeds, livestock and coffee, also declined. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of futures prices, a barometer of inflation and general economic trends, continued to fall. Despite rising oil and byproduct costs, the index of 21 basic farm and industrial commodities slipped 1.18, to 230.92 - with 100 equal to the index in 1967.
It was the index's lowest level since July 20, when it stood at 230.30, reflecting excellent crop prospects, declining industrial demand for raw materials and weak energy prices. But it turned upward after the run-up in oil prices from the Middle Eastern crisis renewed inflation fears.
Unsubstantiated rumors that banks are having difficulty collecting on outstanding loans to domestic and foreign gold producers also weighed on the silver and platinum markets.
''With shares in gold mining companies falling with bullion prices and many banks facing their own liquidity problems, we expect that many cash-short producers will be forced to sell or swap anticipated output for cash,'' said William B. O'Neill, senior futures market strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures Inc.
Steven J. Pepper, senior vice president at the Republic National Bank of New York, said bids for gold had been reduced overnight in foreign markets, mainly as Monday's drop of $12.50 an ounce in New York inspired selling in those markets.
''The market appeared to stabilize when we opened our books about 7:30 this morning,'' Mr. Pepper said. ''Then the bids for gold began to shrink. To make matters worse, the commodity funds began unloading metals in the last 45 minutes of Comex trading.''
Comex spot October silver closed at $4.142 an ounce, up a cent on what dealers said was hedge buying by some gold traders.
But the spot October platinum contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange dropped a further $5.60 an ounce, to $388.50, bringing the two-day loss to $28.40.

HEADLINE: Profits Up at Microsoft and Down at Lotus

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation today reported strong gains in revenues and earnings, while the Lotus Development Corporation reported declining earnings on essentially flat sales, which it attributed to upgrading its most popular product.
The company's stocks moved in seemingly unexpected directions. Microsoft shares closed at $54.625, down $1.875, in heavy over-the-counter trading, while Lotus gained $1.625, to $14.375. 
The price of Lotus was apparently helped by two company announcements. Lotus said it expected a big increase in profits in the fourth quarter and it planned to repurchase up to five million shares of its outstanding common stock, or approximately 12 percent of its 43 million shares outstanding.
Commenting on the market's negative reaction to Microsoft's positive results, David Readerman, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in San Francisco, said: ''No one believes the 'e' in earnings-per-share growth stories anymore. People are questioning what personal computer growth rates will be next year.''
For its third quarter ended Sept. 30, Microsoft reported earnings of $87.6 million, or 71 cents a share, up 76 percent from $49.6 million, or 43 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 57 percent, to $369.4 million, from $235.2 million in the third quarter of 1989.
''We were particularly pleased with the strong demand for Windows 3.0 and applications products for the Windows 3.0 environment during the quarter,'' Michael Hallman, Microsoft's president and chief operating officer, said in a statement. Windows 3.0 is a software program that gives I.B.M.-compatible PC's much of the ease of use of Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh.
Lotus reported third-quarter earnings of $8.6 million, or 20 cents a share, less than half the $23 million, or 54 cents a share, it earned in the comparable period last year. Revenues rose 2 percent, to $157.4 million, from $153.9 million in the third quarter of 1989.
''While the quarter was negatively affected by the transition to 1-2-3 Release 3.1 from 3.0, we are encouraged by initial marketplace response to the product,'' Jim Manzi, the president and chief executive of Lotus, said in a statement.
Should sales of 1-2-3 Release 3.1, the latest version of the company's accounting spreadsheet software, remain strong, and barring a major downturn in the economy, Lotus expects a significant increase in its profitability in the fourth quarter, the company said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Top Executive Ousted At New Haven Register

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The top executive at The New Haven Register was dismissed Monday night by the paper's owner, the Journal Register Company, after he resisted the second round of layoffs in a month, reportedly on the ground that they would seriously damage the newspaper.
Journal Register is a holding company owned by E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, a New York investment company that was in partnership with Ralph Ingersoll Jr. until they divided their newspapers earlier this year. The Register and the other Ingersoll papers in the United States went to Warburg while Mr. Ingersoll kept the British papers. 
Robert M. Jelenic, president of Journal Register, based in Princeton, N.J., said the layoffs were ''just prudent business'' prompted by declining revenues. He said he the paper would not be seriously hurt.
''The paper is very strong,'' Mr. Jelenic said.
Thomas P. Geyer, who was dismissed by Mr. Jelenic as The Register's chief executive, declined to discuss his opposition to the layoffs.
But a Register executive who spoke on condition of anonymity said that Mr. Geyer had expressed concern that the paper's news coverage in the suburbs and ability to maintain the paper's delivery standards were in jeopardy.
The executive said Mr. Geyer had also felt that The Register was being forced to generate excessive profits to provide money to meet debt payments on about $200 million owed from the paper's purchase. Last year, Mr. Ingersoll and Warburg paid Mark Goodson, the game show entrepreneur, a reported $245 million for The Register, which was considered a huge price at a time when New England was in an economic slump.
Mr. Jelenic said the debt, which he declined to quantify, had played no role in his decision to order 31 layoffs yesterday and 19 on Oct. 3.
David J. Butler, editor of The Register, said that nine full-time members of the news staff and one freelancer were laid off yesterday, and nine full-time and two part-time members of the news staff were laid off Oct. 3. At the end of 1988, when the New Haven economy was booming, the news staff was 151; it is now 108.
''I don't think the layoffs jeopardize the news coverage, but they hurt news coverage somewhat,'' said Mr. Butler, who added that such projects as the study of race relations in New Haven were the kind of luxuries that would have to be sacrificed.
The Register has circulation of 105,000 daily and 140,000 Sunday, the Audit Bureau of Circulations says.
Mr. Goodson bought The Register in 1986 for about $185 million. Mr. Ingersoll had a longstanding agreement to manage Mr. Goodson's papers. Mr. Geyer, who was the top operating officer for all Ingersoll papers, decided to concentrate on The Register.

HEADLINE: Mr. Dinkins Faces Fiscal Reality

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins and his advisers have finally awakened to reality. By ordering New York City agencies to plan for cuts of more than $1 billion, they are beginning to acknowledge the depth of the city's economic problems. At the same time, though, City Hall has saddled itself with an imprudent labor settlement that urgently needs to be modified.
The settlement reached with the teachers' union for a 5.5 percent salary increase is not only too generous; it forces other union leaders to demand equivalent deals. As the new service cuts so starkly dramatize, the city cannot afford increases like that. To demand sacrifice from the public, while giving generous pay increases to municipal workers, amounts to paying for those increases with cuts in city services.
As worthy as teachers are of raises, the settlement with the United Federation of Teachers was a mistake. The city can avoid compounding it now by rolling back all or part of the contract, and by slowing down its negotiations with the other unions.
The Board of Education, scheduled to vote on the contract next Wednesday, can delay that vote at least until the city modifies its financial plan early next month. In the interim, the city can get an independent analysis of a questionable part of the contract - the plan to reduce the city's contribution to its teacher pension fund by changing the fund's earnings assumption. The savings are supposed to pay for 2.5 points of the raise. Moreover, if the city can save on its pension contribution, the money could do more good going into the city treasury - and reducing service cuts for all New Yorkers.
The next several days of labor negotiations could be crucial to the city's financial future. If other unions get settlements equivalent to the U.F.T. contract, the new service cuts will barely begin to deal with the cost. The more the unions get, the more the Dinkins administration will have to cut programs and tax the public. In fact, with the economy worsening, there's a good chance that the city will have to lay off members of the very same unions that are on the verge of getting raises.
Finally, fortunately, the Dinkins administration is starting to show some common sense. If it continues, by slowing down its labor negotiations and doing whatever possible to roll back the U.F.T. contract, New York may yet be able to respond to fiscal strain reasonably and not ruinously.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sealift Deficiencies Exposed in Gulf Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The crisis in the Middle East has generated renewed criticism of United States maritime policy (or lack of it) as evidenced by the paucity of useful U.S.-flag sealift capacity to move an American expeditionary force and its materiel overseas, and the consequent reliance on foreign tonnage to do the job.
In early August, at the outset of the White House response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, United States maritime unions were told to bend every effort to man the ships that were to be broken out of reserve to supply a field army in Saudi Arabia. Some 40 or more of these ships were activated and manned by seagoing union personnel.
The unions were also told to be prepared to man additional vessels on short notice, to scour the waterfront for qualified people, even to recruit pensioned seamen who were physically capable of cutting it at sea. The union response, as in past conflicts, was prompt and effective.
But few additional ships have materialized as the Navy has judged the reserve fleet inventory unequal to the task. These ships, many of World War II vintage, are slow, mechanically unreliable, rigged with archaic cargo gear and generally ill suited to rapid deployment to destinations of opportunity. Senator Ernest Hollings, chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, said last month that so many reserve fleet vessels were forced into Spanish ports after the Atlantic crossing that ''it looked like we were invading Spain.''
Rather than resort to these reserve fleet relics, the Navy culled American and foreign merchant fleets to find more suitable tonnage and found few U.S. vessels that could be diverted to military supply without disrupting essential commercial operations. The neglect of our ''fourth arm of defense'' over the years has left the remaining U.S. operators with a minimum number of vessels to service their trade routes. Result: the U.S. is forced to rely on foreign countries to supply its armed forces.
The Navy's Military Sealift Command said last month that 35 of the 50 ships thus far chartered to the sealift are flying foreign flags. The ''ship of choice'' for Operation Desert Shield is the roll-on, roll-off vessel. All 17 of this type vessel in the reserve fleet have been activated and the Navy has had to look abroad for additional tonnage. This problem will become more acute as the Kuwaiti stalemate continues or escalates.
Repeated admonition to the Administration and Congress has failed to stem the erosion of America's maritime base priorities. Farm and other vested interests have fought all attempts to regain America's historical status as a major sea power. Such self-serving tactics place the national security in most serious jeopardy; endorsement of this distorted triage is tantamount to a dereliction of duty in those who are sworn to ''provide for the common defense.''
Ignoring history's lessons carries its much-vaunted peril, of course, but there is no law of man or nature that says we absolutely must repeat our mistakes. ''The obvious point,'' said Robert W. Kesteloot, a former Navy official, ''is that if we had a robust U.S.-flag merchant marine, we would not have to rely on foreign shipping as we are currently forced to do.''
This self-evident position is being echoed through a wide spectrum of the national forum as renewed debate on the sealift has been triggered by the shortcomings made manifest in the Persian Gulf crisis.
A ready reserve fleet in activeservice, out at sea, contributing to America's economy as well as its defense, is far preferable to a muster of ancient hulks gathering rust and expense in some maritime boneyard.
A United States-flag reserve fleet, chartered and operated by American steamship companies, manned by American seamen and hauling a far greater share of American cargo than the ''normal'' 3 or 4 percent, would be a viable asset to the country, able to discharge its military obligations in times of emergency, reduce the enormous United States balance-of-payments deficit, provide employment for its citizens, and once again show the flag around the world.
 
GUNNAR LUNDEBERG
Pres., Sailors' Union of the Pacific
 San Francisco, Oct. 3, 1990

HEADLINE: Why Puerto Ricans Want Statehood

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A House panel's approval of a bill authorizing a referendum on Puerto Rico's status (news article, Sept. 28) correctly states that Puerto Ricans on the island now favor statehood. It was indicated that ''statehood at this point appears to be preferred, primarily because it would mean greater economic aid for the island's residents and give Puerto Ricans, who already have United States citizenship, full political representation . . .''
True, dissatisfaction with colonial status is behind the preference for statehood. But the prospect of more government aid has not played a major role. A poll conducted by Dr. Frank I. Luntz & Associates and sponsored by El Mundo newspaper and Channel 40 of Puerto Rico proves the point. Puerto Ricans were asked to rank seven issues related to the upcoming referendum in order of importance to them. ''More assistance from the Federal Government'' ranked last. The issue that ranked first had to do with which status ''would provide more employment opportunities.'' The right to vote for President and Congress ranked a close second.
Your article is one of several that have cited an increase in financial aid as the main reason Puerto Ricans prefer statehood. The value Puerto Ricans attach to their attainment of greater job opportunities has been glossed over or missed altogether. This is not a trivial fact. Puerto Ricans are the poorest minority in the United States, and many have taken this to mean we do not have a strong work ethic.
The poll findings suggest that to conclude Puerto Ricans are the poorest group in the United States because we are ''lazy'' is simplistic and unfair. Other groups are more successful at least partly because they do not find themselves affected by the same complex interaction of historical, social, political and economic factors in which we find ourselves embedded.
Statehood means two main things: (1) more employment opportunities and (2) the end of 500 years of colonialism.
 
GILBERTO PAGAN
 Colonia, N.J., Sept. 28, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Tax Or Spend?

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
These are glory days for American democracy. Congress is in an uproar, the wavering White House is acquiring a new sense of direction, and the American voter may soon be treated to a real campaign.
The Democrats are acting like old-fashioned Democrats. ''Soak the rich'' - a phrase born in 1934 to blast F.D.R.'s embrace of Huey Long populism - is the new battle cry of suddenly unabashed liberals.
Having suckered President Bush into abandoning his no-tax firewall, Democrats have shifted the focus of the budget debate away from spending and onto the source of more taxes.
They call this ''the fairness issue.'' A central tenet of liberalism is government's guarantee that everyone, working or not, needy or not, is entitled to what politicians decide is a fair share of what the nation produces.
Republicans traditionally grumble that this classic, straightforward demagoguery encourages ''class warfare,'' turning rich against poor. They get defensive when charged with standing for vested property interests by opponents who claim to belong to ''the party of the people.''
But these self-conscious conservatives miss the point of politics in an age of affluence. The fairness issue has been turned on its head. Most people think of themselves as closer to being rich than to being poor, and consider it unfair to carry all those unproductive others on their backs.
When these more-rich-than-poor Americans utter such sentiments, old-fashioned liberals deride them not only for being selfish but racist to boot. This swells the ranks of conservatives, because most voters are not so motivated and resent politicians who make them feel guilty.
Therefore, Republicans should not fear class warfare; the almost-rich far outnumber the almost-poor, and most of the people in the middle tend to identify with the almost-rich, whom they want to become.
Moreover, most people now know that the target of taxers has to be the middle-class pocket; squeezing the richies may be egalitarian fun but is not where the big money is.
What happens if you surtax millionaire incomes by 10 percent and add a 10 percent tax on furs, boats and jewelry, as the House liberals suggested? The budget deficit might be reduced by 2 percent, not counting the losses to the Treasury of taxes from people prevented from selling luxury items.
The hidden tax increase in that liberal budget proposal is to reinstate ''tax bracket creep'' - using inflation to automatically increase tax rates. That's $36 billion out of middle-class pockets for one year's creep; prevent indexing for five years, as would surely follow, and you achieve the liberal dream of ''fairness'' - redistributing income on a grand scale.
The Republican President, chastened by a whopping drop in support after waffling on the central promise of his campaign, says he would veto that bill. That fat and easy target will never reach his desk; Senate Democrats are taking a slightly more sober route of taxing booze and gas.
But whatever budget the Democratic Congress passes, its philosophical approach to the deficit will be new taxes in this ''in'' year and pious promises of reduced rates of spending in the ''out'' years. Tax now, cut spending later.
This liberal approach will pass over the objections of most of the Republican minority in Congress. Such dissent is healthy; if it means that the Government shuts nonessential services for a while, that will dramatize the depth of disagreement and bring the voters to the polls.
The only way the minority will become a majority is to draw an issue of principle. Within the Administration, Mr. Bush's Stolypin, Jack Kemp, soldiers on in loyal silence, but in Congress, the Republican minority must hold the Bob Packwood line on tax rates and align itself with the majority opinion in the nation. Where will it all end? Isn't compromise the name of the game? The game's name is political purpose. Compromise should be struck after the will of the people has been expressed. Let Mr. Bush veto the taxation budget, let the Republicans uphold the veto, and let us use this election as a referendum on taxing vs. spending.
The current impasse is no cause for national embarrassment; on the contrary, it is the overdue surfacing of basic political difference.
A closed-down Government on Election Day would bring out anti-incumbent voters in force. Candidates, take your positions: tax and service reductions vs. tax and service increases. Duck that in your spots and feel the voter heat.
