HEADLINE: For Adobe, Whether Humble or Fashionable, It's Mud to Mud

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS CRUCES, N.M., Oct. 15

 BODY:
It is the odd paradox of adobe that it serves at once as the fashionable choice of shelter for the rich in the American Southwest and as the promise for housing the poor in the third world. Common mud, or ''earthen architecture,'' to use the stiffer technical term, has come to the fore again as architects march backward in time in search of style and shelter.
An increasingly urgent question is how to preserve the relics of this primitive form of shelter, which grows so gracefully out of the earth from which it was dug, but which also melts when it rains, cracks when it heats and cools, flakes in the wind and shudders when the earth quakes.
Santa Fe sophisticates aside, more than 30 percent of the world's people still live in earthen homes, said Neville Agnew, scientific program director at the Getty Conservation Institute in Marina del Rey, Calif. The institute is a sponsor of the Sixth International Conference on the Conservation of Earthen Architecture here this week.
Not a few of the more than 300 participants who came from about 30 countries were surprised to learn from Richard Pieper, a New York architect, that many 19th-century homes in rainy upstate New York are really nothing more than bricks of mud beneath Greek Revival and Gothic Revival wooden skins.
That these houses could survive so long in such a hostile clime serves to underscore the versatility and durability of earthen architecture, often scorned in this and other parts of the world as a sign of poverty. But a new appreciation for its advantages over cement and wood is emerging: with foot-thick walls, an earthen home acts as a thermal stabilizer, damping daily temperature swings by keeping the warmth of the day at night and the cool of the night during the day.
Indeed adobe construction, which dates back 10,000 years, may serve mankind for centuries to come. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, looking forward to human colonization of the moon, has considered building structures there by filling bags with moon rocks and dust, and stacking them up.
For now, though, the economic crisis in poorer nations has drawn attention to mud. ''The housing problems of the Third World are such that we cannot ignore any technology,'' said Hugo Houben, a Belgian who is vice president of the International Center for Earth Construction in Grenoble, France. ''How are we going to build thousands of classrooms and hospitals?'' he said. ''We have got to revitalize local know-how and use it.''
It seemed both incongruous and fitting to hold the Adobe 90 conference in New Mexico, where multimillionaires live in splendid adobe-style mansions in Santa Fe only a few miles from primitive Pueblo Indian adobes that are still occupied nearly a millennium after their construction.
More than 500,000 Americans lived in 176,000 adobe homes in 1980, according to census figures, mostly in New Mexico, Texas, Arizona and California. About 1,500 new adobes are built annually. Given the labor involved, it is cheaper in this country to build a conventional home, but in drier parts of Africa, Asia and South America, mud is the cheapest and perhaps the only option for shelter.
Adobe is made by mixing clay, sand and silt and forming the mixture into bricks, which dry hard in the sun. In some countries the preferred technique is rammed earth, in which the mud mixture is piled into a wooden form that is removed when the mud is dry. In a third method, called puddling, layer upon layer of mud is applied by hand.
Sun-baked bricks are used in the American Southwest; asphalt or chemicals may be added to stabilize the mud. Sometimes straw is added to bind the mud and promote drying.
Adobes need much attention, especially after rains, but they hold up well if the roof and foundation are good. ''All it needs is a good hat and a good pair of shoes,'' said Paul G. McHenry Jr., an architect in Albuquerque.
But matters are far more complex when it comes to preserving archeological remains, all the more so because many earthen landmarks are still occupied. The ravages of time and neglect can be seen just 20 miles north of here in the remains of Fort Selden, a 19th-century Army outpost set in a clump of cottonwoods in the Mesilla Valley. The walls have crumbled, and only the outlines of the encampment can be discerned.
Nearby, 64 slabs of adobe stand on the parched desert floor like rows of ancient Mayan steles. They are part of two experiments in adobe conservation. On one side, Michael R. Taylor, an archeologist with the National Park Service, is trying different coatings, caps and foundations on 13 walls built five years ago, comparing their resistance to the elements with the resistance of a ''control'' wall that has had no special protection or treatment - ''amendments,'' as they say in the adobe game. These techniques are being explored as ways of preserving historic adobe buildings, but they might eventually be found useful in new construction.
Mr. Taylor has found, for example, that it does not help to top a wall with a cap of regular bricks overhanging the sides. A cap but serves only to dribble rainwater right into the mud, badly eroding the upper part.
Another concern is water entering from below by capillary action. No concrete apron or foundation has worked, Mr. Taylor said. ''We have not come up with anything better than keeping the water away with a good slope away from the walls.''
Nearby is a more elaborate experiment started two years ago by the Getty institute. Lined up in three rows, 51 test walls are subjected to a variety of stresses including spraying and wind. Each wall has a different protection, like a chemical treatment or a textile canopy, except for one control wall of adobe.
Mr. Agnew of the Getty institute said that injecting either of two chemicals into the walls proved highly effective in consolidating the adobe and retarding decay. These are alkylalkoxysilanes, similar to bathtub caulking, and diisocyanates, used in the manufacture of certain paints. These chemicals react with moisture and bind to the clay.
One of the test walls stands under a tentlike structure made of a special synthetic knitted cloth, dun colored to match the desert, originally developed for horticulture. The wall under this ''aerotextile'' will be examined for wear over the next year or so.
Another approach to preservation is to rebury excavated structures, so Mr. Agnew is also testing ''geotextiles'' to wrap around archeological materials to protect them from moisture, roots and insects until they are dug up again for study.
But debate rages among experts over the use of chemical or other irreversible preservation methods on archeological sites. ''To experiment on an object is a very serious thing; you can totally destroy it,'' said Alejandro Alva Balderrama, an architect with the International Center for the Study of the Restoration and Conservation of Cultural Property, an international agency in Rome.
He cited the case of earthen remains at Gela, in Sicily, that were destroyed because a plastic tent put up to protect them created an unexpected microclimate. He and other experts favor regular maintenance, by which new mud plaster is applied to shore up decaying structures.
Mr. Agnew of the Getty institute strongly dissents. Regular maintenance for occupied earthen structures like the casbahs of North Africa is appropriate, he argues, but not for abandoned old sites. ''After 100 years of mud repair, you don't have a historic object anymore,'' he says. ''If you can find the right chemical, combined with shelter, you can minimize damange to the historic fabric.''
If chemical treatments to preserve ancient earthen architecture are controversial, such constraints do not apply to new construction. The rub here is money. Mr. Houben of the Center for Earth Construction in Grenoble helps developing countries build housing. Mud and labor are cheap in those countries, but they cannot afford the stablizing chemicals. They must turn to local resources and know-how, he said, adding, ''What we stabilize with is gray matter, not cement.''

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Presidential Popularity And the Role Of the Media

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
When a President's popularity goes into decline, he is not likely to blame either himself or the abstraction that politicians in their pious mood call ''the American People.'' To blame oneself, besides being hard on the ego, means giving grist to the opposition; to blame the American People may signify a death wish. So who does one blame? Why, naturally, the media, by which is mainly meant television.
In the interpretation that Vice President Dan Quayle advanced last Sunday on ''Face the Nation,'' as he was ducking Lesley Stahl's questions about Mr. Bush's changeability on the budget, much of the Administration's problem can be traced to the way Washington correspondents have been reporting the story; if only they got it right, the American People would understand that the President is consistency itself with no special solicitude for the rich.
How much of the blame or credit has television earned for the President's slippage? Not, in this viewer's estimate, all that much. Despite the reputation for liberal leanings of journalists in Washington and New York, they have proven themselves willing to pick on all residents of the White House, whatever the party label. (If John F. Kennedy got off easy, he owed it more to his camera-friendly style than to his politics.) Skepticism is in the nature of the job, and the President exists to be the national target for praise and censure. More often than not, however, journalists, like politicians, take their lead from the public. They pick up on inchoate dissatisfactions and then feed them back in a form that both confirms and exacerbates.
In the two issues that are now confounding the nation - the standoff on the budget and the facedown in the Middle East - television news was far from hasty in criticizing the White House. Quite the contrary. In the first days and weeks of the movement of American troops into Saudi Arabia, the emphasis was all on the nastiness of Saddam Hussein and Washington's brilliant success in rallying so many members of the United Nations against him. Mr. Bush was the hero of the hour, although he did not share credit with the media for his good marks in the polls.
The camera's concentration on the young Americans in the desert may have subdued public enthusiasm by bringing home to viewers the realization that these fresh-faced soldiers would be the first to die should war break out. But it was inevitable that as the weeks wore on, support for the exercise would wear down, and questions that went unasked in the first flush of patriotism would be heard. Officials on talk shows, compelled to react to inklings of impatience, as well as to President Hussein's threats of destruction, boasts of defiance, hints of compromise, began to seem vague and wishful.
It was also the President's bad luck that the effects of America's deployment in the Gulf were felt instantly in the form of higher gasoline prices. Here was another story that was made for television. Day after day, the news cameras were directed at the ever-rising figures on the pumps. Could the prices have gone up any faster, some viewers must have begun asking, if Iraq had been left to take over Kuwait? Was Kuwait worth $10 or $20 a week? Soon, the television stories about the misfortunes of Kuwaitis began to be accompanied by stories about the wealth and power of the country's ruling family.
To Mr. Bush's further misfortune, the already worrisome economic outlook, darkened by uncertainty in the Middle East, was brought to the center of attention by the budget fiasco. But here again, the television news programs and talk shows by no means leaped on the President early in the process. The negotiations were so secretive, the politicians so reticent that correspondents had trouble getting a line on what was happening; there was not much disposition to lay blame on anyone.
It was only after the weeks of negotiating came to nothing and the public exploded that network newshounds scented blood and headed yelping toward the White House. These days, anchors and correspondents permit themselves to refer to the President's flipflopping as an accepted fact rather than attributing it to some Democrat. Television started nothing, but it picked up fast on the national mood, just like the Democrats in Congress. That comes naturally to a mass medium, which is nourished by its umbilical link to its audience.
So to get back to those polls, Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle are kidding themselves if they think they have been cooked by the tube. The television tube is a great reflector that catches the nation's passions and sends them back in brighter and hotter hues. Should a deal be struck on the budget or with Iraq, the President's curve will doubtless go up again, and he can count on being treated better on the airwaves.
The criticisms of the budget finaglings now heard on television and the developing sense of unease over Iraq in the nightly reports may have taken away a couple of points from the President's popularity, but for the root of the decline, he will have to look to the real world, to his own actions and to the American People.

HEADLINE: On the Fiscal Stage, Rohatyn's Star Dims Among His Old Fans

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
In New York City, certain word associations are inevitable: bagels, lox; Russian, Tea Room; fiscal crisis, Felix G. Rohatyn. As the city once again faces economic hard times, the eminent investment banker's predictions (dire) and remedies (bitter) have returned him to center stage. As one former City Hall official put it, somewhat sourly, ''The cat is back.''
But the man who once helped save the city from financial ruin is discovering that 1990 is not 1975. Some of the same people who turned to him in that crisis are now turning against him.
Yesterday he announced plans to resign at year's end as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. The corporation, a state watchdog agency established during the fiscal crisis to issue bonds on the city's behalf, was his platform for critiques of the city's financial strategy for the last 15 years. But now, he said, he is concerned that his persona has become too prominent in contract negotiations between the city and its unions. 
''By personalizing this thing, it gives people an excuse not to face reality,'' he said. ''It's not the unions vs. Felix Rohatyn, it's the unions versus the reality of the city's condition.''
Mr. Rohatyn left open the possibility that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo could persuade him to stay after the new year. ''He could lock me in a room,'' Mr. Rohatyn said, ''but all things being equal, my intention is to get out.''
Mr. Cuomo said yesterday, ''If I win on Nov. 6, I will go to him and say, 'Please stay.' ''
Mayor David N. Dinkins said that Mr. Rohatyn's departure was up to Mr. Rohatyn and the Governor, but that he expected Mr. Rohatyn to remain an adviser to his administration.
Mr. Rohatyn said the criticism by his sometime allies helped persuade him to announce his departure.
Where he once found esteem, he now finds silence, or worse. Mr. Dinkins has politely thanked him for his advice and then ignored it. Labor leaders have labeled him ''the enemy.''
Mr. Rohatyn, who has been critical of the city's handling of a financial crunch he anticipated more than a year ago and calls far more serious than that of 1975, finds himself cast no longer as mediator, problem-solver and disinterested statesman, but as the leading adversary of labor and City Hall. He does not like it. ''People get angry, and say 'Who the hell are you to tell us this, you're just wishing for a crisis so you can be back on the front page of The New York Times,' '' he said. ''I find that disconcerting.''
But Mr. Rohatyn is clearly not entirely comfortable with the prospect of leaving a platform that helped transform him from banker to leading public policy sage.
 
'Not Going to Retire'
In explaining on Friday that he had told Mr. Cuomo last summer of his desire to step down from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Mr. Rohatyn took care to note that the city's precarious economy might oblige him to stay.
''I obviously am not going to retire, because I don't think that would be right,'' he said. ''If I am going to try and be helpful and effect change, I might as well do it from the platform that I have.''
Despite their attacks on Mr. Rohatyn, union leaders said yesterday that they were surprised by his announcement. ''I was stunned,'' said Barry Feinstein, the president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who on Tuesday called Mr. Rohatyn ''the enemy'' of labor.
''I didn't expect Felix to be leaving office,'' he said.
Mr. Feinstein said he had no doubt that Mr. Rohatyn would leave, but some of the financier's own associates, as well as aides to Mr. Cuomo, said there was still a chance that Mr. Rohatyn could be coaxed into staying. Gary Fryer, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, said the Governor had told Mr. Rohatyn that he ''understood his feelings,'' but asked him for ''time to discuss this after the election.''
 
Shock at Some Unions
Mr. Dinkins has refrained from disagreeing publicly with Mr. Rohatyn, but he took issue with Mr. Rohatyn's assertion that the city should reconsider a new teachers contract, limit wage increases for other city unions and convene a special meeting of labor and business leaders and government officials to develop a financial strategy for the city. Such a move could symbolically suggest that City Hall could not solve the city's problems.
''All of these parties are involved, we consult them as we go,'' Mr. Dinkins said recently. ''Having these various elements at a single meeting is questionable. I am not prepared to discuss it right now.''
Labor leaders, outraged by Mr. Rohatyn's attack on the 5.5 percent salary increase recently negotiated for public school teachers, were more belligerent. ''He never even called me ahead of time to tell me what he is going to do, I was absolutely shocked,'' said Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers.
Victor Gotbaum, the former head of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Muncipal Employees who was best man at Mr. Rohatyn's wedding, put the friendship forged in 1975 momentarily aside. ''In 1975 Felix was part of the solution, but now he is part of the problem,'' Mr. Gotbaum said.
Mr. Feinstein, another longtime friend of Mr. Rohatyn, grudgingly conceeded that Mr. Rohatyn's gloominess about the economy could bear out. ''Over the years, Felix has been wrong, wrong, wrong, but it may be that this is one in 15 crises that he's right about.''
 
Concerned About Layoffs
Mr. Rohatyn, who, as he did in 1975, has called for ''shared sacrifice,'' said he detected one important difference now from then. ''We had unions recognizing that there was a crisis and that they had to give something up,'' he said. ''Today, they clearly have no such impression.'' He said he was concerned that wage increases would inexorably lead to layoffs of city employees.
Mr. Rohatyn spoke with wry nostalgia of the ''crazy days'' when ''we were running the city from a table at Elaine's, with Woody Allen sitting at the next one.'' But he said he had no desire to resume so critical a role.
''I think you need someone who can wake up every morning and say this is my chance to be in the sunshine, and today I'm going to invent something new,'' he said, adding, ''I've been in the sunshine, and I'm not sure I can invent anything new.''
 
Took Off His Glasses and Fedora
Mr. Rohatyn, who vowed to speak out on fiscal matters as long as he is chairman of M.A.C., has not abandoned his other platforms. Mr. Rohatyn, a senior partner at Lazard Freres investment firm, is an adviser to Mr. Cuomo, and he lists Henry Kissinger and Francois Mitterrand among his many friends. He has written an article about the current economic slump for the Nov. 8 issue of The New York Review of Books, given speeches, appeared on television and made his advice available to Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Dinkins.
Norman Adler, a political consultant and former lobbyist for labor groups, was skeptical that Mr. Rohatyn would be content to sit this crisis out. ''If you don't want to be recognized as Superman, its easy: you don't take off your glasses and fedora,'' Mr. Adler said, adding, ''Felix hasn't seen his glasses and fedora for months.''
Few in New York felt that Mr. Rohaytn's threat to leave an institution whose powers were diminished when its surpluses were turned over to the city would significantly diminish his voice in matters of city or state. ''Even if he does step down, he won't be fading away,'' Mr. Adler said.
Mr. Rohatyn said as much himself. ''I will always be an adviser to the Governor,'' he said on Friday, ''whether I'm chairman of M.A.C. or sitting on my stoop in Southhampton.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
BUDGET MEASURE CLEARS 2 HURDLES IN SENATE VOTES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
After Senate leaders from both parties struggled all day to line up votes, their budget package passed its first critical tests late tonight.
The senators rejected a proposal to raise taxes on the wealthy, largely out of fear of a Presidential veto, and turned down an effort to scrap an increase in the gasoline tax.
The first votes seemed to have secured passage of the package, which would raise taxes on gasoline and other items and would cut Medicare and other benefits.
After Senate approval, which is expected Thursday, the budget legislation will go to a conference with the House, where senior lawmakers will try to resolve the differences in the two versions under the watchful eye of the White House.
The first proposal defeated tonight, by a vote of 67 to 32, was much like the measure passed by the House on Tuesday to put more of the burden of deficit reduction on the wealthy and less on the middle class. 
Then, the senators rejected an amendment favored by many Southern and Western senators of both parties that would have kept the Federal gasoline tax from being raised and would have meant that the overall package would have fallen short of the goal of $40 billion in deficit reduction this year and $500 billion after five years. The vote was 59 to 40.
Both votes came on parliamentary motions rather than on the substance of the issues in each measure, giving senators a way to support their leaders without directly voting down politically attractive measures.
The Senate was racing to beat a deadline, 48 hours away. The Government's authority to spend money lapses at midnight Friday, and President Bush has pledged to close down the Government again if no budget that satisfies him has been enacted by then. The first proposal, offered by Senators Kent Conrad of North Dakota and Max Baucus of Montana, received strong support from their fellow liberals. Like the House measure, it would have raised the top tax rate, placed a surtax on millionaires and increased the minimum tax paid by the wealthy.
Mr. Bush has said he would veto such a measure. John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, explained the President's position on higher taxes on the wealthy in a television interview today. ''Once they start playing with taxes at one end, they can't stop,'' he said.
 
Deflecting a Veto
The rejection of the Conrad-Baucus amendment came on a procedural vote after Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, said the certainty of a veto made Senate approval irresponsible.
Though Mr. Mitchell is himself a strong proponent of higher income tax rates, he told his colleagues: ''It is a question of whether we want to make a statement or make a law. Adoption will result in making a very strong statement but adoption of no law.''
Senator Conrad argued that a veto, and the resulting portrait of President Bush as a patron of the rich, would not be the worst outcome. ''It seems to me we ought to give the President that opportunity,'' he said.
Earlier, urging his colleagues not to change the bill that had been assembled compromise by compromise over many weeks by the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Mitchell told the Senate: ''This is a test. This is a test for every senator. And ultimately, this is a test of our nation's future.
''Do we have the courage to do something that's difficult, that's unpleasant, that's unpopular? Can we not keep in mind the national interest?''
 
Opposition From Left and Right
Senator Mitchell's Republican counterpart, Bob Dole of Kansas, agreed that if the politically popular amendments were adopted, ''we might as well fold up our tent.''
But the leaders faced opposition from the left and right. Mr. Baucus declared, ''If we are going to raise taxes to address the deficit, the rich should pay their share.'' Senator Brock Adams, a Washington Democrat, agreed. ''We can no longer let the wealthy off scot-free,'' he said.
Senator Steve Symms, a conservative Republican from Idaho, led the fight to strip from the leaders' bill the part that would more than double the Federal gasoline tax. ''This is a good issue to draw the line on as to whether we want to raise taxes on the American people,'' Senator Symms said. Later, he added: ''Stop taxes. Freeze spending.''
 
A Vote for 'the Common Good'
But the leaders insisted that the yearlong effort to cut the deficit by the largest amount in history was doomed if the changes were made.
Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, swallowed his personal enthusiasm for the Conrad-Baucus proposal, saying, ''I'm going to do it in the name of the common good, and the common good is reducing the deficit that is eating away at the vitals of the economy of the United States.''
And Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, said his Texas constituents were adamantly opposed to a higher gasoline tax but added that he had to support one because ''the job we have to do is to make a critical cut in the deficits we are facing.''
Senator Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat who can occasionally swing votes with his eloquence, was enlisted by the leaders.
''I hate this,'' he began, saying that if a bill came out of a Senate-House conference with a large increase in the gasoline tax, he would vote against it. But approving a bill tonight, he said, would ''at least get us to conference.''
 
Shape of a Compromise
Already today, even before the Senate cast a vote, lawmakers were beginning to discuss the shape of a compromise.
A senior Republican Senator suggested that the White House and the Senate could probably accept an increase in the top tax rate to 31 percent. That is above the current 28 percent but below the 33 percent in the House bill. But the Senator said the 10 percent surtax in the House bill and the one-year delays in adjustments of tax brackets and personal exemptions for inflation would probably be dropped. Suspension of the inflation adjustment would cost middle-income families a few hundred dollars a year in extra income taxes.
A leading Democratic Representative suggested that House members could probably be persuaded to accept a higher gasoline tax, though not so large as the one in the Senate measure. He also said the House might back a provision in the Senate bill that would limit the deductions that could be claimed by affluent taxpayers.
Few taxes are so unpopular as gasoline taxes. According to the Highway User Federation, the average household pays about $3 a week in gasoline taxes. But the figure tends to be higher in the South and West, where public transportation is not available and where long distances must often be traveled to work and for routine chores. For a commuter with a 30-mile round trip, doubling the gasoline tax would cost about $1 a week.
''This is like a dagger in the heart of the poorest state in America, Mississippi,'' said Senator Trent Lott, a Mississippi Republican.
These are among the main elements of the Senate bill:
* An increase in the Federal gasoline tax to 18.5 cents in 1992 from 9 cents now.
* A doubling of the annual Medicare deductible, to $150. The monthly Medicare premiums the elderly pay for insurance against doctors' bills, now $28.60, would rise each year as medical costs increased.
* An increase to $89,000 from $51,300 in the amount of wages subject to the 1.45 percent payroll tax for Medicare.
* A 10 percent luxury tax on automobiles costing more than $30,000, boats costing more than $100,000, private planes costing more than $250,000 and furs and jewelry costing more than $5,000.
* Tax breaks totaling $3.5 billion over five years to encourage oil and gas production. They would not become effective unless the price of oil, now more than $40 a barrel, fell below $34.
* A limit on itemized deductions for affluent taxpayers. Taxpayers would have their deductions reduced by 5 percent of the amount their annual income exceeded $100,000.
* Requirements that all state and local employees pay Medicare taxes and that those not in a public employee retirement system pay Social Security taxes.
* Higher taxes on alcoholic beverages and tobacco.
* A $15 billion cut in agriculture programs, primarily price supports paid to farmers.
* An expansion of tax credits for poor workers.
The measure would also impose a variety of fees for Government services, including a charge for commercial use of data from the National Weather Service.

HEADLINE: House Openly Debates C.I.A. Aid in Angola

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The House conducted a rare and bitter public debate today over a major Central Intelligence Agency program as critics of American-backed guerrillas in Angola sought unsuccessfully to end the agency's $60 million in annual support for the rebels.
By a vote of 246 to 175, the House rejected a measure by Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, that would have ended C.I.A. support of the Angolan rebels and forced the Bush Administration instead to detail the request for aid to Congress in public.
But the House later approved an amendment by Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, that did restrict the Administration's options for future C.I.A. aid. The amendment, approved 213 to 200, would suspend military assistance to the rebels, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, for three months once the Administration certifies that Angola's Government has agreed to a cease-fire, a political settlement with Unita, and the holding of elections within two years. 
Since 1985, the C.I.A. has provided increasing military aid to the rebels. The aid, which is approved by both intelligence committees of Congress, supports the rebels in a war against Angola's leftist Government, which lawmakers said today receives more than $500 million a year in aid from Moscow. Theoretically, the aid is classified, but the program is covert in name only.
The debate came as the House considered legislation that would allot about $30 billion for the new fiscal year for the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies. Included in the bill is financing for rebels in both Angola and Afghanistan who are backed by the C.I.A. That bill later passed by a voice vote. ''The funding of Unita guerrillas is a cold-war anachronism,'' Mr. Dellums said. ''We are providing cold-war dollars that have wreaked incredible havoc on the people of Angola.''
Mr. Dellums and other backers of the amendment argued that the measure would not end aid to Unita, but would only force the Administration to make its case for the assistance in public.
But a coalition of liberals and conservatives who support the rebels asserted that the amendment would effectively kill the C.I.A.'s Angola program at the verge of success. Unita's leader, Jonas Savimbi, and officials of Angola's Government are reported to be near a cease-fire in their long war, with important details like the date of free elections still to be worked out.
Under the Solarz amendment, aid would remain suspended as long as this situation prevailed. But the aid would resume if the Angolan Government lagged in carrying out the agreement, broke the cease-fire or began stockpiling arms for an offensive.
The House bill goes to a conference committee, where its provisions will be melded with those of a similar bill that the Senate passed this summer.
The Senate bill is notable because it includes the first legal definition of so-called covert actions, easily the most controversial of the C.I.A.'s espionage duties.
The 1947 law that established the C.I.A. contained no explicit permission for the agency to conduct secret activities abroad other than collecting information. Over the years, Presidents and spymasters have interpreted that silence as a charter to wage paramilitary wars, run propaganda campaigns and even to overthrow other governments.
The Senate bill defines a covert action as an activity by the Government ''to influence political, economic or military conditions abroad so that the role of the United States Government is not intended to be apparent or acknowledged publicly.''
That definition includes operations conducted by agencies other than the C.I.A., in an attempt to prevent future scandals such as the Iran-contra affair, in which a guerrilla war against the Nicaraguan Government was managed largely from the White House. But it also excludes Federal law-enforcement activities overseas, espionage actions whose ''primary purpose'' is to gather intelligence, ''traditional diplomatic or military activities'' and routine support for publicly acknowledged Government programs.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Soldiers Have Some Beefs for the Boss

BYLINE: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IN SAUDI ARABIA, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The men of the headquarters supply platoon of the Second Squadron of the Army's Fourth Cavalry Regiment had a few things they wanted to get off their chests.
''Tell George Bush to get off the golf course and out of his fishing boat and come out here in the desert to take a look at what we're doing and drink some hot water with us,'' declared Pvt. Brett Thompson, 21 years old. ''We're tired of being kept in the dark like we don't have the intelligence to be told what's going on.'' 
It was only one of many heated comments by the mostly young enlisted men of this unit, which has been working an average 18 to 20 hours a day for the last two months.
''I had to come out here to find out what the Army really thinks I'm worth - nothing,'' said an angry private who asked not to be identified. ''Why is it that when the U.S. economy gets bad we always go to war?''
In shouted comments, more than a dozen soldiers in the unit complained of very slow mail, no news, no clear definition of their mission, few cots, no chance to telephone home, almost no recreational equipment and a feeling that senior commanders either do not listen or do not want to hear their complaints.
Although some soldiers said mail delivery had improved, it still seems slow and erratic. Pvt. John Barnes, 20 years old, said he had received no mail in more than a month.
Commanders said there are plans to install phones at a nearby town and to ferry troops to a beach resort for a break, but nothing seems definite yet.
''The longer we just sit here like this, the worse morale is going to get,'' said Sgt. Rolland Brooks, a veteran of Vietnam. ''I don't think we came over here to fight for low oil prices. The atrocities we came to stop are still going on in Kuwait and we're just sitting here.''
''I think all the big people involved in this should come out to the desert, here in the sun,'' Sergeant Brooks added. ''I think they'd make a decision real fast.''
''I want to be able to go to church,'' said Pvt. Woodrow Campbell, 19. ''It matters to me.''
A sergeant said a tent was being raised to serve as a chapel. Several men said the fact that their unit has a chaplain is very important to them.
Several soldiers complained that they were taking a pay cut because they were sent to fight in Saudi Arabia. They said they lost a supplemental $180 per month for off-base living expenses in the United States, and were given instead an extra $110 hazardous duty pay -adding up to a loss of $70 a month for risking their lives in the desert.
''We work for less pay than most American civilians,'' one private said, ''and we have a job that starts at 4 in the morning and doesn't end most nights until 9 P.M.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
House Approves Pact Relaxing Czech Trade

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The House tonight unanimously approved a trade agreement between the United States and Czechoslovakia that would reduce tariffs and increase business ties and tourism between the two countries.
The accord, which was signed by the two Governments in April, still has to be cleared by the Senate. Action expected before Congress adjourns.
Newly democratic Czechoslovakia would get the lowest possible tariffs for its exports to the United States, making products like Czech glassware and beer more competitive in the American market. Trade between the United States and Czechoslovakia now runs about $150 million a year.
In return for getting favorable tariff treatment, Prague has agreed to treat Americans the same way as Czechoslovaks in establishing bank accounts and paying for goods within the country. Also, hard-currency earnings of American companies in Czechoslovakia can be immediately taken out of the country.

HEADLINE: Navajo Leader Is Guilty In a Tribal Bribery Trial

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz., Oct. 17

 BODY:
Peter MacDonald Sr., the suspended leader of the Navajo Nation, the country's largest Indian tribe, was found guilty today in Navajo tribal court on 41 of 42 counts of accepting bribes, violating the tribe's ethics laws and conspiracy.
His son, Peter (Rocky) MacDonald Jr., was found guilty of all of the 23 similar charges he faced.
Leaving the tribal courthouse here smiling and holding hands with his wife, Wanda, Mr. MacDonald told reporters the verdict ''was no surprise'' because the special prosecutor was ''snow jobbing'' the jury. He also said he still considered himself chairman of the tribe and asked for votes in the tribe's Nov. 6 election. 
 
No Decision on Appeal
His lawyer, Val R. Jolley of Farmington, N. M., said that Mr. MacDonald would probably appeal his conviction to the Navajo Supreme Court but that he would not represent him.
The defense called no witnesses in the two-week trial and Mr. MacDonald did not take the stand.
Although Navajo ethics laws require Mr. MacDonald to step down as chairman, Mr. Jolley said he should remain leader of the tribe until the Navajo Tribal Council impeaches him.
''Since nobody has been convicted under this statute before nobody really knows the procedures,'' Mr. Jolley said. Sentencing is scheduled for Monday, and Mr. Jolley said his client faced up to 10 years in tribal jail and thousands of dollars in fines.
 
Two Trials Pending
Mr. MacDonald faces two other criminal trials in the Navajo court, and Robert Rothstein, a special prosecutor brought in by the tribe, said 70 potential corruption cases involving former Navajo officials were pending. Mr. Rothstein is a member of the Santa Fe law firm of Rothstein, Bennett, Daly, Donatelli & Hughes.
Special prosecutors accused the MacDonalds of acting as a team to solicit $400,000 in what were portrayed as consulting fees and loans from businessmen seeking preferable treatment or lucrative contracts worth millions of dollars from the tribe.
In several instances, prosecutors said, the younger Mr. MacDonald was hired as a consultant who was supposedly familiar with tribal procedures. Several witnesses testified that all that was known about him was his relationship to his father, and that many times he performed no work.
''People paid for influence and that's what Rocky MacDonald got them,'' said Mark Donatelli, another special prosecutor.
The jury found that the MacDonalds conspired to hide their illegal transactions by fabricating documents to conceal illegal transactions.
Mr. Jolley argued that the prosecution's evidence was largely circumstantial and inconclusive. Acknowledging the MacDonalds took money, he said they were loans or gifts based on social relationships or legitimate consulting fees.
Mr. Donatelli said today's verdict should send a message that tribal governments expect honest leaders.
 
Years of Prosperity
Mr. MacDonald, who was the Navajo chairman for 13 years over two periods between 1970 and the time of his suspension, led the Navajos during an era in which the tribe experienced much of its economic growth.
By next year the tribe expects to earn $73 million from its reserves of oil, gas, coal mining, investments, timber and land rentals. Another $20 million will come in from its own business taxes. Its annual general budget averages $88 million, tribal officials say. Federal appropriations bring in another $100 million annually.
Long seen as brash, enigmatic yet charismatic figure on the 26,100-square-mile reservation, Mr. MacDonald remains a man of contrasts simultaneously revered and reviled by Navajos and non-Indians.
Throughout the trial, he called the proceedings against him a ''sham'' and ''political witchhunt.''
On Tuesday, Mr. MacDonald is scheduled to stand trial in tribal court on charges of defrauding the tribe on its purchase of a ranch for $33.4 million.
On leaving the court today, he had no comment on last week's Federal indictment of a former associate, Byron Brown, in connection with the 1987 purchase of the ranch.

HEADLINE: Federal Budget Puts Wild Card Into Ohio Race

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Oct. 14

 BODY:
With a base of support in this largely ethnic, racially diverse and heavily unionized city, George Voinovich, a Republican who is a popular former Mayor, seemed to start the campaign for governor of Ohio already holding the Democratic trump card.
So it was hardly surprising that polls this month showed Mr. Voinovich with a lead of 10 percentage points or more over the Democratic nominee, Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., the State Attorney General.
But in the budget dispute in Washington, Mr. Voinovich may have been dealt a troublesome wild card, as many reports of the rancorous battle over taxes have cast the Republicans as protectors of the rich.
''You bet it's going to affect my vote,'' said Iva Schuster, as she stacked supplies at a K mart store in the working-class suburb of Berea. ''They're trying to put the screws to blue-collar people like us.'' 
 
Working Class vs. Elite
In a dash, Democrats here have hit the airwaves with commercials that portray Mr. Voinovich as part of a Republican Party establishment that caters to the elite.
Mr. Celebrezze, who has also criticized his opponent for recently holding a $25,000-a-ticket fund-raising event with President Bush, contends that his polls now show the race even.
Until now, the contest to succeed Gov. Richard F. Celeste, a Democrat who is required by state law to step down after serving two consecutive terms, has seen little in the way of fireworks or political drama.
''Voinovich has been running very strongly in traditionally Democratic country,'' said Herbert Asher, a political science professor at Ohio State University. ''Now Celebrezze has finally latched on to something that could narrow the gap: populism. He's running against Washington, putting himself forward as the man who will fight for the working class.''
But Mr. Voinovich stands to benefit from an economic upswing in Cleveland, a city that was flat on its back in 1979, when he took over as Mayor.
The symbol of Cleveland's renaissance is rising on the banks of the Cuyahoga River, where a gleaming new 52-story building, Tower City Center, boasts expensive stores, hotels and movie theaters. Along with other new commercial projects, the center is seen as a symbol of civic pride, a jewel amid the rust that characterized the long, hard times for this old factory city.
 
Delay in Endorsement
''I'm a registered Democrat, but I'm voting for Voinovich,'' said Leon Burleigh, a security guard inside the center, who said he owed his job to the aggressive policies of the former Mayor. ''And he's been fair to everyone. He's given blacks a fair shake.''
Cleveland's Mayor, Michael White, a Democrat, has endorsed Mr. Celebrezze. But the Mayor, who is black, did not do so until well into the campaign, and political observers here say the delay demonstrated Mr. Voinovich's popularity among voters here, black and white. Mr. Voinovich stepped down as Mayor in December after 10 years in office.
Throughout Ohio, especially in urban centers that experienced hard times in the 1970's, many voters cite the Cleveland turnaround as reason enough to support the Republican. ''If he can do for the rest of Ohio what he did for Cleveland,'' said Doug Welker, who works for the General Motors Company in Youngstown, ''then I'm all for Voinovich.''
But many Ohioans expressed resentment toward Republicans on the tax issue.
Vice President Dan Quayle campaigned Saturday with Mr. Voinovich in rural southeastern Ohio, the impoverished, hilly country that shares many of the problems of Appalachia.
Curtis Ramey, a 49-year-old firefighter in Rio Grande, took his 6-year-old grandson to the curbside in the little town to catch a glimpse of the Vice President, who waved from the back seat of a black limousine that moved past the clapboard houses here.
 
Paying Fair Share
''I wanted the boy to see the Vice President, but I'm voting Democrat,'' Mr. Ramey said curtly, folding his arms against his chest. ''The rich people ought to start paying their fair share. The Republicans don't seem to understand that.''
The two candidates are generally viewed here as honest and intelligent politicians, if not dynamic campaigners. Their agendas do not seem drastically at odds, although they differ on the abortion issue.
Mr. Celebrezze, reversing a longtime stand, has declared his support for a woman's right to abortion; Mr. Voinovich, who has characterized his opponent as ''a flip-flopper'' on the issue, opposes abortion except in cases of rape, incest or where necessary to protect the health of the woman.
''The abortion issue hasn't had the kind of salience that it has in other states,'' said Mr. Asher, the political science professor. ''Voinovich has done very little to scare the pro-choice people. He's said he wouldn't try to change the status quo.''
At the rally in Rio Grande with Mr. Quayle, Mr. Voinovich stressed patriotism and prosperity. The Republican, a tall, slender man with an angular face, punched his index finger in the air and vowed that rural Ohio ''will not be forgotten.''
''There will be jobs, more jobs, better jobs,'' he said.
 
'Rights of Victims'
In his endorsement, Mr. Quayle praised Mr. Voinovich as someone who would ''put the rights of victims ahead of the rights of criminals.'' And he accused Congressional Democrats of stalling on the budget.
''They fight us on everything,'' Mr. Quayle said with exasperation.
At a country fair in nearby Gallipolis, where Mr. Voinovich stopped briefly with the Vice President, a young dental hygienist sat on a bale of hay and promised her vote.
''The Republicans believe people should have to work for a living,'' said the woman, Raegene Wood, as she listened to a country music band strum a Merle Haggard standard. ''The Democrats are more for giving handouts.''
On the stump, Mr. Celebrezze, the son of a former Mayor of Cleveland, has the deliberate manner of an economics professor, explaining the certitude of his theories.
''Our message is very simple,'' he told a group of black supporters in Columbus on Saturday. ''We will work on behalf of working people and forgotten people.''
''The Republicans have no concept of what working people earn,'' he added, rolling his eyes in disgust over the $25,000-a-ticket Republican event that Mr. Bush attended here earlier in the campaign. ''I intend to work for the people who make $25,000 in a whole year.''

ANALYSIS
 
While the candidates differ on the issue of abortion, the race appears to pivot on the coice between Mr. Voinovich's pro-business stance, which invigorated Cleveland during his years as Mayor, and Mr. Celebrezze's position that workers and others ofmodest means are not getting a fair shake from government, especially on taxes.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Cuomo Tactics: Avoiding Curse Of Incumbency

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York is defying the odds against incumbents this year because: (a) - Republicans miscalculated by presuming that he was invulnerable. (b) - Even after serving for 15 years in state government, he manages to be regarded as a political outsider. (c) - The anti-incumbent tide may be greatly exaggerated. (d) - All of the above. The correct answer is (d). With Election Day less than three weeks away, almost nobody realistically doubts that Mr. Cuomo will win a third term - in sharp contrast to three other Democratic governors from the Northeast who chose not to run again and at least two Republicans who are considered vulnerable. About all that is left to ponder is whether Mr. Cuomo's victory margin will hit a record high and whether voter turnout will plummet to a record low, and why.
The G.O.P.'s Misjudgment: Mr. Cuomo had raised $7 million by last spring, and potential challengers were duly intimidated. But they either failed to detect, or felt unequipped to capitalize on, two trends detected in some public-opinion polls: while the Governor was still personally popular, fewer people were impressed with his performance; moreover, many New Yorkers said they were dissatisfied with the direction in which they thought the state was going. 
A well-financed, articulate challenger who offered a convincing rationale for his candidacy could have given Mr. Cuomo a run for his money. None of those qualities seemed to apply to Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republicans' nominee of last resort.
That no more credible candidate could be enlisted also reflects the decline of political parties, which no longer can absorb campaign debts or bruised egos. Republicans have been deprived of an opportunity to deflate the Presidential trial balloons that are sent up periodically on Mr. Cuomo's behalf. He has been denied the chance to hone his skills for a more challenging national campaign.
The Odd Man In: Mr. Cuomo served in Albany as secretary of state and then lieutenant governor before being elected governor in 1982, but he has largely avoided the curse of incumbency. ''Mario never had the personality of an incumbent,'' said David Garth, the media strategist. ''He always has someone to be in moral conflict with - the Mayor, the Legislature, the President. As a result, it always looks like he's an outsider.''
He has also often been on the cutting edge of issues, saying that New York's problems are not unique and that many stem from Federal abdications. ''Mario has always sounded the anti-Washington, anti-conventional-wisdom alarm,'' said Robert D. Squier, a political consultant to Dr. John K. Silber, the Boston University president, whose victory in last month's Democratic primary for governor of Massachusetts was viewed as evidence that voters crave a fresh approach.
William Mulrow, an official of Mr. Cuomo's campaign, analyzed Dr. Silber's platform and said that although his politically unconventional views sound fresh, ''most of what he proposes has already been tried or accomplished in the past eight years in New York State.''
The Mixed Blessing of Incumbency: Many voters are incensed about being taxed more for benefits that they never seem to reap. But newness alone in a challenger is not enough. Among statewide incumbents, only Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the lone Republican, appears to be vulnerable. In a period of economic uncertainty, Mr. Rinfret has helped define his own race as one between an erratic newcomer and an experienced political tactician.
''This is a time of uncertainty, confusion, even occasional moments of chaos,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''People want strength.'' Mentioning Presiden Bush and Mayor David N. Dinkins in the same breath, he said, ''There is a sense in the people that government is not being clear, decisive and giving effective leadership'' - weaknesses the media seizes upon.
''Dinkins's 'ambivalence' - they love to charge you with ambivalence,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''Bush? Look what they're doing to Bush - flip-flop. This is a very important characteristic - not being able to make the decision. That's what the people see and that is what the media is playing up. And I understand it.''
Rather than capping the number of terms an official can serve, Mr. Cuomo would reduce the edge of officeholders by publicly financing campaigns. But the two-term Governor dismisses the notion that incumbency is now a fatal liability. ''We see two dots, we draw one line and we think we have a rhombus,'' said Mr. Cuomo, whose oblique angles comprise a candidacy that may not always seem to be politically symmetrical but is in surprisingly good shape.

HEADLINE: Environmental Bond Passage in Doubt

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
With less than three weeks to go until Election Day, strong opposition by upstate New York residents to the $2 billion environmental bond issue has put government and private supporters on the defensive and passage of the measure in doubt.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who hoped to get easy political mileage from the 21st Century Environmental Quality Bond Act, instead finds himself the target of criticism from upstate residents, particularly those in the Adirondacks, who oppose using bond proceeds to buy private land there.
''Many of the people north of the Tappan Zee will not support the bond issue,'' Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine said on Tuesday at a gathering of supporters of the bond act.
Last spring, in the afterglow of Earth Day, environmental groups were confident the bond issue would pass easily. All nine previous environmental issues have been approved by voters. 
But a combination of the state's growing financial problems, upstate hostility to land purchases and a general lack of knowledge about the bond act have given supporters cause for concern, they say.
People around Adirondack Park are already angry about a state commission's report last spring recommending large land purchases and stricter regulation. Such acquisitions will depress economic activity in the region, opponents say.
''We feel the money could be better used in New York City for fire, police and disadvantaged kids, rather than buying land and letting it sit here,'' said Marty Mischenko, a spokesman for the Adirondack Solidarity Alliance in Lewis.
Prominent critics include Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who is running for re-election against Carol Bellamy, a supporter of the bond act; Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor, and the New York Farm Bureau, the state's largest farm advocacy organization. All of these assert the bond issue is fiscally irresponsible.
''The state is broke,'' Mr. Rinfret said, ''and can't afford the acquisition of more land at this time.''
The bond act would authorize borrowing $1.975 billion for land purchases, recycling programs, closing landfills and historic preservation.
''We don't have a way to pay for these projects if it fails,'' said Anne Crowley, a spokeswoman for Mr. Cuomo. ''That's precisely why the Governor proposed the bond act.''
''It may be in some trouble because of the bad financial news over the last month or two,'' said Larry Shapiro, a representative with the New York Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit environmental lobbying and research organization.
The Heritage 2000 Alliance, an umbrella organization of supporters of the bond act, has begun a public relations campaign. Mr. Cuomo, who has made the bond act a top priority, will keep pressing for it, a spokesman said.
''He's been all over the state explaining what the bond act would do, why it is necessary and why it is affordable and why it can't wait,'' said the spokesman, Thomas Conroy. Supporters say the bond act would cost each state resident $7 a year for the life of the bonds.
In a recent survey of registered voters by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, 71.5 percent of the respondents said they had not heard of the bond act.
At $800 million, land acquisition would account for the largest chunk of the proceeds. Money for land purchases from the last two bond acts has been committed or will soon be obligated. The remaining $1.175 billion would be divided into these categories:
* Solid-waste programs like recycling, landfill closure and medical-waste disposal would get $525 million.
* A wide range of environmental restoration and preservation projects, $201 million.
* Acquisition and improvement of municipal parks and historic preservation, $175 million.
* Financing of a local sewage-treatment plant loan fund, $174 million.
* Assistance in the development of the West Side waterfront esplanade along the Hudson River, $100 million.
Including the esplanade money, New York City can expect to receive $500 million to $700 million of the bond issue proceeds, said Sandford Evans, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection. City officials estimate that New York would receive $100 million to buy land in the Catskill watershed area to protect drinking water quality and $100 million for recycling and closing landfills.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The proposed $2 billion environmental bond issue would include money for development of the West Side waterfront along the Hudson River, seen from the north. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dinkins Links Teacher Raise To Albany

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that if the State Legislature did not approve changes in pension earnings assumptions to finance almost half of a 5.5 percent raise for teachers, New York City would not be liable for making up the difference.
In one sense, Mr. Dinkins's comments -made in response to questions about the raise on a day when he came under more pressure from fiscal monitors critical of the contract - simply restated his contention that only 1.5 percent of the raise would be borne directly by the city budget.
''If we don't get the pension fund money, we have no commitment to fill that hole,'' Mr. Dinkins said. But in other ways, Mr. Dinkins stepped out on a political tightrope. 
On the one hand, he seemed to be sending a signal to the financial community. Senior mayoral aides acknowledged that by so publicly attempting to shift more of the burden for the contract to the Legislature, he could be paving the way for a renegotiation of the entire contract, if fiscal conditions grew so bad that the Legislature would not approve the change.
 
Union Takes Exception
On the other hand, he risked alienating the teachers union, his strong political ally, which says a deal is a deal. And there is no reason to suspect that the Mayor actually hopes that the deal will fail under present conditions.
Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the United Federation of Teachers, said yesterday that the union did not share the Mayor's view on the raise. ''There was no mention of any contingencies when the memorandum of understanding was signed,'' she said. ''It's our position we have a legal, binding contract, assuming ratification by the members and approval by the Board of Education.''
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said in an interview that he was sure the school board would devise ''some kind of safeguards'' to assure that the Legislature's approval would be necessary before the raise could take effect.
Indeed, city officials said the memorandum of agreement between the city and union specified that a provision in the existing contract, based on the state civil service law, would continue. That provision says that any part of the contract that requires legislative approval to provide financing shall not become effective until the relevant body has acted.
It appears doubtful that the Mayor could simply drop the matter into the Legislature's lap, since it would not be likely to buck the powerful teachers union even if the Mayor asked it to, and Mr. Dinkins's aides said he had not.
In fact, legislative aides in Albany said the Mayor had told the leaders there that he could not possibly renege on the teachers contract, since he would never again have credibility with labor.
The city is proposing to raise, from 8.25 percent to 9 percent, the figure that represents how much it thinks the pension fund's investments will earn each year. A higher earning estimate means that the city would need to contribute less to the fund, and the extra money would be used to generate a 2.5 percent raise for the teachers. The rest of the 5.5 percent increase would come from state aid and previously budgeted city funds. Other unions still negotiating contracts have said they will seek similar raises using the same approach.
James A. Yates, counsel to Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, said, ''I assume that if the Mayor asks for us to approve'' the change ''and it's actuarially sound, then the Assembly would approve it.'' Prudent Assumptions? Carl A. Carlucci, secretary to the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee, said, referring to City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, ''If every actuary in the world said this is a bad idea, or if Liz Holtzman said this is not prudent,'' then the Assembly might have to look skeptically at it.
Some pension experts have suggested such an increase might not be prudent, given a declining economy, and might commit the city to bailing the funds out in the future.
Ms. Amlung of the teachers union said the city may want to delay the payment of the raise until Albany approves the change in pension assumptions. But she said the union believed the settlement could not be abrogated, and was studying what actions it could take to enforce it.
But yesterday, in the latest criticism of the idea, the board of the Municipal Assistance Corporation unanimously urged that savings from such pension changes be used to close a projected gap in the city's budget for the coming fiscal year of at least $1.4 billion, and to avoid the large-scale layoffs of city workers that Mr. Dinkins has warned might be necessary.
 
'Social Balance' Called For
In a letter to the State Financial Control Board, which includes Mr. Dinkins, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the City and State Comptrollers, and to the Speaker of the City Council, which would also have to approve use of the pension money, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, said, ''Credible fiscal balance is necessary for full and free access to the credit markets.''
He added, repeating a theme he has sounded often in recent weeks: ''Social balance dictates the fewest number of layoffs possible. Both objectives will be served by dedicating whatever pension savings are deemed prudent to general budget purposes.''
Mr. Rohatyn said yesterday that he planned to step down by the end of the year. But Mr. Rohatyn's views still hold considerable sway in the financial markets, and he is only one of a number of critics who have raised concern about the teachers pay agreement. City Council President Andrew J. Stein has said that the pension changes should not be approved, and aides to Ms. Holtzman, the City Comptroller, predicted yesterday that scrutiny of the issue would grow as both state and city faced larger budget gaps.
Mr. Dinkins met yesterday with officials of Moody's Investors Service and the Standard and Poor's Corporation, in an effort to assure them that he will keep the city's budget balanced. Last week, citing concerns about the teachers contract and other matters, Standard and Poors, a major credit rating agency, warned that the city's bond rating might fall.
''I explained to them that I had an understanding, a grasp of the situation in which we find ourselves,'' the Mayor said.

HEADLINE: In Connecticut, A Big Silence On Prison Crisis

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOMERS, Conn.

 BODY:
Detailed proposals about crime and punishment have been few and far between in Connecticut's race for governor. Many people inside the state's overwhelmed criminal-justice system say the relative silence has raised the level of campaign honesty.
With a crushing budget deficit looming for the state, a huge prison expansion only now approaching midway, and a toughened sentencing system taking effect this month after years of debate and public outcry, experts say that promises of sweeping reform in how Connecticut deals with crime could probably not be kept.
For the short-term, they say, the state's next governor will be just one more prisoner of the apparatus forged in the 1980's. 
 
Operating Budget Has Tripled
Prior financial commitments alone will be considerable. The 10-year prison expansion that began in 1985, at nearly $1 billion for 8,200 new prison beds, is one of the most expensive in the nation. Yet the prison system is still expected to fall far short of the growing criminal population.
The new construction has in turn forced a tripling of the prison operating budget since 1985, to $231 million this year, and state budget officials say that further large spending increases for new guards and administrators extend as far as the eye can see. The Department of Correction is seeking a 49 percent one-year spending increase, to $345.6 million, for the year that begins next July 1.
Here at the Somers Correctional Institution, the state's largest prison, the concerns are more gut-level. Somers, which was built to house 900 inmates in 1963 now holds more than 1,400 and officials plan to squeeze in another 200. The prison, set on 1,400 acres that were once part of a Shaker farm, is one of four state prisons on the site, with a combined population of about 3,500 - more than a third of the state's prison population of 9,876. Two more prisons are to be completed by 1993. There are shortages of both space and staff. Younger guards with less experience, hired in the expansion, are supervising inmates who are more violent and less controllable than ever. Double-bunking in many cell blocks has pushed tensions higher still. A shortage of guards has made mandatory 16-hour tours-of-duty common. Then there is what they call ''creaming down.'' The phrase, attributed to the state's Commissioner of Correction, Larry Meachum, is a direct result of the way Connecticut has expanded its prisons, with almost all of the growth in lower-security, fast-track construction of dormitory-style prisons rather than higher security - and far more expensive - individual-cell lockup prisons.
With only one maximum-security prison in the state, Somers, here on the Massachusetts border, officials admit that many inmates who should stay in maximum security are shipped out. Like skimming cream on milk, the idea is to take out the best of the worst criminals and disperse them to other operations.
Guards say, however, that creaming down leaves Somers with an ever-harder core of violent inmates, and the new dormitory prisons with growing numbers of only slightly less dangerous inmates who cannot be isolated in cells when things get out of hand. The dormitory prisons don't have cells.
 
'A Lot More Dangerous'
''It means that cheap minimum-security structures are housing maximum-security inmates,'' said Michael Ferrucci Jr., the chief negotiator for the union that represents state prison guards.
''It's a lot more dangerous job than it used to be,'' said Officer William Stark, who has worked at Somers for eight years. ''All you want to do is do your shift and get out alive or unhurt.''
Law-enforcement and prison authorities directly blame creaming down - along with simple overcrowding - for a riot in June that caused more than $2.7 million in damage at a four-year-old minimum-security prison just down the road from here in Enfield. Some officials warn that worse could come on the next governor's watch if the high-security prisons, to be built in the second half of the plan, are not built.
''If it were a perfect world, we would have one cell per inmate,'' said William H. Carbone, chairman of the state's Prison and Jail Overcrowding Commission, which oversees prison construction in the state. ''But the rate of increase in the population did not permit us to do that. What was feasible was dorms.''
 
Pay Would Be Frozen
So far, none of the three major candidates for governor has proposed any sweeping changes in either the construction plans or operation of the system, though one, Representative John G. Rowland, Republican of Waterbury, has said he would try to make it easier for the state to impose the death penalty and would seek salary concessions from all state employees, including prison guards, whose pay would be frozen.
Mr. Rowland has also said he would not rule out trying to squeeze more inmates into the current space, perhaps up to 130 percent of capacity. Current state law imposes a ceiling at 110 percent of capacity.
Both the Democrat, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, of Hamden, and the former Senator, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., running on his own Connecticut Party, have said that building more prisons is fruitless, though neither has recommended turning back on commitments already made.
Both men have emphasized alternatives to incarceration, especially community service and drug rehabilitation. Mr. Morrison says in addition that he would favor life without parole or ''death in prison,'' as he calls it, for particularly heinous crimes.
 
Opposition From Lawmakers
In any event, efforts to change the sentencing system would probably encounter opposition from lawmakers and administrators who worked, in some cases for years, on the overhaul completed just last spring.
The plan, enacted under public pressure to keep inmates in jail longer, eliminated a supervised home-release program that had allowed many convicted criminals - especially for nonviolent crimes like selling drugs - to be released after serving only 10 percent of their sentences.
In its place, the new law requires anyone sentenced to prison to serve at least 50 percent of their sentence before being eligible for release. Longer prison time will in turn, however, require more prisons and Mr. Carbone's commission is expecting to have waiting on the next governor's desk in January a request for at least 3,000 to 4,000 more prison beds, or the equivalent of about 10 new units.
''Those are optimistic numbers that 4,000 beds are going to be enough,'' said State Representative Richard D. Tulisano, Democrat of Rocky Hill, who is co-chairman of the General Assembly's Judiciary Committee, and the main author of the new law. ''We have yet to accept that we can't build our way out of this.''

HEADLINE: Nobel Winner Salves a Bruised Baruch

BYLINE: By SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
The award of a Nobel Prize to a faculty member would bring pride and joy to any campus but for Baruch College, the award of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science on Tuesday to Dr. Harry M. Markowitz had a special poignancy.
''The whole campus is just very joyous,'' Virgil Bird, chairman of the college's Faculty Senate, said yesterday.
These have been rough times for the Manhattan school, the largest school of business in the nation and the school that trained as many as one-third of the accountants in the city. Last March, a major accrediting agency, the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools, deferred Baruch's normal 10-year reaccreditation on the ground that it had not done enough to hire minority faculty members and that it had done a poor job in retaining minority students. 
Educators at the time said the action was the first time that a major college had been threatened with a loss of accreditation on such grounds. Baruch, a college of 16,100 students, in the Gramercy Park section, is the second-largest branch of the City University of New York. Many faculty members, Mr. Bird said, were ''very demoralized by the controversy.''
 
College's President Resigns
Soon after the accrediting body's action, Dr. Joel Segall, the president of Baruch for 13 years, resigned, and students began questioning the value of their degree credits.
Those fears were largely allayed at the end of June when the Middle States fully reaccredited Baruch after accepting a comprehensive plan by the college for hiring more minority faculty members and providing more support for minority students. Still, many faculty members, administrators and students say the announcement of Dr. Markowitz's prize - for developing a theory for diversifying assets in investment portfolios - was a needed boost to the college's morale and reputation.
''I think the recognition of Dr. Markowitz's award provided a very good example of the hidden treasures on this campus,'' said Dr. Joyce F. Brown, the City University's vice chancellor of urban affairs who became acting president of Baruch on Sept. 1.
Toni Colavito, editor in chief of the student newspaper The Ticker, said while many students believed the criticisms of the college were justified, they were ''happy to get some good publicity for a change.''
 
Proof of 'a Real University'
Dr. Frederick S. Lane, a professor of public administration, said too many New Yorkers tended to take the City University for granted.
''Many people think the ideal university is always some place else,'' said Dr. Lane, who served as executive director of the Governor's Task Force for Higher Education in the mid-1970's. ''I think Dr. Markowitz's Nobel Prize shows they're wrong - that New Yorkers have a real university right in front of them.''
But Dr. Donald H. Smith, chairman of the college's education department, said that he did not want people to draw the wrong conclusions.
''I think it's wonderful for the college that Dr. Markowitz received the Nobel Prize but I don't think it is indicative of anything concerning the Middle States findings,'' he said. ''Middle States questioned the lack of diversity and inclusion on this campus. No one ever complained that the people presently employed were not people of quality.''
Faculty members in Baruch's School of Business and Public Adminstration are pursuing a grievance against the Middle States association before the Council of Post-Secondary Accreditation, a Washington group that oversees the nation's major accrediting organizations. The grievance claims the deferral of the college's reaccreditation was unjustified.
The college, in its response to the accrediting association, promised that Baruch would recruit more minority candidates for administrative and teaching positions, would review the content and organization of programs to retain students and would re-evaluate its curriculum to insure that it prepares students for a ''multicultural college and work environment.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Harry M. Markowitz of Baruch College after hearing of his Nobel award in Tokyo, where he is teaching a class. (Associated Press)
