HEADLINE: 'Productivity Gain' in Pact With Teachers Is Optional

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
A concession won by the New York City Board of Education in its contract with the teachers union - a speedier system for disciplining teachers - is not compulsory, officials have acknowledged. It is an option that teachers can choose.
The disclosure may raise further questions about the wisdom of the 5.5 percent wage increase that was granted to the teachers as part of the contract. Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, and others have challenged the prudence of such an increase at a time of budget cuts. 
Replying to these critics, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez took pains yesterday to defend the pay increase, telling the Board of Education in a four-page statement that he sought ''the largest increase the city could afford'' so he could retain the ''best and brightest'' teachers. He singled out the optional disciplinary process for tenured teachers as one of the productivity gains he had won. #3-Member Panels Now Used The new process is part of a contract agreement that must still be approved by the union membership and the board. And since it is optional, teachers can still pick the current disciplinary procedure, which is more time-consuming.
At present, charges of incompetence, insubordination, drug use or other misconduct are heard by three panelists, one chosen by the board, one by the union and an impartial chairman chosen by both sides. The panel's ruling is not binding and can be appealed to the State Commissioner of Education.
The new process would effectively reduce the panel to a single arbitrator whose decision and penalties, announced within two weeks of the close of hearings, would be binding. Administrative appeals would be barred, though a teacher could resort to the civil courts.
Both officials of the board and the United Federation of Teachers said when the agreement was announced that the new process would shave months off the time needed to choose panelists and to schedule hearings. It would also save thousands of dollars in teachers' salaries, which are paid until a ruling is made.
 
'May Have Been My Fault'
The fact that teachers can reject the binding arbitration procedure and elect to use the three-member panels was not publicized by James S. Vlasto, press secretary to Mr. Fernandez, when the press secretary explained the contract accord on Oct. 1. The union's press statement also did not say the new procedure was voluntary, calling it an ''experimental disciplinary and termination process.''
Mr. Vlasto said the failure to clarify the provision ''may have been my fault.''
''There was a little confusion about the final wording of the memorandum,'' he said, referring to the contract. He added, however, that there was no effort to conceal the voluntary nature of the deal, because ''we were satisfied with it.''
Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the union, said she had told reporters at a City Hall news conference on the accord that the new procedure was voluntary.
 
Speed Offers Benefits
Both Mr. Vlasto and Ms. Amlung contended that most teachers would prefer binding arbitration.
It will be chosen, Ms. Amlung said, by those who ''want to have their name cleared'' or those ''who recognize the validity of the charges'' and want to ''get it over with quickly.''
Rhonda Weingarten, counsel to the union's president, also noted that the new disciplinary procedure had to be optional, since any changes in the current process would require state legislation.
According to Lawrence E. Becker, head of the board's Office of Legal Services, the board disposed of 53 cases of professional misconduct from September 1989 until July 1990, with 40 resulting in an employee's leaving the system. Three-quarters of the cases involved tenured teachers, he said. #5.5 Percent Raise Defended In his statement yesterday, Mr. Fernandez argued that only 1.5 percent of the 5.5 percent pay increase would come from city funds. A second 1.5 percent portion, he said, is derived from state aid allocated for inflationary rises, and a 2.5 percent portion ''comes from the teachers own pension fund.''
Actually, the pension savings would stem from a more optimistic assumption about how much interest the pension fund's investments would earn. The city could then reduce its contributions to the fund and use the savings for increased teacher salaries.
Mr. Fernandez argued that the size of other union raises should not be linked to that given to the teachers. ''In contrast to other city agencies,'' he said, ''our schools are constantly losing staff to nearby school districts, which consistently pay more than we do.''

HEADLINE: Talks by I.B.M. and Motorola On Advanced Chip Collapse

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Negotiations between Motorola Inc. and the I.B.M. Corporation to license the computer maker's most advanced memory-chip technology have collapsed, dashing some people's hopes of an American alliance that would strengthen the nation's semiconductor industry.
The talks, which began earlier this year, focused on offering I.B.M.'s four-million-bit computer memory design to Motorola. The chips, which store the equivalent of more than 300 pages of typed text, are the highest capacity now in production. They are used in the most advanced computers, from mainframes to laptops. 
The collapse of the negotiations was disclosed recently by people familiar with them in the Government and in the industry. An I.B.M. spokesman said that since the company had never acknowledged the discussions, it would not comment on the report that they had ended. Motorola also refused to comment.
High-capacity memory chips, known as dynamic random access memories, or D-RAM's, have grown increasingly important in all modern electronic products. Being able to build the most advanced memory chips is seen as vital to competing in the semiconductor business.
Currently, I.B.M. is the only American manufacturer of the four-million-bit chip. Motorola, which has an agreement to produce one-million-bit chips under license from the Toshiba Corporation of Japan, plans to use Toshiba's technology to produce four-million-bit chips in the future.
According to I.B.M. executives and industry analysts, the computer maker has been trying to create a second source of semiconductor supply separate from Japanese manufacturers and has also been seeking to fashion a broader industrywide alliance to strengthen America's high-technology manufacturing base.
The Motorola-I.B.M. relationship has also been cited by Charles H. Ferguson, a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as a crucial element of a proposed American-European strategy for withstanding Japanese industrial competition.
Writing in the July issue of the Harvard Business Review, Mr. Ferguson advocates the formation of American ''keiretsu,'' or cooperating associations of private corporations whose technologies complement each other. The Japanese have made large inroads in world high-technology markets by using the keiretsu to allocate investments in strategic industries.
''It surprises me,'' Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., an economist and former United States trade official, said recently. ''It seemed like a logical thing. It was in line with thinking about cooperative deals to give the United States companies the same kind of heft and bulk of the Japanese.''
 
Dominance Expected to Wane
But other industry executives have contended that Japanese control of semiconductor memory technology will begin to wane because of the huge capital costs in developing advanced semiconductor plants.
''My view is that Japanese domination is anomalistic,'' said Andrew S. Rappaport, the president of the Technology Research Group, a semiconductor consulting group in Boston. He argues that in future generations of computer memories, competitors from regions around the globe will enter the market, thereby lessening Japanese control of the industry.
The International Business Machines Corporation, based in Armonk, N.Y., has already licensed its semiconductor technology to Micron Technologies Inc., a computer memory maker in Boise, Idaho, and was prepared to make a similar agreement with United States Memories, a consortium seeking to create an independent American maker of memory chips.
One other American company, the Dallas-based Texas Instruments Inc., is now making D-RAM's, with help from Hitachi Ltd. of Tokyo.
 
Other Talks Fall Through
Earlier this year I.B.M. also discussed licensing its memory technology to Cypress Semiconductor Inc., a Silicon Valley chip maker, but Cypress declined to come to an agreement, saying I.B.M. was asking too much.
Several people in the industry familiar with the I.B.M.-Motorola negotiations said similarly that the talks had broken off last month because I.B.M. was asking substantially more for access to its technology than Motorola was paying to Toshiba.
Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., originally entered the negotiations because it was concerned about its dependence on Toshiba, one of the world's leading semiconductor makers, according to the Government and industry executives.
 
Looking to the Future
Nevertheless, in July, Motorola said it had signed a memorandum with Toshiba that covered a second phase of their agreement. Industry executives believe that the memo covers future technologies through 16-million-bit memory chips and beyond. A Government official familiar with the negotiations has said Toshiba ''sweetened the pot.''
Last year, Motorola agreed to participate with I.B.M. in developing X-ray technology to use in advanced chips. The technology may be widely used later in the decade.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Tumble $2.17, To Below $37

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices tumbled yesterday as the stalemate continued in the Persian Gulf. The decline occurred despite a report that the nation's oil inventories were falling.
''With a lack of fresh news and a lack of military action, these levels just might be too high for this market,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, analyst at Pegasus Econometrics, speaking of the record prices oil has reached recently. ''It seems like the market wants to regroup at a lower level.'' 
Oil for delivery in November on the New York Mercantile Exchange tumbled $2.17, to $36.72 a barrel. Although it rose 94 cents on Tuesday before the inventory report was released, oil prices have been mostly retreating from last week's record trading high of $41.15 a barrel and its record close of $40.42.
 
Heating Oil Below $1
Unleaded gasoline also sank, with the November contract losing 4.48 cents, to 93.40 cents a gallon. Heating oil for November delivery tumbled 5.75 cents, to 98.25 cents a gallon, the first time it has dipped under $1 a gallon since Oct. 4.
Analysts said the oil market was weighed down by the belief that crude was still widely available, despite the report that the nation's oil inventories fell last week.
The American Petroleum Institute, a leading industry group, said Tuesday, after the futures market had closed, that oil inventories fell 6.2 million barrels, to 343.3 million barrels in the week ended Oct. 12. But the institute said oil stocks were still 499,000 barrels above levels a year ago.
''I don't think there's a real shortage of crude right now,'' said Mark Scullion of Gerald Inc.
The group also said inventories of heating oil last week were a steep 15.6 million barrels above a year ago, at 120.3 million barrels, as the industry scaled up production for the winter season.
Traders may be sensing that the recent jump in oil prices on the Mideast war scare was overdone, analysts said.
 
Doubling Since Aug. 2
Oil prices have nearly doubled since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait prompted supply fears. But, as one trader said, ''There's nothing doing in the Middle East except the Saudis are producing a lot of oil.''
Traders were unsure how to interpret a statement by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d urging the world to have patience as economic sanctions tighten the noose on Iraq. But they thought it suggested a deadlock in the Middle East situation.
Testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Baker rejected a compromise solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Iraq again dismissed suggestions that it would withdraw from Kuwait.
 
Seasonal Shutdown At Hand
Analysts said prices also eased on the belief that the demand by refiners for crude oil would drop as they started to shut down some operations for seasonal maintenance.
The petroleum institute data showed the shutdown was already under way, with refineries running last week at 85.8 percent of capacity, down 1.8 percent from a week before.
Iraq reacted yesterday to oil price fluctuations, saying it welcomed a Venezuelan proposal made earlier this month to convene a United Nations conference of oil producing and consuming countries.
''The acute current fluctuations of oil prices serve speculators in the oil market at the expense of producing and consuming countries and of developing states,'' Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi, said.

HEADLINE: Head of Dow Jones Sets His Retirement

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Warren H. Phillips, the longtime chairman, chief executive officer and guiding spirit of Dow Jones & Company, announced yesterday that he would step down as chief executive of the publishing and information company on Jan. 1 and retire on July 1, soon after he turns 65.
Peter R. Kann, the company's president and chief operating officer and publisher of The Wall Street Journal, will become chief executive officer. It is widely assumed that Mr. Kann, who is 47 years old, will also be named chairman when Mr. Phillips retires.
Kenneth L. Burenga, the company's general manager, will replace Mr. Kann as chief operating officer. 
By choosing Mr. Kann as his successor, Mr. Phillips has insured that Dow Jones will have at its head a person who rose from the news operation of The Wall Street Journal, the company's crown jewel.
Mr. Phillips was the managing editor of The Journal for several years and Mr. Kann won a Pulitzer Prize in 1972 for his coverage of the India-Pakistan war as The Journal's Asia correspondent.
 
Striking Growth
For much of the 15 years since Mr. Phillips became the company's chief executive officer, Dow Jones experienced enormous prosperity and was a darling of Wall Street, principally because of the striking growth of advertising and circulation of The Journal during the boom years of the 1980's.
As The Journal succeeded financially, Mr. Phillips greatly expanded its size while adding to its existing reputation as one of the nation's premier news organizations. He added a third section and pushed aggressively to cover Asia and Europe with separate editions.
But in recent years, and especially in recent months, the company's performance has been damaged by declining advertising sales at The Journal and reduced profits from the company's information services group, which includes Telerate Inc., a financial data company.
Indeed, Mr. Phillips will be stepping down at a time when the wisdom of his decision to acquire Telerate for $1.6 billion is being questioned by industry analysts because of Telerate's failure to justify the investment thus far.
''The last half-decade has been much less joyous than the first 10 years,'' said John S. Reidy, an analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. He added that whether the Telerate investment proves a success will not be known ''for a couple of years.''
Last week, Mr. Phillips and Mr. Kann announced a cost-cutting plan that included a freeze on capital spending and all departmental budgets, including total salary costs, at the budgeted 1990 level. Because of negotiated salary increases with unions, the freeze likely means that vacancies will not be filled.
The plan also callled for ''holding down news space in our publications,'' a reduction in the number of special reports, postponing the creation of a magazine, cutting the use of freelancers and correspondents, eliminating almost all relocations of people, and other moves to save money.
While The Journal has been subject to economy efforts during Mr. Phillips's tenure, there has been a great reluctance to do anything that might be perceived as diminishing the quality or breadth of the paper's coverage.
 
No More Immunity
Analysts interpreted the plan as a signal that The Journal would no longer be immune to severe constraints if they were necessary, and they hailed Mr. Phillips for his willingness to make the cutbacks.
''He stepped up and made the decision he had to,'' said James D. Dougherty, an analyst at County NatWest Securities Inc.
But Mr. Dougherty and others expressed concern that the cuts The Journal had made, similar to those at many other papers, would eventually hurt.
''I suspect the average reader may not notice next year or the year after that, but eventually they have to,'' Mr. Dougherty said. A spokesman for Dow Jones said none of the executives involved in yesterday's announcement would be available for an interview.
As head of the company, Mr. Kann will be faced with the task of restoring The Journal's level of profitability and making Telerate a financial success that will justify the company's enormous investment.
In 1985, the company's business publications group, which includes The Journal and Barron's, accounted for about 75 percent of Dow Jones's operating income; in 1989, that contribution had declined to 30 percent, reflecting both the difficult times for advertising and the absence of big cuts in overhead.
The information services group provided 64 percent of Dow Jones's operating income 1989, which showed an overall decline of 4.6 percent, to $335 million, on revenues of $1.7 billion.
 
Premium Stock Price
Throughout the 1980's, as Dow Jones revenues more than trippled and net income increased more than five fold, the company's stock sold at a premium of up to 25 times annual earnings per share, compared with the average for the Standard & Poor's 500 companies of 14 times earnings per share.
Though the stock closed unchanged yesterday at $19, about 15 times its annual earnings per share, even that multiple is higher than the current S.& P. average multiple of 13 times earnings.
But restoring the old magic will be difficult, many analysts say, because The Journal is the key to the company's success and it is suffering from problems that may be deeper than the cylical pain of a depressed general economy.
The Journal's advertising linage declined 9.3 percent in the first nine months of 1990, and 16 percent in the third quarter.
 
A Thinning Market
But even before the stock market crash and the current advertising trough, advertising volume had begun to decline as the ranks of middle managers - the paper's core market - began to thin because companies were consolidating and eliminating positions.
The Journal also began to face increasing competition from USA Today, the national edition of The New York Times, Investor's Daily and other publications that cut into its franchise on financial advertising.
In recognition of the need to diversify Dow Jones's business, Mr. Phillips steered the company toward electronic publishing of financial data.
In 1985, the company acquired 32 percent of Telerate, a fast-growing company that provides traders in the financial markets with data like price quotes on bonds.
By 1987, Telerate earnings were growing at 45 percent a year and Dow Jones increased its stake to 56 percent, and then 67 percent in 1988. It completed the acquisition this year for a total of $1.6 billion.
But the slowdown in the financial services business in the last few years and intense competition among data suppliers have hurt the information services group. For the first half of 1990, the group, which includes the Dow Jones news service, reported a 44 percent drop in earnings; it declined 36 percent in the third quarter compared with a year earlier.
The poor operating results were heavily influenced by the costs of developing Telerate's electronic system for foreign exchange, called the Trading Service.

HEADLINE: New Rule On Benefits Approved

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
In a move that financial experts say will eventually slash millions of dollars from corporate earnings, the board that makes the nation's accounting rules voted yesterday to require employers to subtract from each year's earnings reports a portion of the costs of the health benefits that they have promised to future retirees.
After 20 months of debate with employers and accountants, who generally accepted the change but lobbied vigorously against potentially costly provisions, the seven-member Financial Accounting Standards Board in a 4-to-3 vote instructed its technical staff to write the rules. They are to be published by the end of the year.
The reason for the change is to make the costs of promised health-care benefits clear to investors and corporate executives and other employees. Most large companies provide some retirement health benefits. 
 
'A Milestone'
Dennis R. Beresford, the board's chairman, said that the rules would be formally adopted in December. ''I don't expect any changes,'' he said, though in theory, changes could be made. He called yesterday's action ''a milestone.''
Most companies have been accounting for benefits to current retirees on a pay-as-you-go basis, but under the new rules, which are to start taking effect in 1993, companies will not be able to wait until costs are incurred. A portion of the expected costs must be taken against each year's reported income.
Accountants and health actuaries will have to estimate the obligation to present and future retirees and report accrued costs as an expense, based on spreading the costs over a number of years.
At the General Motors Corporation, for example, which says it currently spends about $1 billion each year on retiree health benefits, the reported costs will increase, though the actual cash outlays will not be affected by the new rules, Gene Flegm, an assistant controller, said. G.M. also spends $2 billion for present employees' health costs.
 
At Least $227 Billion
Companies will also have to provide an estimate of their total obligation in a footnote to balance sheets. Government officials have estimated that the obligation for all companies will be $227 billion to $400 billion. Richard Ostruw, a vice president in Cleveland with Towers Perrin, a benefits consulting firm, said that $227 billion would cover just the combined obligations of the 1,000 largest companies.
In another vote yesterday at its Norwalk, Conn., headquarters, the accounting standards board rejected efforts by employers to stretch the period of an employee's working career to be used in calculating when retirement will begin. Four board members voted to stand by its rule, which bases the period on when an employee becomes eligible to retire rather than an estimated retirement date. Two members dissented, and one said he would decide later whether to join the majority.
At G.M., Mr. Flegm said, employees are eligible to retire at age 55 but often continue to work until 62. Employers had asked the board to let them estimate the actual retirement dates of their employees.
Some employers and accountants said they were disappointed that the board had not agreed to this change and others that would soften the effects of the rules. But they welcomed changes that the board had accepted since issuing a preliminary version of the rules in February 1989.
''The importrant thing is that there was agreement to go to accrual accounting,'' said Harold Dankner, a Washington partner with Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting and benefits consulting firm.
''While every accountant may find conclusions of the board that he or she would like to change, over all, the board has reached the right conclusions,'' said Benjamin S. Neuhausen, a partner in Chicago with Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm.
Among other changes, the board delayed the rules by one year, to 1993, for large companies and to 1994 for those with fewer than 500 workers. Employers will be permitted to adjust their accounting costs, if they have announced changes in benefit plans that are ''likely to occur.''
The rules were also changed to allow companies to account immediately for costs that otherwise could be spread over 20 years but would be increased by calculations of interest costs.
 
Inflation Rates
But the board rejected an employer request to use general consumer costs as the basis for calculating inflation, rather than the much higher health-care inflation rate.
The board can act by a 4-to-3 majority until Dec. 31. Next year, under a change recently adopted by its governing body, the Financial Accounting Foundation, a 5-to-2 majority will be required. Mr. Beresford said that action on the retiree health issue would probably be completed in December.
A handful of large employers have changed their benefit plans for future retirees to try to limit the liability. Among them are American Telephone and Telegraph, Pillsbury, American Airlines and TRW. Benefits experts said most large companies were studying the issue, particularly as they have become aware of the accounting issues. But Mr. Flehm said the automobile companies had long been sensitive to retiree health costs. ''When you've got $3 billion in cash going out the door, you don't need anybody to tell you about it.'' he said.

HEADLINE: Home Building Off 8th Month in Row

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Construction of new homes fell in September for the eighth straight month, the Commerce Department said today. The slide is the longest in more than 30 years, as activity slowed to a recession-era pace.
Total starts on single-family homes and apartments fell six-tenths of 1 percent last month after a revised 1 percent decline in August, reducing starts to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.14 million units. 
The last time starts were lower was in August 1982, when the annual rate was 1.046 million units. There have never before been eight straight drops in construction activity since the Government started recording the statistics in 1959.
Real estate analysts said the industry had not hit bottom yet, particularly in the Northeast, where home building and sales in New York and Massachusetts have plunged.
''Given the events of the past couple of months, with the invasion of Kuwait, higher interest rates, falling consumer confidence, we expect the housing industry will continue to decline for the next two to three quarters,'' said Dick Peach, an economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association.
 
'Very, Very Bad'
Housing starts fell 11 percent in the Northeast during September and were below levels recorded in the 1981-82 recession. ''The situation in the Northeast is very, very bad,'' said Dave Seiders, an economist for the National Association of Home Builders. ''We're still searching out the bottom there.''
Regionally, the housing picture varied widely. Starts fell 4.4 percent in the West, but they gained 3.3 percent in the Middle West and 3 percent in the South.
Building of single-family homes rose 4.3 percent in September, but that was more than offset by a 14.3 percent drop in apartment construction. Mr. Seiders attributed the apartment decline partly to a less willing attitude on the part of banks and savings institutions to extend credit to contractors.
The department revised the August drop in housing starts to 1 percent from its previously reported 1.7 percent decline.
Total starts last month were 10 percent lower than in September 1989, when they were at a 1.263-million-unit rate; building in the first three quarters of 1990 was also running 10 percent below comparable 1989 levels.
Mr. Seiders said builders hoped the worst was behind them. After a further small decline in the first quarter of 1991 there might be a gradual pickup, he said.
 
Rate Decline Expected
Current mortgage interest rates for 30-year loans that now average 10.66 percent should fall below 10 percent in six months, Mr. Seiders projected, which would aid building activity. Rates now are far below the staggering 15 to 16 percent range for mortgages that were common in the early 1980's when the country was in recession, he noted.
The building industry started 1990 strongly as record warm temperatures in January made construction work easier and starts soared by 23 percent, to an annual rate of 1.57 million units. But building slackened with the return of more normal weather, and home building went into a long tailspin that shows no immediate sign of ending.
Building permits, an indicator of future plans, fell 4.2 percent in September, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.01 million units, after declining 3 percent in August. Permits for single-family homes were down 3.8 percent, to 733,000 units, while permits for apartments fell 5.2 percent, to 273,000 units.
The number of houses started in September totaled 95,400, before seasonal adjustment, compared with 103,800 in August.

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Climbed 0.2% In September

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Government reported today, with a 7.5 percent spurt in automobile production masking an underlying manufacturing weakness.
The Federal Reserve report was ''loaded by the motor vehicle numbers, which are unsustainable,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. Excluding autos, the Fed said production dropped one-tenth of 1 percent. 
At the same time, the central bank revised output figures for July and August to show the industrial economy stronger than reported last summer. Production in July was increased from flat to a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent, and August output was changed from a decline of two-tenths of a percent to an advance of one-tenth of a percent.
The Fed also said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities was unchanged at 83.6 percent. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels.
''There were a lot of questions about whether we were still growing in the third quarter,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York securities dealer. ''What we had was an economy that was slipping into recession in slow motion.
''We still feel that given the sharp deterioration in consumer and business confidence on the heels of the oil shock, the economy will show negative growth in the fourth quarter.''
 
'Aggressive Rebates'
The 7.5 percent gain in auto output, Mr. Jones said, resulted from ''aggressive rebates that tend to steal from future demand.'' He noted that sales dropped from a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.2 million in the last 10 days of September, when incentives were offered, to 6.5 million in the first 10 days of October.
Production at manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September. But the Fed said, ''Apart from the sharp rise in motor vehicle assemblies, manufacturing output dropped two-tenths of 1 percent.''
Indeed, Mr. Dederick said that ''if you look at the components, the declines were fairly widespread.''
Output of durable goods - automobiles and other big-ticket items expected to last at least three years -increased two-tenths of 1 percent, down slightly from a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in August.
Manufacturing of nondurable goods also gained two-tenths of 1 percent after slipping one-tenth of a percent the previous month.
Output at mines gained four-tenths of 1 percent after slumping 1.7 percent in August. Utility production rose nine-tenths of 1 percent after a 1.3 percent advance in the previous month, in part because of warm weather.

HEADLINE: NCNB's Net Tumbles 60.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 17

 BODY:
The NCNB Corporation today reported sharply lower third-quarter earnings, citing problem loans and deterioration in the economy.
The bank reported net income for the quarter of $57 million, or 51 cents a share. That was down 60.3 percent from $143.6 million, or $1.45 a share, in the 1989 period.
''NCNB's earnings this quarter reflect the difficult operating environment facing banks today,'' said Hugh McColl, the chairman of the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, which has more than $69 billion in total assets.
''Continuing increases in problem loans and loan losses, combined with the continuing deterioration of the U.S. economy, dictate our cautious stance on credit quality issues,'' he said. ''This caution was illustrated by our decision to strengthen our reserve for loan and lease losses by $67 million in the third quarter, to $593 million.''
The bank said the earnings for the current quarter were affected by its decision to place $146.4 million in reserve for loan and lease losses. That's more than twice the $66.3 million placed in reserve in the 1989 quarter.

HEADLINE: MCI Posts Large Loss In Quarter

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The MCI Communications Corporation posted a large third-quarter loss yesterday because of a one-time charge against earnings, while three of the seven Bell regionals reported small changes in sales and earnings.
The revenues of MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, were lower than expected, said Edward M. Greenberg, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. ''Certainly it's getting tougher to take market share away from A.T.& T.,'' he said.
But O. Gene Gabbard, the chief financial officer of MCI, disagreed. ''It's not any tougher right now, and maybe even a little easier than it was earlier this year or last fall,'' he said. 
Revenue growth in the entire long-distance industry slowed in September as the economy weakened, Mr. Gabbard added.
BellSouth and Pacific Telesis both reported little change in sales and earnings, while Ameritech announced a modest improvement in third-quarter results, in part because of increased revenues from telephone directory advertising, lease financing and other businesses not directly related to local telephone service.
''Any time you get an earnings report that you can look at and say, 'fine,' and file it, that's good news,'' said Jack B. Grubman, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc.
 
MCI
MCI said it lost $168 million on sales of $2 billion in the third quarter, compared with a profit of $165 million, or 62 cents a share, on sales of $1.67 billion in the 1989 period. The loss included a $550 million charge for replacing obsolete equipment. The quarterly earnings are before payment of dividends on preferred stock.
Without the charge, announced on Aug. 21, MCI said it would have earned $180 million for the quarter. MCI's stock fell $1.125 a share, to $29.625, in heavy over-the-counter trading of 5.8 million shares.
Mr. Gabbard, the financial officer, estimated that growth in the long-distance industry slowed to a 10 percent annual rate last month, from 12 to 13 percent earlier in the year. He predicted that growth would not recover this year, but said a contraction of the industry was unlikely. ''We believe it would take a 1930's-type Depression'' to do that,'' he said.
MCI's acquisition on Aug. 14 of Telecom U.S.A., the nation's fourth- largest long-distance network, increased costs, said Mr. Gabbard, the former chairman and chief executive of Telecom.
 
Ameritech
Chicago-based Ameritech, which serves Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin, announced that third-quarter profits grew 7.6 percent, to $311.2 million, or $1.18 a share, from $289.1 million, or $1.06 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.67 billion, from $2.55 billion in the period last year.
Ameritech's higher earnings compensated for its lackluster growth of 2.8 percent in telephone lines served, well below the national average of about 3.5 percent, said Stephanie Georges, a telecommunications analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. The company's ability to increase earnings faster than revenues is ''definitely evidence you can manage your costs,'' she added.
Shares in Ameritech rose 25 cents each, to $63.50,on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
BellSouth
Third-quarter profits at the BellSouth Corporation dipped to $402.9 million, or 84 cents a share, from $404.4 million, or 84 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales were essentially unchanged, at $3.55 billion.
BellSouth is based in Atlanta and serves nine Southern states, several of which reduced local telephone rates in exchange for giving the company greater flexibility in pricing and investment decisions.
BellSouth added 52,454 new cellular subscribers during the quarter, for a total of 589,614. But Ms. Georges of Salomon Brothers said the company's pace of adding new subscribers was slowing, while profit margins in the cellular business fell as new customers used their phones less than earlier customers.
Shares in BellSouth closed unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange, at $52.
 
Pacific Telesis
Based in San Francisco and serving California and Nevada, the Pacific Telesis Group reported third- quarter earnings of $285 million, or 72 cents a share, on revenues of $2.47 billion. The company earned $278 million, or 68 cents a share, on revenues of $2.37 billion a year earlier.
A $391 million reduction in the rates of its Pacific Bell subsidiary, as part of a new regulatory system in California, depressed the results. Shares in Pacific Telesis rose 25 cents each on the New York Stock Exchange, to $44.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.&T. in Venture To Lay Cable to Japan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The largest international telephone companies in the United States and Japan announced plans yesterday to link the two countries in 1996 with a high-capacity undersea cable of radically new design.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Kokusai Denshin Denwa said the new cable would be able to carry 600,000 simultaneous conversations, compared with 40,000 conversations for cables laid in the recent years. The first trans-Atlantic cable, laid in 1956, carried 48 conversations. 
A.T.& T would not estimate the cost of the planned cable, citing uncertainty about the final design and route. The cable would use a new technique for periodically renewing the signal as it crosses the ocean floor. The technique will make it possible for the first time to increase the speed with which calls may be transmitted after the cable has been laid, said Jack M. Sipress, A.T.& T.'s director of research, development and manufacturing for underwater systems.
''The technology A.T.& T. is talking about will certainly be useful,'' said Leland L. Johnson, a senior communications economist at the Rand Corporation. The huge growth in international telephone calls, particularly for facsimile machines, is making large capacity increases necessary, he said.
The new cable should cost no more than existing cables, but the investment cost per line should fall sharply because the new cable can handle more conversations and computer and facsimile data, said William B. Carter, the executive director of A.T.&T.'s international facilities unit. The last significant cable laid, across the Atlantic Ocean in 1988, cost about $360 million, or $9,000 for each of its 40,000 lines.
Fiber-optic cables use lasers to send voice and data through hair-thin strands of glass. But the signals fade with distance and have to be renewed periodically.
Current cables rely on ''repeaters,'' which look like torpedoes and cost about $800,000 apiece. Each repeater receives a light signal, which converts it into an electrical signal, amplifies it and then converts it back into light for transmission to the next repeater.
The planned cable would use recently developed optical amplifiers, which increase the power of a light signal as it passes through a piece of specially treated optic fiber attached to a small laser. The signal is never converted into electricity, allowing for periodic increases in the number of conversations the cable can handle.
Repeaters on current cables are spaced every 40 to 60 miles and soon will be spaced up to 100 miles apart as technology advances, Mr. Sipress said. The optical amplifiers will initially be spaced every 20 to 30 miles, but they are cheaper than repeaters and bigger spacing distances should be possible in the future, he said.
A.T.&T.'s stock fell 75 cents today, to $30.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
